The other Rabbi IonathaÃÑ Ben Vziel, which wrote before the coming of Chri≈øt as the Iewes them≈øelues, be≈øides both Catholick and Prote≈øtant witne≈ø≈øes, approue, and cite him in their booke, Be≈øepher Bibakim, of collections: here readeth: erit ≈øacrificium panis in terra in capite montium Eccle≈øiae: he, the Me≈øsias shal bee a ≈øacrifice of bread on the head of the mountaines of the church. Let him con≈øider that hath eyes, that as it is ≈øaid, hee is the Me≈øsias of whome the whole p≈øalme ≈øpeaketh, therefore when hee ≈øaith, and hee shall bee a cake of wheate on earth, on the head of mountaines, hee meaneth, and would ≈øay, that a cake of bread shal bee the ≈øacrifice ouer the heads of preists vvhich are in the church. And Iacobus de Valentia. (in p≈øal. 72.) longe before the≈øe times, proueth again≈øt the Iewes, that theire Targum readeth:
erit placeutula tritici ≈øuper capita Sacerdotum. Hee ≈øhall bee a little cake of wheate aboue the heads of prei≈øts. Neither doth either the Greeke, or any Latine readinge contradict the≈øe mo≈øt auncient and approued readings: the Greeke ≈øterigma ≈øignifieth, fulcimentum flabilimentum or firmamentum, that which ≈øu≈øteineth, beareth vp or ≈øtrengtheneth ≈øome other: ≈øo is the Latine, what exemplar ≈øoeuer wee follow, or readinge, frumentum or firmamentum, or as Iacobus de Valentia writeth. (vt ≈øupra) S. Ierome readinge, memorabile triticum, memorable wheate. For all the≈øe ≈øignifications and properties, in an excellent maner are verified of Chri≈øt, and the holy ≈øacrifice of his body. And the Copula, or verbe in all learned languages, Hebrue, Greeke, Latine, Iehi, e≈øtai, erit, mu≈øt needes haue relation, and connection with the Me≈ø≈øias, onely there ≈øpoken of both immediatlie before, and after: the next ver≈øe beeing, by our prote≈øtantes tran≈ølation, the Hebrue Greeke and Latine agreeing. (p≈øal. 72. Hebr. ver≈ø. 17.) his name shall endure for euer: his name shall bee continued as longe as the ≈øunne: and men shall bee ble≈ø≈øed in him, all nations
shall cal him ble≈ø≈øed. And ≈øo to the end of the p≈øalme: ≈øo the whole p≈øalme before the 16. ver≈øe.

9. Therefore ≈øtraunge it ≈øhould be, that in a whole p≈øalme, both by Iewes, Catholicks, and prote≈øtants, entreating onely of the Me≈ø≈øias, there ≈øhould bee one only ver≈øe, relatinge a matter quite extrauagant by prote≈øtants tran≈ølation, beeing thus: There shall bee an handful of corne in the earth vpon the toppe of the mountaines: the fruite therof shall shake like Lebanon, and they of the citie shall florish like gra≈ø≈øe of the earth. And then immediately followeth, of the Me≈ø≈øias by the≈øe prote≈øtants tran≈ølation: His name shal endure for euer. Which hath no connexion with the former, if we expound it of materiall corne, and for the prophet to ≈øay only, there shall be an handful of corne in the earth vpon the top of mountaines, neuer was, or can bee in that materiall ≈øence, any ≈øigne or di≈øtinction to knowe the Me≈ø≈øias by, which is the ≈øcope of that p≈øalme. And yet in their p≈øalmes in meeter printed. (an. 1614. cum priuilegio Regis regali, conferred with the Hebrue, as the≈øe men write) they make the matter wor≈øe: thus it is:
The mightie mountaines of the land
of corne shall bringe ≈øuch thronge,
That it like Cedar trees shall stand
in Libanus all alonge.
Their cities eke full well shall ≈øpeed,
the fruites thereof shall pa≈øse:
In plenty it shall far exceede,
and ≈øpringe as greene as gra≈ø≈øe.
This is the Rithme, the rea≈øon I leaue to others to finde, it pa≈ø≈øeth my skill‚ñ™ But this I am certaine of, that neuer any ≈øuch thing chaunced in the time of Chri≈øt, ≈øince, or before to my readinge: and for any prote≈øtant, or other, to ≈øay, that come as high as Cedar trees, with the re≈øt de≈øcribed in their Rithme, ≈øhall bee at the cominge of the Me≈ø≈øias, is to deny Chri≈øt, and with the Iewes to expect an other, yet to come, when ≈øuch things may bee performed.

10. Therefore to let others pa≈ø≈øe, I will conclude this matter with Iacobus de Valentia, that learned Bi≈øhop of Cri≈øtopolis. (in p≈øal. 71. and Hieronymus √† S. fide a Iew.) both longe before this time of controuer≈øies: The fir≈øt ≈øaith: per hoc quod additur, in ≈øummis montium: by that which is added in the tops of mountaines, is expre≈ø≈øed that this
aboundance is not to bee vnderstood of wheate, or materiall corne, as the blind Iewes doe ≈øay, that in the cominge of the Me≈øsias there shal bee great aboundance of corne, and wine, and oyle. Therefore here is recompted, and foretold, the ≈øacrifice of the Eucharist, in which Christ is daily offered in the forme of breade, for Christ is daily lifted vp ouer the heads of preists, as it is figured in the 29. chapter of Exodus, where God commaunded a peece of breade to bee lifted vp, ouer the heads of the prei≈øts before the people. The ≈øame figure was of the bread of propo≈øition in the 25. chapter of Exodus, and 24. of Leuiticus. Therefore in an other tran≈ølation which is called Targum, it is: erit placentula tritici ≈øuper capita Sacerdotum. Hee ≈øhall bee a little cake of wheate aboue the heads of prei≈øts. Therefore Dauid ≈øaith ≈øoe: This Kinge the Me≈øsias shall bee firmament, or corne, or memorable wheate in earth vpon the tops of mountaines, that is, he shall bee lifted vp ouer the heads of preists in the forme of breade, for preists are often in ≈øcriptures vnderstood by mountaines, for their eminency of dignity, as is ≈øaid before. And againe: after the Prophet had foretold, that the Me≈øsias should bee God and man, and
worshipped of all nations, and Kings of the world, after hee addeth, that this Kinge Me≈ø≈øias shall bee corne and wheate, and a peece of of bread on the tops of mountaines, and ouer the heads of prei≈øts, as hath beene declared there by many tran≈ølations. And ≈øo it is manife≈øt, how this Sacrament is not onely po≈øsible, but al≈øo many wayes figured, and foretold in the lawe, and Prophets. And ≈øo it plainely appeareth, that Christians doe not adore bread, as the blind Iewes doe lie, but we adore Chri≈øt con≈øecrated vnder tho≈øe accidents.

11. The learned Iew. Hieronym. √† S. fide l. 1. contr. Iudaeos. hauing di≈øputed in the like maner, thus concludeth: we learne that the Iewes affirme that p≈øalme, Deus iudicium tuum Regi da: ≈øpeaketh all thinges of the Me≈ø≈øias: now therfore vvhere it ≈øaith: hee shall bee firmament on earth on the tops of mountaines, and the Caldy traÃÑ≈ølation ≈øaith, that hee (the Me≈øsias) shall bee a ≈øacrifice of bread on earth on the head of the mountaines of the Sinagogue: The mountaines of the Sinagogue are the prei≈øts of the church, which de facto euery day doe eleuate or lift vp the Me≈øsias ouer their heads: and this is ≈øo manifest, that it cannot bee denied but by them, to
whom the malediction of E≈øay the Prophet is come, that they should bee made blinde in eyes and hart. I≈ø. 42. And to this ca≈øe and condition are all they brought, by the≈øe holy and learned authorities, which deny the truth of this holy ≈øacrifice: for it is euident that in the ≈øence of prote≈øtant Sacramentaries, this prophe≈øie to bee fulfilled at the cominge of the Me≈ø≈øias, was neuer performed: when in this Catholick con≈øtructioÃÑ it is iu≈øtified & effected in the whole world: And if we ≈øhould come to Libanus it ≈øelfe, though now many hundred yeares vnder the Mahumetans, yet wee are a≈ø≈øured euen by prote≈øtants them≈øelues, that Chri≈øt in the forme of bread is there mo≈øt religiou≈ølie and aboue other places, eleuated dailie by prei≈øts ouer their heads in the holy ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe; there bee Catholicke Chri≈øtians in greate number, with Patriarke, Archbi≈øhop, Bi≈øhops and religious men obedient to the Pope of Rome in all the dominions of the graÃÑd Segnior of the Turke, there bee ≈øo many Chri≈øtians frequenting Ma≈ø≈øe, that a prote≈øtant telleth vs: They make aboue two third parts of his Empire. Cytraeus lib. de ≈øtatu. Eccle≈øiae pag. 20.21. Munster.
in Co≈ømograph. Ed. Grimstom. booke of e≈øtates pag. 1053. & 1064. of that, which the Prophet ≈øpeaketh of Chri≈øts beeing a prei≈øt after the order of Melchi≈øedech, I haue ≈øpoken before: onely I add here from the learned Father (Anasta≈øius Abb. l. contra Iudaeos) di≈øputing again≈øt the Iewes, who hauing proued from the hi≈øtory of Gene≈øis, and S. Paule, the dignitie of the prei≈øthood of Chri≈øtians, aboue that of the old te≈øtament, and that of Melchi≈øedech greater al≈øo then that was, inferred, that the ≈øacrifice of Chri≈øtians mu≈øt needes be much more excellent: Si Typus ille excelleÃÑtior erat Iudaico Sacerdotum, profecto multo magis erit ip≈øa veritas. If that Type or figure was more excellent then the Iewi≈øh prei≈øthood, ≈øurelie the truth it ≈øelfe mu≈øt needes bee much more excellent: which is no other by any Chri≈øtiaÃÑs, but Chri≈øts mo≈øt holy body and blood in the ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe.

div.head: THE V. CHAPTER. Wherin the ≈øame holy doctrines are ≈øo al≈øo proued out of the Prouerbs of Salomon. cap. 9.
div.p:
S. Ciprian. ep. 63. ad Cecil. hauing cited the hi≈øtory of Melchi≈øedech & how Chri≈øt
in≈øtitutinge the mo≈øt holy ≈øacrifice of his body and blood, to be offered by his prei≈øts, in holy Ma≈ø≈øe, therein fulfilled that figure of Melchi≈øedech, he addeth: Sed & pe ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ Salomonem Spiritus Sanctus typum Dominici ≈øacrificij ante praemonstrat, immolatae hostiae & panis & vini, ≈øed & altaris & Apostolorum faciens mentionem. Saptentia, inquit, aedificabit ≈øibi domum, & ≈øubdidit columnas ≈øeptem. Mactauit ≈øuas ho≈øtias, mi≈øcuit in cratera vinum ≈øuum, & parauit men≈øam ≈øuam & mi≈øit ≈øeruos ≈øuos, conuocans cum excel≈øa praedicatione ad crateram dicens: Quis est in≈øipiens declinet ad me: & egentibus ≈øen≈øu dixit: venite, edite de meis panibus, & bibite vinum quod mi≈øcui vobis. But by Salomon al≈øo the holy Gho≈øt doth ≈øhew before the figure of our Lords ≈øacrifice, making mention of an offered ho≈øte, and bread and wine, as al≈øo of an altare, and the Apo≈øtles Wi≈øedome, ≈øaith hee, did build for him≈øelfe an hou≈øe, and put vnder it ≈øeuen p ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ lers, killed his ho≈øtes, mingled his wine in a boule, and prepared his table, & ≈øent his ≈øeruants calling with a loude preachinge to his cup, ≈øayinge: who is vnwi≈øe, let him decline to mee: and to needy in ≈øence hee ≈øaid: come
you, eate you of my breads, and drinke the wine which I haue mingled for you. This expo≈øition of S. Cyprian is approued by the church of Chri≈øt. Breuiar. Roman. in fest. corpor. Christ. and S. Augu≈øtine in his 4. booke of Chri≈øtian doctrine. cap. 21. & l. 17. ciuitat. cap. 20. And in his bookes, de ciuitate De ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ , hee likewi≈øe ≈øo expoundeth it: and calleth the ≈øacrifice there figured, corpus, & ≈øanguinem Chri≈øti, the body, and blood of Chri≈øt, ≈øucceedinge the old ≈øacrifices, id enim inquit ≈øacrificium ≈øucce≈øsit omnibus illis ≈øacrificijs veteris testamenti, quae immolabantur in vmbra futuri. For that ≈øacrifice, ≈øaith hee, hath ≈øucceeded all tho≈øe ≈øacrifices of the old te≈øtament, which were offered in ≈øhadow of that was to come.

2. And Rabbi Samuel in his booke of the cominge of the Me≈ø≈øias, which he ≈øent to Rabbi I≈øaac Ma≈øter of the Sinagogue, writeth thus, vppon that place, and of this holy ≈øacrifice: Rabbi Samuel l. de aduentu Me≈øsiae cap. 20. hoc ≈øacrificium pulcherrime & apte de≈øcribit Salomon Propheta. Salomon the Prophet doth mo≈øte excellently and aptly de≈øcribe this ≈øacrifice (of Christians) in the 9. chapter of his booke of Prouerbs: when
hee ≈øaith, mo≈øt high wi≈øedome hath communicated his ≈øacrifice, mingled his wine, and prepared his table, then hee ≈øente his ≈øeruants, ≈øayinge, who is a little one, lett him come to me, and the vnwi≈øe ≈øhall eate my bread, and drinke my wine tempered with water, √¥ my Ma≈øter what is this prepared table of the mo≈øt high wi≈øedome but the altare, √¥ my Ma≈øter? what is the breade & wine mingled, but the ≈øacrifice of bread and wine, and of water which is offered on the altare? who are the vnwi≈øe called by the ≈øeruants of wi≈øedome, but the gentiles, or nations which knew not God, called by the Apo≈øtles? and it is to be noted, he ≈øaith, his bread and his wine, for by that hee doth in≈øinuate, that this ≈øacrifice is acceptable to God, and that to this banquet ≈øo high, and ≈øo ≈øpirituall, hee did not call our Fathers which were wi≈øe in the lawe, who were occupied in the ≈øacrifice of the lawe, which carnall ≈øacrifice hee hath not left vnto vs. Whereuppon it cometh, that wee (the Iewes) dete≈øt in the gentiles the ≈øacrifice of bread & wine which God hath appointed, and in no re≈øpect reiecteth, as he doth reiect ≈øacrifices of fle≈øh.

3. And Hieronymus √† S. fide. l. 1. contra Iudaeos cap. 1. by who≈øe booke diuers thou≈øandes of Iewes (hee beeing al≈øo a Iewe) were conuerted, proueth again≈øt them, that a principall rea≈øon why they did not receaue Chri≈øt, was becau≈øe he taught a new law‚ñ™ prei≈øthood, and ≈øacrifice, which cannot con≈øi≈øt together with the lawe, prei≈øthood and ≈øacrifices of Moy≈øes. If we re≈øort to the originall text of Hebrue, as our prote≈øtants would ≈øeeme be≈øt to allowe, wee haue a greater allowance there for the≈øe my≈øteries; for wheras S. Cyprian with the vulgare latine readeth, wi≈øedome builded to her≈øelfe an hou≈øe, ≈øapientia aedificauit ≈øibi domum: the Hebrue is Banetha Beithah, builded his hou≈øe: Chri≈øt the wi≈øedome of his father builded his hou≈øe, his church, as it is commonly expounded: And where S. Cyprian readeth, mactauit ≈øuas hostias, killed his ≈øacrifices, in the plurall number, as the latine vulgare, immolauit victimas ≈øuas, ≈øacrificed his victims, the Hebrue in the ≈øingular number, to de≈øigne one ≈øingular ≈øacrifice, is, Tabechah Tibchah, offered vp his ≈øacrifice; and therefore our Engli≈øh Prote≈øtants in their late priuiledged tran≈ølation
readinge quite otherwi≈øe: shee hath killed her bea≈øtes: haue prophaned that holy text in this point, ≈øoe the Hebrue readeth of Chri≈øt in this place: his table: his bread: his wine which hee mingled. And this is ≈øo euident and manife≈øt, that Seba≈øtian Ca≈øtalio the prote≈øtant lingui≈øt tran≈ølated: victimam ≈øuam immolauit, vinum libauit: hee offered his ≈øacrifice hee ≈øacrificed his wine: Ca≈øtal. in hunc loc. Prou. 9. So that the ≈øacrifice here mentioned, mu≈øt needs be that, which Chri≈øts eternal wi≈øedome, offered, & therfore the altar wheron it is offered is called, his table, & when it is called bread, or food, or flesh, the Hebrue Lehem ≈øignifying them all, or wine, it is not ab≈øolutely ≈øo called, but his bread, or his food, or his fle≈øh, and his wine, which hee mingled, or ≈øacrificed, as this prote≈øtant before hath taught vs. Therefore we mu≈øt needes conclude from hence, that the prei≈øthood of Chri≈øtians, is a true ≈øacrificinge prei≈øthood, and neither prote≈øtant or other, finding other ≈øacrifice then holy Ma≈ø≈øe, it mu≈øt needes bee this.

div.head: Wherin the ≈øame mysteries are proued by the ≈øame maner out of the Prophet E≈øay, and others. THE VI. CHAPTER.
div.p:
OVr Prote≈øtants of England in the Titles of the 56.60. and 61. chapters of E≈øay the Prophet interpret them of Chri≈øt, and his holy Religion: ≈øo doe many ≈øcriptures, all readers may ≈øee cited and alleaged in the Margins there by them: and yet in the≈øe places the holy Prophet doth te≈øtify, that there ≈øhall bee a ≈øacrificing prei≈øthood an externall ≈øacrifice, and altar whereupon it ≈øhal bee offered in this lawe of Chri≈øt, In the fir≈øt place which Chri≈øt him ≈øelfe expoundeth of him≈øelfe and his law, the Prophet ≈øpeaking of the conuer≈øion of the gentiles to Chri≈øt, writeth thus by prote≈øtants tran≈ølation: Euen them will I bringe to my holy mountaine (his church) and make them ioyfull in my hou≈øe of prayer: their burnt offerings and ≈øacrifices, shall bee acceptable vppon my altar: for my hou≈øe shall be called an hou≈øe of prayer for all people. The Hebrue, Greeke,
and Latine readings doe all manife≈øtly expre≈ø≈øe ≈øacrifice and altar, whereon it was to bee offered, and that ≈øacrifice to bee acceptable to God: therefore ≈øeeing an altar, wheron ≈øacrifice is offered, a ≈øacrifice theron offered, and a prei≈øt ≈øacrificinge or offeringe ≈øuch ≈øacrifice, are in all learninge mutuall correllatiues, and cannot po≈ø≈øibly bee ≈øeparated, the≈øe mu≈øt needes bee found among Chri≈øtians by this place of the Prophet.

2. And in the 60. chapter v. 7. ≈øpeaking al≈øo of the conuer≈øion of the Gentiles, there foretelleth, howe the prei≈øtes, which hee ≈øhould choo≈øe in them, whome hee vnder≈øtandeth by the Rammes of the flock, the≈øe beeing cheife of naturall ≈øheepe, as prei≈øts be in the ≈øpiritual fold and ≈øheep of Chri≈øt, ≈øhall offer acceptable ≈øacrifice vpon the altar of God in the church of the Gentiles conuerted. The Hebrue Greeke and Latine texts all agree propo≈øing vnto vs, a ≈øacrifice offered on the altare in the lawe of the Me≈ø≈øias: and can haue no other con≈øtruction, except we will returne to Iudai≈øme: for as a learned Father proueth. (Anasta≈øius Abb. l. contra Iudaeos.) ≈øignificat gentes ≈øacrificaturos
e≈ø≈øe Deo ≈øacrificijs acceptis, quare non de ≈øacrificijs legis intelligi potest, neque de altari t ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ rrestris Hieru≈øalem, ergo ≈øpiritualis. The Prophet ≈øignifieth, that the Gentiles ≈øhall ≈øacrifice to God with acceptable ≈øacrifices, wherefore hee cannot bee vnder≈øtood of the ≈øacrifices of the lawe, nor of the altar of the material Hieru≈øalem (being euacuated. I≈ø. c. 61. v. 5) therfor of the ≈øacrifice & altar of the ≈øpiritual Hieru≈øaleÃÑ, the church of Chri≈øt: as the whole chap. ≈øheweth of the glory of the hou≈øe of God, among the gent ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ es, wanting among prote≈øtants. And in the next chapter, where our prote≈øtantes reade: ≈øtraungers shall stand and feede your flocks, and the ≈øonnes of the Aliens, shall bee your plow-men, and your vine dre≈ø≈øers: The ≈øame Father together with S. Cyrill glo≈ø≈øeth: clar√® hic vt annotauit Cyrillus, ≈øignificat futuram e≈ø≈øe tran≈ølationem legis, & Sacerdotij: non enim amplius ex tribu Leui erant futuri Pastores & Sacerdotes. Quod ≈øi alia erit lex, & aliud Sacerdotium, ergo & alia ho≈øtia, & aliud Templum. The Prophet doth here clearely ≈øignifie as S. Cyrill hath noted, that there ≈øhould bee a tran≈ølation or chaunge of the lawe and prei≈øthood: for
pa≈øtors & prei≈øts were not to be any more of the tribe of Leui: But if there ≈øhould bee an other lawe, and prei≈øthood, therefore al≈øo an other ≈øacrifice and Temple mu≈øt needes bee. So other holy and learned Fathers, all of them vnitinge to euery true lawe, & Religion, a ≈øacrificinge prei≈øthood and ≈øacrifice: amonge whome Theodoret vpon tho≈øe words of S. Paul, by prote≈øtants tran≈ølation, ≈øaith: For the prei≈øthood being changed, there is made of nece≈øsitie a change al≈øo of the lawe: lex coniuncta est Sacerdotio, nece≈ø≈øe e≈øt enim, vt ce≈ø≈øante Sacerdotio, idip≈øum legi quoque accidat. The lawe is ioyned to prei≈øthood, for of nece≈ø≈øitie it is, that the prei≈øthood cea≈øing, the ≈øame mu≈øt al≈øo chaunce to the law. Hebr. cap. 7. v. 12. Theodor. in hunc locum. This our prote≈øtants haue yeelded vnto before: Therfore, if now contrary to them≈øelues, & ≈øo great rea≈øon, and authoritie, they would take a ≈øacrificinge prei≈øthood and ≈øacrifice from the lawe of Chri≈øt, they mu≈øt al≈øo take away the lawe of Chri≈øt, and Chri≈øt him≈øelfe, except they will leaue him without a lawe.

3. Againe in his 66. and la≈øte chapter, the ≈øame Prophet ≈øpeakinge of the gentiles
to bee conuerted to Chri≈øt, and his church of them, as our prote≈øtants expound him by publicke warrant. Prote≈øt. title of the 66. chapter of I≈øay. ≈øpeaketh thus in the par≈øon of God: I will al≈øo take of them (the gentiles) for prei≈øts and for Leuites, ≈øaith the Lord. The learned tongues, Hebrue, Greeke, and Latine reade, Lachonim, eis Iiereis, in Sacerdotes, for prei≈øts, ≈øacrificing preists, as they name the prei≈øtes of the lawe of Moy≈øes. Therefore except wee ≈øhould deny (which wee may not doe) there was no ≈øacrificing prei≈øthood, or ≈øacrifice in that lawe, wee mu≈øt allow the like, though in a more excellent maner to the lawe of Chri≈øt. This may ≈øuffice for this holy Prophet.

4. S. Augu≈øtine proueth the ≈øacrificinge prei≈øthood of Chri≈øtians, and theire mo≈øt holy ≈øacrifice out of the books of the Kings of reiecting the ≈øonnes of Hely and the old prei≈øthood, and to in≈øtitute the new. Augu≈øtin. l. 17. ciuitat. cap. 5.1. Reg. 2. Quod addit manducare panem: that which hee addeth to eate breade, doth elegantly expre≈øse that kinde of ≈øacrifice, of which our prei≈øt him≈øelfe (Chri≈øt) ≈øaith. Ioh. 6. the bread which I shal giue is my flesh for the life of the world:
that is the ≈øacrifice, not after the order of Aaron, but after the order of Melchi≈øedech. Ana≈øta≈øius proueth the like out of Aggeus the Prophet, of the externall glory of the churches of ≈øacrificinge Chri≈øtians there foretold. Others proue the ≈øame from other places of the lawe, and Prophets. Ana≈øtas. l. cont. Iud. Agg. 2. S. Augu≈øtine expounding the 33. p≈øalme and there ≈øpeakinge much of the holy ≈øacrifice, which Chri≈øt in≈øtituted of his ble≈ø≈øed body, and blood, vnder the formes of bread, & wine, and Gods reiecting the ≈øacrifices of the law of Mo≈øes, writeth how this was figured by Kinge Dauid, di≈ø≈øemblinge and concealing him≈øelfe, before Kinge Achis, in the fir≈øt booke of the Kinges cap. 21. a figure how Chri≈øt did ≈øhadow his diuinitie, therby the better to alter and change the lawe, prei≈øthood and ≈øacrifices of Moi≈øes, and in≈øtitute the new.

5. This was there forewarned, ≈øaith this holy Father, e≈øpecially by two thinges, in that hi≈øtory. Fir≈øt that the ≈øcripture ≈øaith of Kinge Dauid, hee chaunged his countenance before them: immutauit os ≈øuum coram eis. S. Augu≈øtine readeth, vultum ≈øuum. The
≈øecond is as S. Augu≈øtine readeth: ferebatur manibus ≈øuis. Hee was borne in his owne hands. And ≈øo the Greek in al copies, plainlie is: „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ . (v. 10.) as in the former, „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ . (v. 9.) Hee chaunged his face or par≈øon. Vppon the fir≈øt hee ≈øaith: Mutauit vultum ≈øuum, quia erat ibi ≈øacrificium ≈øecundum ordinem Aaron, et postea ip≈øe de corpore & ≈øanguine ≈øuo instituit ≈øacrificium ≈øecundum ordinem Melchi≈øedech. Mutauit ergo vultum ≈øuum in Sacerdotio, & dimi≈øit gentem Iudaeorum, & venit ad gentes. Hee chaunged his countenance, becau≈øe there was ≈øacrifice accordinge to the order of Aaron. And after hee in≈øtituted a ≈øacrifice of his body, and blood, after the order of Melchi≈øedech. Therfore he chaunged his countenance in the prei≈øthood, & for≈øooke the people of the Iewes, and came to the gentiles.

6. And againe ≈øpeakinge how the deniers of this holy ≈øacrifice and Chri≈øts reall pre≈øeÃÑce there as he promi≈øed in the 6 chapter of S. Iohn were like to King Achis, condemning this for folly in Chri≈øt, as Achis cen≈øured Kinge Dauid for his ge≈øtures in concealinge him≈øelfe. He addeth, (conc. 1.)
Erat in illis regnum ignorantiae, qua≈øi Rex Achis. Id e≈øt regnum erroris eis dominabatur. Ille autem dicebat: ni≈øi quis manducauerit carnem meam, & biberit ≈øanguinem meum: quia mutauerat vultum ≈øuum: qua≈øi furor iste & in≈øania videbatur, dare carnem ≈øuam manducandam hominibus, & bibendum ≈øanguinem. Ideo qua≈øi in≈øanus putatus e≈øt Dauid, quando dixit ip≈øe Achis arreptitium hunc mihi adduxistis. Nonne videtur in≈øania, manducate carnem meam & bibite ≈øanguinem meum, & quicunque non manducauerit carnem meam, & biberit ≈øanguinem meum, non habebit in ≈øe vitam? qua≈øi in≈øanire videbatur, ≈øed Regi Achis in≈øanire videbatur, id e≈øt stultis & ignorantibus. There was in them the kingdom of ignorance, as Kinge Achis, that is the kingdome of error ruled in them. For hee ≈øaid, except a man eate my fle≈øh and drinke my blood: becau≈øe he had chaunged his countenance, as fury and madnes it was thought to giue his fle≈øh to bee eaten, and his blood to bee drunken of men. Therefore Dauid was reputed as a madd man, when Achis him≈øelfe did ≈øay, you haue brought this madd man vnto me, is it not thought madnes to ≈øay, eate my fle≈øh, and drinke my
blood, and who≈øoeuer doth not eate my fle≈øh and drinke my blood, shall not haue life in him? hee did ≈øeeme to bee as madd, but hee did ≈øeeme to be madd to Kinge Achis, that is to ≈øay, vnto fooles, and ignorant men.

7. The ≈øecond which this holy learned Father, expoundeth to bee propheticall of this mi≈øtery, in that place is that which I noted: hee was borne in his owne handes: of this ≈øaith S. Augu≈øtine, & ferebatur in manibus ≈øuis. Hoc vero fratres quomodo po≈ø≈øet fieri in homine, quis intelligat? Quis enim portatur in manibus ≈øuis? in manibus aliorum pote≈øt portari quis, manibus ≈øuis nemo portatur. Quomodo intelligatur in Dauid ≈øecundum litteram, non inuenimus, in Christo autem inuenimus. Ferebatur enim Christus in manibus ≈øuis, quando commendans ip≈øum corpus ≈øuum, ait. Hoc e≈øt corpus meum. Matth. 26. Ferebat enim illud corpus in manibus ≈øuis. Ip≈øa e≈øt humilitas Domini nostri Ie≈øu Christi, ip≈øa multum commendatur hominibus. And hee was borne in his owne handes: √¥ my bretheren who can vnder≈øtand, how this can bee done in a man. For who is carried in his owne handes? ≈øome man
may bee carried in other mens hands, but no man is carried in his owne hands. How it can be literally vnder≈øtood in Dauid, we doe not finde. But wee finde it in Chri≈øt. For Chri≈øt was carried in his owne hands, when ≈øpeaking of his owne body, he ≈øaith. This is my body. For he carried that body in his owne hands. That is the humility of our Lord Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, that is much commended vnto men. And in his next ≈øermon vpon that p≈øalme, expounding all the ge≈øtures of Kinge Dauid, before King Achis, to bee figures of, and fulfilled in Chri≈øt, he writeth againe in this manner of the ≈øame matter. Augustin. conc. 2. ≈øupr. in p≈øal. 33.

8. Et ferebatur in manibus ≈øuis. Quomodo ferebatur in manibus ≈øuis? Quia cum commendaret ip≈øum corpus ≈øuum, & ≈øanguinem ≈øuum, accepit in manus ≈øuas, quod norunt fideles: & ip≈øe ≈øe portabat quodamodo cum diccret: Hoc e≈øt corpus meum: And hee was carried in his owne hands. How was hee carried in his owne hands? Becau≈øe when hee recommended his owne bodie and blood, he tooke that which the faithfull know, into his owne handes: and hee after a certaine maner carried him≈øelfe, when he ≈øaid, this
is my bodie. And ≈øpeakinge plainely, that Chri≈øt was figured, and repre≈øented in that hi≈øtory of Kinge Dauid, hee ≈øaith: Quis est? notus e≈øt Dominus no≈øter Ie≈øus Christus. In corpore & ≈øanguine ≈øuo voluit e≈ø≈øe ≈øalutem nostram. Vnde autem commendauit corpus & ≈øanguinem ≈øuum? de humilitate ≈øua. Ni≈øi enim e≈ø≈øet humilis, nec manducaretur, nec libaretur. Who is it that was ≈øignified by Dauid, it is our knowne Lord Ie≈øus Chri≈øt. Hee would haue our ≈øaluation to be in his body and blood. From whence did hee recommend his body and his blood? from his humilitie. For if he had not beene humble, he would neither haue beene eaten, or been our drinke. Many ≈øuch te≈øtimonies more may bee brought from the lawe and Prophetes, & ar ≈øo v≈øed of the be≈øt learned holy Saints that liued in the primatiue church, which I mu≈øt and wittingly doe pa≈ø≈øe ouer to auoide tediou≈ønes, not ≈øo well ≈øuteinge with a preface or introduction: therefore I will now la≈øtely come to the la≈øte Prophet Malachias, and his prophe≈øie of this holy mi≈øtery.

div.head: THE VII. CHAPTER. Wherin the ≈øame is proued at large by all expo≈øitions and testimonies, euen by our protestants them≈øelues, out of the Prophet Malachy.
div.p:
MAny of the holy learned Fathers of the primatiue church, demon≈øtrate again≈øt the Iewes, Chri≈øt to bee the true Me≈ø≈øias by this holy ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe, theÃÑ offered by the conuerted gentiles, in all the world: for citinge the prophe≈øie of Malachias, of Gods reiectinge the ≈øacrifices of the law of Moy≈øes, and his acceptinge of the pure ≈øacrifice of the gentiles, they proue therby, that who≈øoeuer denieth that prophe≈øie to bee fulfilled and verified, in the holy ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe, con≈øequently denieth Chri≈øt Ie≈øus to bee the true Me≈ø≈øias, and mu≈øt, as yet the mi≈øbeleeuinge Iewes doe, expect an other. S. Augu≈øtine ≈øaith: Hoc ≈øacrificium per Sacerdotem Chri≈øti ≈øecundum ordinem Melchi≈øedech, cum in omni loco √† ≈øolis ortu v≈øque ad occa≈øum, Deo iam videamus offerri, ≈øacrificiuum autem Iudaeorum quibus
dictum est, non e≈øt mihi voluntas in vobis, nec accipiam de manibus vestris munus, ce≈ø≈øa≈ø≈øe, negare non po≈ø≈øunt, quid adhuc expectant alium Christum, cum hoc quod Prophetatum legunt, & impletum vident, impleri non potuerit ni≈øi per ip≈øum. When we ≈øee this ≈øacrifice to be offered to God by the prei≈øthood of Chri≈øt according to the order of Melchi≈øedech, in euery place from the ri≈øing of the ≈øunne, euen to the ≈øetting therof, and they cannot deny, but the ≈øacrifice of the Iewes to whom it was ≈øaid, I haue no will in you, neither will I receiue guift from your handas, to haue cea≈øed, why doe they yet expect an other Chri≈øt, when this which they reade to haue beene prophe≈øied, and ≈øee to bee fulfilled, could not bee fulfilled but by him. Augustin. l. 18. ciuitat. cap. 35. Malach. cap. 1. Augustin. l. 1. cont. aduer≈øar. leg. & Prophet. c. 20. orat. contr. Iudaeos c. 9.

2. The very ≈øame argument, and expo≈øition of that prophe≈øie, v≈øe the≈øe holy Fathers following (to omit others too many to be cited) within the fir≈øt 400. yeares: S. Clement, S. Iu≈øtine, S. Irenaeus, S. Martial, Tertullian, S. Cyprian, Eu≈øebius, S. Chri≈øo≈øtome, Aurelius Bi≈øhop of Carthage, and
others, all again≈øt the Iewes, therby inuincibly prouing again≈øt them, that the ≈øacrifices of that people had then cea≈øed, and their Religion euacuated, and the Religion of Chri≈øt onely true, becau≈øe according to that mo≈øt vndoubted true prophe≈øie, the ≈øacrifice of Chri≈øtians, the holy Ma≈ø≈øe was then in their times offered in all the world. And this is ≈øo euident in all antiquitie, that both the Magdeburgian prote≈øtants, Caluine, and others confe≈ø≈øe, that S. Irenaeus, S. Ciprian, S. Athana≈øius, S. Ambro≈øe, S. Augu≈øtine and Arnobius doe ≈øoe expound it. And our prote≈øtants of England in their newly authori≈øed bible, by his maie≈øtie, doe proue as much: for thus they tran≈ølate that pa≈ø≈øage, of the Prophet Malachias: I haue no plea≈øure in you (the Iewes) ≈øaith the Lord of ho≈øtes, neither will I accept an offering at your hand (from your hand) the Hebrue, as they note in the margine, for from the ri≈øing of the ≈øunne, euen vnto the goinge downe of the ≈øame, my name shall bee greate among the heathens, ≈øaith the Lord God of ho≈øtes. Clem. l. 7. Const. Apostolic. cap. 31. Iustin. dial. cum Tryphon. Irenaeus l. 4. c. 32. Martial. epistol. ad Burdegal. c. 3. Tertul. l.
3. cont. Marcion. c. 22. Ciprian. l. 1. cont. Iud. c. 16. Eu≈øch. Cae≈øar. l. 1. demonstr. euangelic. cap. 10. Chry≈øostom. ad p≈øal. 95. Aurel. Carthag. epist. ad Marcellinum. Magdeburg. cent. 2. col. 63. cent. 3. col. 83. Calv. l. de ver. eccle≈ø. reform. Prote≈øt. Bible Malach. 1. v. 10.11.

3. Where the Prophet expre≈ø≈øely maketh this greatnes of the name of God amonge the gentiles and the pure ≈øacrificing which with incen≈øe ≈øhoulde by them bee offered vnto God in all places, to bee a notion, and di≈øtinctiue ≈øigne to bee a≈ø≈øured by, that the ≈øacrifices of the Iewes were to cea≈øe, and determine, and to demon≈øtrate, that as the lawe of Chri≈øt is more excellent then the lawe of Moi≈øes, ≈øo the ≈øacrifice of the ≈øame, and the prei≈øts which offered the ≈øame, taking their dignitie from the worthines of the ≈øacrifice which they ≈øhould offer, ≈øhould bee more worthie, then tho≈øe of the Iewes, which hee did reiect. For ≈øo it is in all languadges, Mincha tehora, a pure oblation in Hebrue: „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ a pure ≈øacrifice in Greek: in omni loco ≈øacrificatur, & offertur nomini meo oblatio munda. In euery place a cleane oblation is ≈øacrificed and offered to my name: in Latine. Fertum purum: a pure ≈øacrifice: as
the prote≈øtant Seba≈øtian Ca≈øtalio readeth: a pure offeringe: as our Engli≈øh Prote≈øtants tran≈ølate. And it is ridiculous, for any man to expound it of prayer, without ≈øacrifice externall, for the Prophet there plainly oppo≈øeth this the externall ≈øacrifice of Chri≈øtians, which was to be receaued, to the others of the Iewes which were then to cea≈øe, & the cheife prote≈øtaÃÑts haue ≈øo expounded and tran≈ølated it before: and here hee ≈øpeaketh of both prayer expre≈ø≈øed in the word thymiama in Greeke, Muctar in Hebrue, as the Engli≈øh Prote≈øtantes, together with S. Augu≈øtine, S. Hierome, Eu≈øebius and others expound it: and externall ≈øacrifice in the other as is before recited. prote≈øt. of Engl. and Fr. Ma≈øon. of con≈øecrat. of Bish. pag. 219.220. Augu≈øtin. Hierom. & Eu≈øeb. apud Ma≈øon. ≈øupr.

4. Which being ioyned with the known ≈øacrificing verbe or verball Maggash, cannot po≈ø≈øibly haue any other interpretation, but as plainely and literally expre≈ø≈øeth the publicke ≈øacrifice of the Ma≈ø≈øe, v≈øed by Chri≈øtians, as any mi≈ø≈øale, or Catholicke writer doth, or can doe in generall termes, not de≈øcendinge to the particular expre≈ø≈øing
of the ble≈ø≈øed body and blood of the Me≈ø≈øias there offered, which belonged onlie to the time of the lawe of Chri≈øt, and not tho≈øe figuratiue dayes: yet by many attributes and properties ≈øo de≈øcribeth it, that it cannot bee applied to anie other. For it termeth this ≈øacrifice, a pure offering, the pure ≈øacrifice, the ≈øacrifice wherein onely God woulde bee plea≈øed, the ≈øacrifice that should ≈øucceede the ≈øacrifices of the lawe, and euacuate them, a ≈øacrifice to bee offered in all places, as Christ was to bee honored in all, and to continue for euer. Neuer to be abrogated by any other; all which are before remembred by the Prophet, and cannot by any po≈ø≈øibilitie be truely ≈øpoken of any other ≈øacrifice, then this of the mo≈øt ble≈ø≈øed body and blood of Chri≈øt, offered by his holy prei≈øtes in that ≈øacrifice, which from the Hebrues we cal Ma≈ø≈øe in our language.

5. Neither can any thinge be ≈øo briefly ≈øpoken by God, to confute the friuolous & vaine obiections, of ≈øome prote≈øtants, allmo≈øt now quite exploded out of the world, by Catholicke arguments, about dimen≈øions, and pluralities of places & locations
of this mo≈øt ble≈ø≈øed Sacrament, and ≈øacrifice; for God here by the mouth of his holie Prophet, a≈ø≈øuringe vs that this ≈øacrifice ≈øhall bee but one, and no more, as it is before expre≈ø≈øed in all holie languages, Hebrue Greke and Latine, yet ≈øo miraculous and extraordinary it ≈øhall bee that. Be cal Machom, „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , in omni loco, in euerie place, by prote≈øtant tran≈ølation out of Hebrue, Greeke and Latine iu≈øtifyinge it, this onely pure ≈øacrifice ≈øhall bee offered to God: That if the≈øe men will either beleeue naturall or ≈øupernatural rea≈øon, and authoritie, God or man, they may ≈øee the vanitie of theire contradiction. For whereas they would per≈øuade their adhereÃÑts and others, that one and the ≈øame ≈øacrifice cannot bee offered in many places, God him≈øelfe te≈øtifieth the quite contrary, that this ≈øhall bee offered in all places, and yet bee but one pure ≈øacrifice, as is before declared, by all tran≈ølations, and the originall text it ≈øelfe, from the worde of God by his holie Prophet.

6. And it is as euident, from this onely clau≈øe: in euery place: that this could be no other ≈øacrifice, then the ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe,
v≈øed in the Catholicke church of Chri≈øt, now dilated into all nations, and in euery place: for there bee now in the world but foure great profe≈ø≈øions of Religion, Chri≈øtians, Iewes, Mahumetans, and Pagans. No Chri≈øtian will or may ≈øay, that prophe≈øie of the true wor≈øhippers of God, & pure ≈øacrifice to bee offered vnto him, is, or can bee vnder≈øtood of any of them; for fir≈øt the pagans ≈øacrifices were not offered to God, but to Idols: they were not pure and holy, but mo≈øt wicked and abhominable: they had not any one ≈øacrifice, that was generally offered in all places. Eu≈øeb. Tertul. cont. Iud. Iu≈øtin. cont. gent. Ari≈øtid. Plutarch. in vit. &c. The Mahumetans haue no externall ≈øacrifice at all to offer in any place. Mahum. in Alcor. hi≈øtor. Turric. and theire whole Religion, by all Chri≈øtians is damnable, and their ≈øect could neuer yet be called vniuer≈øall, in all places. And to ≈øpeake with prote≈øtants, as before, in tho≈øe contries, which the Turke po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øeth: The Chri≈øtians make aboue two third parts of his Emipre. Edw. Grym≈øt. pag. 1064. Auth. of the booke of the estates in the great Turke in A≈øia. Therfore there is nothing in that Religion
that can bee called this pure ≈øacrifice, offered to God in euery place.

7. The ≈øacrifices of the Iewes were manie, and not one by one, and all of them reiected by God in this place of the Prophet, as our prote≈øtants thus tran≈ølate. (Malach. cap. 1.10.) I haue no plea≈øure in you, ≈øaith the Lord of hostes, neither will I accept an offering at your hand. And then immediatly the conuer≈øion of the Gentiles, and their pure ≈øacrifice to bee offered to God. (ver≈ø. 11.) in euery place, is ≈øet downe. So that not any one ≈øacrifice of the Iewes, could after this time be acceptable to God, none could bee this pure ≈øacrifice, in any place, much le≈ø≈øe in euery place, when the Iewes Religion was neuer ≈øo extended. And as the holy ≈øcriptures and Hieronymus, √† Sancta fide a Iewe. (l. 1. contr. Iudaeos cap. 9.) proueth, the Iewes might neuer offer ≈øacrifice out of Hieru≈øalem, and ≈øo this could not po≈ø≈øibly be ment of them: ostendit nobis in hoc quod dicit: In omni loco: quod haec oblatio munda, fienda erat per vniuer≈øum mundum, vbicumque per modum e≈ø≈øet a≈øsignatum: per contrarium ≈øacrificiorum antiquorum, de quibus erat prohibitum ne alibi qu√†m in Temple
Iero≈øolymitano fierent. The Prophet ≈øheweth vnto vs, by that hee ≈øaith: in euery place: that this pure oblation, was to be made in all the world, where≈øoeuer it was a≈ø≈øigned in the world: by the contrary of the old ≈øacrifices of which it was forbidden, that they ≈øhould not be offered in any other place, then in the Temple of Hieru≈øalem. And proueth there out of the Iewes Thalmud, often repeating, that their ≈øacrifices were to cea≈øe: quaedam locutio ≈øaepe in Talmud reiterata quae dicit ≈øic: in tempore futuro, vniuer≈øa ≈øacrificia, excepto ≈øacrificio confe≈øsionis annihilata erunt. All ≈øacrifices ≈øhould be annihilated but the ≈øacrifice of confe≈ø≈øion, called Thoda in breade and wine: meaninge the ≈øacrifice of Chri≈øtians, as I haue proued in due place.

8. And Rabbi Samuel. (Marrochian. l. de aduent. Me≈øsiae cap. 20.) writing to Rabbi I≈øaac Ma≈øter of the Sinagogue, vppon this prophe≈øie of Malachie ≈øaith. Timeo Domine mi, quod Deus eiecit nos √† ≈øe, & ≈øacrificium nostrum, & acceptauit ≈øacrificium gentium, ≈øicut dicit per os Malachiae: √¥ my Ma≈øter, I feare, that God hath ca≈øt vs away froÃÑ him, and our ≈øacrifice al≈øo, and hath accepted
the ≈øacrifice of the gentiles, as hee ≈øpeaketh by the mouth of Malachy. And immediatlie citing the wordes of that Prophet, as before, concludeth thus for the ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe v≈øed by Chri≈øtians: ≈øacrificium gentium, est mundus quam ≈øacrificium no≈øtrum. The ≈øacrifice of the gentils (≈øo he called Chri≈øtians conuerted of the gentiles) is more pure then our ≈øacrifice.

9. Thus commonly al≈øo the holy Chri≈øtian Fathers, among whom S. Augu≈øtine citinge that prophe≈øie of Malachie, thus ≈øpeaketh to the Iewes. (Augu≈øtin. orat contra Iudaeos cap. 9.) Quid ad haec re≈øpondetis? aperite oculos tandem aliquando & videte, ab oriente ≈øole v≈øque ad occidentem, non in vno ≈øicut vobis fuerat constitutum, ≈øed in omni loco ≈øacrificium Christianorum offerri, non cuilibet Deo, ≈øed ei, qui i≈øta praedixit, Deo I≈ørael. What do you an≈øwere to the≈øe things? open your eyes ≈øometime at the la≈øte, and ≈øee, that the ≈øacrifice of Chri≈øtians is offered from Ea≈øt to We≈øt, not in one place as it was appointed vnto you, but in euery place, not to euery one that is called God, but to him, the God of I≈ørael, that foretold th ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ ≈øe thinges. Therefore ≈øeeing the word of God
propo≈øed by his holy Prophet cannot bee vntrue, but mu≈øt needs be verified in ≈øome ≈øacrifice, offered thus vnto him by ≈øome profe≈ø≈øors of Religion, and all others be≈øides Chri≈øtians are thus clearely excluded, and Chri≈øtians haue only one externall ≈øacrifice of the Ma≈ø≈øe, conteining the oblation of Chri≈øts mo≈øt ble≈ø≈øed body & blood, the onely mo≈øt pure ≈øacrifice and acceptable vnto God, and offered in euery place in the whole world, it mu≈øt needs bee this pure and generall ≈øacrifice.

10. To which our prote≈øtants them≈øelues (to make all ≈øure) do thus giue te≈øtimonie. Fir≈øt his Maie≈øtie, as Ca≈øaubon hath publi≈øhed by warraÃÑt. (Ca≈øaub. Re≈øp. ad Card. Per. pag. 51.52.) neither is the Kinge Ignorant, nor denieth, that the Fathers of the primatiue church did acknowledge one ≈øacrifice in Christian Religion, that ≈øucceeded in the place of the ≈øacrifice of Moi≈øes lawe. And both from our Kinge, and D. Andrewes, the Prote≈øtant Bi≈øhop now of Winche≈øter, affirmeth of this ≈øacrifice. (pag. 50.51. ≈øup.) It is Christs body, the ≈øame obiect and thinge which the Roman church beleeueth. An other diuidinge Chri≈øtians into the Latine and
Greeke church, as the common diui≈øion is, and telling vs, as all acknowledge, that in all contries of the Latine church, remayning ≈øtill in obedience to the ≈øee of Rome, the ≈øacrifice of the Ma≈ø≈øe is publickly in all places offered, and in the contries that haue reuolted lately from it, the ≈øame ≈øacrifice is priuatly with many ≈øtill celebrated, thus hee writeth of the Greeke church. (Edwine Sands relation of Religion cap. 53. or 54.) with Rome they concur in the opinion of tran≈ø≈øubstantiation, and generally in the ≈øeruice and whole body of the Ma≈ø≈øe, in praying to Saints, in auricular confe≈øsion, in offeringe of ≈øacrifice and prayer for the dead. They hold purgatory al≈øo, and worshipping of pictures. Their Liturgies bee the ≈øame, that in the old time, namlie S. Ba≈øils, S. Chri≈øostoms, and S. Gregories (that which the Roman church now v≈øeth) tran≈ølated without any bendinge them, to that chaunge of language, which theire tongue hath ≈øuffered.

11. Chytraeus a German protestant, writinge de statu Eccle≈øiae, of the state of the church. (pag. 7.8.11.13.15.18.20.21.) ≈øaith: Among all the nations of Greece, A≈øia, Africa, Ethiopia, Armenia &c. all places are full of
Ma≈ø≈øes, the ≈øacrifice of the Ma≈ø≈øe is offered for the liuing and the dead. The Georgians inhabiting old Iberia, and Albania. The Syrians name S. Ba≈øile author of their Ma≈ø≈øe. The Armenians inhabitinge mo≈øt large ≈øpaces of the earth from the bounds of Cappadocia and Cilicia vnto Iberta the Ca≈øpian ≈øea, Media and A≈øsiria, are moste like the papists in Religion and ceremonies, in their Ma≈ø≈øe they remember inuocation, and interce≈øsion of Saints, offering vp of the Sacrament. Al≈øo euery where in Per≈øia, and all the east, the Chri≈øtians doe the ≈øame. The Maronites at mount Libanus, are conformable to the Latine church in all thinges. The Iacob is in A≈øia and Africke, are more by much propagated and haue their Ma≈ø≈øes.

12. Our Engli≈øh Prote≈øtant tran≈ølator of the author of the booke, of the estates, Empires, & principalities of the world. (Edw. Grymston. pref. to the Reader.) although as he confe≈ø≈øeth he altereth and addeth at his plea≈øure, cannot finde out any one prouince, or contry of note in al the whole world, where hee dareth to affirme, and can proue that this holy ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe is not there offered vnto God. The ≈øame proueth. (pag. 102. to pag. 283. in the e≈øtate of the K. of Spaine.)
that the Kinge Catholicke of Spaine, by land and Sea in all parts of the worlde Europe, A≈øia, Africke, and America, is the greate≈øt Emperour and Kinge that now pre≈øently is, or euer heretofore hath beene in the world, po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øinge more territories, and dominions, then all Turkes, Tartars, Pagans, and enemies of Chri≈øtianitie, that be, and yet in all the≈øe dominions this mo≈øt holy ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe is publickly offered and celebrated with great honor, and glorie. So that if it were receued no where els, but in his territories, the prophe≈øy of Malachias is fulfilled in his dominions, as well appeareth by this, and all Co≈ømographers of the≈øe dayes, that truely ≈øett downe the e≈øtates of great Princes. There is no maine part, ab ortu ≈øolis v≈øque ad occa≈øum, from the ri≈øinge of the ≈øunne vnto the ≈øetting thereof, nor from the ≈øettinge to the ri≈øing againe, but he hath ≈øome dominion there: as a late ver≈øe is of the Enfante Mary of Spaine her Father, and her brother is in the ≈øame condition:
Vnto her greatnes witnes giues the ≈øunne,
tasked no houre, to shine at any hand,
As he his cour≈øe about the globe doth runne,
but on ≈øome part of her late Fathers land.
An homage which hee neuer did before,
to any Prince, nor like to doe no more.

13. And yet be≈øides the≈øe ≈øo many and va≈øte countries, our prote≈øtants haue told vs before, that all the other three parts of the world, A≈øia, Africke, and Europe, are full of Ma≈ø≈øes, and ≈øacrificinge Chri≈øtian prei≈øts. Which this prote≈øtant al≈øo confirmeth. (Grymston. ≈øupr. in the≈øe kingdoms pag. 700. &c.) teaching that not only in the territories, but in Tartaria, China, Iapan, Peru, Magor, Calicut, Nar≈øing, Per≈øia, all the Turks e≈øtates in Europe, Africk and A≈øia, Monomotapa, Congo, Moraco, and from the ri≈øing to the ≈øetting of the ≈øunne, the prophe≈øie of Malachie is iu≈øtified and performed, for in all the≈øe places, Mincha tehora, thu≈øia Cathara, the pure ≈øacrifice, hee ≈øpeaketh of, the holy ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe, is offered to the name of God, and his name is great among the Gentiles.

14. This is the ≈øtate of thinges at this time. Thus it was from the fir≈øt planting
of chri≈øtianity in the whole known world, by the holy Fathers before: and appeareth in the mo≈øt auncient Ma≈ø≈øe of S. Marke, the Euangeli≈øt, v≈øed among the fir≈øt Chri≈øtians of this nation, as I ≈øhall ≈øhew hereafter, in which thus wee finde. Per quem (Chri≈øtum) offerimns rationabilem & incruentam oblationem hanc, quam offerunt tibi Domine omnes gentes, ab ortu ≈øolis v≈øque ad occa≈øum, √† Septentrione ad meridiem: Quia magnum nomen tuum in omnibus gentibus, & in omni loco inceÃÑ≈øum offertur nomini tuo Sancto, & ≈øacrificium & oblatio. By whome (Chri≈øt) wee offer this rea≈øonable and vnbloody oblation, which √¥ Lord all nations doe offer vnto thee, from the ri≈øing of the ≈øunne, to the ≈øetting therof, from North to South, becau≈øe thy name is great in all nations, and in euery place incen≈øe, and ≈øacrifice & oblation, is offered to thy holy name. Liturgia. eccl. Alexandr. & S. Marci Euang. M. S. per antiq. tempore Britan.

div.head: AN HISTORIE OF THE HOLY PREISTHOOD, AND ≈øacrifice, of the true church. The fir≈øt age.

THE VIII. CHAPTER. Wherin is proued by all kinds of testimonies, Catholicks, Prote≈øtants, and what≈øoeuer, that Chri≈øt the true Me≈øsias as his calling and dignitie required, in abrogatinge the preisthood and ≈øacrifices of Mo≈øes lawe, instituted an other more perfect ≈øacrificinge preisthood, and ≈øacrifice of his ≈øacred body, and blood in Ma≈ø≈øe.
div.p:
HAuing declared and proued at large out of the holy Prophets and lawe of Mo≈øes, by all learned languages, and tran≈ølations, Hebrue, Greeke, and Latine, by all learned interpreters of ≈øcriptures, a≈øwell before, as after Chri≈øt, the auncient Rabbines, and primatiue Fathers of the church of Chri≈øt, as they are allowed and receiued both by Catholicke and Prote≈øtant writers, and their con≈øent herein. That our
ble≈ø≈øed Sauiour Chri≈øt our Redeemer, and high prei≈øt, after a more excellent manner accordinge to the order of Melchi≈øedech, was to euacuate the legall prei≈øthood, and ≈øacrifices of the lawe of Mo≈øes, as in them≈øelues figuratiue, and vmbraticall, beeing to cea≈øe & determine at the coming of the Me≈ø≈øias, & to found and in≈øtitute a prei≈øthood and ≈øacrifice more perfect, effectuall, & as S. Paul ≈øtileth it. Hebr. cap. 7. v. 24. and our prote≈øtants tran≈ølate it, „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , an vnchaungeable prei≈øthood, and con≈øequently a ≈øacrifice and law vnchaungeable, for ≈øo the≈øe men tran≈ølate the ≈øame holy Apo≈øtle: euery high preist is ordeyned to offer guifts and ≈øacrifices for ≈øinnes, and: for the preisthood beeing chaunged, there is made of nece≈øsitie a chaunge al≈øo of the lawe. (protest. tran≈øl. Hebr. cap. 5. v. 1. Hebr. cap. 7. v. 12.

2. Therefore the time of this mo≈øt happie chaunge and alteration beeinge now come, at his la≈øte pa≈ø≈øouer, or eating of the Pa≈øchall lambe, a figure (as I haue by greate≈øt allowance, and warrant formerly declared) of this mo≈øt holy chri≈øtian ≈øacrifice, although our Sauiour had often celebrated
that legall fea≈øt before, or none or ≈ømal memory thereof left in ≈øcripture, yet when in this la≈øte hee was to end the olde, and ordeine the new, hee ≈øent his two great Apo≈øtles and mo≈øt beloued, S Peter and Saint Iohn, to prouide the fir≈øt Chri≈øtian church as ≈øome not vnworthly call it. (Proclus apud Flor. Rem. l. 8 Luc. cap. 22. v. 12.) to in≈øtitute this mo≈øt ≈øacred prei≈øthood & ≈øacrifice in, „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , a large vpper Roome furnished (as our Engli≈øh prote≈øtaÃÑts tran≈ølate) but as the Greeke word is, and freÃÑch Hugonots al≈øo do read, a great Roome strewed with carpets. (Hugon. gallic. apud Florim. Raemund. ≈øupr. de origin. haere≈ø. l. 8. cap. 12) into which our high prei≈øt and Sauiour did enter, vt Rabbinorum nonnulli affirmant, veste ≈øacra, quam ip≈øi appellant Taleth indutus, as ≈øome of the Rabbines affirme, hauinge on a ≈øacred or ≈øacrificinge ve≈øtement, which they call Taleth. And there after hee had ended the ceremony of the lawe about the Pa≈øchall Lambe, he in≈øtituted this new ≈øacrifice of Chri≈øtians, and gaue power and commaundement to his Apo≈øtles pre≈øent, to doe the ≈øame; Hoc facite, doe this, which I haue done, in this
mi≈øtery.

3. Wee haue heard already, and it is infidelitie to deny it, that he was a prei≈øt, according to the order of Melchi≈øedech, that hee mu≈øt needes by that title offer a ≈øacrifice with ≈øome re≈øemblance to that of Melchi≈øedech, in bread and wine, that he was to chaunge the lawe, prei≈øthood, and ≈øacrifice: hee had not done any of the≈øe offices of the Me≈ø≈øias, and high prei≈øt before, onely hee had in the ≈øixt chapter of S. Iohn, giuen his faithfull promi≈øe (which he could not violate) that he would performe it: this was the la≈øte day, time, and oportunitie wherein he could po≈ø≈øiblie effect it, with his holy Apo≈øtles, to whom this charge before al others was fir≈øt and chiefly to be recommended, hee being that very night to be betrayed, violently taken, and ≈øeperated from them, and neuer to communicate with them againe in the ≈øhort time of his life; Therefore now or neuer he was of nece≈ø≈øitie to make performance of this mo≈øt holy dutie; and if not now, the lawe, prei≈øthood, and ≈øacrifices of the lawe, had not beene abrogated and chaunged, but Iudai≈øme had beene ≈øtill in force, and Chri≈øt
could not truely and lawfully haue enioyed the title of the true Me≈ø≈øias, if ≈øo excellent, and euident ≈øigne, and propertie, of the holy Redeemer, had beene wantinge and defectiue in him.

4. Therefore all kinde of witne≈ø≈øes that be or then were in the world, frends or enemies, whether Iewes Gentiles or Mahumetans, whether Chri≈øtians, Catholicks, either the auncient Fathers or later writers, and the be≈øt learned prote≈øtants them≈øelues giue euidence, that Chri≈øt at that time in≈øtituted a new ≈øacrifice, and ≈øacrificinge prei≈øthood. The auncient Rabbines before Chri≈øt, ≈øo expounded the ≈øcriptures, of the old te≈øtament, as I haue ≈øhewed before, and both Catholicks, and prote≈øtants ≈øo a≈ø≈øure vs. (Franci≈øc. Stancar. & Petr. Gallat. l. 10. cap. 4.5.6.7.) The Iewes that liued in the time of Chri≈øt, ≈øoone after, and at this day acknowledge it, hauinge proued by their lamentable experience, that after the in≈øtitution of the new ≈øacrifice, and prei≈øthood by Chri≈øt, as hee forewarned them of the cea≈øing of their ≈øacrifices, and de≈øolation of the Temple of Ieru≈øalem, where onely by their lawe they might bee offered, they
lie in that for≈øakeÃÑ ≈øtate which al the world ob≈øerueth, and the Prophet thus by prote≈øtants tran≈ølation foretold of them. (O≈øee c. 3. v. 4.) The children of I≈ørael shall abide manie yeares without a Kinge, and without a Prince, and without a ≈øacrifice, and without an Image, and without an Ephod, and without Seraphim, prei≈øtly and ≈øacrificing ve≈øtures. Iudic. cap. 17. v. 5.

5. And al that write again≈øt the Iewes, as the holy Archbi≈øhop S. Gregentius, Iulianus Pomerius Archbi≈øhop of Toletum, Rabbi Samuel, Hieronymus a S. fide, Paulus Burgen≈øis, Petrus Gallatinus, Franci≈øcus Stancarus a prote≈øtant, and others and their owne Thalmud is witnes, that the hate of the Iewes again≈øt Chri≈øt and Chri≈øtians, is not ≈øo great for any thing, as that Chri≈øt at that time ordeyned a new ≈øacrifice and ≈øacrificinge prei≈øthood, and reiected tho≈øe of the lawe of Moy≈øes. The gentiles ≈øoone after conuerted did confe≈ø≈øe it in all places, and in this kingdome of Britanie as I ≈øhall inuincibly demon≈øtrate herafter. The Mahumetans in their Alcaron and other authors giue te≈øtimony to this. So doe the mo≈øte holy and be≈øt learned Fathers
of the primatiue church Greeke and Latine, S. Denis the Areopagite conuerted by S. Paul, S. Irenaeus, S. Ba≈øil, S. Iohn Chri≈øo≈øtome, Theodoret, S. Martial ≈øcholler to S. Peter the Apo≈øtle, S. Ambro≈øe, S. Augu≈øtine, Prima≈øius, and longe before the≈øe S. Clement, Ignatius, Anacletus, with Pope Alexander, liuing in the fir≈øt hundred yeares, & others after, without number, plainlie ≈øome of them ≈øayinge that Chri≈øt then taught the new ≈øacrifice of the new te≈øtament, which the church receauing from the Apostles, doth offer to God in the whole world. And that it is ≈øo certaine and vndoubted a truth, that Chri≈øt did then make his Apo≈øtles ≈øacrificing prei≈øts, that in their iudgement, no man had called it into question. Quod Dominus potestatem celebrandi, & conficiendi noui testamenti my≈øteria, Apostolis per haec verba contulerit, hoc nemo opinor in dubiuÃÑ vocat. Gregent. Archiep. Tephren. di≈øput. cum Herban. Iudeo. Iulian. Pomer. l. 1. & 2. contr. Iudaeos. Rabbi Samuel Marrochian. l. de Aduent. Me≈øsiae cap. 19.20.21.22.23.24.25.26.27. Hieronym. √† S. fide l. 1. & 2. contr. Iud. Paul. Burg. cont. Iud. Petr. Gallat. & Franci≈øc. Stancar. l. 10.11. Thalm. & Abraham.
Mahum. Rabb. Sam. ≈øupr. cap. 27. Dioni≈ø. Areopag. Eccle≈ø. Hierar. part. 3. c. 3. Irenaeus l. 4. c. 32. cont. haer. Victor Antiochen. in c. 14. Marci. Ba≈øil. de ≈øacrificijs ritu & Mi≈ø. celebr. forma. Chri≈øo≈øt. de ≈øacrificijs, & Homil. 8. & ad cap. 26. Matth. & alibi ≈øaepe. Theodoret. in c. 8. ep. ad Hebr. Martial. epi≈øt. ad Burdegal. cap. 3. Ambro≈ø. l. praep. ad mi≈øs. ad cap. 11. epi≈øt. 1. ad Cor. & alibi. Augu≈øt. l. 17. ciuitat. c. 20. & quae≈øt. 43. l. 1. quae≈øt. in Euang. Prima≈ø. in epist. 1. Corinth. c. 11. can. 3. Apo≈øt. Alexand. 1. epist. ad Orthodox.

6. And this ≈øacrifice was, and is his ≈øacred body, and blood, vnder the formes of breade and wine, ≈øo miraculou≈øly effected both then, and ≈øtil by the mini≈øtery of con≈øecrated prei≈øts by his omnipotent power, annexed by promi≈øe to this ≈øacred and con≈øecrating words, this is my body: this is my blood: & that his holy Apo≈øtles were then made ≈øuch ≈øacrificinge prei≈øts, and ≈øupernaturally enabled to that highe≈øt and holie≈øt function. Neither can any prote≈øtant of England bee of other opinion: for except contrary to the iudgement and te≈øtimony of all people, Iewes, Mahumetans, Pagans, and Chri≈øtians, which acknowledge
Ie≈øus Chri≈øt to haue beene, and ordeined a new ≈øacrifice, and prei≈øthood, they will ca≈øt off all nature and name of Chri≈øtianitie, and goe further then any infidell yet hath done, mo≈øt fooli≈øhlie and bla≈øphemou≈øly to ≈øay, there was neuer any ≈øuch as is called Ie≈øus Chri≈øt: they mu≈øt confe≈ø≈øe with the re≈øt, that hee ordeined the≈øe thinges, they mu≈øt ≈øay, either with Turks and Pagans his in≈øtitution was not holy herin, or with the Iewes, that this ≈øacrifice is, panis polutus, poluted bread, and not his body. (Hieronym. √† S. fiae l. contr. Iud. 2. Iud. in Thalm. & alibi.) & his holy prei≈øts, be, ton≈øi, shauelings, as ≈øome of them prophanely do: or acknowledg with true Catholick Chri≈øtians in all ages, times, and places, that the ≈øacrifice and prei≈øthood he then ordeyned, are the mo≈øt perfect, ab≈øolute, and permanent for euer. For ≈øo all te≈øtimonies and euidences vpon which Chri≈øtian Religion buildeth, the word of God deliuered in holie ≈øcriptures, or tradition with the warrant and practi≈øe of all the holy Apo≈øtles, and church of Chri≈øt, haue already, or will in this en≈øuing treati≈øe a≈ø≈øure vs.

7. Therefore many of our be≈øt learned
prote≈øtants, and with publicke warrant, and priuiledge haue graunted before. (pref. cap. 1.) that Chri≈øt did not onely in≈øtitute and offer this mo≈øt holy ≈øacrifice, but did giue power vnto his Apo≈øtles, & commaundement al≈øo, to doe the ≈øame. That it ≈øucceeded to the ≈øacrifices of Moi≈øes lawe, that is was from the beginning the ≈øacrifice of the altare, and vnbloody ≈øacrifice, ≈øacrifice offered for the liuing and the deade (Morton appeale l. 3. c. 13. Franc. Ma≈øon l. 5. pag 233 243. Middlet. Papistom. pag. 92 113.49.137.138.47.45.) And among others to make al ≈øure, his maie≈øtie is auouched to be of the ≈øame minde. (I≈øaac Ca≈øaub. re≈øp. ad Card. Peron. pag. 51.) that from that time of Chri≈øts in≈øtitution, there is in his Church, and hath euer beene an externall ≈øacrifice, wherin is conteined the body and blood of Chri≈øt. And a prote≈øtant Bi≈øhop amonge them ≈øpeakinge in all their names. (Morton appeale l. 3. cap. 13.) ≈øaith: The prote≈øtants acknowledge in the Eucharist, a ≈øacrifice Euchari≈øticall. Which, and more, they are all bound to doe, by an expre≈ø≈øe ≈øtatute of parlament receaued & confirmed by three prote≈øtant Princes, Kinge Edward the ≈øixt, Queene Elizabeth, and
our pre≈øent ≈øoueraigne Kinge Iames, wherin is expre≈ø≈øely thus enacted. (Statut. an. 1. Edu. 6. cap. 1. an. 1 Elizabeth cap. 2. an. 1. Iacobi cap. 25.) The mo≈øt comfortable Sacrament of the body and blood of our Sauiour Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, commonly called of the altare, instituted of no le≈ø≈øe author then our Sauiour, both God and man. The in≈øtitution of which Sacrament being ordeyned by Chri≈øt, as is afore≈øaid, and the words, this is my body which is broken for you; This is my blood of the new te≈øtament, which is shed for you, and for many, for the remi≈øsion of ≈øinnes, ≈øpoken of it, beeing of eternall infallible and vndoubted truth, the most ble≈øsed Sacrament &c. The≈øe bee the wordes of the ≈øtatute e≈øtabli≈øhed by his pre≈øent maie≈øtie in parlament, with publicke a≈ø≈øent of all Engli≈øh Prote≈øtants, mini≈øters or others: in which ≈øtatute penalties bee decreed again≈øt al gaine≈øayers of this holy ≈øacrifice, and prouide an e≈øpeciall writ again≈øt ≈øuch tran≈øgre≈ø≈øors. statut. ≈øupr.

8. And to make all matters vnque≈øtionable in this point, this ≈øtatute was enacted when there were none but ≈øacrificing prei≈øtes in England, diuers yeares before the booke of making mini≈øters was inuented.
Which the wordes of the abridgement of our ≈øtatuts approued by his maie≈øty (to reiterate them) thus doe te≈øtifie. (Abridgm. of ≈øtat. an. Dom. 1611. Titul. ≈øeruice and Sacraments cap. 1) the first makinge of this statute was before the Ma≈ø≈øe was taken away, when the opinion of the reall pre≈øence, was not remoued from vs. Therefore this ≈øtatute wholly and without any other exception, limitation, or re≈øtriction beeing publickly made, approued, reuiued and confirmed by three ≈øeuerall publicke parlaments, of three Prote≈øtant Princes, cannot be contradicted by any Engli≈øh Prote≈øtant: and except contradictions can both bee true, which is vnpo≈ø≈øible, it is not po≈ø≈øible but the contents of this ≈øtatute of Chri≈øts in≈øtitutinge the holy ≈øacrificinge prei≈øthood, and ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe at his la≈øt ≈øupper, mu≈øt needes bee an article of faith, and infallible truth, in the Religion and iudgement of Engli≈øh Prote≈øtants. Therefore ≈øome of their be≈øt learned. (Feild l. 3 cap. 29. pag. 138. Couell examin. pag. 114.) haue with publicke applau≈øe, and warrant written, that it is here≈øie, to bee of other opinion. For ≈øo they ≈øhould deny and gain≈øay the vniuer≈øally receaued,
and practi≈øed opinion, of the primatiue church. Who≈øe cu≈øtome vniuer≈øall and from the beginninge was, to offer the ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe, both for the liuing and the dead. Which all men know, cannot be performed, but by ma≈ø≈øing and ≈øacrificing prei≈øts, Ma≈ø≈øe and ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øts, ≈øacrifice and ≈øacrificing prei≈øts, beeing vn≈øeperable correlatiues, in al eueÃÑ humane knowledge, and learninge, both of Catholicks, and Prote≈øtants, Chri≈øtians, Iewes, Mahumetans, Pagans, or what≈øoeuer infidels, profe≈ø≈øinge learninge, or followinge the light and warrant of nature.

9. And for the very v≈øuall name it ≈øelfe of this mo≈øt holy ≈øacrifice, called generallie in the latine church, Mi≈ø≈øa, or ≈øacrificium Mi≈ø≈øae, Ma≈ø≈øe, or the ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe, ≈øeing it was to be the oÃÑly external ≈øacrifice of the whole church of Chri≈øt, it could not po≈ø≈øibly be named by any denomination more aptly, then the word Mi≈øsa, Ma≈ø≈øe, beeing by diuers learned in the holy tongs, a name both in Greek Hebrue and latine fittly ≈øignifyinge ≈øacrifice, or equiualent thereof: of the Greeke there is mo≈øt difficultie, and yet ≈øome learned gretians, as Albericus (dictione
Mi≈ø≈øa.) te≈øtifie, that Mi≈ø≈øa is a Greeke word, ≈øignifyinge interpellation, or interce≈ø≈øion, ≈øuch as ≈øacrifice to God ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ s. That it is an Hebrue word, and aptly taken for ≈øacrifice, we haue the con≈øent allmo≈øt of all Hebritians, both Catholicks, and prote≈øtaÃÑts, as of the fir≈øt Alc ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ atus, Hector Pintus, Claudius Sanctus, Pamelius, Demochares, Ca≈øalius, Capino, Cauus, Couarrunias, Pauinus, Heruetus, and others. Alciatus l. 7. parerg. cap. 10, Hect. Pint. in cap. 3. Dan. Claud. Sainct. praef. ad Liturg. Pamel. in Tertull. l. de orat. & praef. in Liturg. Graecor. Demochar. tract. 2. de Mi≈ø≈ø. c. 1. Ca≈øalius l. 1. ≈øacrif. Mi≈ø≈ø. Io. Capr. Can. l. 12. de loc. c. 13. Couarr. l. 4. Var. re≈øol. c. 22. Pagn. v. Mitza.

10. And amonge Prote≈øtants, Seba≈øtian Mun≈øter, Philip Melancthon, and Iohn Fro≈øter Profe≈ø≈øors of Hebrue ar of the ≈øame opinion, and to iu≈øtifie our Engli≈øh name of that holy ≈øacrifice, to be taken al≈øo from the Hebrue, where wee call it Ma≈ø≈øe, or Mas, the worde or radix Mas in Hebrue, ≈øignifieth tribute or due paiement, ≈øuch as wee owe in this ≈øacrifice beeing commaunded to doe it, hoc facite, and the vnleuened breade that was eaten with the Pa≈øchall
Lambe, and con≈øecrated by Chri≈øt is Ma≈ø≈øah, in Hebrue. Mon≈øter. in gramatica & lexic, Hebraic. Philip. Mel. Apolog. confe≈ø≈ø. Augu≈øtan. Iohn. Froster. in Lexic. Hebraic. edit. Ba≈øil. an. 1557. Petr. Veg. in p≈øal. 101. And to come to the Latine word, Mi≈ø≈øa, Ma≈ø≈øe, S. Albinus our learned countryman, expoundinge tho≈øe la≈øte wordes in Ma≈ø≈øe, ite mi≈ø≈øa est, ≈øaith: id est directa, ≈øiue mi≈ø≈øa est, id e≈øt perfecta est pro nobis oblatio & oratio. That is, ≈øacrifice or oblation and prayer for vs is directed, or ≈øent, or perfected. S. Albin. l. de diuin. officijs. ≈øo doth Remigius Anti≈øiodoren≈øis, ≈øaying. Mi≈øsa dicitur, qua≈øi tran≈ømi≈ø≈øa, vel qua≈øi tran≈ømi≈øsio. Remig. Anti≈øiodoren. expo≈øitio. de celebrat. mi≈ø≈øae. And Petrus Lombardus. Mi≈ø≈øa dicitur quia mi≈ø≈øa e≈øt ho≈øtia, cuius commemoratio fit in illo officio: vnde dicitur: Ite mi≈ø≈øa e≈øt. Petr. Lumbard. l. 4. ≈øent. Where we ≈øee that it is called Mi≈ø≈øa, becau≈øe it is a ≈øacrifice ≈øent, or offered vnto God, and not of di≈ømi≈ø≈øinge the people. Which is euident by the practi≈øe of the church in all places, which at the ende of all Ma≈ø≈øes di≈ømi≈ø≈øeth the people: but as our prote≈øtants them≈øelues confe≈ø≈øe (Foxe tom, 2. in Queene Mary.) ≈øaith not alwaies, ita mi≈ø≈øa e≈øt, but
≈øometimes, benedicamus Domino, ≈øoometimes, requie≈øcant in pace, and in the old Muzaraban Ma≈ø≈øe, in ≈øolemne fea≈øts, where wee ≈øay in the end of Ma≈ø≈øe, ite mi≈ø≈øa est, they ≈øaid, ≈øolemnia completa ≈øunt, the ≈øolemne ≈øacrifice is ended, and in other fea≈øts: mi≈ø≈øa acta e≈øt: ma≈øse or the ≈øacrifice, is ended. (mi≈ø≈øa Muzarab. antiq. in concil. 4 Toletan. & alibi.) And in this ≈øence it was alwayes accepted, in all ages, from the Apo≈øtles, as our prote≈øtants them≈øelues ≈øhall euidently confe≈ø≈øe hereafter, in this hi≈øtory.

div.head: THE IX. CHAPTER. Shewinge how the Apostles in generall being by Christ ordeyned ≈øacrificinge prei≈øts, did accordinge to that power and commaundement giuen vnto them, offer the ≈øacrifice of Christs body and blood in Ma≈øse, and ordered other preists to that end.
div.p:
ANd by this it is al≈øo manife≈øt, that the Apo≈øtles were ≈øacrificinge and ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øts, and did, as that prei≈øtly dignitie confered vpon them, required, offer this holy ≈øacrifice, accordinge to the warrant
and commaundement of Chri≈øt vnto them, to doe, that which he did in that behalfe. So that if we had no further authoritie, for their ≈øacrificinge prei≈øthood, and dutie to offer this ble≈ø≈øed ≈øacrifice, but that they were, as before is ≈øhewed, made ≈øacrificing prei≈øts by Chri≈øt, ≈øeeing that prei≈øthood and ≈øacrifice was neuer to cea≈øe, but to bee continued in the church of the Me≈ø≈øias, vnto the end of the world, and the≈øe men were the cheife≈øt in≈øtruments, and rulers, which our Sauiour in≈øtituted, to conuert the nations, and communicate this ≈øacred prei≈øthood and power, to offer this ≈øacrifice, vnto others, ≈øtill to bee continued, without interruption, wee mu≈øt enforcedlie yeelde, that they left ≈øuch a ≈øacrificinge power, and ≈øome maner and order how this ≈øacrifice was to bee ≈øolemnized, to ≈øucceedinge generations. Which I ≈øhall proue of euery one of the Apo≈øtles in particular, in the next chapters, onely here of them all in general, that this doctrine of con≈øecration, prei≈øthood & ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe, they taught and deliuered to the churches where they liued and preached, wee haue many and worthie arguments and witne≈ø≈øes.

2. S. Chri≈øo≈øtome telleth vs plainly, how the Apo≈øtles practi≈øinge and deliuering the order of this ≈øacrifice, decreed that the faithfull departed should bee remembred then, and prayed for. Ab Apostolis ≈øancitum est, vt in celebratione venerandorum my≈øteriorum, memoria fiat eorum qui hinc dece≈ø≈øerunt. Nouerunt illis multum hinc emolumenti fieri, multum vtilitatis, ≈øtante ≈øiquidem vniuer≈øo populo, manus in caelos extendente, caetu etiam ≈øacerdotali, venerandoque po≈øito ≈øacrificio: quomodo Deum non placaremas pro istis orantes? (Chri≈øo≈øtom. Homil. 3 in cap. 1. epist. ad Philipp.) It was decreed by the Apo≈øtles, that in the celebration of the venerable my≈øteries, a memory ≈øhould bee made of them that were departed this life. They knew much gaine, much profit did therby come to them, for all the people ≈øtandinge holdinge vp their hands to heauen, the prei≈øtlie company, and the venerable ≈øacrifice offered: how could it bee that wee ≈øhoulde not appea≈øe God, prayinge for them? The very like hee writeth in an other place. (Chri≈øost. Homil. 69. ad popul. Antiochen.) And S. Ba≈øile ≈øetting downe many thinges deliuered by the tradition of the Apo≈øtles,
≈øaith. (S. Ba≈øil. l. 5. de vniuer≈øal. eccl.) this tradition did commend the words of long prayer, and con≈øecration ouer the breade and chalice, ≈øet downe in order: multifariam digesta ≈øuper panem & calicem prolixae orationis & con≈øecrationis verba commendauit? Irenaeus ≈øaith the church receaued this order of ≈øacrifice, from the Apo≈øtles, and in his time offered it to God in all the world. Oblationem noui testamenti Eccle≈øia ab Apostolis accipiens in vniuer≈øo mundo offert Deo. Irenaeus l. 4. cap. 32. contr. haere≈ø. The auncient learned Bi≈øhop Stephanus Eduen≈øis writtinge of this holy ≈øacrifice, ≈øetteth down the maner how the Apo≈øtles practi≈øed and preached it. (Stephan. Eduen. Epi≈øc. l. de Sacramento Altaris cap. 20.) Sicut Magister docuerat Apo≈øtoli ≈øe & alios communicando con≈øecrationem corporis & ≈øanguinis Domini facere caeperunt, & fieri per vniuer≈øas Eccle≈øias instituerunt. Primo ≈øine aliquo ornatu fiebat canonis my≈øterium, postea cum canone legebatur epi≈øtola, & Euangelium. Deinde √† Romanis Pontificibus, quibu≈ødam additis ad ornatum & decoratum; Eccle≈øiae celebranda aliqua ≈øu≈øceperunt. As Chri≈øt theire Ma≈øter had taught them, the Apo≈øtles communicating
them≈øelues, and other began to make the con≈øecration of the body and blood of our Lord, and preachinge in≈øtituted it to bee done throughout all churches. Fir≈øt without any ornament the mi≈øtery of the canon of Ma≈ø≈øe was practi≈øed, afterward with the canon were reade the epi≈øtle, and Gho≈øpel. After this ≈øomethings for ornament, were therto added by the Popes of Rome, the churches receiued the re≈øt to be celebrated.

3. Where wee ≈øee the whole body and ≈øub≈øtance of the Ma≈ø≈øe, con≈øi≈øtinge in the holy canon perfected, practi≈øed, and deliuered by the Apo≈øtles. And what was after added by the Popes of Rome, were onely ceremoniall for honor and ornament ≈øake and not nece≈ø≈øitie, as hee there expre≈ø≈øeth, and I wil demon≈øtrate herafter by our prote≈øtants them≈øelues, and for this place their prime man and fir≈øt prote≈øtantlye made Archbi≈øhop, te≈øtifieth as much as this holy Bi≈øhop hath done before. For he ≈øaith plainlie. (Matth. Parker. l. de Britan. antiq. cap. 17. pag. 47.) that the order and forme of Ma≈ø≈øe, which the Apo≈øtles v≈øed, and deliuered to the church, duceÃÑtis aÃÑplius aÃÑnis in prima Eccle≈øia durauit, continued aboue two hundred
yeares in the primatiue church without alteration. And then beeing ≈øomewhat altered, by Pope S. Zepherine, the chaunge which was made, was to a more excellent forme and matter. Ad pulchriorem materiam formam
que . S. Proclus Patriarch of Con≈øtantinople and ≈øucce≈ø≈øor to S. Chri≈øo≈øtome there te≈øtifieth, that Saint Clement receaued the forme of Ma≈ø≈øe from the Apo≈øtles, and publi≈øhed it to the world. (Proclus tractat. de traditione diuin. Liturgiae. infra. cap.) Quia Sacro≈øancta illa my≈øteria √† Sanctis Apostolis ≈øibi reuelata in lucem edidit. And how daily after Christs A≈øcen≈øion they a≈ø≈øembled and found great comfort in this holy ≈øacrifice of Christs body and blood, ≈øaid Ma≈ø≈øe with longe prayers. Cum multam con≈øolationem in mistico illo Dominici corporis ≈øacrificio po≈øitam inueni≈ø≈øent, fu≈øi≈øsim√® & longa oratione Liturgiam decantabant; and more plainely, as hereafter, preferringe it before all other holy duties and exerci≈øes. And Amalarius Fortunatus maketh this rea≈øon, why the forme and order of this ≈øacrifice, was by our Sauiour recommended to the care of the Apo≈øtles (Amalar. Fortunat. l. 3. de Eccle≈ø. offic. cap.) Saluator quo vehementius commendaret mysterij illius altitudinem
vltimum hoc voluit infigere cordibus & memoriae di≈øcipulorum, a quibus ad pa≈ø≈øionem digre≈ø≈øurus erat, & ideo non praecipit, quo deinceps ordine ≈øumeretur, vt Apostolis per quos Eccle≈øias di≈øpo≈øiturus erat, ≈øeruaret hunc locum. Our Sauiour that hee might more vehemently commend the worthines of that mi≈øtery, would haue it the la≈øt thing hee was to fa≈øten into the harts and memorie of his di≈øciples, from whom he was to depart to his pa≈ø≈øion, and therefore did not commaund in what order it ≈øhould afterwards bee receaued, that hee might re≈øerue that dutie to the Apo≈øtles, by whom hee was to di≈øpo≈øe the churches.

4. To this all the holy Fathers before, that te≈øtifie Chri≈øt ordeyned this holy ≈øacrifice, and recommended it to his Apo≈øtles, beare witnes; for none but Antichri≈øtians will ≈øay, that the Apo≈øtles taught or practi≈øed, otherwi≈øe then Chri≈øt in≈øtituted and commaunded. And they were ≈øo zelous in this holy doctrine, that as both Catholicks and Prote≈øtants haue proued before, they were wicked Hereticks by S. Ignatius te≈øtimony that then denyed this B. ≈øacrifice to bee the body and blood of Chri≈øt,
which were giuen and ≈øhed for the ≈øinnes of the worlde. (Ignat. apud Theodoret. Bezam. Whitaker. & al. ≈øupr.) And Leontius Bizantinus writing again≈øt the Hereticks Ne≈øtorius and Eutiches charging them fir≈øt with denyinge the Nicen creed, and producinge a p≈øeudo≈øimbolum of their owne inuention, taxeth the Hereticke with an other prophane impietie not inferior to the other, to deny the holy order of the ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe, ordeyned and in≈øtituted by the Apo≈øtles, receaued by the Fathers, and that of S. Ba≈øil penned by the ≈øame holy ≈øpirit; & inuented an other Ma≈ø≈øe of his owne to ≈øu≈øteine his here≈øie full of bla≈øphemies. Audet & aliud malum non ≈øecundum ad ≈øuperiora, aliam enim Mi≈ø≈øam effutiuit praetor illam qua √† patribus tradita est Eccle≈øijs, neque reueritis illam Apostolorum, nec illam magni Ba≈øilij in eodem ≈øpiritu con≈øcriptum, in qua Mi≈ø≈øa bla≈øphemijs non precationibus mysterium Eucharistiae oppleuit. And this wickednes was ≈øo great by this renowned author, that hee calleth it Antichri≈øtianitie and the denier of the Apo≈øtles Ma≈ø≈øe, Antichri≈øt. An vt alius Antichri≈øtus adhuc expectetur par e≈øt, qui ≈øic Chri≈øtum oderit, & quae Christi ≈øunt
mutare nitatur? And our Engli≈øh Prote≈øtants them≈øelues both ≈øay that the ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe for the liuing and the dead, was a tradition of the Apo≈øtles, and Aerius was iu≈øtly condemned of here≈øy by the primatiue church, for denyinge ≈øacrifice for the dead. And this is publickly and authoritatiuely approued by the remembred ≈øtatute of Queene Elizabeth, Kinge Eduard the 6. and Kinge Iames our pre≈øent ≈øoueraigne, a≈ø≈øuringe vs, that this holy ≈øacrifice of the altare, was in≈øtituted by Chri≈øt at his la≈øte ≈øupper with his Apo≈øtles, deliuered to theÃÑ, and by them to the church and ≈øucceeding Chri≈øtian prei≈øts to the end, and conteyneth the oblation of the mo≈øt ≈øacred body and blood of Chri≈øt. Middleton. Papistom. pag. 49.137.138.47.48. Feild. l. 3. cap. 29. pag. 138. statut. an. 1. Edu. 6. an 1. Elizab. & an. 1. Iacob. Reg.

div.head: THE X. CHAPTER. Wherin is particularly proued of all the holy Apo≈øtles and Euangeli≈øts, that they were ≈øacrificinge ma≈øsinge preists, and did both practi≈øe and teach the ≈øame doctrines. And first the 4. Euangelists and S. Paule, who haue remeÃÑbred the≈øe misteries in holy ≈øcriptures.
div.p:
THis being thus inuincibly proued, and acknowledged, both by Catholicke and Prote≈øtant authoritie, that both Chri≈øt our Sauiour in≈øtituted this holy ≈øacrifice, and ≈øacrificinge prei≈øthood; and his Apo≈øtles receauinge them from him, did all in generall both exerci≈øe and deliuer the ≈øame vnto the churches, there can bee no Chri≈øtian de≈øirous to retaine that name, that may oppo≈øe again≈øt the ≈øame; yet for a further manife≈øtation of the≈øe truthes, vnto all, that will not de≈øperatly dwell in error, I will now proue in particular, how euery one of the Apo≈øtles, and Euangeli≈øts, both beleeued, practi≈øed, and taught the≈øe mi≈øteries. And fir≈øt to begin with the foure Euangeli≈øts,
and S. Paule, who haue committed the≈øe Chri≈øtian holy ≈øecrets, to holie writinge; I will ≈øhew how both in the≈øe their ≈øacred ≈øcriptures, they teach and allowe the ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe, and a ≈øacrificinge or ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øthood, by order and ≈øacred office to offer that ≈øacrifice. And to put vs out of all doubt or que≈øtion that this is and was theire meaninge in tho≈øe holy ≈øcriptures, I will proue, that euery one of them was a true ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øt, and actually did offer, and celebrate the mo≈øt honorable ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe, in e≈ø≈øential thinges, as the holy Catholicke ma≈ø≈øing prei≈øts of the church of Rome now doe, and haue euer mo≈øt religiou≈øly done, in all ages. The ≈øame I will likewi≈øe proue, of all the other Apo≈øtles, in their order, onely I will craue leaue of S. Peter, the fir≈øt, and cheife≈øt, to remember him la≈øte in this matter; for as I haue proued at large in other places, as amonge the Apo≈øtles hee was the fir≈øt, and allmo≈øte onely Apo≈øtle, which planted the faith of Chri≈øt in the≈øe parts of the world: So wee in Britanie did fir≈øt receaue from him, our holy ma≈ø≈øinge and ≈øacrificinge prei≈øts, and prei≈øthood, neuer hitherto altogether
di≈øcontinued, or interrupted, but by him and his ≈øucce≈ø≈øors in the Apo≈øtolicke ≈øea of Rome fir≈øt founded, and euer after ≈øucce≈ø≈øiuely in all ages pre≈øerued in this kingdome, as will appeare hereafter.

2. Therefore to begin with the Euangeli≈øts and S. Paule, which ≈øpeake of the≈øe mi≈øteries in ≈øcripture, S. Mathew the Apo≈øtle (and fir≈øt in order amonge the Euangeli≈øts) writeth of Chri≈øts deliuery of this ≈øacrifice in the≈øe wordes, as our Engli≈øh Prote≈øtants by his maie≈øties priuiledge tran≈ølate them. (Matth. cap. 26. v. 26.27.28.) Ie≈øus tooke breade and ble≈ø≈øed it, and brake it, and gaue it to his di≈øciples, and ≈øaid, take eate, this is my body. And hee tooke the cup, and gaue thankes, and gaue it to them ≈øavinge, drinke ye al of it for this is my blood of the new testament, which is shed for many, for the remi≈øsion of ≈øinnes. The Greeke text, which the≈øe men ≈øay mu≈øt bee here preferred, is word by word as they tran≈ølate, ≈øpeakinge of Chri≈øts body, that it was at that pre≈øent giuen there, and his blood in the pre≈øent tence ≈øhed for remi≈ø≈øion of ≈øinnes „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ . Therefore if Chri≈øts oblation, and giuing his body, and blood,
vppon the Cro≈ø≈øe was a ≈øacrifice, as all agree, ≈øeeing it was ≈øo in re≈øpect it was there giuen and offered for remi≈ø≈øion of ≈øinnes, here beeing the very ≈øame body and blood, and giuen for remi≈ø≈øion of ≈øinnes, it mu≈øt needes bee al≈øo a ≈øacrifice, and not onely euchari≈øticall or of thanks giuing, but ≈øatisfactory: for what≈øoeuer tal ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ eth away ≈øinnes, by its owne vertue, as the Euangeli≈øt here ≈øpeaketh of this, mu≈øt needes be ≈øuch, and Chri≈øts body and blood beeing of infinite value in them≈øelues and of their own nature, can not but be ≈øatisfactorie for ≈øinnes, when≈øoeuer, how≈øoeuer, & by whom≈øoeuer they are offered, or giuen for remi≈ø≈øion of ≈øinnes, though the limited power of prei≈øts may bringe ≈øome limitation to their ≈øatisfaction, the ordinance and in≈øtitution of Chri≈øt, ≈øo di≈øpo≈øing in this ≈øacrifice, as it is now daily offered by con≈øecrated prei≈øts, as the common opinion is, otherwi≈øe a thing of illimited worth, ≈øhould bee of like de≈øeruinge, and ≈øatisfaction.
