3. And this is ≈øo euident, that not onely all learned Fathers, and antiquitie do from hence teach, that Chri≈øt in this place in≈øtituted the ≈øacrifice of the new te≈øtament, as
I haue cited diuers before, but our greate≈øt enemies and per≈øecutors, as namly the pre≈øent Prote≈øtant Archbi≈øhop of Canterbury the director of Ma≈øter Ma≈øon, and hee al≈øo with others. (Ma≈øon. praefat. & lib. 5. cap. 6. pag. 235. Abb. ibidem. Magdeburgent. in S. Iren.) acknowledge, particularly naminge S. Irenaeus, S. Chri≈øo≈øtome, and S. Gregorie, from them concluding in the≈øe words: That Chri≈øt did then teach the oblation of the new testament, which the church throughout all the world doth, when shee ≈øaith, this is my body. And they plainly ≈øay. (Ma≈øon and D. Georg. Abbots ≈øupr. pag. 233.) that the≈øe wordes of Chri≈øt recited before by S. Matthew, this is my body which is giuen for you, and this is my blood of the new te≈øtament which is shed for you, doe argue a ≈øacrifice to God. And if this was not a ≈øacrifice, then by prote≈øtant Religion, admittinge nothing but ≈øcriptures in matters of faith, Chri≈øt Ie≈øus was not the prei≈øt after the order of Melchi≈øedech, which was promi≈øed; for exceptinge this, the whole new te≈øtament is ≈øilent of any prei≈øtly act, of that order, which hee performed in all his life, and ≈øo that being a di≈øtinctiue ≈øigne, of the true Me≈ø≈øias, they
would depriue all mankinde of Redemption, and our mo≈øte ble≈ø≈øed Sauiour of the title, and honour of redeeminge vs. Therfore thus they graunt. (Abbots and Ma≈øon ≈øupr. pag. 243.) Christ hauing offered him≈øelf, for a ≈øoueraigne ≈øacrifice, vnto his Father, ordeyned, that wee should offer a remembraunce thereof, vnto God, in steade of a ≈øacrifice. Which they mu≈øt needes vnder≈øtand of Chri≈øts oblation in this place, before his pa≈ø≈øion, for they make this before his commaundement, and power giuen to his Apo≈øtles, of celebrating this mi≈øtery, by the≈øe words as the≈øe men tran≈ølate. (Luc. cap. 22. ver. 19.) doe this in remembrance of mee. So that Chri≈øt ordeyninge, that we ≈øhould do what hee did, as the words bee manife≈øt, and Chri≈øt as they confe≈ø≈øe there, offered him≈øelfe for a ≈øoueraigne ≈øacrifice vnto his Father, we mu≈øt offer Chri≈øt in the ≈øame maner, for a ≈øoueraigne ≈øacrifice vnto God.

4. And for a cleare demon≈øtration, that together with the coÃÑmaundement a prei≈øtlie ≈øacrificinge power was giuen by tho≈øe wordes, to his holy Apo≈øtles, and they by them made ma≈ø≈øing, and ≈øacrificing prei≈øts, to ≈øacrifice, as Chri≈øt by the≈øe prote≈øtants,
and the ≈øcripture before, did at that time his ble≈ø≈øed body, and body, it is not lawfull, or validate in either Religion of Catholicks, or Prote≈øtants, for any Chri≈øtian man, or woman to intermeddle to offer, or mini≈øter in the≈øe things, what≈øoeuer we ≈øhall name them, or iudge them to bee, but a Catholickly con≈øecrated prei≈øt, by the one, or prote≈øtant mini≈øter by the other, therfore tho≈øe ≈øacred words, do this (Matth. cap. 26. v. 20. Marc. cap. 14. v. 17. Luc. c. 22. v. 14.) gaue prei≈øtly and ≈øacrificing power to his Apo≈øtles, only pre≈øent, by the Euangeli≈øts: for if they had beene generally ≈øpoken vnto all Chri≈øtians, all Chri≈øtians ≈øhould both haue power, & were bouÃÑd vnder daÃÑnation to take vpon them to mini≈øter in ≈øuch things; for the wordes, doe this, to whom≈øoeuer they were ≈øpoken, conteyne an expre≈ø≈øe commaundement, to bee performed.

5. And to make this matter more euident, it is manife≈øt by the prote≈øtant parlament ≈øtatute of Kinge Edward the ≈øixt, Queene Elizabeth, and King Iames. (Statut. 1. Edw. 6.1. Eliz. & 1. Iacob. ≈øupr.) That the Prote≈øtants of England neither doe,
nor by their Religion may, make it a matter of commaundement and nece≈ø≈øitie, for lay par≈øons to communicate vnder both kindes, but doe freely acknowledge, that in the fir≈øt fiue hundred yeares of Chri≈øt, the Sacrament was mini≈øtred vnto, and receaued of the laitie ≈øometimes in one, ≈øomtimes in both kindes, and yet the practi≈øe of the church was holy in tho≈øe dayes; therfore there neuer was a generall commaundement to al Chri≈øtians to receaue in both kindes: yet S. Paul ≈øettinge downe Chri≈øts ordinance, and in≈øtitution of this holy ≈øacrifice, he ≈øaid both concerninge his body and blood, he gaue this expre≈ø≈øe commaundement: doe this in remembrance of mee. Decembris, the Magdeburgian Prote≈øtants with others te≈øtifie:) ex eius praedicationis fonte, tota Gallia fidei Rinulos accepit: out of the fountaine of his preaching all Fraunce receauing the channels
of faith. (Magd. centur. 1. l. 1. in Trophimo.) yet the auncient Britti≈øh antiquitie ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed by our prote≈øtants (of which before, and more herafter) is a ≈øufficient warrant and witne≈ø≈øe, that hee deliuered and ob≈øerued in Fraunce, a certaine forme and order of the holy ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe, and the ≈øame was v≈øed and practi≈øed, al≈øo both at Rome and here in Britanie likewi≈øe at that time. M. S. Britan. antiq. pr. Stores in exordium.

32. And the ≈øame is as euidently proued, from his renowned ≈øcholler S. Denis the Areopagite; Who in his booke of the eccle≈øia≈øticall Hierarchie. (cap. 5.7. & epi≈øt. ad Demophil.) ≈øetteth downe the whole order of the ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe, and how the prei≈øt behaued him≈øelfe at the holy altare, both before and after con≈øecration, how the catechumens, energumens, and publick penitents, were not permitted to bee pre≈øent, but onely to the prayers which were before the oblation of the ≈øacrifice: He ≈øetteth down how bread and wine was propo≈øed on the altare, how ble≈ø≈øed, con≈øecrated into the body & blood of Chri≈øt, and offered in ≈øacrifice. How greate reuerence
and prayer was al≈øo v≈øed vnto Chri≈øt vnder the externall ≈øpecies. O tu diuinum ≈øacrati≈øsimumque Sacramentum, obducta tibi per ≈øigna ob≈øcuritatum, qua≈øi vela & integumenta, patefacta per≈øpicu√® nobis ostende, menti≈øque nostrae oculos ≈øingulari, & quae obtegi non pote≈øt, luce comple. Hee ≈øheweth how a memory of Saints is there made, mystica Sanctorum recitatio fit. He teacheth how the prei≈øt or Bi≈øhop, prayed for the dead, for remi≈ø≈øion of their ≈øinnes, and to come to glory. Precatur oratio illa diuinam clementiam, vt cuncta dimittat per infirmitatem humanam admi≈ø≈øa peccata defuncto, eumque inluce ≈øtatuat, & regione viuoruÃÑ. Which is as much as the RomaÃÑ church now v≈øeth, in that holy ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe. And hee remembreth how in the ende the prei≈øt acknowledgeth the dignitie of that holy ≈øacrifice, to bee ≈øo great, that he was vnworthy to offer it, but that Chri≈øt did both giue power and commaund to doe it, when hee ≈øaid to his Apo≈øtles, doe this in commemoration of mee. Religios√® ≈øimul, & vt Pontificem decet, po≈øt ≈øacras diuinorum operum laudes de ≈øacrificio, quod ip≈øius dignitatem ≈øuperat, ≈øe purgat, dum prim√≤ ad cum clamat, tu dixisti,
hoc facite in meam commemorationem.

33. And how carefull, and diligent an ob≈øeruer, and practi≈øer of this ma≈ø≈øing doctrine hee was, in act and deed, daily in his whole life, we may be a≈ø≈øured by the worthie writers of his life and death, Hilduinus Abbot of S. Denis in Fraunce where hee was buried, about 800. yeares ≈øince, Ro≈øwita or Ro≈øwida, not longe after and others, who confidently and from publick te≈øtimony, write, that neither his ≈øtrict impri≈øonment in a dungeon could hinder him from performing this holy dutie, but there both per≈øuadinge the people pre≈øent, and writinge vnto others ab≈øent, to confirme them more, ≈øaid Ma≈ø≈øe in that vnfit place: & to proue how acceptable it was, Chri≈øt Ie≈øus with a multitude of Angels appeared vnto them all, with ≈øuch a light from heauen, as had beene ≈øeene, at the very time when they were to communicate, & comforted his holy Martir. Sed nec carcereis prae≈øul praeclarus in antris de≈øinit ob≈øequium Domino per≈øoluere dignum: ≈øed docuit plebem studios√® conuenientem, ac celebrat ≈øacrae ≈øolit√≤ ≈øolemnia Mi≈ø≈øae: Est vbi caelestem debebat frangere panem, lux noua tristifico ≈øubito fulgebat
in antro, in qua ≈øidereae regnator ≈øplendidus aulae ≈øcilicet angelica pariter comitante caterua apparens, charum con≈øolabatur amicum. Trithem. l. de ≈øcriptorib. in Hildonio. & Ro≈øwida. Hilduinus Abb. in vita S. Dioni≈øij Areopag. cap. 29. Roswita l. de vit. S. Dioni≈ø. Areopag. & alijs.

div.head: THE X. CHAPTER. How all the rest of the, Apo≈øtles in particular S. Andrew, Iames the great, Thomas, Iames the le≈ø≈øe, Philip, Bartholomew, Symon, Thaddaeus, and Matthias, were ≈øacrificinge Prei≈øts, and Apostles, and v≈øually offered the ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe.
div.p:
NOw let vs come to the re≈øt of the holie Apo≈øtles which haue not in ≈øcriptures written of the≈øe mi≈øteries, and proue of them all, and in order (except S. Peter the fir≈øt, whom I haue promi≈øed to put in the la≈øt place) that in their ≈øacred functions, they offered the mo≈øt holy ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe. And fir≈øt to begin with S. Andrew. It is a receaued opinion. Iodoc. Cocc. Tom. 2. l. 7. artic. 5. de purgator. that this holy Apo≈øtle
did fir≈øt deliuer that forme of Ma≈ø≈øe, which was auntiently and from the beginninge v≈øed in the church of Con≈øtantinople, and after called the Ma≈ø≈øe of S. Iohn Chri≈øo≈øtome, the great and learned Patriarke of that place, becau≈øe it was enlarged by him, and is ≈øtil, as our prote≈øtants acknowledge, v≈øed to this day in the churches of Greece. Edwin. Sands relation of Religion. cap. 53. or 54. And that hee him≈øelfe did v≈øually and daily offer this mo≈øte ≈øacred oblation of Chri≈øts body and blood, wee haue mo≈øte auncient and vndeniable te≈øtimonies, whether we will profe≈ø≈øe our ≈øelues Catholicks or prote≈øtants in Religion; for both the≈øe agree in this, that S. Andrew was martyred by Aegeus ProcoÃÑ≈øull of Achaia in the citie Patras: and they celebrate his day of fe≈øtiuitie, vppon the la≈øte of Nouember. And they doe, or ought if they make not fictions of theire owne, deduce the hi≈øtory of his pa≈ø≈øion from the auncient penners and relators thereof, which bee the prei≈øts and deacons of Achaia, which were eye witne≈ø≈øes and pre≈øent at the ≈øame. S. Cyprian, or who≈øoeuer was the auncient Author of the booke amonge his workes, de duplici
Martyrio. The old Anonimus who wrote the booke of the Apo≈øtles liues, publi≈øhed by the learned Bi≈øhop of Vienna Fredericus Nau≈øea, S. Simeon Metaphra≈øtes him≈øelf, a learned grecian and auncient of tho≈øe parts, S. Iuo, S. Bernard, Algerus, the auncient writer of the liues of Saints, the whole latine church in the publicke ≈øeruice of the fea≈øt of S. Andrew the Apo≈øtle, the auncient Breuiary of the church of Salisbury in England, and others are witne≈ø≈øes, that S. Andrew beeinge per≈øuaded and threatned by Aegeus the Procon≈øull, to ≈øacrifice to the Pagan Gods, an≈øwered publicklie vnto him in the≈øe wordes: Ego omnipotenti Deo, qui vnus & verus e≈øt, immolo quotidie, non taurorum carnes, nec hircorum ≈øanguinem, ≈øed immaculatum Agnum in altari: cuius carnem po≈øteaque omnis multitudo credentium manducauerit, Agnus qui ≈øacrificatus est, integer per≈øeuerat & viuus. I doe daily ≈øacricrifice to God almightie, the onely true God, not the fle≈øh of bulls, nor blood of goates, but the immaculate Lambe vppon the altar, who≈øe fle≈øh after all the multitude of beleeuers haue eaten, the Lambe that is ≈øacrificed, remayneth whole and liuinge.
Breuiar. & Mi≈ø≈øale Rom. Martyrolog. Rom. Bed. & V≈øuard. vlt. Nou. Prote≈øtant comm: Booke in calendar. Nouem. & infe≈øt. vlt. Nouem. Cooper v. Andreas Godw. conuer≈ø. Magdeb. cent. 1. in Andr. Apostolo. Act. S. Andrea per Presb. & Diacon. Achaiae. Ciprian. l. de duplic. Mart. Anonim. in mirac. vit. & Pa≈ø≈ø. Apost. in S. Andrea. Sim. Metaphr. in S. Andr. S. Iuo Carnoten. Epi≈øc. ≈øerm. de Sacram. dedicat. ≈øer. 4. Algerus contra Berengar. S. Bernard. apud Franci≈øc. Feuarden. annotat. in Frenaeum l. 4. contra haer. cap. 32. pag. 361. Iacob. Genuen. Epi≈ø in vit S. Andrea vlt. Nouem. Breu. Eccle≈øiae Salisbur. ibidem.

2. Thus it is euident that S. Andrewe the Apo≈øtle did offer this holy ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe, and euery day: and that the ≈øacrifice was Chri≈øt him≈øelf the true Lambe of God that taketh away ≈øinnes Amonge the holy auncient and renowned witne≈ø≈øes, S. Iuo ≈øupr. ≈øer. 4. ≈øpeakinge of this holy ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe thus wtiteth: In memoriam veniunt verba beati Andreae Apo≈øtoli, quibus a≈ø≈øerit & in caelis e≈ø≈øe corpus Domini, & de altari po≈øse ≈øumi corpus Domini. Cuius inquit carnes cum ≈øint come≈øtae in terris √† populo, ip≈øe tamen in caele≈øtibus ad dexteram Patris integer per≈øeuerat
& viuus. The wordes of S. Andrew the Apo≈øtle doe come to memory, in which hee affirmeth, that the body of our Lord is in heauen, and yet may his body bee receued from the altare. Who≈øe fle≈øh ≈øaith hee, when it is eaten of the people on earth, yet he per≈øeuereth whole and aliue in heauen, at the right hand of his Father. And this giueth full ≈øatisfaction for S. Andrew, that hee was a ≈øacrificinge and ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øt.

3. The next in order is S. Iames the brother of S. Iohn the Apo≈øtle, and Euangeli≈øt, martired by Kinge Herode as we reade in the 12. chapter of the Acts of the Apo≈øtles, where our prote≈øtants thus reade: About that time, Herod the Kinge stretched forth his hand to vexe certaine of the church. And he killed Iames the brother of Iohn with the sword. (Actor. cap. 12. ver. 1.2.) Which his timely death hath taken from him ≈øuch ample memory as is deliuered of ≈øome other Apo≈øtles that liued longer, in hi≈øtories. But beeing a≈ø≈øured before by all kinde of te≈øtimonies, that he was one of them to whom our ble≈ø≈øed Sauiour gaue power, and commaundement to offer the holy ≈øacrifice
of his body and blood, that he there being con≈øecrated a prei≈øt, and one of the three Apo≈øtles which our Sauiour mo≈øt loued, and hee him, it would be more then impietie to thinke, hee either neglected the power, or brake the commaundement of his Ma≈øter, whome he ≈øo much loued, and loued him againe; for ≈øo he ≈øhould not haue beene ≈øo principall a frend and louer of Chri≈øt, but his profe≈ø≈øed enemy, in continually violatinge his lawe, and commaundement. And being both brother to S. Iohn, and con≈øecrated and ordeyned prei≈øt at the ≈øame time, in the ≈øame maner, and order as hee was, how could S. Iohn be a ma≈ø≈øinge and ≈øacrificinge prei≈øt, ≈øo vndeniably as is proued of him, except S. Iames were al≈øo in the ≈øame degree?

4. Further it is proued that S. Iames liued ≈øometime before his death & was martired in Hieru≈øalem, where the publick ≈øacrifice of the Chri≈øtian church at that time was the holy Ma≈ø≈øe: for as Hieremias Patriarke of Con≈øtantinople proueth again≈øt the Prote≈øtants in his cen≈øure, and others. The holy Ma≈ø≈øe is a ≈øacrifice instituted of Christ. (Hierem. in cen≈øura. Concil. 6. Con≈øtantinop.)
in memory and commendation of all his mercy and humilitie ≈øustained for our ≈øoules. Saint Iames the Apo≈øtle, called our Lords brother, fir≈øt reduced into order that liturgie, and ≈øacrifice, beeinge ≈øo in≈øtructed of Chri≈øt to doe it, in all parts of that holy ≈øacrifice, nothing els is handled, but an vniuer≈øall order of thinges, which our Sauiour vndertooke for our redemption. Then this S. Iames al≈øo a cheife Apo≈øtle of the ≈øame Chri≈øt, con≈øecrated with the ≈øame ≈øolemnitie the other was, and liuinge and dyinge in the ≈øame place, a great Saint and Martyr as the oother was, could not po≈ø≈øibly differ from him in this point: nor from the re≈øt of the Apo≈øtles, all of them by all con≈øent before, agreeinge in the≈øe mi≈øteries. And it is an hi≈øtoricall approued veritie, by all antiquities, that the≈øe few di≈øciples which this S. Iames conuerted in Spaine, and brought with him to Hieru≈øalem, were directed and ≈øent thither againe by S. Peter the Apo≈øtle, that great ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øt (as hereafter) and they were ≈øuch as he that ≈øent them in that re≈øpect.

5. S. Thomas followeth next in Apo≈øtolick order, how hee was a ≈øacrificinge
and ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øt I haue ≈øhewed before in S. Iohn. And this holy Apo≈øtle preachinge in India, altares and diuers other pregnant arguments of his ≈øaying Ma≈ø≈øe in tho≈øe parts are found amonge them there. Christiani qui Indias frequentarunt, quas olim diui Thomae praedicatio peragrauit, altaria Christiana cum reliquijs quibu≈ødam Imaginis Virginis in ≈øpeluncis inuenerunt. Florimund. Raem. de origine Haer. l. 8. cap. 12. And Franci≈øcus Aluares. (de reb. Ind.) that liued longe in tho≈øe parts, writeth, that their Annals te≈øtifie, they had a church built in their contry within ten yeares of Chri≈øts A≈øcen≈øion, which church there ≈øtill remayneth, and beareth the name, as euer it did, the church of our Lady of Mount Sion, and the rea≈øon why it is ≈øo called, is becau≈øe the ≈øtone where of the altar was builded, was brought thither from Mount Sion. The ≈øame is proued by others, and prote≈øtants them≈øelues, further declaringe the maner of their ≈øaying Ma≈ø≈øe, ≈øtill continued with great reuerence, and deuotion; teachinge how they neuer ≈øay Ma≈ø≈øe without incen≈øe, and three cleargie men, a prei≈øt, deacon, and ≈øubdeacon, and they deriue their Religion
from S. Thomas the Apo≈øtle. An other, an Engli≈øh Prote≈øtant mini≈øter from experienced trauailers, and antiquitie writeth: est Capella Indorum: there is a Chappell of the≈øe Indians conuerted by S. Thomas in Mount Caluary at Hieru≈øalem, where onely the pilgrims of India, by theire preists ≈øinge Ma≈ø≈øe, after their order con≈øecrating and makinge, conficientes, the Sacrament of the body and blood of Christ, of bread and wine. They behaue them≈øelues with greate≈øt attention, reuerence, humilitie, and deuotion. Therfore wee cannot doubt but S. Thomas taught, and practi≈øed the≈øe mi≈øteries, both there, and where≈øoeuer hee liued and preached. Edw. Grim. booke of e≈øtates pag. 1088.1089.201.203. Sebast. Munster. l. 6. cap. 57. vide multos apud Gul. Ei≈øengr. centen. 1. fol. 168. Rich. Hackluits booke of trauailes in mount Sinay. Sir Iohn Mandeuil pag. 36. cap. 14.

6. Concerning S. Iames commonly called S. Iames the le≈ø≈øe, and brother of our Lord, who≈øe place is ordinarily numbred next, I haue ≈øpoken before, how, and by Chri≈øts appointment, as the greeke writers ≈øay, hee compo≈øed a forme of Ma≈ø≈øe, and deliuered it to the churches, where hee liued,
and ≈øo mu≈øt needs bee a profe≈ø≈øor and practi≈øer of that, which he taught to others; and con≈øequently con≈øecrated ma≈ø≈øing and ≈øacrificinge prei≈øts, to performe the ≈øame. His Ma≈ø≈øe approued of in the ≈øixt generall councell held at Con≈øtantinople, as our prote≈øtants allow, is ≈øtil extant, and known to all learned men, in all things of ≈øub≈øtance agreeing with the v≈øuall pre≈øent mi≈ø≈øale of the Roman churche. Cen≈øura Oriental. Hieremias Patriarch Con≈øtantinapol. ib. cap. 10. Proclus S. Nichol. Methon. & Be≈ø≈øarion apud Gul. Ei≈øengr. cent. 1. fol. 186. Concil. general. 6. can. 52. can. Apost. 3. Mi≈ø≈øa 5. Iacobi in Biblioth. Patr. & al. Morton apol. part. 2. pag. 8.

7. Now followeth S. Philip, which followed the ≈øame opinion, and practi≈øe of the holy ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe: for wee doe not onlie often reade in generall, that hee founded churches, and con≈øecrated Bi≈øhops, prei≈øts, deacons and other inferior cleargie men, which none but they which hold a ≈øacrificinge prei≈øthood, and ≈øacrifice of Chri≈øts body and blood in holy Ma≈ø≈øe, allowe: But S. Simeon Metaphra≈øtes liuinge where S. Philip preached, with others te≈øtifieth
in particular: Sacerdotes & altaria vbique in illis locis statuit & construxit, pro ≈øacrificijs illis quae fiebant in daemonum altaribus, ≈øacro≈øancti fecit in eis peragi ≈øacram mi≈øterij celebrationem. Hee appointed prei≈øtes and builded altars, euery where in tho≈øe places, and for tho≈øe ≈øacrifices which were v≈øed to bee offered vppon the altars of deuils, hee cau≈øed the holy celebration of the ≈øacred mi≈øtery to bee perfected. Anonimus. ≈øupr. l. in Pa≈ø≈ø. Apostol. in S. Philippo Gul. Ei≈øengr. centur. 1. fol. 157.158. & alibi. Simeon Metaph. in S. Philippo Apostolo Sur. die 1. Maij. And the prote≈øtant Seba≈øtian Mun≈øter with others teacheth, how the Abi≈ø≈øines te≈øtifie from their Apo≈øtolick antiquities, and con≈øtitutions of the Apo≈øtles them≈øelues, pre≈øerued by continuall tradition with them, that amonge other mi≈øteries of Chri≈øtian Religion deliuered by them, this of the holy ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe, and Chri≈øts ≈øacred body and blood offered therin, was one, and that S. Philip the Apo≈øtle was principally theire Apo≈øtle, and preached the≈øe things to them. A≈ø≈øerunt imprimis Philippum Apo≈øtolum apud eos praedica≈ø≈øe Euangelium. Seba≈øtian. Munst. Co≈ømograph.
l. 6. cap. 56.

8. Touchinge S. Bartholomew, we read that hee preached in India, where that knowne ma≈ø≈øinge Apo≈øtle taught, and left that holy ≈øacrifice, ≈øo that two Apo≈øtles if they had not beene confirmed in grace, & free from error (as all agree they were) no Chri≈øtian will thinke they could preache and practi≈øe contrary doctrines, in ≈øo great mi≈øteries, to, and in one people, place, and time, and wee further reade, that S. Bartholomew coÃÑ≈øecrated many prei≈øts, which (as before) mu≈øt needs be ≈øacrificing ma≈ø≈øing prei≈øts. And he made Kinge Polimius a ma≈ø≈øinge Bi≈øhop, and maker of ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øts, continuinge ≈øo 20. yeares, be≈øides others. Breuiar. Rom. in fest. S. Bartholom. Abd. cert. Apo≈øtol. l. 8. Antonin. part. 1. titul. 6. Petr. de natal. l. 7. cap. 103. Martyr ‚Ä¢
log. Rom. die 24. Aug. Dion. Areopag. l. mi≈øtic. Theolog. Eu≈øeb. l. 5. hist. c. 10. Origen. in Gen. Hieron. l. de ≈øcript: in pauten.

9. S. Simon and Iude could not bee of any other profe≈ø≈øion opinion or practi≈øe in this point, beeing both with the re≈øt of the Apo≈øtles con≈øecrated ≈øacrificinge prei≈øts, and S. Simon ≈øo zelous a louer of Chri≈øt,
as our prote≈øtants write, that hee thereby was named Zelotes, by a kinde of excellency, and S, Iude as he him≈øelfe is witnes, in his epi≈øtle, was frater Iacobi, brother to S. Iames, that notorious ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øt, and Apo≈øtle as is before declared: and S. Simon is generally taught, to haue conuer≈øed mo≈øt in tho≈øe contries, where S. Marke that ma≈ø≈øinge Euangeli≈øt practi≈øed, and plaÃÑted that doctrine. And S. Iude fir≈øt preached in Iury diuers yeares, where his ma≈ø≈øing Brother S. Iames was ≈øo renowned for writinge the forme of this holy ≈øacrifice, and both practi≈øing it him≈øelfe, and deliueringe it to others. And they con≈øecrated Abdias Bi≈øhop of Babilon, who by his owne, and all te≈øtimonies, was a ma≈ø≈øinge and ≈øacrificinge prei≈øt, and Bi≈øhop, who could make and con≈øecrate no others but ≈øuch as hee was, and had authoritie to doe. Socrat. l. 1. cap. 15. Niceph. hist. l. 4. c. 32. Fortunat. Godwin. Conuer≈ø. of Britanie. Iud. Epi≈øc. c. 1. v. 1. Martyrolog. Rom. die 28. Octob. Bed. & V≈øuard. ib. Stowe histor. Godwin. Conu. of Brit. Nicephor. l. 2. cap. 4. Ado Treuer. & Bed. 5. cal. Nouemb. Nicephor. lib. 2. cap. 40. Guliel. Ei≈øengr. centen. 1. part. 5. di≈øt.
7. fol. 168. Abd. certam. Apost. l. 4. Antonin. part. 1. Petr. de natal. l. 9. cap. 115. Abdias l. de certam. Apost. l. 6. Iul. African, praefat. histor. Apostol. Anonym. in S. Bartholom.

10. S. Matthias beeing cho≈øen into the place of Iudas the traitor, by the other Apo≈øtles, could bee of no other iudgement, and Religion herein, then they were. And the places hee preached in, giue te≈øtimony vnto this: for whether wee will ≈øay with Sophronius, Dorothus, and Nicephorus, that hee preached in Aethiopia, wee haue heard that ma≈ø≈øinge Apo≈øtles and prei≈øts preached there: or with our auncient Martyrologes, that hee was martired in Iury, S. Iames and the other Apo≈øtles before haue proued hee mu≈øt needs hee a ma≈ø≈øinge and ≈øacrificinge prei≈øt, and execute that holy function, liuing and dying there. Sophron. apud Hier. l. de ≈øcrip. Eccle≈ø. Doroth. in Synop≈ø. Nicephor. l. 2. c. 40. Martyrolog. Rom. 24. Febr. Bed. Ado. & V≈øuard. ib. I≈øidor. l. de vit. & obit. Sanct. cap. 81.

11. To conclude with S. Barnabas, extraordinarily called to bee an Apo≈øtle, as S. Paul, hee is commonly taken to bee the fir≈øt compo≈øer of the Ma≈ø≈øe of Milane, in
Italy, named S. Ambro≈øe his Ma≈ø≈øe, in re≈øpect of certaine additions of his vnto it, & v≈øed with great priuiledge in that church, to this day, not differinge in any materiall point from the pre≈øent order of ≈øaying Ma≈ø≈øe v≈øed in the re≈øt of the Romane Latine, or Greeke church at this time, or wher≈øoeuer. Traditio Eccl. Mediolanen. in Ital. Iodoc. Cocc. l. 6. To. 2. articul. 9. lib. 7. artic. 5. And this Ma≈ø≈øe was, as our prote≈øtants them≈øelues acknowledge, in ≈øuch v≈øe and credit in the Latine church, that it was more v≈øuall then that called S. Gregories Ma≈ø≈øe, vntill the time of Pope Adrian the fir≈øt about the yeare of Chri≈øt 780. Their words bee the≈øe. (Io. Balaeus in act. Roman. Pont. lib. 3 in Hadrian. 1.) Mi≈ø≈øarum ritus √† magno Gregorio editus, occidentalibus Eccle≈øijs imperauit. Pope Adrian commauÃÑded the order of the Ma≈ø≈øe publi≈øhed by Gregory the greate, to bee v≈øed of the we≈øt churches, till which time S. Barnabas and S. Ambro≈øe Ma≈ø≈øe ≈øtill v≈øed at Millane were more v≈øuall, as an other thus writeth. (Foxe Tom. 1. act. and Monum. pag. 130) Pope Adrian the first ratified and confirmed the order of Saint Gregories Ma≈øse, aboue the order of S. Ambro≈øe Ma≈ø≈øe,
for vnto this time, which was about the yeare of our Lord 780. the Liturgie of S. Ambro≈øe was more v≈øed in the Italian churches. Therefore there is no difficultie but S. Barnabas as the re≈øt of the Apo≈øtles, was al≈øo a ≈øacrificinge ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øt.

div.head: THE XI. CHAPTER. How S. Peter the cheife Apostle, and fir≈øt founder of the church of Christ in this our kingedome, was a ≈øacrificinge, ma≈øsinge prei≈øt, deliuered a forme of Ma≈ø≈øe to the church, con≈øecrated many ma≈øsinge prei≈øts in this part of the world nere vnto vs, and ≈øome of this kingdome.
div.p:
NOw la≈øtely to come to S. Peter, the prime and cheife of the Apo≈øtles, hee could not bee at difference with the re≈øt in this, but mu≈øt needs bee a ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øt as they were, and ≈øo for this purpo≈øe is it little, materiall whether this contry receaued the faith from him, or any other of the Apo≈øtles. But becau≈øe both Catholicks, and prote≈øtants agree. (Gul. Cambden in Britan. Theatr. of great Brit. l. 6. controuer≈ø. hi≈øtor.
To. 1. in S. Petro.) that both Greeke and Latine antiquities giue that vnto him, as is lately proued at large, hee mu≈øt al≈øo bee the fir≈øt in≈øtitutor of our eccle≈øia≈øticall Hierarchie, in con≈øecratinge vnto vs, diuers holy Bi≈øhops, and prei≈øts, which that is deliuered already, proueth to haue beene ma≈ø≈øing Bi≈øhops, and prei≈øts, and by tho≈øe ≈øacrificinge Bi≈øhops, and his ≈øacrificinge ≈øucce≈ø≈øors, our prei≈øts and Bi≈øhops were euer ≈øacred ma≈ø≈øinge Bi≈øhops, and prei≈øts vnto the≈øe daies, of innouation, as will manife≈øtlie appeare in all ages, herafter by this treati≈øe. For, be≈øides that, which is ≈øaid before, how all the Apo≈øtles were ma≈ø≈øing and ≈øacrificing prei≈øts, and all the other Apo≈øtles and Euangeli≈øts be≈øides S. Peter, wee haue of him in particular, more and mo≈øte credible witne≈ø≈øes, then are needfull to be alleadged. S. I≈øidor ≈øaith. Ordo Mi≈ø≈øae vel orationum, quibus oblata Deo ≈øacrificia con≈øecrantur, primum √† S. Petro e≈øt in≈øtitutus, cuius celebrationem vno eodemque modo vniuer≈øus peragit orbis. The order of Ma≈ø≈øe; or of the praiers by which the ≈øacrifices offered vnto God are con≈øecrated, was fir≈øt in≈øtituted by S. Peter, who≈øe celebration the whole world
ob≈øerueth in one, and the ≈øame maner. I≈øodor. l. 1. de officijs cap. 15. de Mi≈ø≈øa & orationibus.

2. Our holy auncient learned contriman, S. Albinus, or Alcuinus by others, purpo≈øely entreatinge of this mo≈øt ble≈ø≈øed ≈øacrifice, and the ceremonies thereof, thus writeth: Celebratio Mi≈øsae in commemorationem Pa≈øsionis Christi peragitur, ≈øic enim ip≈øe praecepit Apostolis, tradens eis corpus & ≈øanguinem ≈øuum, dicens hoc facite in meam commemorationem, hoc e≈øt in memorian Pa≈øsiones mea. Tanquam diceret, quod pro ve≈øtro ≈øalute pa≈ø≈øus ≈øum, ad memoriam reuocate. Hanc Petrus Apostolus primus omnium Antiochiae dicitur celebra≈ø≈øe. The celebration of Ma≈ø≈øe is done in commemoration of the Pa≈ø≈øion of Chri≈øt, for ≈øo hee gaue commaundement vnto his Apo≈øtles, when he deliuered vnto them his body and blood, ≈øaying doe this in commemoration, which is in memory of my pa≈ø≈øion: as though hee had ≈øaid, recall vnto memory that I ≈øuffered for your ≈øaluation. This Ma≈ø≈øe S. Peter the Apo≈øtle is ≈øaid fir≈øt to haue celebrated at Antioche. Albinus alij Alcuinus l. diuin. offic. cap. de celebrat. Mi≈ø≈øae.

3. Egbertus writinge how the court of the Kinge, Regalis aula, at Antioch was in the time of S. Peters beeinge there made a Chri≈øtian church, amonge other holy functions S. Peter exerci≈øed in it, hee ≈øaith hee ordinarily ≈øaid Ma≈ø≈øe, in qua communiter populum docuit, & Mi≈øsas celebrauit. (Egbert. Abb. ≈øerm. de incremento & manifestat. Cathol. fide.) And againe. (≈øerm. 10.) Sacerdotalem ordinem nos accepimus √† Romana Eccle≈øia, Romana autem Eccle≈øia, ab Apo≈øtolo Petro, Petrus √† Chri≈øto, Chri≈øtus √† Deo Patre, qui vnxit eum oleo laetitiae, hoc e≈øt Spiritu Sancto prae participibus ≈øuii, & iurauit dicens ad cum, tu es Sacerdos in aeternum, ≈øecundum ordinem Melchi≈øedeih. Verus Sacerdos erat Dominus no≈øter Ie≈øus Chri≈øtus. Ip≈øe inui≈øibiliter dedit corpus & ≈øanguinem ≈øuum, quando coram di≈øcipulis panem & vinum in cana benedixit benedictione calesti; & fecit ≈øua admirabili potestate vt ≈øub ≈øpecie eiu≈ødem panis, & vini ≈øumerent de manibus ip≈øius corpus & ≈øanguinem eius. Ip≈øe quoque ≈øicut pollicitus est, cum Eccle≈øia ≈øua est, v≈øque ad con≈øummationem ≈øaeculi, & quotidie inui≈øibiliter offers per manus Eccle≈øiae Deo Patri pro ≈øalute mundi, corpus & ≈øanguinem ≈øuum ≈øub ≈øpecie panis &
vini. Propterea dictus est Sacerdos ≈øecundum ordinem Melchi≈øedech, qui erat Rex Salem, & Sacerdos Dei ≈øummi, & oblationem fecit Deo ex pane & vino. Dominus Ie≈øus Christus di≈øcipulos ≈øuos fecit veros Sacerdotes. Dedit eis pote≈øtatem conficiendi corpus & ≈øanguinem ≈øuum ≈øub ≈øpecie panis & vini, quando dixit ad eos. (Luc. 22.) hoc est corpus meum quod pro vobis tradetur; Hoc facite in meam commemorationem. Omnem denique potestatem quae ad Sacerdotij officium, & ad epi≈øcopalem dignitatem ≈øpectat, ab illo acceperunt. Eandem autem pote≈øtatem ≈øinguli ≈øucce≈ø≈øoribus relinquerunt, in illis terris, & in illis Eccle≈øijs, quas eis Dominus conuertendas, & gubernandas delegauit. Et vt nunc de reliquis taceam, Beatus Petrus princeps Apostolorum in Romana vrbe, presbyteros, & Epi≈øcopos ordinauit, & omnem pote≈øtatem quae ad officia eorum pertinebat, eis dedit, ≈øicut ip≈øe √† Domino Ie≈øu Christo acceperat.

4. We haue receued prei≈øtly order from the church of Rome, and the church of Rome receaued it from the Apo≈øtle Peter, Peter receaued it from Chri≈øt, Chri≈øt receaued it from God his Father, who anointed him with oyle of gladnes, that is with
the holy gho≈øt aboue his partakers, and ≈øwore, ≈øaying vnto him. (p≈øal. 10.) thou art a prei≈øt for euer, after the order of Melchi≈øedech. Our Lord Ie≈øus Chri≈øt was a true prei≈øt. Hee did inui≈øibly giue his body and blood, when before his di≈øciples at his ≈øupper hee ble≈ø≈øed breade and wine, and made by his admirable power that vnder the ≈øpecies of the ≈øame bread & wine, they ≈øhould receaue from his hands, his body and blood. Hee al≈øo, as hee hath promi≈øed, is with his church vnto the ende of the world, and doth daily inui≈øibly offer by the hands of the church, to Go ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶
‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ he Father for the ≈øaluation of the worlde, his body and blood vnder the forme of bread and wine. Therfore hee is called a prei≈øt after the order of Melchi≈øedech, who was Kinge of Salem, and prei≈øt of the high God, and made offeringe vnto God of breade and wine. Our Lord Ie≈øus Chri≈øt made his di≈øciples prei≈øtes. Hee gaue them power to make his bodie and blood vnder the forme of breade, and wine, when hee ≈øaid vnto them. (Luc. 22.) this is my body, which ≈øhall bee giuen for you: doe this in my commemoration. Finally they receaued from him all power,
which beloÃÑgeth to the office of prei≈øthood, and epi≈øcopall dignitie. And euery one of them, left the ≈øame power to their ≈øucce≈ø≈øors, in tho≈øe contries, and in tho≈øe churches, which our Lord commended to them to conuert and gouerne. And at this time to bee ≈øilent of the re≈øt, S. Peter cheife of the Apo≈øtles in the city of Rome ordeyned prei≈øts, and deacons, and gaue them all power which apperteined to their offices, as hee him≈øelfe had receaued from our Lord Ie≈øus Chri≈øt.

5. And thus from S. Peter deduceth a continuall ≈øucce≈ø≈øion of ≈øacrificinge ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øts, and Bi≈øhops in all this We≈øt part of the world; And amonge others teacheth how particularly this our kingdome of England had our ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øts, and Bi≈øhops by that deduction from S. Peter, and his ≈øucce≈ø≈øors in the Apo≈øtolicke ≈øee of Rome. Stephanus Edueri≈øts. (l. de Sacramento Altaris.) a learned Bi≈øhop many hundred yeares ≈øince, ≈øaith: ≈øicut Magi≈øter docuerat, Apostoli ≈øe & alios communicando con≈øecrationem corporis & ≈øanguinis Domini facere caeperunt, & fieri per vniuer≈øas Eccle≈øias praedicando instituerunt. As Chri≈øt theire
mai≈øter had taught, ≈øo the Apo≈øtles communicatinge them≈øelues, and others, began to make the con≈øecration of the body and blood of Chri≈øt, and by preachinge in≈øtituted it to bee done through all churches: and ≈øheweth how the canon of the Ma≈ø≈øe was v≈øed by S. Peter, & the re≈øt from the beginninge. Primo ficbat canonis mysterium. Before any thinge was added by the Popes of Rome. And Pa≈øcha≈øius Rathertus plainely ≈øaith, it was the common opinion in his time, that S. Peter was the Author of the canon of Ma≈ø≈øe: re≈øpice in Sacramentorum celebratione, instituente beato Petro, vt credimus, quid orat Sacerdos in canone. And then hee addeth particularly, that by S. Peters in≈øtitution, the prei≈øt praieth, v ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ fiat corpus & ≈øanguis dilecti≈øsimi filij tui Domini no≈øtri Ie≈øu Christi: That it may bee made the body, and blood of thy mo≈øte beloued ≈øonne, our Lord Ie≈øus Chri≈øt. Pa≈øcha≈øius Ratbert. l. de corpore & ≈øanguine Christi.

6. I reade in an auncient Anonymus Manu≈øcript hi≈øtory of this kingdome. (M. S. hist. incipit in principio creauit Deus. cap nomina ≈øummorum Pontificum.) post Pa≈øsionem Chri≈øti anno ≈øequenti beatus Petrus Apostolus
tenuit cathedram ≈øacerdotalem in partibus orientis annis quatuor, vbi primam Mi≈ø≈øam celebrauit. Deinde venit Antiochiam, vbi cathedram adeptus, ≈øedit annis ≈øeptem, inde venit Roneam. The next yeare after the Pa≈ø≈øion of Chri≈øt, S. Peter the Apo≈øtle held his prei≈øtly chaire in the parts of the ea≈øt foure yeares, where hee fir≈øt celebrated Ma≈ø≈øe. From thence hee came to Antioch, where obteyning the chaire, hee ≈øat ≈øeuen yeares, from thence hee came to Rome. The auncient Engli≈øh hi≈øtory, commonly called Caxtons hi≈øtory, becau≈øe printed by him, thus te≈øtifieth: Peter the first Pope was able≈ø≈øed man, and glorious Apostle of Chri≈øt, hee was head of the church (after S. Hierome) 37. yeares, and he held his Bishoprick in the easte fiue yeares, and hee ≈øaid Ma≈ø≈øe. hee made our Lords body, then after hee came to Antioch. old English hi≈øtor. published by Caxton. part. 4. an. D. 34.

7. Martianus Polonus hath the ≈øame words, with our Manu≈øcript hi≈øtory before cited. Walfridus Strabo 800. yeares ≈øince writeth, how the Romans receaued the v≈øe and ob≈øeruations of their Ma≈øse (common to the we≈øtern world) from S. Peter the cheifest
of the Apo≈øtles. Martin. Polon. in ≈øupputat. tempor. col. 27. in S. Petro. Walafrid. Strab. l. de ob≈øeruat. cap. 22. The like hath S Clement ≈øcholler and ≈øucce≈ø≈øor to S. Peter, Come≈øtor, Ioannes Belethus, Pope Innocentius the third, Polychronicon, Ioannes Cantabrigien≈øis, Petrus de natalibus, He≈øichius, Nicholaus Caba≈øilla, Germanus S. Beda, S. Hierome, Theonas, Ca≈ø≈øianus. S. Anacletus, who was made prei≈øt by S. Peter, as hee him≈øelfe witne≈ø≈øeth, S. Epiphanius, Ionas Aurelien≈øis, our learned coÃÑ tryman, with diuers others, cited by Ei≈øengrenius and others. And to take the warrant of Prote≈øtants with vs, for this veritie: fir≈øt wee haue the te≈øtimony of the Magdeburgians from Martinus Polonus, and others, in quibu≈ødam chronicis vt Martini & aliorum, not onely that S. Peter ≈øaid Ma≈ø≈øe, but in ≈øome ≈øort the order thereof. Our fir≈øt Engli≈øh Prote≈øtant Archbi≈øhop of Canterbury expre≈ø≈øely acknowledgeth, that S. Peter ≈øaid Ma≈ø≈øe both in the easte, Mi≈ø≈øam dictaÃÑ √† Petro in orientalibus regionibus, and after hee came into the we≈øt al≈øo, and that, illius traditio √† Christi primo instituto ducentis amplius annis in prima Eccle≈øia durauit. The order
of Ma≈ø≈øe which S. Peter v≈øed & taught, continued in the primatiue church aboue 200. yeares from the in≈øtitution of Chri≈øt vntill the time of Pope Zepherine. Clem. Rom. l. 10. Recognit. histor. ≈øchola≈øt. cap. 7. in act. Apostol. Io. Belethus l. de offic. diuin. cap. 124. Innocent. 3. Praefat. l. 1. Polychronic. l. 4. cap. 6. Ioannis Cantabrigien. in pupill. oculi. c. 8. Petrus de natalib. l. 4. cap. 108. He≈øichius Hiero≈øol. in act. cap. 20. & cap. 23. Leuit. l. 6. Nichol. Caba≈øs. c. 28. de Mi≈ø≈ø. Germ. Con≈øtantinp. in can. Mi≈ø≈ø. Anaclet. epi≈øt. 2. & al. apud Ei≈øengren. centen. 1. fol. 116.117. Magdeburg. ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ ent. 1. l. 2. cap. 6. col. 500. Math. Parker. antiquit. Britannie. pag. 47. cap. 17.

8. And this Pope by this great prote≈øtants confe≈ø≈øion, was ≈øo far from chaunginge any e≈ø≈øentiall thinge therin, to make it wor≈øe, that to in≈øi≈øt in his wordes: donec eam Zepherinus 16. Romanus Pontifex quorundam ≈øua≈øionibus ad pulchriorem materiam formamque mutare voluit: vntill Zepherine the ≈øixteenth Pope of Rome by the per≈øua≈øions of ≈øome would chaunge that Ma≈ø≈øe to a more excellent matter and forme. And to put vs out of doubt that Pope and S. Zepherine did make no chaunge or alteration
of this S. Peters Ma≈ø≈øe, now after two hundred yeares, in prote≈øtants iudgement, but that which rather honored, then in any re≈øpect di≈øgraced this holy ≈øacrifice, all the chaunge which this Prote≈øtant Archbi≈øhop findeth made herin by this holy Pope, is this, by his owne te≈øtimony, that where before woddeÃÑ challices were v≈øed in ≈øome places, in tho≈øe times of per≈øecution and nece≈ø≈øitie, this Pope (to v≈øe this prote≈øtants words the 16. Pope of Rome) constituted that Ma≈ø≈øes should bee celebrated with patens of gla≈ø≈øe. Zepherinus 16. Romanus Epi≈øcopus, patents vitreis Mi≈ø≈øas celebrari constituit. (Matth. Parker ≈øupr. cap. 18. pag. 47.) Which an other Engli≈øh Prote≈øtant purpo≈øely entreating of ≈øuch thinges, thus expre≈ø≈øeth: ≈øanguinis Christi con≈øecrationem in vit ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ eo calice, non ligneo, vt antea, fieri debere statuit. Pope Zepherine con≈øtituted, that the con≈øecration of the blood of Chri≈øt ≈øhould bee made in a chalice of gla≈ø≈øe, & not of wood, as before was v≈øed. Robertus Barns in vita Pontific. Roman. in Seuer. alij Zepherin. And further: Cum Epi≈øcopus celebraret Mi≈ø≈øae ≈øacra, iu≈øsit omnes presbyteros ade≈ø≈øe. Hee commaunded that all the prei≈øts ≈øhould be pre≈øent,
when the Bi≈øhop celebrated the ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe.

9. This is all S. Zepherine altered in this Ma≈ø≈øe of S. Peter, by the≈øe prote≈øtants own graunt: Therefore it is ≈øufficiently agreed vpon both by Catholicks and the be≈øt learned prote≈øtants, that according to the common opinion in that re≈øpect, S. Peter did not onely and v≈øually ≈øay Ma≈ø≈øe, beeinge a ma≈ø≈øing and ≈øacrificing prei≈øt, by his prei≈øtlie con≈øecration, but as the great Apo≈øtle of Chri≈øt compo≈øed an order, or forme of ≈øaying Ma≈ø≈øe, and deliuered it to the church to practi≈øe, and it was ≈øo accordingly receaued, and practi≈øed with the be≈øt learned & mo≈øt holy men, the glorious lights of Gods hou≈øe, in that primatiue and freely confe≈ø≈øed vn≈øpotted dayes of Chri≈øtianitie. What this holy order was, and how it did not differ in any ≈øub≈øtantiall or e≈ø≈øentiall matter from that Ma≈ø≈øe which the pre≈øent Roman church now v≈øeth, I ≈øhall ≈øufficiently proue, with the good leaue, and likinge, both of Catholicke, & learned prote≈øtant authors, hereafter.

10. In the meane time, to make that which is already ≈øaid vnque≈øtionable, S.
Peter euer left in the renowned places where hee liued, this holy doctrine, and practi≈øe of ≈øaying Ma≈ø≈øe. And whether ≈øoeuer he ≈øent any Apo≈øtolick men to preach the gho≈øpell, this was a principall charge, & power bequeathed vnto them. For Hieru≈øalem where S. Peter fir≈øt preached I haue ≈øpoken ≈øufficiently in S. Iames before, ≈øo for S. Marke at Alexandria, & the African parts. For Antioch al≈øo I haue written what might ≈øuffice, yet will I add ≈øomewhat of the glorious ≈øucce≈ø≈øor of S. Peter there, S. Ignatius, whome S. Chri≈øo≈øtome the great ornament of that very church S. Felix, and Theodoret doe allowe mee to call, the immediate ≈øub≈øtitute or ≈øucce≈ø≈øor of S. Peter there, and that by S. Peter hee was con≈øecrated Bishop, dextera beati Petri fui≈ø≈øe ordinatum Epi≈øcopum Eccle≈øiae Antiochenae, and, per magni Petri dexteram Pontificatum ≈øu≈øcepit. Though I doe not deny, but as S. Clement did to S. Linus, and Cletus at Rome, ≈øo S. Ignatius might and did giue place to Saint Euodius at Antioche. Whome great Authors therefore name S. Peters fir≈øt ≈øucce≈ø≈øor there. (S. Io. Chri≈øo≈øtom. orat. de tran≈ølat. corp. S. Ignatij Antioch. Felix. Rom. Pont.
epist. ad Zenon. Imper. in S. Synod. Con≈øt. act. 1. Theodoret. dialog. 1. Immutab. Eu≈øeb. chr. & hist. l. 3. c. 16. Hieron. l. de ≈øcriptor. in Ignat. Ignat. epi≈øt. ad Antioch.

11. This holy Saint and learned Father con≈øecrated by S. Peter, was ≈øo farr a ma≈ø≈øing prei≈øt, and earne≈øt practi≈øer and patron of this holy ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe, wherein Chri≈øts ≈øacred body and blood ar offered, that as not onely Theodoret and al Catholicks with him teach, but as the grand prote≈øtants Beza, Peter Martyr, Scultetus, Whitaker, and others as enforced doe graunt, that S. Ignatius did condemne Simon and Menander for hereticks, becau≈øe according to theire knowne here≈øie again≈øt Chri≈øts true humanitie, they did reiect the ≈øacrifice of his body and blood in the ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe: (Theodoret. Dial. 3. Beza Dial. Cyclops. Peter Mart. loc. 12. Mi≈ø≈øae. Scutlet. part. 1. Medull. patr, l. 1. Whitaker contra Camp. & al.) They doe not receaue (≈øaith S. Ignatius) Euchari≈øt and ≈øacrifice, becau≈øe they doe not confe≈øse the Eucharist to bee the body of our Sauiour Ie≈øus Christ, which ≈øuffered for our ≈øinnes, which his Father by his bountie rai≈øed againe. 12. The prote≈øtants of Magdeburg. (cent. 2. col. 113. cap. 6.) acknowledge (which no man can deny) in epistolis Ignatij vt hodie extant vtrimque legitur & ≈øacrificium immolare, & Mi≈ø≈øas facere. Wee reade both to offer ≈øacrifice, and ≈øay Ma≈ø≈øes in the epi≈øtles of Ignatius, as they are extant at this day. And our Engli≈øh Prote≈øtants confe≈ø≈øe in the≈øe termes. (Sutcli≈ø≈øe ≈øubu. pag. 32.) Wee reade in Ignatius this phra≈øe, offerre, and, ≈øacrificium „Äà‚óä„Äâ , to offer, and, immolate ≈øacrifice. And not to in≈øi≈øt vpon the words of S. Ignatius (Ignatius epi≈øtol. ad Smirnen≈ø.) „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ which the olde tran≈ølation turneth,
‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ ≈ø≈øam facere, to ≈øay Ma≈ø≈øe, the other Greeke wordes of this holy Saint which the Magdeburgian prote≈øtants doe allowe for his (Magdeburg ≈øupr.) „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , and „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ do in all lexicons and Greeke Authors, properly ≈øignifie ≈øacrificinge, or offering ≈øacrifice; and yet as that holy Father witne≈ø≈øeth, this was in his time the act and office of Chri≈øtian prei≈øts. And
≈øaith: this prei≈øthood, is the toppe or cheife of all good things amonge men, and hee that rageth again≈øt it, doth not reproach maÃÑ, but God and Christ his onely begotten Sonne, who by nature is the highest preist of God his Father, and hee teacheth how an externall ≈øacrifice offered vppon an externall materiall altar, is a proper act of this holy prei≈øthood. (Ignat. epi≈øtol. ad Hieron. epi≈øtol. ad Ephe≈ø.) And that this ≈øacrifice in particular is, a medicine of immortality, a pre≈øeruatiue again≈øt death, and procuringe life in God. The bread of God, heauenly food, which is the flesh of Chri≈øt, and blood of Chri≈øt. Ignat. epi≈øt. ad Trallian. ad Ephe≈ø. & ad Roman.

13. And if wee attend S. Peter in his iorney from the ea≈øt to the≈øe we≈øtern parts, as Rome, & from thence to this kingdome of Britanie, wee ≈øhall ≈øtill finde antiquities, and monuments, though ≈øo many ar lo≈øte, that hee ≈øtill continued his holy function in ≈øayinge Ma≈ø≈øe, and neither there, nor here did or could con≈øecrate any but ≈øacrificinge ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øts. This holy Apo≈øtle cominge in his iorney to Rome to Pi≈øa a famous citie of Hetruria in Italy, vppon the Sea coa≈øte, with his di≈øciples, we finde
auncient euidence, that he there ≈øaid Ma≈ø≈øe, & in honor & memory of him a church was there builded, and after his death dedicated vnto him, yearely frequented with great re≈øorte of pilgrims. (Martin. Pere≈ø l. de diuinis & Apost. traditionib. part. 3. fol. 70.) and part of the very altar whereon hee ≈øaid Ma≈ø≈øe is there ≈øtill kept in the ≈øacrarie of that church, with an antiquitie in authenticall old characters, testifying the truth herof. Certa parte altaris vbi celebrauit in ≈øacrario templi maioris venerabiliter recondita, vna cum te≈øtimonio literis valde authenticis & vetustis, hinc rei fidem minim√® ≈øu≈øpectam facientibus. Al≈øo there is at Naples, as both Catholicks and prote≈øtants witnes, an old church, where S. Peter ≈øaid Ma≈ø≈øe, and the church thereuppon called: Ad diui Petri aram: At the altar of S. Peter. (Benedict. Fulco l. de locis antiq. Neopolitan. Lindan. Apolog. Iacob. Gualter. tabula chronographic. ≈øecult. 1. pag. 44.) at the entrance of the dore whereof, this in≈øcription ≈øtill remayneth to keepe it in remembrance.

q.l: O faithfull man ≈øtay, and before thou enter into the church, worship Peter ≈øacrificinge.

div.p:
14. For Rome wee haue ≈øtill the portable and remoueable altare whereon S. Peter and many of his ≈øucce≈ø≈øors there in per≈øecution ≈øaid Ma≈ø≈øe. (Antiquitat. Eccl. Lateran. Romae. Breuiar. Rom. die 9. Nouembr. in dedica. Ba≈øilic. Saluatoris.) wee haue all his ≈øucce≈ø≈øors holy Saints and Martyrs allmo≈øt 300. yeares by prote≈øtants confe≈ø≈øion, all of them ≈øacrificinge, and ma≈ø≈øing prei≈øtes, as ≈øhall bee manife≈øt in their times and places, and the foure fir≈øt of them S. Linus Cletus, Clement, and Anacletus, con≈øecrated and ordered ma≈ø≈øing and ≈øacrificing prei≈øts, by their holy Ma≈øter and predece≈ø≈øor S. Peter him≈øelfe, as both they them≈øelues and other auncient authors te≈øtifie. We are warranted by our prote≈øtants with others before, that the forme and order of the ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe which S. Peter compo≈øed, v≈øed, and deliuered to the church, was without any chaunge or alteration, continued in that church of Rome & the≈øe we≈øtern nations aboue 200. yeares: from whence it appeareth con≈øequently & plainlie by the≈øe prote≈øtante writers, that this
kingdome of Britanie receauing the faith from Rome in the Apo≈øtles times, and generally in the times of Pope Eleuthenus & Victor, who both were before S. Zepherine, in who≈øe dayes they ≈øuppo≈øe ≈øome addition to haue beene v≈øed in that Ma≈ø≈øe, inuincibly prou ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ th, that this kingdome with others did not onely admit Ma≈ø≈øe, and ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øts in the fir≈øt conuer≈øion thereof, but the very vnchaunged and vnaltered Ma≈ø≈øe of S. Peter him≈øelfe. We haue the Catalogues and hi≈øtories of the ≈øucce≈ø≈øions of Bi≈øhops in all renowned churches in this part of the world, which receaued theire fir≈øt Apo≈øtles and Bi≈øhops from S. Peter, that are pre≈øerued, te≈øtifyinge that the≈øe their fir≈øt Apo≈øtles, Prei≈øts, and Bi≈øhops ≈øent vnto them from S Peter, were ma≈ø≈øinge and ≈øacrificinge prei≈øts, and Bi≈øhops. If I could exemply but in halfe the number of them which were ≈øo ordered, and ≈øent by S. Peter into Italy, Spaine, Germanie, and Fraunce, I ≈øhould make to longe a digre≈ø≈øion from the que≈øtion of Britanie, which I cheifly handle, write a forreine hi≈øtorie, and entertaine my reader ouer much in ≈øuch affaires: therefore I will only
in≈øi≈øt in ≈øome few of the cheife≈øt, tho≈øe that came neare≈øt vnto vs, and with whom our Britans in al probable iudgement had mo≈øt intercour≈øe, commerce, or acquaintance.

15. I begin with S. Maximinus, and S. Lazarus whom Chri≈øt rai≈øed to life, ≈øeeing to the fir≈øt one of the 72. di≈øciples of Chri≈øt S. Peter commended S. Mary Magdalen, becau≈øe ≈øome prote≈øtants thinke S. Io≈øeph of Aramathia that buried Chri≈øt, and liued, died, and was buried with vs in Britanie, came into Fraunce with them. (Guliel. Ei≈øengren. centenar. 1. part. 5. di≈øt. 3. fol. 148. Theater. of great Britanie l. 6. That the fir≈øt ≈øaid Ma≈ø≈øe we are taught, becau≈øe we read, that hee did mini≈øter the holy Euchari≈øt, to S. Mary MagdaleÃÑ after Ma≈ø≈øe was ended. Quod morienti S. Magdalenae po≈øt Mi≈ø≈øarum ≈øolemnia Sacro≈øanctam Euchari≈øtiam admini≈øtra≈ø≈øe legimus. Anton. Democh. l. 2. de Ma≈ø≈ø. contra Caluin. Petrus de natal. l. 5. Antonin. part. 1. Volater. l. 7. Guliel. Ei≈øengr. cent. 1. fol. 148. pag. 2. This for Aqueus where he was Bi≈øhop. For S. Lazarus his beeing a ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øt, and his ≈øaying of Ma≈ø≈øe, at Mar≈ø≈øiles in Fraunce, where hee was Bi≈øhop, the holie vestiments in which hee ≈øaid Ma≈øse beeing
to this day pre≈øerued and to be ≈øeene in the cathedrall church there, ar ≈øufficient witnes. In Cathedrali Eccle≈øia, vestes in quibus Mi≈ø≈øam celebrabat, adhuc hodie con≈øcruantur & monstrantur. Demochar. l. 2. contr. Caluin. c. 32. Petr. de natal. l. 1. c. 72. Antonin. part. 1. tit. 6. cap. 19. Guliel. Ei≈øeng. centen. 1. fol. 149.

16. How famous S. Martial di≈øciple of S. Peter, and ≈øent into Fraunce by him, was in many parts of that nation ≈øo wel known to our Briti≈øh Druides in tho≈øe dayes, it is not vnknowne to any antiquarie of the≈øe contries: And as little ignorance can any man pretend, that hee was a ma≈ø≈øinge ≈øacrificinge prei≈øt, for ≈øo renowned hee was for this, that the infidels them≈øelues then knew it, amonge whome the cheife idolatrous prei≈øt or Druid of Limogen, as the french Annales tel vs, for≈øooke the towne by rea≈øon of an Hebrue called Martiall, who being come into Gaule, v≈øeth not wine, nor flesh, but when he offereth ≈øacrifice to God: ≈øi non que au ≈øacrifice de Dieu. Who buildinge a chappel there, celebrated Ma≈ø≈øe in it. Celebr√© le Sainct ≈øacrifice de la Me≈ø≈øe. S. Aurelian. in vet. S. Martialis. Doctor. Puel. D. Tigeon. Cl. March. Ro. Seigneur de Faux Augenin hi≈øtor.
Gallic. in S. Martial. Vincent. in ≈øpecul. hi≈øt. cap. 41. Io. Gualt. Chronolog. eccle≈øia≈øticopol. an. Do. 56. And in that citie ≈øtill remayneth the holy altar, on which hee v≈øed to ≈øay Ma≈ø≈øe whereof hee him≈øelfe maketh mention in his epi≈øtle, ad Burde galen≈øes, & for that cau≈øe ≈øo honored, that it is by publick edict of parlament examining and approuing the truth of that hi≈øtory, from auncient time, decreed, that ≈øeuen candels should continually bee kept burninge before it, the body of that their Apostle beeing buried neare vnto it. Florimund. Remund. de Origen. haere≈ø. l. 8. cap. 12. edict. inter log. parlam. Galliae de hac re. Annon videtis S. Martialem ad Burdegalen≈øes nostros ≈øcrip≈øi≈ø≈øe, ≈øe aram Deo I≈øraelis & martyri ip≈øius Stephano dedica≈øse? ea ara in ciuitate Lemogicum, vbi Apostolus ip≈øe Aquitaniae quie≈øcit, con≈øpicitur, aedificata √† Principe Stephano, quem ad Chri≈øtiani≈ømum ip≈øe conuerteret: ante eam noctes die≈øque ardent ≈øeptem candelae, iuxta antiquam istam fundationem, in parlamento nostro, & di≈øceptatam, & confirmatam.

17. And this holy Saint, and Apo≈øtle of Aquitaine, him≈øelfe teacheth, what great honor and reuerence is due to Chri≈øtian ≈øacrificing
prei≈øts, and what an excellent ≈øacrifice they offer of Chri≈øts ≈øacred body & blood in holy Ma≈ø≈øe: thus he writeth to his late conuerted Chri≈øtians. (S. Martial. Epi≈øc. ad Burdegale≈ø. cap. 3.) honorabatis Sacerdotes qui decipiebant vos ≈øacrificijs ≈øuis, qui mutis & ≈øurdis ≈øtatuis offerebant, qui nec ≈øe nec vos iuuare poterant: nunc autem mult√≤ magis Sacerdotes Die omnipotentis, qui vitam vobis tribuunt, in calice & pane vino, honorare debetis. Before you were conuerted to Chri≈øt, you did honour your prei≈øts, which deceaued you with their ≈øacrifices, which did ≈øacrifice to dumbe and deafe ≈øtatues, who could neither helpe them≈øelues, nor you. But now much more you ought to honour the prei≈øts of God almighty, which giue vnto you life in the chalice, and liuelie breade. And a little after, ≈øpeaking more plainely of this holy ≈øacrifice, offered vnto God, vppon the altar, hee ≈øaith: Sacrificium Deo Creatori offertur, in ara Chri≈øti corpus & ≈øinguinem in vitam aeternam offerrimus. Quod Iudaei per inuidiam immolauerunt, putantes ≈øo nomen cius √† terra abolere: nos cau≈øa ≈øalutis no≈øtrae, in ara ≈øanctificata proponimus, ≈øcientes hoc ≈øolo remedio nobis vitam prae≈øtandam, &
mortem effugandam: hoc enim Dominus no≈øter mi≈øit nos agere in ≈øui commemorationem. Sacrifice is offered to God, our Creator, vppon the altar. We offer the body and blood of Chri≈øt for euerla≈øting life. That which the Iewes did offer through enuy, thinking to aboli≈øh his name from the earth; wee offer this vppon an hallowed altare, knowinge that by this onely remedy, life is to be giuen vnto vs, and death to bee auoided. For this our Lord Ie≈øus commaunded vs to doe in his commemoration.

18. Thus this holy Saint, that ≈øtilleth him≈øelfe. The Apo≈øtle of Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, who as hee ≈øaith was pre≈øent with Chri≈øt in his life, when hee was buried, and ≈øee him after his re≈øurrection. (Martial. epist. ad Burdegal. epestol. ad Tholo≈øanos.) was one of his 72. di≈øciples, & was by ≈øpeciall commaund of Chri≈øt vnto S. Peter, who≈øe di≈øciple hee after was, ≈øent by him to bee the happy Apo≈øtle of that contrie. And I haue rather amonge many others in the like condition, cited this hi≈øtory of S. Martial, becau≈øe morally to ≈øpeake, the be≈øt learned Druids & others of this our Britanie, where the cheife≈øt and commaunders in that ≈øect remayned,
could not bee ignorant of the≈øe thinges; for both S. Aurelianus ≈øucce≈ø≈øor immediate to S. Martial at Limogen, and S. Martial al≈øo him≈øelfe are mo≈øt worthy witne≈ø≈øes, that Sigebertus the ≈øummus Sacerdos, high prei≈øt, Arch-flamen, and cheife≈øt of the Druids ≈øect, in tho≈øe partes, was by S. Martial conuerted, to this his holy, ≈øacrificinge and ma≈ø≈øing Chri≈øtian Religion. (S. Aurelian. in vit. S. Martial. & Martial. epi≈øtol. ad Burdegal. cap 3.) And S. Aurelianus doth make this his holy conuer≈øion ≈øo famous, that it could not be concealed, from the rulers of the Druids Religion in Britanie, whom it ≈øo much concerned. (Aurelian. ≈øupr. & annotat. in S. Martial.) for pre≈øently after, Benedicta, wife of the Prince of that Prouince, was conuerted by S. Martial, this high prei≈øte of the Druids: Sigebert being al≈øo conuerted, did breake in peeces all their Idols, destroyed their Temples, except the Temple dedicated to the vnknowne God, and shiuered the altars of the diuils into du≈øt. Ip≈øemet Sigebertus Pontifex Idola omnia confregit minutim, & Templa euertit, excepto Templo ignoti Dei, & altaria daemonum in puluerem. Which S. Martial him≈øelfe doth ≈øufficiently
in≈øinuate, when hee ≈øaith: dum altaria daemonum, in puluerem redigerentur, aram ignoti Dei ad con≈øecrationem re≈øeruari iu≈øsimus. Quia dedicata in nomine Dei I≈ørael, & te≈øtis ip≈øius Stephani, qui pro eo √† Iudaeis pa≈ø≈øus est. (S. Martial ≈øup. cap. 3) when the altars of the deuils were beaten into du≈øt, wee commaunded the altare of the vnknowne God to bee re≈øerued for con≈øecration. Which was dedicated in the name of the God of I≈ørael, and Martir Stephen, who ≈øuffered for him by the Iewes.

19. And if wee come to the nearer parts of Fraunce, Paris, Rouen, Britany, Normandy, Picardy, and all the ≈øea coa≈øte, we ≈øhall euidently ≈øee, that no other doctrine or practi≈øe of this holy ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe, could po≈ø≈øibly haue entraÃÑce into this kingdome: for in tho≈øe parts wee finde S. Denis the Areopagite, that glorious ma≈ø≈øinge, and Ma≈ø≈øe teachinge Father, S. Pauls ≈øcholler, ≈øent thither by the ma≈ø≈øinge Pope, S. Clement, with his ma≈ø≈øinge companions, S. Ru≈øticus, and Eleutherius, and S. Nica≈øius ≈øent a ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øt, and Bi≈øhop, by the ≈øame ma≈ø≈øinge Pope. (Gregor. Turonen. l. 1. hist. Sur. in vit. Genouefuae. Metaphr. 3. Octob.
Bed. & V≈øuard. 7. id. Octob. Volater. l. 15. Breu. Rom. in S. Dioni≈ø. Arnold. Merman. l. Britones, Normandos, Rothomagen≈øes, Picardos, omnemque maris Oceani tractum instruxit, formauitque fide S. Nica≈øius √† S. Clemente illue Apo≈øtolus delegatus imperante Nerone. Conuer≈ø. gent. tabul. Eccle≈ø. Rothomagen. And ≈øome thinke he preached and practi≈øed this doctrine al≈øo, in this our Britanie. Harris. Theatr. l. 1.

20. If we circuite further, and come to Gallia, Belgica, Collen, Mentz, Treuers, Lothoringia, Al≈øa≈øia, Heluetia and tho≈øe parts, wee ≈øhall finde in the≈øe daies of the Apo≈øtles ≈øent thither by S. Peter, S. Clement vncle to S. Clement the Pope, his glorious companions S. Man≈øuetus our contriman, Cele≈øtius, Felix, and Patiens: wee ≈øee ≈øent thither al≈øo by the ≈øame Apo≈øtle & his authoritie, S. Maternus, one of the 72. di≈øciples of Chri≈øt, with S. Eucharius, Valerius, our noble Britan, S. Beatus, and others. Arnold. Mohu. ≈øupr. Io. Scomer. Gul. Ei≈øengren. cent. 1. Antonin. part. 1. Petr. de natal. l. 10. cap. 113. Ant. Democh. lib. 2. de Mi≈ø≈ø. Sebast. Mun≈øter. in Co≈ømograph. Bed. 18. cal. Octobr. Wolfg. Bawr. in vit. prae≈øul.
Memetocern. Annal. Colonien. & Treueren. And that the≈øe were ma≈ø≈øinge, and ≈øacrificinge prei≈øts, wee haue many authorities: onely I will exemplify in the two cheife≈øt, to which the others were ≈øubordinate in ≈øuch affaires, and taught and practi≈øed as tho≈øe two their ≈øuperiors, S. Clement and S. Maternus did.

21, Of the≈øe it is euident, not onely becau≈øe they were both con≈øecrated prei≈øts, and directed by that great ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øt, and Apo≈øtle S. Peter, who≈øe commaund & order, and their owne in≈øtitution beeing ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ holy Saints they neither did nor could violate, but al≈øo that they v≈øually ≈øaid Ma≈ø≈øe, as fir≈øt of S. Clement it is te≈øtified, of his publicke, and ≈øolemne ≈øayinge of Ma≈ø≈øe, Mi≈øsarum ≈øolemnijs celebratis, wherewith he armed him≈øelfe before hee wrought that great miracle, in de≈øtroyinge the horrible dragon which had killed at Metz, ≈øo many men, & other creatures; by which publick miraculous deede many were conuerted to the faith of Chri≈øt. Antonin. part. 1. tit. 6. cap. 26. Anton. Demochar. l. 2. de Mi≈ø≈øa. c. 42. Gulielm. Ei≈øengren. centen. 1. fol. 147.) And to performe this holy ≈øolemnitie and ≈øacrifice
of Ma≈ø≈øe, hee ordered cleargie men, in diuers degrees, and orders, in diuer≈øis gradibus, which no Chri≈øtians but ≈øuch as allow the ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe, admit, and builded churches there. (Antonin. ≈øupr. Petr. de natal. l. 10. c. 113. Vincent. l. 9. cap. 42.) S. Maternus al≈øo the di≈øciple of the ≈øame ma≈ø≈øing Apo≈øtle, S. Peter, and ≈øent into Germany by him, who preached in many prouinces thereof, buildinge diuers churches to holy Saints, as S. Iohn Bapti≈øt, his Ma≈øter, S. Peter, and others, was ≈øo renowned a ma≈ø≈øing prei≈øt, that among other his wonderful miracles. (Petrus Mer≈ø≈øaeus Cratepol. Catalog. de Archiepi≈øcop. Treuern.) it is commonly deliuered, and written of him, that he ≈øaid three Ma≈ø≈øes in one day, in far distant places. Diuer≈øis ac longe distantibus locis. So renowned were the≈øe men for that mo≈øt holy function, and office, ≈øo zelous and deuoute in the performance thereof, and God ≈øo well plea≈øed, and ≈øerued in that ≈øo ≈øacred an exerci≈øe, that he did ≈øo miraculou≈øly concurre vnto it.

div.head: THE XII. CHAPTER. Wherein is proued euen by protestants, that what≈øoeuer Apo≈øtle or other, first preached Christ in Britanie, brought ≈øacrificinge preisthood hither: and S. Peter fir≈øt founded here our eccle≈øiasticall Hierarchie, of ≈øacrificinge ma≈øsinge preists and Bishops.
div.p:
NOw we may hope that no man being by name a Chri≈øtian, will bee ≈øo oppo≈øite an Antichri≈øtian, to thinke, that Chri≈øt which could not teache errors, or contrary doctrines, and deliuered but one, and the ≈øame true, and infallible Religion to the whole world, for all places, people, and ages, had one Religion for the re≈øt of the world, in Europe, A≈øia, and Africke, all of them as before, embracing in the Apo≈øtles time the holy ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe, and ≈øacrificinge prei≈øthood: and an other for Britanie, quite different, and neuer heard of in any antiquitie, neuer practi≈øed in any other forme, or order, neuer regi≈øtred in any monument. And ≈øeeing all the Euangeli≈øts, and Apo≈øtles of Chri≈øt, together with their
di≈øciples, were ma≈ø≈øinge and ≈øacrificinge prei≈øts, and there were no other to preach, and propagate true Religion, in this, or any other nation, vnder heauen, but they, how could any Caluini≈øtical communion, or other new deui≈øe bee imagined to haue had beeinge here? For who≈øoeuer it was, which any prote≈øtant doth, or will affirme, to haue beene the fir≈øt preacher of Chri≈øtianitie in this kingdome, S. Peter, S. Paul, or S. Simon Zelotes, who onely among the Apo≈øtles are reported in hi≈øtories to haue beene in this kingdome, as our be≈øt learned prote≈øtant antiquaries with others truely acknowledge, or S. Io≈øeph of Aramathia, for which many contend, or who≈øoeuer, if they were prei≈øts (as prei≈øts they mu≈øt needes bee in all opinion Catholicke or Prote≈øtant, that ≈øhould found our church) they mu≈øt needes al≈øo be ma≈ø≈øing and ≈øacrificing prei≈øts, no other Chri≈øtian prei≈øts beeinge in the whole worlde at that time, as before is euident. Theater of great Britanie lib. 6. Camb. in Britan. Godw. conuer≈ø. of Brit. Stowe hist. Holinsh. hi≈øt. of Engl.

2. And for tho≈øe three Apo≈øtles, I haue particularly proued in euery of them, that
they all, as al≈øo all the re≈øt of that holy order of the Apo≈øtles which diuided the world among them to conuert it to Chri≈øt, were without any exception, ma≈ø≈øing prei≈øtes. And if any man will per≈øi≈øt in S.
