14. And in the time of S. Man≈øuetus, the fir≈øt Bi≈øhop of London in the Saxons time, when S. Peter did miraculou≈øly appeare about the dedicatinge of the church of we≈øtmin≈øter, as many both holy and auncient Catholicke writers, and prote≈øtants antiquaries a≈ø≈øure vs, and the circum≈øtances of the hi≈øtorie demon≈øtrate it to bee true, hee ≈øent this charge and commaund to S. Mellitus Bi≈øhop of London, who had determined to dedicate it the next day followinge: I haue dedicated the church, and by authoritie of my ≈øanctification preuented the epi≈øcopall benediction. Therefore tell the Bishop what thou ha≈øt heard and ≈øeene, and the ≈øignes remayninge will iu≈øtifie thy wordes to bee true. Therfore let him ab≈øteine from dedication, and ≈øupply that which wanteth, to offer there the holy ≈øacrifice of our Lords body and blood. Ego ≈øum Petrus qui cum meis ciuibus con≈øtructam in meo nomine ba≈øilicam dedicaui, epi≈øcopalemque benedictionem meae ≈øanctificationis authoritate praeueni. Dic ergo Pontifici quae vidi≈øti & audi≈øti, tuoque ≈øermoni ≈øigna parietibus impre≈øsa testimonium perhibebunt. Super≈øedeat igitur dedicatione, ≈øuppleat quod omi≈øimus Dominici
corporis & ≈øanguinis Sacro≈øancta my≈øteria. S. Alured. Riuall. M. S. in vita S. Eduardi Regis & confe≈ø≈ø. Iacob. Gen. Epi≈øc. in eius vit. & M. S. antiq. Sur. in vit. eius & Capgrau. in eius vit. Franc. Ma≈øon l. of con≈øecrat. here wee ≈øee, that S. Peter now in glory, both allowed and commaunded the ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe, which when hee liued and conuer≈øed on earth, hee had practi≈øed, frequented, and in≈øtituted with ≈øo great diligence and deuotion.

15. So likewi≈øe when in the time of the Dani≈øh fury here, hee appeared to comfort this afflicted contry, where hee had preached and taught this holy doctrine, hee did not chu≈øe any man to reueale his glad tidings vnto, and the deliuery of this kingdome, but S. Brithwold, that great and famous ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øt, and Bi≈øhop of Winche≈øter, or Wilton, and in the mo≈øt known ma≈ø≈øinge place of England, the Abbey of Gla≈øtenbury, and did fortell, how S. Edward Kinge and confe≈ø≈øor, that mo≈øt great reuerencer of holy Ma≈ø≈øe, perhaps yet vnborne, and borne in exile in Normandy, ≈øhould bee Kinge in England, and deliuer it from tho≈øe floods of mi≈øeries, wherewith
it was then ≈øurrounded, and longe time had beene. And to a≈ø≈øure vs this was a true vi≈øion, and prophe≈øie of S. Peter, and hee an approuer of all louers of holy Ma≈ø≈øe, as God al≈øo is, this hee addeth: Erit cum dormieris cum patribus tuis, vi≈øitabit Dominus populum ≈øuum, & faciet Dominus redemptionem plebis ≈øuae. Eliget enim ≈øibi virum ≈øecundum cor ≈øuum qui faciat omnes voluntates ≈øuas, qui me opitulante regnum adeptus Anglorum Danico furori finem imponet. Erit enim acceptus Deo, gratus hominibus, terribilis hostibus, amabilis ciuibus, vtilis Eccle≈øiae, laudabilemque vitam ≈øancto fine concludet. It ≈øhall come to pa≈ø≈øe, when thou ≈øhalt ≈øleepe with thy Fathers, our Lord will vi≈øit his people, and our Lord will cau≈øe a redemption of his people. For hee will chu≈øe vnto him≈øelfe a man, accordinge to his owne hart, which ≈øhall doe all his de≈øires, who by my helpe obteyninge the crowne of England, ≈øhall make an end of the Dani≈øh fury. For hee ≈øhall bee acceptable to God, gratefull to men, terrible to his enemies, amiable to his citi≈øens, profitable to the church, and hee ≈øhall conclude his laudable life, with an holy end. And the holy and learned writers of his life thus
immediatly add: all which things the euent of the thinge proued to bee fulfilled in S. Edward. Quae omnia in beato Eduardo completa rei exitus comprobauit. Therefore this mu≈øt needs bee a true vi≈øion, and prophe≈øie of S. Peter. Alured Riuall. l. de vit. S. Eduardi Iacob. Epi≈øc. Gen. in vit. eius M. S. antiq. ibid. Capgrau. in Catal. in S. Eduardo Rege & Confe≈ø≈øore Sur. in vit eius & Lippom. Godwin Catal. of Bi≈øhops in B. Brithwild.

16. This is that holy Kinge that left the hereditary miraculous power of curing the di≈øea≈øe called the Kings euill obteyned by his piety, to his ≈øucce≈ø≈øors. This is that great reuerencer of ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øts, this is hee who at the time of eleuation at holy Ma≈ø≈øe in England, vpon Whit≈øunday did ≈øee by reuelation the Kinge of Denmarke drowned in the ≈øea by the coa≈øte of Denmarke, as hee was takinge ≈øhip to come to inuade England, and his nauy di≈øper≈øed, which, peractis Mi≈ø≈øarum ≈øolemnijs, as ≈øoone as Ma≈øse was ended, hee confidently related. This holie Kinge, to ≈øpeake in prote≈øtants and their authors words. (Stowe hi≈øtor. in Edward CoÃÑ fe≈øsor.) before the day of his natiuitie was elected of God, who per≈øeuering in cha≈øtitie, ledd
all his life dedicated to God in true marriage, wherefore as wee haue knowne proued by good and ≈øufficient men being witne≈ø≈øes, God greatlie glorified him in his life with wonderful ≈øignes. Therefore it is euident that S. Peter, and God him≈øelfe, with the whole court of heauen, did, and doe allowe of ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øts, and the holy ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe, not only as it was celebrated in the beginning, but after all additions which prote≈øtantes write, or imagine, were put vnto it; for after all the≈øe added and longe after, as wee ≈øee, both S. Peter and God him≈øelfe did thus approue, and honor the both reuerent ≈øayers, and hearers of that ble≈ø≈øed ≈øacrifice.

div.head: THE XIII. CHAPTER. Wherein is proued, how after the death of S. Peter, in the time followinge commonly a≈øcribed to S. Linus and Cletus in the ≈øee of Rome, and to Marius Kinge in Britanie, the Britans both at home and abroade v≈øed the ≈øacrificing prei≈øthood, prei≈øts and Ma≈ø≈øe.
div.p:
HItherto wee haue ≈øpoken of S. Peter, who being martired by Nero the Emperor,
it is a que≈øtion whether S. Linus, whom (and S. Cletus) he had con≈øecrated Bi≈øhops at his beeinge at Rome before he ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ came into the≈øe We≈øt parts, or S. Clement did immediatly ≈øucced him; S. Leo the ≈øecond with our renowned contrimen, S. Marianus, Florentus Wigornien≈øis, and to ≈øpeake in Martinus Polonus wordes. (Leo Papa 2. epistol. decretal. Marian. Scot. lib. 2. aetat. 6. in Nerone. Florent. Wigorn. an 50. al. 72. Martin. Pol. ≈øupputat. col. 33. in Lino.) They which ≈øearched more diligently concerning the chaire of the Romane church, doe ≈øay, that Linus and Cletus did not ≈øitt as Popes, but as coadiutors of the Pope, to whome S. Peter in his life onely committed the di≈øpen≈øation of eccle≈øiasticall things: for which beeing endowed with ≈øo great authoritie, they de≈øerued to bee placed in the catalogue of the Popes, but S. Peter appointed S. Clement his ≈øucce≈ø≈øor. Dicunt qui de cathedra Romanae Eccle≈øiae diligentius per≈øerutati ≈øunt, quod Linus & Cletus non ≈øederunt vt Pontifices, ≈øed vt ≈øummi Pontificis coadiutores, quibus in vita ≈øua beatus Petrus vnam tradidit eccle≈øiasticarum rerum di≈øpen≈øationem: propter quod tanta authoritate dotati, meruerunt in catalogo Pontificum
poni. Clementem vero ip≈øe beatus Petrus ≈øucce≈ø≈øorem constituit. Which S. Clement him≈øelfe as he is commonly receaued, doth al≈øo likewi≈øe affirme of him≈øelfe, and S. Leo ≈øaith: Linum & Cletum nihil vnquam legibus ≈øuis ex pontificali ministerio, pote≈øtatiu√® egi≈ø≈øe, ≈øed quantum eis √†beato Petro praecipiebatur, tantum ≈øolumodo agebant. Linus and Cletus did nothinge at any time by theire lawes by papall mini≈øtery or power, but how much was commaunded them by S. Peter, ≈øo much onely they did. Clem. Roman. epi≈øtol. 1. Leo Papa 2. epi≈øt. decretali ≈øupr. apud Marian. Wigorn. & alios. which wee finde in their liues that the fir≈øt, ex praecepto Petri Apostoli constituit, vt mulier in Eccle≈øiam velato capite intret: con≈øtituted by the commaundement of S. Peter, that a woman ≈øhould haue her head couered, when ≈øhee entred the church. The other by the precept of S. Peter ordeyned 21. preists in the citie of Rome. Cletus, hic ex praecepto Petri, viginti & vnum presbyteros ordinauit in vrbe Roma. Martin. Polon. ≈øupputat. in Lino & Cleto & alij.

2. But becau≈øe many others, and great authors incline to thinke they were Popes,
I meddle not to di≈øcu≈ø≈øe this matter, little pertinent to my pre≈øent purpo≈øe, becau≈øe very little is written of them: But this mo≈øt certaine it is, that whether they were Popes, or no, being con≈øecrated by S. Peter that knowne ma≈ø≈øing prei≈øt, and Pope, and hauinge S. Clement their ≈øucce≈ø≈øor, that knowne, ma≈ø≈øinge Pope, they mu≈øt needs bee al≈øo ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øts, and Popes, if they were Popes. And for S. Linus who as both Catholicks & Prote≈øtants te≈øtifie, did write the acts of S. Peter in the ≈øame ≈øort as they are publi≈øhed, giueth plaine te≈øtimony, to the daily ≈øaying of Ma≈ø≈øe, & offering therin the ble≈ø≈øed body and blood of Chri≈øt, and ≈øheweth how the ≈øigne of the Cro≈ø≈øe was v≈øed in the celebration thereof euerie day: √¥ crux quae quotidi√® car ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ s immaculati Agni fidelibus diuid ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ populis. Linus in hi≈øtor. pa≈ø≈ø. S. Petri. And it is proued not onely by hi≈øtories, but S. Paul him≈øelfe doth ≈øufficiently incline vs to knowe, that his cheife lodginge was in the then cheife ma≈ø≈øinge hou≈øe of our Chri≈øtian Britans, at Rome, and not onely of him, and other the Popes, but ≈øuch holy di≈øciples as came to Rome vnto them: for writing vnto S. Timothie.
2. Timoth. 4.) hee remembreh onely to ≈øalute him, but fower par≈øons, Eubulus, Linus, Pudens, and Claudia, which ≈øeeme to haue had all, or the mo≈øte of their permanency in that hou≈øe, where S, Timothy al≈øo had beene entertayned when hee was at Rome: and therefore they alone ≈øalute him, beeing as S. Chri≈øo≈øtome and Theodoret wel note vppon this place, the mo≈øt eminent Chri≈øtians then in Rome. S. Chri≈øostom. & Theodoret. in 2. Tim. 4. for S. Linus was a Bi≈øhop there ordeyned by S. Peter, and the other three renowned for their harbouring of the Chri≈øtians, there at that time, as mo≈øt certaine it is of Pudens and Claudia, and not vnprobable as I haue ≈øhewed in other places that Eubulus was our noble contriman and Father to Claudia, and ≈øo for his ho≈øpitalitie to the Saints of God, fir≈øt remembred in this ≈øalutation, all hi≈øtories beeinge ≈øilent of him and no other nation claiming him to bee from them.

3. Therefore this beeing then ≈øo renowned a receptacle, and ma≈ø≈øinge hou≈øe, although S. Linus did not intermeddle in ≈øendinge prei≈øts, or preachers into this, or any other countrie, yet the Chri≈øtian Britans
which liued at home, could not bee ignorant what was done in ≈øuch things, in this holy hou≈øe of our ≈øo eminent Chri≈øtians at Rome, ≈øeeing there was continuall traffick and intercour≈øe betweene Rome and Britanie at that time, and ≈øo much euen in ≈øpirituall things by our be≈øt prote≈øtant antiquaries of this kingdom. (Theater of great Brit. l. 6. Matth. Parker. antiquitat. Britan. pag. 2.3. Godwin. conuer≈ø. of Britanie pag. 17.18. Cambd. in Britan. Stowe histor.) that they a≈ø≈øcribe a great part of the labours and meanes of plantinge the faith of Chri≈øt in Britanie, to our holy Britti≈øh Lady Claudia, and tho≈øe of that hou≈øe in Rome. All of them beeing Chri≈øtians, as both Catholicks and Prote≈øtants write, totamque ≈øuam familiam Christi fidem amplexos, and that number ≈øo greate, that there were in it in the beginning of the next age an hundred men, wantinge foure, nonaginta ≈øex homines, that were Chri≈øtians, and not fewer in this time by probable opinion, the owners of the hou≈øe beeing both ≈øo honorable and religious, all of them hearers at the lea≈øte, and frequenters of this mo≈øt holy ≈øacrifice. vit. S. Pudentianae in Breuiar. Rom. die 19.
Maij.

4. And to ≈øpeake in a Prote≈øtant Archbi≈øhops, & great aÃÑtiquaries words: (Matth. Parker. antiquitat. Britan. pag. 3.) Nec veri≈øimil. ≈øolum ≈øed verum iudicandum est, in tam nobil ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ familia fai≈ø≈øe cum Claudia gentiles ≈øuos ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ tannos qui vna bapti≈øati fuerunt, √† quibus Euangelij ignicula per totam gentem Britannicam di≈øper≈øa, viritim ad multos peruenerunt. Neither is it onely to bee iudged likely, but true, that in ≈øo noble a family with Claudia, there were Britans her countrimen, which were bapti≈øed with her, by whome the ≈ømale fiers of the gho≈øpell di≈øper≈øed throughout the whole nation of Britanie from man to man, did come to many. And not onely tho≈øe reuerencers of holy Ma≈ø≈øe which were of the family of Lady Claudia, but many others in Rome, at that time, both Romane and Britti≈øh Chri≈øtians, in theire owne par≈øons cominge from thence into Britanie, par≈øonally performed the≈øe holy offices, as our Theater prote≈øtantes, thus a≈ø≈øure vs. Theater of great Britanie l. 6. cap. 9. it hath al≈øo pa≈øsed with allowance among the learned Senate of our antiquaries, that when Nero began (a little before this time) to
banish and per≈øecute the Christians in Rome, many Romans and Britans beeing conuerted to the faith, fled thence into the≈øe remote parts of the earth, where they might, and did more freely enioy the libertie of their profe≈øsions. Which an other Prote≈øtant Bi≈øhop and antiquary ≈øpeakinge of the≈øe dayes of Claudia, thus coÃÑfirmeth. (Godwin conuer≈ø. of Britanie pag. 18. cap. 3.) Of the≈øe times wee ≈øpeake of, I doubt not wee may v≈øe the words of Ca≈ø≈øiodorus, it was not counted vnlawful for tho≈øe to bee Chri≈øtians, that dwelt beyond Italy and Fraunce, as in Britanie. Whereby vndoubtedly it came to pa≈ø≈øe, that many profe≈øsing Chri≈øt, not daringe to abide nere vnto the hart of the Empire, made choice of our Britanie, vvhere to leade their liues in ≈øuch ≈øort, as they might enioy libertie of con≈øcience. And hee noteth in the mergine: Britanie a refuge for Christians.

5. Therefore although wee ≈øhould follow their opinion, that ≈øay S. Linus and Cletus executed the papall function, excluding S. Clement vntill after their death, though wee finde no prei≈øts purpo≈øely, ≈øent by them vnto this kingdome, or other nation, yet the prote≈øtants them≈øelues do freelie
graunt. The English Protestant Margin. annot. in Matth. Westm. an. 59. Robert. Barnes in vit. Pontif. in Lino Dama≈ø. ≈øeu Ana≈øta≈ø. in S. Lino & Cleto. Breu. Rom. die. 26. April. & 23. Septemb. Martin. Pol. in S. Lino & Cleto. that they were both made prei≈øts by the great ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øt and Apo≈øtle S. Peter, Petrus Apo≈øtolus Linum & Cletum pre≈øbyteros ordinauit, and both of them did al≈øo make prei≈øts, S Linus 18. as both Catholicks and prote≈øtants teach, and diuers Bi≈øhops: and S. Cletus by S Peters commaund con≈øecrated in the citie of Rome 25. prei≈øts, which beeing commaunded by a ma≈ø≈øinge Apo≈øtle, and performed by a ma≈ø≈øinge Bi≈øhop, mu≈øt needs bee ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øts, and all tho≈øe ≈øo many Chri≈øtians of the≈øe times by our prote≈øtants before either Britans or Romans, which either by their concurreÃÑce at Rome ≈øtill ≈øtaying there, or by per≈øonall pre≈øence beinge come, and ≈øtayinge here, gaue a≈ø≈øi≈øtance and helpe towardes the in≈øtruction and conuer≈øion of this our Britanie, mu≈øt needes bee either ≈øayers, or hearers of Ma≈ø≈øe, and practi≈øers and approuers of that holy ≈øacrifice, and ≈øo ioyned them≈øelues with tho≈øe ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øts, and Bi≈øhops
in this kingdome, which I named before and liued longe after this time, as I ≈øhall ≈øhewe hereafter. Or if wee will rather incline to them that ≈øay, the≈øe two were onely coadiutors and not Popes, but giue the papacy in this time to S. Clement as ≈øome Prote≈øtants with many Catholicks before, and others hold, to ≈øpeake in a prote≈øtants words (Robert. Barnes l. de vit. Pontif. Romanor. in Petro. Petrus ordinauit Clementem, ≈øui officij vices ei committens:) Peter ordeyned Clement, committinge the place of his office vnto him: It mu≈øt needs euen by that title bee, that as hee was ≈øacred and receaued this charge and power from that great ma≈ø≈øing prei≈øt, and Bi≈øhop S. Peter, ≈øo hee al≈øo receaued from him that holy ≈øacrificinge prei≈øthood, and power, and ≈øucceeded him in that, as other ≈øacred papall functions, of whome I am to ≈øpeake in the chapter followinge.

div.head: THE XIV. CHAPTER. How duringe the time of S. Clement his papacy, and all this fir≈øt hundred yeares of Christ, our Christian Britans, together with all others continued the≈øe holy doctrines and offices of ≈øacrificing preisthood, preistes, and the ≈øacrifice of the ble≈ø≈øed body and blood of Christ in Ma≈ø≈øe.
div.p:
THis holy and learned Pope, and ≈øucce≈ø≈øor to S. Peter, S. Clement, whether hee pre≈øently executed that highe≈øt pa≈øtorall function, or of humilitie gaue place to S. Linus, and Cletus more aunciently con≈øecrated Bi≈øhops, at and for Rome by S. Peter, beeing him≈øelfe con≈øecrated as before a ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øt, and mo≈øt deuoutly and religiou≈øly as I ≈øhall demon≈øtrate, continually executinge that holy ma≈ø≈øinge and ≈øacrificinge prei≈øtly power, and duty, did not onely in generall impart it to this nation, as hee had care and charge of the whole church committed vnto him, nor in particular becau≈øe hee had re≈øidence and much continuance with our Chri≈øtian Britans
at Rome as S. Cletus, Linus and Peter before had, but becau≈øe in all probable iudgement, hee was longe time here in Britanie with S. Peter, and after by the ≈øame greate Apo≈øtle charged in one of his la≈øte admonitions vnto him, to haue an e≈øpecial care of this kingdome of Britanie in particular, both which are ea≈øely proued by the words of S. Peter vnto S. Clement, as hee him≈øelfe thus relateth them, and produceth them, as one amonge other rea≈øons, why aboue all others ≈øo manie worthie men, hee made choi≈øe of S. Clement to bee his ≈øucce≈ø≈øor. Clemens Rom. epi≈øtol. 1. ex verb. S. Petri. mihi ab initio v≈øque ad finem comes itineris & actuum fueris, quaeque per ≈øingulas ciuitates, me di≈øputante ≈øolicitus Auditor exceperis. Thou ha≈øt beene a companion of my trauailes, and deedes from the beginninge vnto the end. Thou as a carefull Auditor ha≈øt ob≈øerued what I haue preached in euerie citie.

2. And to him againe: If I had any other better then thou, or any had beene ≈øo diligent helper of mee, or any had ≈øo fully receaued my doctrine, and learned my eccle≈øiasticall di≈øpo≈øitions, if I had any ≈øuch other, I woulde not
compell the vnwillinge to vndertake this good vvorke. Si e≈øset alius melior, ≈øi quis mihi alius adiutor tam ≈øedulus adstiti≈ø≈øet, ≈øi quis tam plen√® doctrinae meae rationem caepi≈ø≈øet, ≈øed & eccle≈øia≈øticas di≈øpo≈øitiones √† me tam plen√® didici≈ø≈øet, habens alium talem, non te cogerem opus bonum ≈øu≈øcipere nolentem. And to the Chri≈øtians at Rome in this maner. When hee was to die. Audite me fratres & con≈øerui mei, quoniam vt edoctus ≈øum ab eo qui me mi≈øit, Domino & Magistro meo Ie≈øu Christo, dies mortis meae in≈øtat, Clementem hunc Epi≈øcopum vobis ordino, cui ≈øoli meae praedicationis & doctrinae cathedram trado: Qui mihi ab initio v≈øque in finem comes in omnibus fuit, & per hoc veritatem totius meae praedicationis agnouit: Qui in omnibus tentationibus meis ≈øocius extitit, fideliter per≈øeuerans. Heare mee √¥ my brethren and fellow ≈øeruants, becau≈øe as I am taught by him that ≈øent mee, my Lord and Ma≈øter Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, the day of my death is at hand, I ordeine this Clement to bee your Bi≈øhop, to whome alone I commit the chaire of my preachinge and doctrine, who hath beene a companion vnto mee in all thinges, or places from the begining to the end, and thereby knoweth
the truth of all my preachinge. Who hath beene my fellow in al my tentations, faithfully per≈øeueringe. Clem. ≈øupr. epi≈øt. 1. Marian. Scot. in S. Petro. Flor. Wigorn. in chron. in S. Petro. Leo Pap. 2. epistol. decretal. Alexander 1. epi≈øt. 1. ad omnes orthodox. To. 1. Concil.

3. Therefore ≈øeing S. Peter was in Britanie as I haue ≈øhewed before, and our prote≈øtant antiquaries allowe of tho≈øe auncient recordes, which almo≈øt 800. yeares ≈øince were alleaged for reuerende antiquities, and ≈øay, that S. Peter stayed longe time in this our Britanie, conuerted many, founded churches, and ordeyned Bishops, preists, and deacons; quo in loco cum longo tempore fui≈øset moratus, & verbo gratiae multos illumina≈ø≈øet, & Eccle≈øias con≈øtitui≈ø≈øet, Epi≈øcopo≈øque, & pre≈øbyteros, & diaconos ordina≈ø≈øet. Prote≈øtant Theater of great Brit. lib. 6. cap. 9 antiquitat. graec. apud Sim. Metaphra≈øten die 29. Iunij. Laurent. Sur. 29. Iunij: and was ≈øuch a ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øt and Apo≈øtle, as I haue ≈øhewed before, S. Clement this his vn≈øeparable companion, in all times, and places, from the beginning to the end, and the be≈øt learner, follower, and ob≈øeruer of his doctrine,

Marke, and from him continued to the time of this Author, by continuall tradition, from one to an other.

14. Ip≈øum cur≈øum qui dicitur pre≈øenti tempore Scottorum, Beatus Marcus decantauit & post ip≈øum Gregorius Nazianzenus, quem Hieronymus ≈øuum Magistrum e≈ø≈øe affirmat, & beatus Ba≈øilius frater ip≈øius S. Gregorij, Antonius, Paulus, Macharius vel Ioannes, & Malchus ≈øecundum ordinem Patrum decantauerunt. Inde po≈øtea beati≈øsimus Ca≈øsianus, & post ip≈øum beatus Honoratus, & Sanctus Cae≈øarius Epi≈øcopus qui fuit in Arelata, & beatus Porcarius Abbas qui in ip≈øo monasterio fuit, ip≈øum cur≈øum decantauerunt, qui beatum Lupum, & beatum Germanum Monachos in eorum monasterio habuerunt, & ip≈øi ≈øub norma regulae ip≈øum cur≈øum ibidem decantauerunt. Et po≈øtea Epi≈øcopatus cathedram adepti in Britannijs & Scottijs praedicauerunt. Quae vita beati Germani Epi≈øcopi Anti≈øiodoren≈øis, & vita beat Lupi affirmat. Qui beatum Patricium literas ≈øacras docuerunt, atque enutrierunt. Et ip≈øum Epi≈øcopum in Scottijs ac Britannijs po≈øuerunt, qui vixit annos centum quinquaginta & tres, & ip≈øum cur≈øum ibidem decantauit: & po≈øt ip≈øum beatus Vuandilocus ≈øenex, & beatus Gomogillus, qui habuerunt in eorum monasterio Monachos circiter tria millia. Inde beatus Vuandilocus in predicationis ministerium √†
beato Gomogillo mi≈ø≈øus e≈øt, & beatus Columbanus partibus Galliarum, & ibidem ip≈øum cur≈øum decantauerunt. That order which at this time is called the order of Scots, S. Marke did ≈øinge, and after him Gregory Nazianzen, whome Hierome affirmeth to haue beene his Ma≈øter, and S Ba≈øil brother of the ≈øaid S Gregory, Antonius, Paulus, Macharius or Iohn, and Malchus, accordinge to the order of the Fathers did ≈øinge it. And after that mo≈øt ble≈ø≈øed Ca≈ø≈øian, and after him S. Honoratus, and S. Cae≈øarius Bi≈øhop, that was in Arles, and S. Porcarius Abbot, which was in the ≈øame mona≈øterie, did ≈øinge that order, who had monkes in their mona≈øtery S. Lupus and S Germanus, and they three vnder rule did ≈øinge the ≈øame order: and after made Bi≈øhops preached in Britanie, and Scotlande, which thinges the life of S. German Bi≈øhop of Anti≈øiodor, and the life of S. Lupus doth affirme, who taught S. Patricke holy learning, & brought him vp, and placed him Bi≈øhop in Scotland, and Britanie, who liued an hundred fifty and three yeares, and ≈øonge there the ≈øame order. And after him Vuandilocus an old man, and S. Gomogillus, who had in
their mona≈øtery about three thou≈øand monkes. After S. Vuandilocus was ≈øent to preach by S. Gomogillus, as al≈øo S. Columbanus to the parts of Fraunce, and there they did ≈øinge the ≈øame order.

15. Hitherto the wordes of this ≈øo auncient, and approued Manu≈øcript Britti≈øh antiquitie. So that whether ≈øoeuer, or to whom≈øoeuer we turne our ≈øelues to enquire of the≈øe thinges, whether Hebrues, Grecians, or Latines, Apo≈øtles, Euangeli≈øts, or their Di≈øciples, & with vs at home, Britons, or Saxons, Catholicks or Prote≈øtants, it is clearely and plainely confe≈ø≈øed, that generally in this fir≈øt Apo≈øtolicke age, and hundred yeares of Chri≈øt, which mu≈øt needes bee allowed for a rule, ≈øquare, and direction to all ≈øucceedinge times, and po≈øterities. The holy ≈øacrificing prei≈øthood of the pre≈øent Greeke and Latine church, and all Chri≈øtian nations, whether the≈øe late nouelties, haue not entered, ≈øacrificinge ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øts, and the mo≈øte holy ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe, were our Sauiour Chri≈øt Ie≈øus his ≈øacred ordinances and in≈øtitutions, and ≈øo v≈øed, practi≈øed, and with all honor performed by the whole number of the
Apo≈øtles, without exception, their di≈øciples, and ≈øucce≈ø≈øors in all places, & among the re≈øt, to the great glory thereof, in this our nation of great Britanie. And all this without any materiall chaunge, or alteration in that ≈øacrifice, the principall act, and office of truely coÃÑ≈øecrated prei≈øts, & prei≈øthood, as is before related, and our cheife prote≈øtantes haue before confe≈ø≈øed of the mo≈øte contradicted and que≈øtionable thinges, a ≈øacrifice in≈øtituted by Chri≈øt him≈øelfe, conteyning an oblation of his mo≈øte ble≈ø≈øed body, and blood, both for the liuing and faithfull departed, propitiatory for ≈øinnes, with a memory of the holy Saints in heauen, of which le≈ø≈øer in≈øtance hath bene giuen, becau≈øe few Saints of the new te≈øtament were then at the fir≈øt decea≈øed this life, and entered into glory, yet the churches then dedicated to diuers of them, and inuocation & praier then made vnto them, as before appeareth, maketh it an vndoubted truth.

16. To which I only add for this kingdome of our Britanie from tho≈øe antiquities, both printed, and Manu≈øcripts, which our prote≈øtants mo≈øt allowe, and approue,
that S. Io≈øeph of Aramathia, and his holy company, be≈øides their buildinge a church, in honor of the ble≈ø≈øed Virgin Mary, did expre≈ø≈øely ≈øerue her, and pray vnto her: duod cim praedicti in eodem loco, Deo & beatae Virgini deuota exhibentes ob≈øequia, vigilijs, ieiunijs, & orationibus vacantes, eiu≈ødem Virginis Dei, genitricis auxilio in nece≈øsitatibus ≈øuis refocillobantur. The twelue holy men ≈øpoken of before, S. Io≈øeph and his companions, yeeldinge deuout ≈øeruices to God, and the ble≈ø≈øed Virgin, attendinge to watchings, fa≈øtings, and prayers, were in their nece≈ø≈øities releiued by the helpe of the ≈øame Virgin, Mother of God. (Antiquitat. Gla≈øt. apud Capgrau. in Catalog. in S. Io≈øeph ab Aramath. & S. Patricio. antiq. M. S. tabulis affixae in ead Eccle≈ø. Glaston. and others.) So that whom≈øoeuer S. Peter, S. Paul, S. Io≈øeph, or any other man will truly and ≈øeriou≈ølie allowe, or in his owne ≈øingular conceipt or phanta≈øie imagin, to haue beene the fir≈øt preacher, & teacher of the Chri≈øtian faith, and Religion, in Britanie, or what or who≈øe order and forme of Ma≈ø≈øe, and Liturgie, they will ≈øay was then here v≈øed and practi≈øed, they mu≈øt needs by all authorities, &
warranted iudgements acknowledge, that the holy prei≈øts here in that time were ≈øacrificinge ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øts, their externall Liturgie and ≈øacrifice, the ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe, wherein Chri≈øts holy body and blood were con≈øecrated, and offered both for the liuinge, and faithfull departed, the Saints were remembred, and prayed vnto, and no materiall difference betweene that, and the pre≈øent Ma≈ø≈øe, of either the Greeke or Latine church. And ≈øo I end this fir≈øt age and hundred yeares of Chri≈øt.

div.head: THE SECOND AGE OR HVNDRED YEARES OF CHRIST.

THE XV. CHAPTER. Wherein demonstration is made, both by prote≈øtants and other antiquaries, that ≈øacrificinge ma≈ø≈øinge preists, and Bishops, and ≈øacrifice of Ma≈øse, continued and were honored in this kingdome of Britanie from the beginninge of this hundred yeares, vntill Kinge Lucius time, when it was wholly conuerted to that faith.
div.p:
WE are now come to the beginninge of the ≈øecond age, or century
of yeares of Chri≈øt, when by all accompts in hi≈øtorie, Kinge Coillus, that was bred vp at Rome, was Kinge in Britanie, and S. Anacletus Pope of Rome. When many of our before remembred ma≈ø≈øinge and ≈øacrificinge Britti≈øh prei≈øts, as namely S. Man≈øuetus, S. Beatus, his holy companion before by ≈øome named Achates, and S. Timotheus were liuinge. And though I doe not find any particularly named, whome S. Anacletus ≈øent hither, of the holy prei≈øtly ma≈ø≈øinge order, yet to followe euen the opinion, and direction of Engli≈øh Prote≈øtant antiquaries, in this bu≈øines, wee mu≈øt needs graunt, that hee had a care of this contry as wel as others in this kind, for they te≈øtifie of this Pope; Ab ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ p≈øo Domino primatum Romanae Eccle≈øiae ≈øuper omnes Eccle≈øias, vniuer≈øumque Christiani nomine populum conce≈ø≈øum e≈øse a≈ø≈øeruit. (Robert. Barns l. de vit. Pontific. Roman. in Anaclet. Ormerod. pict. Pap. pag. 78.) Pope Anacletus affirmed, that ≈øupremacy was graunted from our Lord him≈øelfe, to the church of Rome, ouer all churches, and all Christian people. Becau≈øe, ≈øaith hee, Christ ≈øaid to S. Peter, who liued and died at Rome, thou art Peter, or a rocke,
and vppon this rocke I will builde my church. Quia, inquit, Petro agenti & morienti Romae dixit, tu es Petrus & ≈øuper hanc petram aedificabo Eccle≈øiam meam. By which rea≈øon amonge others, diuers other learned Engli≈øh Prote≈øtant writers, with publicke priuilege and allowance, doe proue vnto vs fir≈øt confe≈ø≈øinge with this holy Pope, that Chri≈øt made S. Peter the ≈øupreame and cheife gouernour of his church: ≈øecondly that this ≈øupreamacy was nece≈ø≈øary and to continue foreuer in his church: and thirdly becau≈øe S. Peter dyinge Bi≈øhop of Rome, and at Rome, and there onely po≈ø≈øibly to haue his la≈øte and immediate ≈øucce≈ø≈øor, and ≈øo con≈øtituted by him≈øelfe as is euident in S. Clement before, it euidently followeth by the rea≈øon of this holy Pope, and prote≈øtants, that euen by Chri≈øt him≈øelfe this ≈øupreamacy ouer all churches and Chri≈øtians, was graunted to the church of Rome. Whereuppon the≈øe prote≈øtants te≈øtifie in his life, that hee ordeyned diuers lawes bindinge the whole church, and ≈øtill ob≈øerued. Rob. Barnes in Anacleto.

2. And if we may beleeue the fir≈øt Prote≈øtant Archbi≈øhop of Canterbury, and in
the whole world al≈øo, Matthew Parker, hee telleth vs how in particular his iuri≈ødiction extended into this kingdome of Britanie, and that the diui≈øion and con≈øtitution of Archbi≈øhops ≈øees with vs, was by Pope Anacletus his ordination: Ex Anacle to huius in≈øulae diui≈øionem. (Matth. Parker antiquitat. Brit. pag 24.) And that he was a ≈øacrificinge ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øt, it mu≈øt needs be graunted, both by his owne, and our prote≈øtant te≈øtimonies al≈øo of him; for hee him≈øelfe is witne≈ø≈øe, that hee was made prei≈øt by the great ≈øacrificinge and ma≈ø≈øinge Apo≈øtle S. Peter: √† Sancto Petro Apostolorum Principe, presbyter ordinatus. (Anacletus epi≈øt. 3. To. 1. concil.) and our prote≈øtants do plainely confe≈ø≈øe of this holie Pope: Sacerdotem ≈øacrificaturum, mini≈øtros ve≈øtibus ≈øacris indutos, ≈øeu te≈øtes & custodes ≈øibi adhibere ordinauit. Epi≈øcopos vero, & plures mini≈øtros ≈øibi in ≈øacris faciendis adiungat: & quod Sacerdote maior ac dignior ≈øit. (Robert. Barnes l. de vit. Pontif Roman in Anacleto.) Pope Anacletus ordeined, that when a prei≈øt was to offer ≈øacrifice, hee ≈øhould take vnto him as witne≈ø≈øes and keepers, mini≈øters in holy ve≈øtiments. And that a
Bi≈øhop ≈øhould ioyne vnto him more mini≈øters, when he ≈øaid Ma≈ø≈øe: And that hee is greater, and more worthie then a prei≈øt. The authoritie from whence they cite this, is much more plaine, where the very order wee ≈øtill v≈øe in ≈øolemne Ma≈ø≈øes is expre≈ø≈øed. But the prote≈øtant words manife≈øtly proue that the ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe and ≈øacrificinge ve≈øtures, were v≈øed froÃÑ the daies of the Apo≈øtles. Therfore this holy Pope exerci≈øing ≈øupreamacy, and enactinge lawes for the whole church in Britanie or where≈øoeuer, as the≈øe prote≈øtaÃÑts there doe te≈øtifie, it mu≈øt needs bee confe≈ø≈øed, that the prei≈øts which in his time either for Britanie, or any other nation, were con≈øecrated immediatlie by him≈øelfe, or mediatly by his authority, were as him≈øelfe was, ≈øacrificinge ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øtes, and the deacons al≈øo for which hee made decrees, by the te≈øtimony of the≈øe men. (Robert. Barnes Sup. in Anaclet. Matth. Parker. antiquitat. Britan. pag. 24.) were al≈øo as they teach, ≈øuch as ≈øerued at the altare and ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe, as Ma≈øter Foxe ≈øpeakinge of the very deacons ordeined by Pope Anacletus proueth in the≈øe termes. therefore ≈øerued the office of the deacons, as
wee reade, to lay the offerings of the people vppon the altare, to bee hallowed, and when the mi≈øteries, be con≈øecrated, to distribute the cupp of the ≈øacred blood of the Lord, to the faithfull people. (Foxe Tom. 2. in Q. Mary. Ambro≈ø. l. de omnib. diuin. offic.)

3. And much part of the aboade and re≈øidency of this holy Pope, as al≈øo of his predece≈ø≈øors and ≈øucce≈ø≈øors as appeareth before, and will bee more manife≈øt hereafter, was in that knowne ma≈ø≈øinge and ≈øacrificinge hou≈øe, of our noble contriwoman S. Claudia, or her children. And the order of Ma≈ø≈øe which hee v≈øed, was the ≈øame which was practi≈øed by S. Peter the Apo≈øtle, and by him deliuered to the church, as the≈øe prote≈øtants haue before with other Authors confe≈ø≈øed. (Matth. Parker antiquitat. Brit. pag. 47. cap. 17.) and ≈øuch was the condition of his next ≈øucce≈ø≈øor S. Euaristus, v≈øing the ≈øame order of ≈øaying Ma≈ø≈øe, with S. Peter, and both claiminge, and exerci≈øinge ≈øupreamacie ouer all churches, as the≈øe prote≈øtants a≈ø≈øure vs. (Parker ≈øupr. Barn. in vit. Pontif. in Euari≈øto. Io. Funoc. commentar. l. 5. an. 105. Ed. Grimston.) and Nennius the auncient Britti≈øh writer, who as the≈øe prote≈øtants
≈øay, wrote a thou≈øand yeares ≈øince, doth expre≈ø≈øely affirme, in his Manu≈øcript hi≈øtory, that hee delt with the Kinge him≈øelfe of this our Britanie about the conuer≈øion thereof, probably before Kinge Lucius was borne: Mi≈ø≈øa legatione √† Papa Romano Euaristo. And many were conuerted by this h ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ s meanes. (booke of estates pag. 435. Bal. l. de ≈øcriptor. cent. 1. in Nennio Banchor. Nennius hi≈øtor. M.S.) therefore this Pope being knowne to bee a ma≈ø≈øinge Pope, the prei≈øts which were (by NeÃÑnius) ≈øeÃÑt hither by him, mu≈øt needs bee ma≈ø≈øing prei≈øts, as all others here, at, and before that mi≈ø≈øion were.

4. Next is Pope Alexander, a man, by our prote≈øtants allowance, ≈øtudio euangelizandi & miraculis celebris, interfectus martyr obijt: renowned for his zeale in preachinge the gho≈øpell, and miracle, and dyinge a martyr. (Whitgui≈øt. answ. to the admonit. pag. 97.98. Rob. Barnes l. de vit. Pontific. Rom. in Alexandro 1. Bal. act. Rom. Pontific. in eodem.) this Pope as Albertus Krantzius writeth, ≈øent preachers, and prei≈øts into this our Britanie. (Albert. Krantz. Metropol. l. 1. cap. 6.) therefore to know of our prote≈øtaÃÑts whether they were ma≈ø≈øing prei≈øtes,
we mu≈øt enquire, and learne of them, what he was in this re≈øpect that ≈øent them, becau≈øe hee would not, not could ≈øend others then hee him≈øelfe was, for ≈øuch a bu≈øines. That hee was a ≈øacrificinge ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øt, and Pope the≈øe prote≈øtants thus a≈ø≈øure vs, by the lawes and decrees which as they thus te≈øtifie, hee made and publi≈øhed for the church. (Robert. Barn. in vit. Pont. in Aleaandro 1. Io. Funccius l. 5. commentar. in Alexand. 1. an. 111.) In Eucharistiae ≈øacrificio aquam vino admi≈øceri voluit. Ad Eucharistiae oblationem azimum panem non fermentatum, ≈øumendum e≈øse praecepit. Vno die vnam tantum Mi≈ø≈øam √† ≈øingulis ≈øacrificijs fieri debere, decreto ≈øanciuit. Peccata ≈øacrificio (de Eucharistia loquens) deleri ait: Ideo pa≈ø≈øionem in Mi≈ø≈øa recitandam instituit. Rationem effectus huius ≈øacrificij, hoc est, quod peccata expiet, adiecit, dicens: Quia corpore & ≈øanguine Christi in ≈øacrificijs nihil maius e≈øt. Hee tooke order that in the ≈øacrifice of Euchari≈øt, water ≈øhoulde bee mingled with wine. He commaunded, that vnleuened and not leuened breade ≈øhould bee v≈øed for the ≈øacrifice of the Euchari≈øt. Hee made a decree, that no ≈øacrificing prei≈øt ≈øhould ≈øay more then one
Ma≈ø≈øe in one day. Speakinge of the Euchari≈øt he ≈øaith, that ≈øinnes ar blotted out with ≈øacrifice: therefore hee ordeyned that the pa≈ø≈øion ≈øhould bee recited at Ma≈ø≈øe. He added the rea≈øon of this effecte of this ≈øacrifice to purge ≈øinnes, ≈øayinge: becau≈øe in ≈øacrifice nothinge is greater, then the body and blood of Chri≈øt.

5 The≈øe prote≈øtants add further of this ma≈ø≈øinge Pope, in this bu≈øines (Rob. Barns ≈øupr. in Alex. 1.) In Ma≈ø≈øa pridi√® quam pateretur, v≈øque ad haec verba. Hoc est corpus meum addidit, ad memoriam pa≈øsionis Christi in ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ ul ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ andam He added in the Ma≈ø≈øe, the day before hee ≈øuffered, vnto the≈øe words, this is my body, to impre≈ø≈øe in our memories the pa≈ø≈øion of Chri≈øt. Where we ≈øee it euidently confe≈ø≈øed by the≈øe prote≈øtants them≈øelues, that this primatiue holy Pope Alexander that liued (to ≈øpeake in a Prote≈øtant Archbi≈øhops words, anno 111. in the yeare of Christ one hundred and eleuen) and was a godly Bishop. (Ioh. Whitguift answ. to the admonit. ≈øect. 1.2. pag 97.98. and dif. of the answ pag. 594.) and by the German hi≈øtorian before ≈øent prei≈øts into this kingdome, was as farr engaged in the mi≈øteries of holie
Ma≈ø≈øe, as any Roman ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øt is at this pre≈øent, acknowledging it to be the greate≈øt of al ≈øacrifices, the body and blood of Chri≈øt, a ≈øacrifice expiatinge and propitiatory for ≈øinnes. And what matter was to bee v≈øed and con≈øecrated, and how prei≈øts were to behaue them≈øelues in this mo≈øt holie ≈øacrifice. And it appeareth euen by the≈øe mens te≈øtimonies, that the prei≈øts of that time are ≈øo far from not ≈øayinge Ma≈ø≈øe, that they did not onely daily offer this mo≈øt holie ≈øacrifice of Chri≈øts body and blood for ≈øinnes, but they ≈øaid Ma≈ø≈øe more often then once a day, diuers Ma≈ø≈øes in one day, vntill it was forbidden as before by this holy Pope, That one prei≈øt, should ≈øay but one Ma≈ø≈øe a day. Vno die vnam tantam Mi≈ø≈øam √† ≈øingulis ≈øacrificijs fieri debere, decreto ≈øanciuit.

6. This Pope was as all Chri≈øtians then, far from beinge a parlamentary prote≈øtant of England to puni≈øh ≈øayinge or hearinge of Ma≈ø≈øe daily with a yearely penaltie of foure and twenty thou≈øands, three hundreds & twenty pounds & twenty markes, an huÃÑdred markes for euery Ma≈ø≈øe, or make holy ≈øacrificing ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øts to be traitors, and their entertayners fellons, when
by the≈øe prote≈øtants (Rob. Barnes ≈øup. in Alexandro 1.) this holy Pope excommunicated tho≈øe that re≈øi≈øted the Popes Legats, and forbad preists and cleargie men to bee conuented before a lay tribunall. Legatis Apostolicis ob≈øistentes, decreto excommunicauit. Clericum ad plebeium tribunal pertrah ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ re prohibuit. And yet hee was ≈øo holy and renowned a man, as be≈øides that which prote≈øtaÃÑts haue te≈øtified of him before, an other writeth. (Edw. Grimston. in the e≈øtate of the church of Rome. pag. 435. in Alex. 1.) Alexander a Roman, a man of ≈øo holy a life, as many Roman Senators receaued the Chri≈øtian Religion by rea≈øon of his great pietie. So wee may be a≈ø≈øured that all Chri≈øtiaÃÑs theÃÑ were of his opinioÃÑ in the≈øe things, as they before him were: for none of the≈øe things which the≈øe prote≈øtaÃÑts here ≈øay, hee decreed, were new, or inuented or added by him, but confirmed in their fir≈øt in≈øtitution and integritie, as I haue proued from the≈øe prote≈øtants and others before, that the mixture of water with wine was an apo≈øtolicall tradition. Couel again≈øt Burg. pag. 122.) which S. Alexander him≈øelfe confirmeth, when hee ≈øaith of it. (Cyprian. epistol. 63. Alexand. 1. epi≈øtol. 1.) a patribus
accepimus, & ip≈øa ratio docet. We haue ≈øo receaued it from our predece≈ø≈øors, and rea≈øon it ≈øelfe ≈øo teacheth, and therefore commaundeth, vt pauis tantum, & vinum aqua permixtum in ≈øacrificio offerantur, that onely breade and wine mixed with water, bee offered in the ≈øacrifice, and S. Cyprian plainely ≈øaith it was, Dominica traditio, a tradition of Chri≈øt him≈øelfe, by his owne order and example. And hee with others ≈øo expoundeth Salomon in the Prouerbs to prophe≈øie therof, as I haue declared at large before. Prouerb. c. 9. Ciprian. epi≈øt. 63. ad Cecilium.

7. The eminency of this ≈øacrifice, aboue all others, how it conteyneth the body and blood of Chri≈øt, and is ≈øatisfactory for ≈øinnes, as S. Alexander by the≈øe prote≈øtants teacheth, they haue often told vs before, that it was ≈øoe e≈øteemed from the fir≈øt in≈øtitution thereof by Chri≈øt. That which hee ≈øaith, how it ought to bee ≈øolemnized with vnleuened breade, was al≈øo, as the prote≈øtants, be≈øides the generall practi≈øe of the Latine church, a≈ø≈øure vs, the ordinance of Chri≈øt him≈øelfe, and the lawe it ≈øelfe, as a Prote≈øtant Archbi≈øhop with others thus
