That if any by imprudency ≈øhoulde ≈øhedd any of the blood of Chri≈øt, vppon the ground, hee ≈øhoulde doe penance fourtie dayes. If vppon the altare,
3. dayes. That if vpon the linen cloath vnder the chalice 4. dayes. If vpon the other linen cloathe 9. dayes. That hee ≈øhould lick vp the blood of Chri≈øt, that was ≈øhedd, or if that could not be, either pare it, or wa≈øhe it away, and ≈øo pared or wa≈øhed, either to bee burnt, or kept re≈øerued in the ≈øacrarie. Vt ≈øi quis per imprudentiam de ≈øanguine Chri≈øti effunderet in terram, paenitentiam ageret dies 40. Si ≈øuper altare, dies 3. Si ≈øuper linteum ≈øubstratum calici, 4. dies. Si ≈øuper aliud linteum, dies 9. Sanguinem Chri≈øti effu≈øum lambere, vel ≈øi id fieri non po≈øsit, aut radere, aut eluere: & ra≈øum aut lotum, vel comburi, vel in ≈øacrarium repo≈øitum ≈øeruari.

19. Therefore this Pope beeinge in all mens iudgements, Catholicks and Prote≈øtants. (Ioh. Bal. l. 1. act. Pontif. Rom. in Pio 1.) an holy Saint, and martyr, and to v≈øe a Prote≈øtant Bi≈øhops words, one that did many vvorks of true pietie in the field of the Christian church, multa verae pietatis opera, in agro Chri≈øtianae Eccle≈øiae feci≈ø≈øe perhibetur, was ≈øo wel acquainted with our Chri≈øtian Britans, and both claymed and exerci≈øed ≈øupreame ≈øpirituall iuri≈ødiction ouer all places, and par≈øons in matters of Religion by
the≈øe prote≈øtants. (Robert. Barnes in vit. Pij 1.) Quae ad Religionem ≈øpectant, √† ≈øuae dioce≈øeos ≈øynodis audtenda e≈ø≈øe ≈øtatuit: ≈øalua tamen Pontificia authoritate, of all natious this our Britanie mu≈øt needs then bee an honorer of ≈øacrificinge prei≈øts, and holy Ma≈ø≈øe, in this time, and euer after, vnto the generall conuer≈øion of it in the time of S. Eleutherius, betweene whome and this Saint Pius there were but two Popes, S. Anicetus and S. Sother, both which were not Popes many yeares by the≈øe prote≈øtaÃÑts, not 18. yeares by any of their accompts. Robert. Barn. in Pio 1. Anicet. & Sother. Io. Balaeus in act. Pontif. in ei≈ødem Edvv. Grimst. in the ≈øame Popes. Foxe Tom. 1.

20. And the≈øe Popes were ≈øo far from cro≈ø≈øinge with this, and others their predece≈ø≈øors in the≈øe points of ≈øupreamacy, ≈øacrificinge prei≈øts, and ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe, that by the confe≈ø≈øion of the≈øe prote≈øtants, they made decrees, which confirmed them all, makinge lawes bindinge all Archbi≈øhops, Primates, and Metropolitans, and ≈øhewing they were ≈øubiect to the Pope of Rome, and pre≈øcribed rules for all prei≈øts ≈øayinge Ma≈ø≈øe, and ≈øhauing their crownes, as they now
v≈øe in the Roman church, at this day, Archiepi≈øcopum √† ≈øuo Epi≈øcopo, aut coram primate, aut Romano Pontifice accu≈øandum e≈ø≈øe. Archiepi≈øcopos non Primates, ≈øed Metropolitanos appellandos e≈ø≈øe dixit, ni≈øi i≈øta praerogatiua √† Romano Pontifice concederetur. Capitis verticem ≈øpherulae instar radendum Sacerdotibus, praecopit. Ne Sacerdos celebraret, ni≈øi vt minimum duo ade≈øsent, ordinauit, ne Monacha pallam contrectaret, neu√® thus in aceram poneret, ≈øtatuit. So wee are ≈øure, the≈øe two holy Popes, Saints and Martyrs, were al≈øo ≈øacrificinge Popes, and all prei≈øts at that time vnder them, whether in Britanie or els where, beeinge ≈øubiect and obedient vnto them, were ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øts. And ≈øo wee are now come with a continuall deduction of the≈øe ≈øacred doctrines and practi≈øes, both in the church of this our Britanie, and others vntill the time of Pope and Saint Eleutherius, when and by who≈øe happy meanes hi≈øtorians commonly tell vs, this kingedome was generally conuerted to the faith of Chri≈øt.

div.head: THE XVI. CHAPTER. Wherin is proued by testimonies of prote≈øtants, and others, that this kingdome in the time of Kinge Lucius, was conuerted by ma≈øsing Preists, and Bishops, and the holy ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe, and ≈øuch ma≈øsinge preists and Bishops, continued here in honor, all this age.
div.p:
IN this happy generall conuer≈øion of this kingdome, no man of what Religion ≈øoeuer, can without prophane and irreligious boldnes, and impudentnes affirme in iudgement, that ≈øo wi≈øe and vertuous a Kinge, his Nobles, ≈øo many learned Druides, and others, e≈øpecially moued to Chri≈øtian Religion by the pa ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ ence, pietie, and vertue of the glorious Martyrs, and Saints of tho≈øe dayes by all antiquities, Ma≈ø≈øe ≈øayinge or Ma≈ø≈øe hearinge Chri≈øtians, would write ≈øuch ≈øuppliant letters, and ≈øend Amba≈ø≈øadors ≈øo longe a iorney, as from hence to Rome, to bee conuerted to any other Religion of Chri≈øt, but that ≈øacrificinge and ma≈ø≈øinge profe≈ø≈øion, by the miracles and ≈øanctity of who≈øe profe≈ø≈øors, they were ≈øo
moued and conuinced in iudgement, it was the only truth. Neither would or could Pope Eleutherius an holy & learned Saint, and ≈øucce≈ø≈øor onely to ≈øacrificinge ma≈ø≈øing Popes, and prei≈øts, recommend vnto King Lucius, and this kingdome, any other then ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øts, and Religion, or the learned me≈ø≈øengers of Kinge Lucius, as our prote≈øtants ≈øtile them. (Io. Bal. centur. 1. de ≈øcriptor. in Eluan. & Meduuin. Math. Parker. antiq. Brit. Godwin. Conuer≈ø. of Britanie.) con≈øent to any other, or ≈øo many renowned both prei≈øts and Bi≈øhops, as were ≈øtill remayninge in, or of this nation knowne ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øts, and bi≈øhops, ioyne with the Legats of Pope Eleutherius, in teaching and preachinge any other doctrine, or Religion.

2. Such were our renowned contrimen S. Man≈øuetus, yet liuinge except the Annals of Treuers, or the ≈øame name deceaue vs, con≈øecrated prei≈øt by S. Peter, and now remoued from Toul to Treuers, for the eccle≈øia≈øticall Annals of that archiepi≈øcopall ≈øea tell vs. (Petr. Mer≈ø≈øaeus Annal. Archiep. Treueren. 7.) that S. Man≈øuetus (I reade of no other of that name but our holy coutryman
in that time) was Archbishop of Treuers in the yeare of Christ 160. Man≈øuetus, qui huic nomini & vocationi ≈øuae vita proba, anno Domini 160. optim√® re≈øpondit. And S. Marcellus or Marcellinus our glorious contryman, who before his departure out of Britanie had moued Kinge Lucius to the faith of Chri≈øt, and after of the Tungers, and Archbi≈øhop al≈øo of Treuers returninge hither with the Popes Legats, was ≈øo renowned an in≈øtrument in the conuer≈øion of this kingdome, that the Annals of the place where hee was Archbi≈øhop ≈øay, that by the preachinge of this Saint, the third Bi≈øhop of Tungers Kinge Lucius was bapti≈øed. (Annal-Treuer. in S. Marcello.) S. Marcellus, alijs Marcellinus fuit Tungorum tertius Epi≈øcopus, & huius praedicatione Rex Angliae, id est Lucius, baptizatus e≈øt. The catalogue of the Bi≈øhops of Tunger giueth him greater honor, tellinge vs, that by his preaching hee conuerted Lucius Prince of Britanie with the whole nation to the faith of Chri≈øt. Lucium Britanniae Principem cum tota gente, ≈øua praedicatione ad Christum conuertit (Catalog. Epi≈øcop. Tungren≈ø. in S. Marcello.) And yet I haue ≈øhewed before, that the≈øe were ma≈ø≈øinge
prei≈øts and Bi≈øhops, as their predece≈ø≈øors in tho≈øe places, S Valerius, Eucharius, Maternus and others were.

3. The ≈øame I ≈øay of S. Tymotheus, our holy contryman, by his Mother S. Claudia beeinge a knowne ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øt, and one of the owners of that his, and his brother Nouatus and Si≈øters hou≈øe in Rome, ≈øo notoriou≈øly dedicated to bee the fir≈øt publick ma≈ø≈øinge church there: for this holy ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øt came hither in this time, and was ≈øo great a worker in the conuer≈øion of this his contrie, that the hi≈øtories of Treuers them≈øelues, which giue ≈øuch honor as before to their Archbi≈øhop S. Marcellus in this bu≈øines, yet freely al≈øo acknowledge that Kinge Lucius, was brought to the Religion of Chri≈øt by S. Timothie, whome they call S. Paules di≈øciple, perhaps becau≈øe S. Paul maketh ≈øo honorable a memory of his parents, S. Pudens, and Claudia (2. Timoth. 4.) & likely did baptize this S. Timothie, and therby called his di≈øciple though a very child, when S¬∑ Paul was martyred. (Martyrolog. Rom. die 20. Iunij Baron. annot. ib. Sur. Tom. 3. die 12. Iunij.) and the other S. Timothie his ≈øcholler dead
longe before. S. Lucius Britanniae Rex S. Timothei Apostoli Pauli di≈øcipuli cruditione ad Religionem Christi inductus e≈øt. (Petr. Mer≈øsaeus & Annal. Archiep. & eccl. Treuer. in S. Marcello.) If wee reflect vppon the Saints that were ≈øent cheife Legats hither, from Rome, S. Fugatius, and Damianus, the principall of them in all antiquities, as wee mu≈øt needs to giue them their due, that bee cho≈øen and ≈øelected meÃÑ, they mu≈øt needes be learned vertuous, and of mature age, and iudgment to be imploied in ≈øo weightie a bu≈øines, and as all hi≈øtories te≈øtifie they were, and ≈øo mu≈øt needes bee con≈øecrated ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øts, beeing ≈øacred by tho≈øe remembred ≈øacrificinge Popes, which neither did, nor could con≈øecrate any other, nor they bringe any other doctrine in this or any other points of Religion, but what they had receaued from tho≈øe holy Popes.

4. And to this, be≈øides ≈øo many generall Arguments, S. Gildas the mo≈øte auncient and renowned Britti≈øh Author is a particular witnes, if it could plea≈øe our prote≈øtants to publi≈øh it to the worlde, except that renowned Abbot Doctor Fecknham did abu≈øe his auditory in the fir≈øt parlament of
Queene Elizabeth in his publicke oration, which no indifferent man will thinke, hee did or dur≈øt to doe, for feare of open ≈øhame and confu≈øion, if hee ≈øhould haue aduouched an vntruth in that a≈ø≈øemblie. And yet ≈øpeaking principally of the ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe, then to bee condemned by that parlament, citeth Gildas in the proeme of his hi≈øtory, te≈øtifyinge that the ≈øame Religion, and church ≈øeruice, the ≈øacrifice of Ma≈øse which was then to bee abrogated was brought hither, and ≈øettled here in the Latine tonge by the Legats of Pope Eleutherius. (Abbot Fecknham orat. in parlam. 2. of Queene Elizabeth.) and all our cheife prote≈øtant antiquaries and hi≈øtorians of England, as their Bi≈øhops, Parker, Bale, Godwine, with others Go≈øteline, Powell, Foxe, Fulke, Middleton, Stowe, Holin≈øhed & others confidently affirming, that the Chri≈øtian Brittans neuer chaunged in any materiall thinge, that holy Religion which they receaued in the time of the Apo≈øtles, but con≈øtantly continued in the ≈øame, vntill the cominge of S. Augu≈øtine hither, from S. Gregory the great Pope of Rome, and after. Parker antiquitat. Britan. pag. 6.45.46. Balaeus l. 2. de act. Pontif. Rom.
in Gregor. 1. l. de ≈øcriptor. cent. 1. in August. Dronotho. Godwin. conuer≈ø. of Brit. Powel. annot. in l. 2. Giraldi Camb. de Itiner. Cambr. cap. 1. Foxe act. pag. 463. edit. an. 1576. Fulke answ. to a count Cath. pag. 40. Middelt. papistom. pag. 202 Stow hi≈øtor. in S. Augu≈øtine and Kinge Ethelbert. Holinsh. hi≈øtor. of Engl. cap. 21. pag. 102.

5. But as I haue proued before by the≈øe prote≈øtants and otherwi≈øe, the Britans by that Apo≈øtolicke man receaued the doctrine, profe≈ø≈øion, and practi≈øe of ≈øacrificinge prei≈øthood, prei≈øts, and ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe, and continued them vnto this time; ≈øoe I will demon≈øtrate by them and all antiquities hereafter, in euery age, that they kept and ob≈øerued the ≈øame inuiolablie to tho≈øe dayes, and after without interruption. And yet this is but a needles probation; for being ≈øo inuincibly proued before, that they receaued the≈øe holy doctrines and profe≈ø≈øions from the Apo≈øtles, and from them to the≈øe daies, if they had departed from them now, or after, they ≈øhould bee apparantly guiltie of error in departinge from tho≈øe truthes, which the Apo≈øtles, and all from them to the≈øe dayes continued. And if wee looke
into the catalogues of holy writers, in this time, who≈øe works bee pre≈øerued to po≈øteritie, wee ≈øhall ≈øee, that the holy ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe, and ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øts, were generally in al places in as great v≈øe and honour as at this day. The mo≈øte renowned writers of this time who≈øe bookes bee extant now, were S. Iu≈øtine, S. Irenaeus, and Tertullian, all they doe plainelie te≈øtifie, that the ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe, offeringe vp the ≈øacred body, and blood of Chri≈øt, was the generally v≈øed, & knowne ≈øacrifice of the Chri≈øtians in this time, in omni loco, in euerie place, ≈øaith S. Iu≈øtine. (Iu≈øtin. Dialog. cum Tryhone.) Eccle≈øia in vniuer≈øo mundo offert Deo. The church doth offer it in all the world, ≈øaith S. Irenaeus. (Irenaeus aduer≈ø. Haere≈ø. lib. 4. cap. 32.) therefore the church of Britanie mu≈øt needs offer it; and I haue proued by our Britti≈øh antiquities before, that Rome, Fraunce, and Britanie in the≈øe daies of Eleutherius, and Irenaeus which went to Rome in the papacy of S. Eleutherius, v≈øed one and the ≈øame order of Ma≈ø≈øe. And Tertullian that notorious ma≈ø≈øing Author, declaring how Chri≈øtiaÃÑ Religion was then dilated in the worlde, and the ≈øacrifice of
Ma≈ø≈øe was the common ≈øacrifice thereof, expre≈ø≈øely nameth this our Britanie to haue receaued the Chri≈øtian faith, and to agree with other Chri≈øtian nations therin. (Tertullian. de cultu Faeminar. cap. 11. l. ad Scapul. cap. 2. l. de orat. cap 14. l. de vel. Virg. cap. 9. l. contra Iudaeos.) & S. Iohn Chri≈øo≈øtome ≈øpeaking of this conuer≈øion of our Britans, witne≈ø≈øeth manife≈øtly, and our prote≈øtants acknowledge it for truth, that the Britti≈øh churches then founded, which were many had altars, for their prei≈øts, erected in them. (Chri≈øostom. ≈øerm¬∑ de Pentecost. protest. Theater of great Britanie l. 6. ¬ß. 12.) which as is confe≈ø≈øed before by the≈øe prote≈øtants, neither were, nor could in Chri≈øtian Religion bee ordeyned but for ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øts, and the ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe, as wee finde in the mo≈øte auncient churches of this nation; as S. Io≈øephs dedicated to our Lady at Gla≈øteÃÑ burie. (Antiquit Glaston. Capgrau. in S. Patricio M. S. antiq. in Lucio.) S. Martins at Canterbury, and the olde church at Winche≈øter, where as we read there were Chri≈øtian altares, ≈øo al≈øo that the ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe was from their fir≈øt foundation offered on them. (Bed. hist. l. 1. cap. 27. Galfr.
Monum. l. 11. histor. cap. 4. Stowe hi≈øtor. in Constantine ≈øonne of Cador. &c.) ≈øo of S. Peters church in Cornhill in London and others. And S. Damianus and Phaganus the cheife Legats of S. Eleutherius, bearing ≈øo great deuotion to the ma≈ø≈øing church builded by S. Io≈øeph at Gla≈øtenbury, that they them≈øelues continued, and dwelled there ≈øome time, and ≈øettled twelue of their company to continue there duringe their liues, mu≈øt needs bee ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øts, as all had here euer beene from the Apo≈øtles time: in which faith and Religion this holy Pope, as our prote≈øtants with al antiquities a≈ø≈øure vs, confirmed the kingdome of Britanie: Eleutherius vt bonus paterfamilias effecit, vt confirmatis & con≈øolidatis Britannis in ≈øu≈øcepta prius ab Apostolis doctrina, totum illud regnum, in eius fidei verba iuraret. Ioh. Bal. l. 1. de act. Pontif. Rom. in Eleutherio.

6. So that by this Prote≈øtant Bi≈øhop, and his and other authorities, tho≈øe doctrines of ≈øacrificinge prei≈øts and Ma≈ø≈øe which from the Apo≈øtles dayes, as I haue aboundantly proued, had without di≈øcontinuance euer continued here in diuers particular places and par≈øons, were now generally by this
holy Pope, and his ma≈ø≈øinge Legats, e≈øtabli≈øhed and confirmed in this kingedome: confirmatis, & con≈øolidatis, and this Pope highly commeÃÑded for that his general confirmation, vt bonus paterfamilias. And by their fir≈øt Archbi≈øhop with others before, and as I haue proued by continuall deduction, the order and forme of Ma≈ø≈øe which S. Peter deliuered to the church, was ≈øtill continued after this time, without any materiall chaunge, alteration, addition, or diminution. Neither doth any Prote≈øtant Author challenge S. Eleutherius, of any innouation in Religion, but the contrary: how hee condemned all innouators therein as Tatianus and the Seuerians, makinge a decree again≈øt them, and the knowne Religion of Chri≈øt, his ≈øacrificinge Religion, as before is proued was much increa≈øed by him. Sub hoc Pontifice caepit Eccle≈øia e≈ø≈øe ≈øecurior, ob id Christianorum Religio plurimum aucta est. And yet no chaunge at all therin. (Bal. & Robert. Barnes in vita Eleutherij. Eleutherius epi≈øt. decretal. ad prouincias Gall. To. 1. conc. Io. Bal. act. Pont. Rom. l. 1. in Eleutherio. Rob. Barn in vit. Pontif. Rom. in eodem.) therefore all tho≈øe Bi≈øhops, & prei≈øts
which by all writers hee con≈øecrated, mu≈øt needs bee ma≈ø≈øinge Bi≈øhops, and prei≈øts, as all tho≈øe three Archbi≈øhops, & 28. Bi≈øhops, which he con≈øecrated, or confirmed for this kingdome renowned in hi≈øtories, and all the prei≈øts of this our Britanie vnder them, mu≈øt needes bee ma≈ø≈øing Archbi≈øhops, Bi≈øhops, and prei≈øts. Who≈øe ≈øucce≈ø≈øion here continued vnto the conuer≈øion of the Saxons, and after by all hi≈øtories, and vntill both tho≈øe peoples vnited them≈øelues, as well in this ma≈ø≈øinge and ≈øacrificinge doctrine, which both the Britans, and Saxons had euer ob≈øerued from their fir≈øt conuer≈øions, as in al other points of Chri≈øtian Religion. The names of many of them I haue remembred in other places.

7. And concerninge the ≈øupreame ≈øpirituall power, which this holy Pope both claimed, and exerci≈øed, both in this kingedome, to ≈øettle the≈øe ≈øacred points of Religion here, and in other nations, the≈øe prote≈øtants a≈ø≈øure vs, it was as great and ample, as euer any his ≈øucce≈ø≈øors did, or now doe challenge in ≈øuch affaires. The≈øe men tell vs. (Rob¬∑ Barnes in vit. Eleutherij. protest. annot. Mag. in Matth. We≈øtm. an. 188.)
hee condemned hereticks, and made decrees again≈øt them; he made lawes binding all cleargie men, & in the ca≈øes of Bi≈øhops, re≈øerued judgement to the ≈øee of Rome, vt nihil ni≈øi apud Pontificem definiretur. In his epi≈øtle to Kinge Lucius, ≈øo recommended by our prote≈øtants, hee pre≈øcribeth what lawes hee was to v≈øe. Hee appointeth the limits and bounds of Britanie, as the≈øe men witnes in the lawes of Kinge Edward t ‚Ä¢ e Confe≈ø≈øor. His Legats di≈øpo≈øed of all ≈øpirituall things here, in that time, and he by his papal authoritie confirmed them. And ≈øo they continued vntil here≈øie and infidelity in the Pagan Saxons time did ouerthrowe them, as all hi≈øtories and antiquities, Britti≈øh, or Saxon, Catholicks or prote≈øtants, as their Bi≈øhops, Parker, Bale and Godwine, with Cambden, Powell, Holin≈øhed, Stowe, and others cited in other places are witne≈ø≈øes. Therefore it will bee but a ≈øuperogated worke, to proceede further to followinge ages, yet for a generall and compleate content to all, I wil though with more breuitie, ≈øpeake al≈øo of them, and here end this ≈øecond age, or hundred of yeares, Pope Eleutherius dyinge in the later ende
thereof, and Kinge Lucius not longe after in the beginninge of the next age, and Pope and S. Victor, the immediate ≈øucce≈ø≈øor of S. Eleutherius both endinge this, and giuing entrance to the next en≈øuinge age, and centenary of the yeares of Chri≈øt by his papall regiment.

div.head: THE THIRD AGE, OR HVNDRED YEARES OF CHRIST.

THE XVII. CHAPTER. How notwithstandinge the manifold tumults, and per≈øecution of Chri≈øtian Religion, in this kingdome of Britanie, in this third hundred yeares, yet the holy ≈øacrifice of Ma≈øse, ≈øacrificinge and ma≈øsinge prei≈øts, and Bishops ≈øtil here continued, without any totall di≈øcontinuance.
div.p:
KInge Lucius dyinge, as Matthew of We≈øtmini≈øter with others writeth, in the yeare of Chri≈øt 201. the fir≈øt of this third hundred yeare, without heire; This our kingdome by that meanes in the beginning of this age was pitifully vexed with warrs,
and tumults; & towards the later end therof lamentably tormented, and afflicted (as the whole Chri≈øtian worlde almo≈øte then was) with the mo≈øte cruell and barbarous per≈øecution of Diocletian, in which among other mi≈øeries, all monuments of Chri≈øtian Religion, ≈øo neare as he could, were ruined and de≈øtroyed; whereby it came to pa≈ø≈øe, that little memory of eccle≈øia≈øticall things then, in this nation is left to po≈øteritie, yet ≈øufficient is to be found, that together with the Popes ≈øupreamacy in ≈øuch affaires, the holy ≈øacrificinge prei≈øthood, the ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe, and diuers renowned ≈øacrificinge Bi≈øhops and prei≈øts, here ≈øtill continued without di≈øcontinuance, in al this age, notwith≈øtandinge ≈øo huge an army of mo≈øte ≈øauage, and cruell enemies ≈øtill fightinge again≈øt them. Matth. Westm. an. gratiae 201. Bed. l. 1. histor. c. 4.6. Parker. antiquit. Britan. Godwin. conuer≈ø. of Britanie. Stowe hi≈øtor. in K. Lucius. Theater of great Brit. l. 6. Foxe Tom. 1. Holinsh. histor. of Engl. Galfr. Monum. hist. Britan. l. 5. cap. 1.2.3.4.5.6.7. Ponticus Viran. Brit. hi≈øtor. l. 5. Gildas l. de excid. & conque≈øt. Britan. cap. 7.8.

2. For Fir≈øt our cheife prote≈øtants haue
told vs before, that S. Peters Ma≈øte continued in v≈øe in the church without any chaunge, vnto the time of Pope and S. Zepherine, which was next ≈øucce≈ø≈øor to S. Victor, therefore by their allowance, wee haue the ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe, a ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øthood, and prei≈øts to offer that holie ≈øacrifice all his time. Therefore when wee finde by many antiquities and hi≈øtorians, a≈øwell Catholicks as Prote≈øtants, that hee ≈øent many learned prei≈øts and preachers into this kingedome, e≈øpecially the more northren parts thereof, which wee now cal Scotland, wee mu≈øt needes if wee had noe other argument, conclude, that they were ≈øacrificinge, and ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øts, becau≈øe they receaued both their con≈øecration, and iuri≈ødiction from ≈øoe knowne a ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øt, and Pope his authoritie. Yet to make this matter more euident, and ≈øhew the ≈øupreame ≈øpirituall power which hee v≈øed euen in this, be≈øides that which he both claimed and exerci≈øed in excommunicatinge the church of A≈øia for their not due ob≈øeruation of Ea≈øter, hee confirmed the order and in≈øtitution of his predece≈ø≈øor S. Eleutherius, in ≈øubiectinge all the churches, and
Chri≈øtians of that part of Britany now termed ScotlaÃÑd, to the Archbi≈øhop of Yorke, a ma≈ø≈øing prei≈øt & Prelate, as I haue ≈øhewed before, the≈øe parts and countries then beeing temporally ruled by diuers temporall Kings, or Princes, and at difference or enmity at that time one with an other. And to make this ReligioÃÑ more permanent with that rude nation, the Scots them≈øelues then began to study diuinitie. (Hector Boeth. Scot. hi≈øtor. l. 6. fol. 89. pag. 2.) beeing therin instructed by tho≈øe preists which Pope Victor ≈øent thither euen to the vttermost part therof to propagate Christian Religion. Incepere & nostri tum primum, ≈øacras colere literas, Sacerdotibus praeceptoribus, quos Victor Pontifex Maximus, ad Chri≈øti dogma propalandum in extremam mi≈øerat Albionem. Which was in the yeare of Chri≈øt 203. Humanae ≈øalutis tertius ≈øupra ducente≈øsimum. And euer continued in the ≈øame as theire hi≈øtorians contend, vnto the≈øe dayes of here≈øie, no≈øtri qua fide & pietate instituti ≈øemel fuerunt hactenus erroribus a≈øpernatis, per≈øeuerant. Which was written in the yeare of Chri≈øt 1526. Anno ≈øalutis Chri≈øtianae ≈øexto & vige≈øimo ≈øupra, mille≈øimum quingente≈øimum.

3. So longe and longer the≈øe ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øts & ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe continued there with honor, by their writers, and our Engli≈øh Prote≈øtants affirme as much in the≈øe termes. (Edw. Grim≈øton. in the est. of the K. of great Britanie pag. 20. cap. 17.) Scotland receaued the Chri≈øtian faith in the time of Pope Victor the first, in the yeare 203. and idolatry did quite cea≈øe, vnder Kinge Craknite, who died in the yeare 313. Cele≈øtine the fir≈øt ≈øent Palladius thither to roote out the Pelagian here≈øie, which began to encrea≈øe there vnder Eugenius the ≈øeconde, who died in the yeare 460. ≈øince this time the realme continued longe in the profe≈øsion of the Romish church, vntill the≈øe later dayes, the daies of Kinge Iames, our pre≈øent ≈øoueraigne, as hee there expre≈ø≈øeth. Therefore ≈øeeing the profe≈ø≈øion of the Romane church, which froÃÑ the beginning by the≈øe authorities, and te≈øtimonies, both Catholicke and Prote≈øtant euer continued there, was the profe≈ø≈øion of the ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe, and ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øts, ≈øuch was the profe≈ø≈øion euer vntill now in tho≈øe parts. Againe this part of this Iland was ≈øubiected both by Pope Eleutherius, and Victor, to the Archbi≈øhop of Yorke a ma≈ø≈øing Prelate,
either S. Theodo≈øius or S. Samp≈øon, therefore the prei≈øtes ≈øubiect to that ≈øee, mu≈øt needs bee ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øts. (Harri≈øon de≈øcription of Britanie in K. Lucius. Godwin Catalog. in Yorke pag. 555. edit. an. 1515.) and both S. Gildas, S. Bede and all antiquities a≈ø≈øure vs, that this Religion was pre≈øerued in peace, and quiet here, vnto the per≈øecution of Diocletian. Gild. l. de excid. Britan. cap. 7. Bed. histor. eccl. l. 1. cap. 4. antiq. Winton. apud Godw. Catal. in Winchester. 1.) and the Annals of Scotland tell vs expre≈ø≈øelie, of the altars chalices, patens, and all ve≈ø≈øels, in≈øtruments, and ornaments v≈øed in the holy ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe, to haue bene in honorable, and publicke v≈øe in this time in that contry. (Hector Boeth. Scot. hi≈øtor. l. 6. fol. 102.

4. And if we leaue Britanie and returne againe to Rome, and the Pope there, S. Zepherine, the≈øe prote≈øtants a≈ø≈øure vs, he was, rei diuinae magis quam humanae inteÃÑtus, a man more giuen to diuine then humaine affaires, a Prote≈øtant Bi≈øhops words: and yet they ab≈øolutly teache, hee claimed and exerci≈øed ≈øupreame ≈øpirituall iuri≈ødiction, and made decrees, concerninge the holy ≈øacrifice of
Ma≈ø≈øe, of what mater, the chalice and paten, in, and on which the body and blood of Chri≈øt ≈øhould be con≈øecrated, in that ≈øacrifice, were to bee made, and how prei≈øts ought to bee pre≈øent when the Bi≈øhop celebrated the ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe, cum Epi≈øcopus celebraret Mi≈øsae ≈øacra iu≈øsit omnes presbyteros ade≈ø≈øe. (Bal. in act. Pontif. Rom. l. 1. in Zepherino. Edw. Grim≈øton pag. 436. in Zepherin. Rob. Barnes in vit. Pontif. Rom. in Zepherin. alij. Sacer) and by the ≈øentence of their fir≈øt Prote≈øtant Archbi≈øhop, hee was ≈øo far from doing any di≈øhonor to this holy ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe, that, ad pulchriorem materiam formamque mutare voluit. The chaunge hee made, was for the more honor therof. Math. Parker antiquitat. Britan. pag. 47. Magdeb. cent. 1. cap. 5 col. 146.) beeing nothing but that I cited before of cau≈øing the ≈øacrificing in≈øtruments to be made of a better matter, making no other chaunge at al therin. And within few yeares after, the next Pope but one, Vrbanus the fir≈øt, as the≈øe prote≈øtants a≈ø≈øure vs made a lawe, that eueÃÑ in the poorer churches the ≈øacrificinge ve≈ø≈øels ≈øhould either bee of gold, ≈øiluer, or tinne. Ne va≈øa ≈øacra vitrea, ≈øed aut aurea, aut argen ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ ea,
aut ≈øtannea in inopioribus Eccle≈øijs e≈ø≈øent, legem tulit. (Rob. Barnes in Vrban. 1. Edw. Grimston. e≈øtate of the church of Rome in Vrban. 1. pag. 436. Magdeb. cent. 1. cap. 6. col. 146.) and that Pope Fabian an holy Saint, and miraculou≈øly cho≈øen to the papall dignitie, made a decree about the ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe, what prei≈øts were to bee allowed to ≈øay Ma≈ø≈øe. And they put it out of all que≈øtion, that the mo≈øt renowned other Fathers of this age, as Tertullian S. Ciprian, with others taught and maintained this doctrine of the ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe. Magdeburg. cent. 1. cap. 4. col. 83. titul. de Euchari≈øt. & ≈øacrificio. ≈øo they write of Pope Stephen, Faelix & Sixtus in this age, whom they acknowledge for holy Saints, and open maintayners and practi≈øers of this ble≈ø≈øed ≈øacrifice, ≈øhewinge how in their time, the whole canon was ≈øecretly read, as is now ob≈øerued. Sixtus, dum Sacerdos canonem ante celebrationem ≈øub ≈øilentio legeret, vt in populo Sanctus triplicatum caneretur, in≈øtituit. And neither bringe any Pope, or Father to the contrary, or any Pope altered any thinge in this holy ≈øacrifice, which they doe or can di≈ølike.

5. And concerning communion it ≈øelfe in one onely kinde, by the laitie, and ≈øuch as ≈øaide not Ma≈ø≈øe, now v≈øed in the Latine church, with much di≈ølike of many prote≈øtants, the≈øe prote≈øtants them≈øelues confe≈ø≈øe vnto vs. (Magdeburgen¬∑ cent. 3. cap. 6. de ritib. circa caenam col. 149) that it was the cu≈øtome of the church of Rome, of Italy, and with other Bi≈øhops for the communicants, to receaue onely vnder the forme of bread. And ≈øome of our Engli≈øh Prote≈øtants as Ma≈øter Parkins. (Parkin≈øus l. demon≈øtr. problem. pag. 155.) giueth many in≈øtances and examples of ≈øuch communicating. And amonge others bringeth S. Ciprian to bee a witnes hereof, writinge in this time, as al≈øo the Prote≈øtants of Germany doe, teachinge this cu≈øtome in tho≈øe churches of Rome, Italy, and others to haue bene more auncient then this time: and mo≈øte certaine it is, that both S. Ciprian, and Tertullian before him, te≈øtifie it was al≈øo ≈øoe v≈øed in Afrike to communicate onely vnder the forme of blood. (Ciprian. l. de lap≈ø. & l. de ≈øpectacul. Tertullia. l. 2. ad Vxorem. cap. 5.) S. Irenaeus proueth the ≈øame of the age before; and both S. Chri≈øo≈øtome, or who≈øoeuer author
of the opus imperfectuÃÑ ≈øuper Matthaeum, S. Augu≈øtine, I≈øichius, S. Bede, Theophilact, and others doe ≈øo expound, that act & example of Chri≈øt at Emaus, in S. Lukes Gho≈øpell, after his re≈øurrection, thus by our prote≈øtants tran≈ølation: hee tooke bread, and ble≈ø≈øed it, and brake, and gaue to them. (Homil. 16. operis imperfect. ≈øupr. Matth. Augu≈øt. con≈øen≈ø. Euang. l. 3. c. 25. I≈øych. l. 2. in Leuit. c. 9. Bed. & Theop. in c. 24. Luc. cap. 24. v. 30.) the ≈øame expo≈øition is made of breakinge of breade, in the 2. and 20. chapter of the acts of the Apo≈øtles, by the auncient author, of that vnperfect worke, and our learned coutrimen, Ionas Aurelianen≈øis, and S. Bede, and the Syriake text readeth, in fractione Eucharistiae, in breakinge the Euchari≈øt. And Iohn Caluine him≈øelfe doth ≈øo plainely expounde the later place of the 20. chapter. Actor. cap. 2. v. 42. cap. 20. v. 7. Homil. 17. operis imperfecti. Beda ad cap. 20. act. Ionas Aurelianen. l. 3. de Imaginib. text. Syriac¬∑ Caluin. in act. 20.

6. And to make all ≈øure, the parlament ≈øtatute of three Prote≈øtant Princes, Kinge Edward 6. Queene Elizabeth, and Kinge Iames. (Statut. parlam¬∑ an. 1. Edw. 6. an. 1.
Elizab, and an. 1. Iacobi Abridg. of stat. titul. ≈øeruice and Sacram.) doth warrant vs, that in the primatiue church, communion was often v≈øed in one only kinde. And the three fir≈øt Euangeli≈øts S. Matthew, Marke and Luke ar ample witne≈ø≈øes, that the words of Chri≈øt, drinke you all of this (the ground of prote≈øtants in this contention) were onely pre≈øent with him, and by him at that time made prei≈øts by all antiquities. (Matth. cap. 26. v. 20. Marc. cap. 14. ver. 17.18. Luc. c. 22. v. 14.) and ≈øo the words and commaundement could not po≈ø≈øibly bee generall, for that cau≈øe, and if they had beene generall, all the whole Chri≈øtian worlde, in all ages Catholicks from the beginninge, and prote≈øtants ≈øince their new cominge, had beene, and ar guiltie of tran≈øgre≈ø≈øinge that in≈øtitution and commaundement. Therfore ≈øeeing wee cannot finde any innouation in the≈øe mi≈øteries, in this time, let vs ≈øeeke out ≈øome more ma≈ø≈øing prei≈øts of this nation, in this tempe≈øtuous ≈øea≈øon. For ≈øuch we finde particularly at Rome S. Mellanius as the Romane Martyrologe with others nameth him, but by the auncient Manu≈øcript hi≈øtory of his life and Capgraue,
S. Mellon. He beeing a noble Britane, and going hence to Rome to pay the tribute of his contry and ≈øerue the Emperor, was conuerted to the faith of Chri≈øt, by the ma≈ø≈øing Pope S. Stephen, and by him takinge fir≈øt all inferior orders, was made a ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øt. Quem praefatus Papa ≈øibi adhaerentem per omnes Eccle≈øiae gradus v≈øque ad Sacerdotium promouit. (Martyrolog. Rom. die 22. Octob. Baron. ib. Vincent. l. 11. c. 74. Petr. de natal. l. 9. c. 93. Demochar. contr. Caluin. M. S. antiq. de vita S. Mellonis. Ioh. Capgrau. in catal. in S. Mellone Epi≈øcopo.) and was ≈øo deuout a ≈øayer of Ma≈ø≈øe, that among other times, as hee was ≈øayinge Ma≈ø≈øe, an Angell openly appeared both to the holy Pope, and him, at the right hand of the altare, and Ma≈ø≈øe beeing ended de≈øigned him to goe to Rouen in Normandy, where hee was the ≈øecond Bi≈øhop, next to S. Nica≈øius, as the Annals of that church are witne≈ø≈øe, and continued there a ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øt, and Bi≈øhop ≈øent from that ma≈ø≈øinge Pope, vntill about the yeare of Chri≈øt 280. which being before the beginninge of the per≈øecution of Diocletian, wee had then here in Britanie great numbers of ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øts, and Bi≈øhops,
as I haue proued before by our be≈øt antiquities.

7. And though for that time wee are in a great defect and want of monuments, yet wee haue warrant enough, that both in, and after that per≈øecution, wee had both ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øts and Bi≈øhops to continue our hierarchicall ≈øucce≈ø≈øion for the pre≈øent time of the per≈øecution in this part of Britanie, where the Romans ruled, & the per≈øecution by that oportunitie and power raged, wee mu≈øt not looke into our churches and altars de≈øtroyed for publick v≈øe of the≈øe holy points of Religion; for as our be≈øt and mo≈øte auncient author, S. Gildas writeth, the Chri≈øtians that remained, did hide them≈øelues, in woods, and de≈øerts and hidden caues. Qui ≈øuperfuerant ≈øiluis ac de≈øertis abditi≈øque ≈øpeluncis ≈øe occultauere. (Gildas l. de excid. & conq. Biitan. cap, 8.) S. Bede and others after both Catholicks and prote≈øtants haue the like. (Bed. hi≈øtor. Eccl. Angl. l. 1. cap. 8. Matth. Westm. in Dioclet. Theater of Brit. 16. Stowe Holinsh. histor. of Eng.) but if wee goe into the Northern parts, beyond the Romans walland bounds, where the Chri≈øtian Britans and Scots vnder King Crathlint
that renowned glory of that nation then reigned, we ≈øhal finde both Ma≈ø≈øe, and ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øts of this our part of Britanie flying thither in honor, and offeringe publicklie the mo≈øte holy ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe, with great reuerence and ≈øolemnitie: ≈øuch were the holy ma≈øsinge preist and Bishop S. Amphibalus, Modocus, Pri≈øcus, Calanus, Ferranus, Ambianus, and very many others, alijque permulti, preachinge the doctrine of Chri≈øt in all the Scotti≈øh contries, Christi ≈øeruatoris doctrinam omnes per Scotorum regiones concionando multis pij≈øque ≈øudoribus ≈øeminantes. Hector. Boeth. Scot. hi≈øtor. l. 6. fol. 102. Veremund. apud eund. ib. Holinsh. hi≈øtor. of Scotland in K. Crathlint.

8. And among the≈øe holy doctrines, that of holy Ma≈ø≈øe, ≈øacrificing prei≈øts, & prei≈øthood were ≈øo honorable, and renowned, that this religious Kinge Crathlint did build a cathedrall church, for that our per≈øecuted ma≈ø≈øinge Bi≈øhop, and prei≈øts, endowinge it with great guifts, and al things nece≈ø≈øary for the honorable and reuerent ≈øayinge of Ma≈ø≈øe, as chalices, patens, Candlesticks, and other ≈øuch thinges, requi≈øite for the v≈øe of ≈øacrifice, made of ≈øiluer and gold, and
an altare inclo≈øed with copper and bra≈ø≈øe. Sed & Crathlintus Rex, ≈øacra Antistitis aedem muneribus ornauit ampli≈øsimis, calicibus, patenis, candelabris, alij≈øque ≈øimilibus, ad ≈øacrorum v≈øum commodis, ex argento auroque fabrefactis, altarique cupro, & aere clau≈øo. And that the≈øe and many others flyinge thither, in this time were of this part of Britanie, where the Engli≈øh inhabite, it is plaine by the≈øe hi≈øtories: ≈øo that it is mo≈øte manife≈øt, that all this third age or hundred yeeres of Chri≈øt, the holy ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe, ma≈ø≈øing prei≈øts, & prei≈øthood, ≈øtil coÃÑtinued in al this kingdome of great Britanie, although not in ≈øuch ≈øplendor, and glory, by rea≈øon of the great afflictions, and mi≈øeries of tho≈øe dayes: as in better times, I will make mention of diuers our ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øts, and Bi≈øhops, that e≈øcaped death, and ≈øuruiued after this per≈øecution, in the next age, and ≈øo end with this.

div.head: THE FOVRTH AGE, OR HVNDRED YEARES OF CHRIST.

THE XVIII. CHAPTER. How the holy ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe, ≈øacrificing and ma≈øsinge preisthood, prei≈øts and Bi≈øhops continued in this kingdome of great Britanie in al this age, without any interruption or di≈øcontinuance.
div.p:
IN the beginninge of this age, and fourth hundred yeare, the ≈øtate of the church of Chri≈øt was little different, either in Britanie, or any other nation, from that wherin it was in the later end of the former, for as our hi≈øtories tell vs, the per≈øecution begun by Diocletian did not cea≈øe, although not in ≈øuch extremitie of rigour, vntill CoÃÑ ≈øtantine the great our contriman had bene Emperor ≈øome yeares, in the ≈øeuenth yeare of his Empire by Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter, Florentius Wigornien≈øis, and others: caepta ≈øemel per≈øecutio, v≈øque ad ≈øeptimuÃÑ annum Constantini feruere non ce≈ø≈øauit. (Matth. We≈øtm. an. gratiae 304. Florent. Wigorn. an. 299. al. 321.) neither doe our Scotti≈øh writers, Veremundus,
Hector Boethius, and others differ herein, for they are witne≈ø≈øes, that manie holy Chri≈øtians of this ≈øouthern part of Britanie, in the time of Con≈øtantius, fledd to the Picts, and Scots, for ≈øuccour, and were there religiou≈øly entertained by King Crathlint. (Veremund. apud Hect. Boeth. l. 6. Scotor. histor. fol. 102. pag. 1.) Constantius Diocletiani more in Britannia Christianae Religioni fuerit in≈øidiatus. Vnde magnus piorum numerus per≈øequeÃÑtium ≈øaeuitiam declinare cupiens, ad Scotos & Pictos coÃÑce≈øsit. Hos Crathlintos Rex, ad ≈øe confugientes beneuolo affectu ≈øu≈øcepit. And the Romane hi≈øtories agree with this, teachinge, that in the beginning of the Empire of Con≈øtantine, & vntill he had the vi≈øion of the Cro≈ø≈øe, and was admoni≈øhed to ≈øeeke and ≈øend for S. Silue≈øter, then Pope, to baptize him, the per≈øecution ≈øtill continued, and S. Silue≈øter hid him≈øelf in the mountaine Soracte, which an Engli≈øh Prote≈øtant Bi≈øhop with the Italian writers thus relateth. (Io. Bal. l. 1. de act. Rom. Pont. in Siluestro.) At postquam ≈øoboles Helenae ≈øancti≈øsima, Cae≈øar Constantinus, apud diuos homine≈øque fauorem nactus, in excel≈øo vidit crucis aere formam. Tunc redijt tandem
Romam, Soracte relicto, atque ≈øub Augu≈øto magnos ≈øortitus honores.

2. Yet notwith≈øtanding this ≈øecret profe≈ø≈øion and practi≈øe of Chri≈øtian Religion, in this time wee haue certaine te≈øtimonies of the continuance of the≈øe holy doctrines of the ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe, ≈øacrificing prei≈øts, and prei≈øthood, in this our Britanie in tho≈øe dayes. For our Scotti≈øh hi≈øtorians before alleaged, giue euidence, that tho≈øe ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øts which I haue named before, did I liue a while after this time, and that in the i≈øle Mona, there was a ≈øacrificinge Bi≈øhop, and prei≈øts that ≈øaid Ma≈ø≈øe, with ≈øuch ritche ornaments and in≈øtruments for that time as I haue de≈øcribed, and that this ma≈ø≈øinge Bi≈øhops name was Amphibalus Bi≈øhop of Soder, beeing a Britane, liued, and died there an old man, longe after the death of S. Amphibalus our martir. Amphibalus Brito vir in≈øigni pietate, primus Antistes ibi creatus, Chri≈øti dogma per Scotorum Pictorumque Regiones propalando, multa contra Gentilium Religionem dicendo, ≈øcribendoque glorio≈øum & Christiano viro plan√® dignum, multa ≈øenectute viuendo fe≈ø≈øus, faelicemque ≈øortitus e≈øt finem. (Boeth. & Veremund. ≈øup. l. 6. histor.
Scot.) where be≈øides the time not agreeing, and the old age wherein this S. Amphibalus liued and died a glorious confe≈ø≈øor, but no Martyr, the contry whence hee was a Britan, Amphibalus Brito, proue it was an other different Saint, from the Martyr Amphibalus, of whome we doe not reade that hee was a Bi≈øhop, nor a Britan, but coming hither from other places of per≈øecution, as the writers of his life are witne≈ø≈øes. Vir quidam meritis & doctrina clarus nomine Amphibalus, tran≈øiens in Britanniam verolamina Domino ducente perue ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ it. (M. S. antiq & Author vitae S. Albani antiquus in vit. S. Albani Ioh. Capgrauius & alij in vit S. Albani.) which he al≈øo him≈øelfe doth witnes in this words to S. Alban My Lord Ie≈øus Christ the ≈øonne of the liuinge God, hath pre≈øerued mee from daungers, and for the ≈øaluation of many, ≈øent mee into this nation. Dominus meus Ie≈øus Chri≈øtus filius Dei viui ≈øecurum inter di≈øcrimina me custodiuit: & pro multorum ≈øalute ad istam me mi≈øit prouinciam.

Certainely this hou≈øell which wee doe now halow at Gods altare, is a remembrance of Christs body, which he offered for vs, and of his blood, which hee shed for vs: So hee him≈øelfe commaunded, doe this in my remembrance. Once ≈øuffered Christ by him≈øelfe, but yet neuerthele≈ø≈øe his ≈øufferinge is daily renevved at this ≈øupper, through mi≈øtery of the holy hou≈øel. And againe: In that holy hou≈øel, there is one thing in it ≈øeene, and an other vnderstoode. That
vvhich is there ≈øeene hath bodily shape: and that vvee doe there vnder≈øtand, hath gho≈øtly might. The hou≈øell is dealed into ≈øondry parts, chevved betvveene teeth, and ≈øent into the belly: hovvbeit neuerthele≈ø≈øe after ghostlie might, it is all in euery part. Many receaue that holy body, and yet notvvith≈øtandinge, it is ≈øo all in euery part, after ghostly mi≈øtery.

13. And ≈øhewing how the Pa≈øchal Lambe was a figure of this holy ≈øacrifice of Chri≈øt, the Lambe of Innocency, and God, which taketh away the ≈øins of the worlde, as in holy Ma≈ø≈øe wee ≈øo pray vnto Chri≈øt there pre≈øent, vnder that denomination, they teach it was the v≈øe and cu≈øtome of our Chri≈øtians in Britanie in that time, to doe the ≈øame, the very words of that olde britti≈øh publicke homely by our prote≈øtants tran≈ølation bee thus: That innocent Lambe vvhich the olde I≈øraelites did then kill, had ≈øignification after ghostly vnder≈øtandinge, of Chri≈øts ≈øufferinge, vvho vnguiltie shedd his blood for our redemption. Hereof ≈øinge Gods ≈øeruants at euery Ma≈øse, Agnus Dei qui tollis peccata mundi, mi≈øerere nobis: That is in our ≈øpeache: Thou Lambe of God, that take≈øt away the ≈øinnes of the worlde, haue
mercie vpon vs. Where wee ≈øee plainelie acknowledged, by this ≈øo auncient antiquitie, in this fourth hundred yeare, and the prote≈øtants them≈øelues, ≈øo tran≈ølatinge and propo≈øinge it, that generally in that time, the holy ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe was offered by the Bi≈øhops, and prei≈øts of Britanie in all places, and all the ≈øeruants of God did then acknowledge, & profe≈ø≈øe, that Chri≈øt the true Lambe of God that taketh away the ≈øinnes of the world was therin offered, and there pre≈øent, prayed vnto by all Gods ≈øeruants. Which is as much as any ma≈ø≈øing prei≈øt, Bi≈øhop, or Pope holdeth, teacheth, or practi≈øeth at this time concerning the≈øe things.

14. And becau≈øe in this age this our kingedome had by agreement both of auncient and late writers, and by prote≈øtants them≈øelues. (Bal. l. de ≈øcriptor. in Palladio & Niniano.) a greate dependance of Rome, both in temporall and ≈øpiritual affaires, and many of our cheife≈øt cleargie men, as S. Teruanus, and S. Ninianus tho≈øe two glorious NorthreÃÑ Bi≈øhops, had both their education, in≈øtruction, ordination, and iuri≈ødiction from thence, as many others had
at this time, and the Bi≈øhops of Rome are ≈øo much charged by our prote≈øtant writers for adding vnto the holy ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe, I will only v≈øe the≈øe mens authority, which ≈øay they will ≈øet downe what euerie Pope did add, Quid alij Pontifices addiderint, ≈øuo loco in Pontificijs actis dicetur. And they are ≈øo farr from not performinge their promi≈øe in this, that they rather relate more then le≈ø≈øe added by the≈øe holy Popes, as will bee made euident by theire owne te≈øtimonies hereafter. Yet for more ample ≈øatisfaction let vs followe them in this point. Of S. Silue≈øter I haue ≈øpokeÃÑ before, next to him ≈øucceeded S. Marke, who as the≈øe men ≈øay, was Pope in the time of Con≈øtantine the great, Con≈øtantino Imperante in Pontificatu ≈øedit, which time was an holy time in Religion, by our Kings iudgement, and ≈øo this Pope not likely to make any publick lawe vnholie. Therefore the≈øe prote≈øtants onely ≈øay of him, that hee ordeyned the creede of the Nicen councell to bee ≈øaid or ≈øunge at Ma≈ø≈øe. (Rob. Barnes in act. Pont. Rom. in Marc. 1. Io. Bal. in vit Pont. in eod. Edw. Grim≈øton. in Marc.) but this Nicen creed is holy in all iudgements, and was receaued, and v≈øed in
Britanie here, in that time, as I haue proued, & it is receaued by the prote≈øtant parlament of England, ≈øub≈øcribed and ≈øworne vnto by all the prote≈øtant Bi≈øhops and mini≈øters of England, allowed in the articles of their Religion, and practi≈øed in theire churches. (Parlam. an. 1. Eliz. K. Iames can. articles of Relig. articl. Creed. commun. booke &c.) and therefore doth a prote≈øtant antiquarie iu≈øtly ≈øay of that holy creed, & time, in the yeare of Chri≈øt, 330. At this time the Nicen creed was commaunded to bee ≈øunge or ≈øaid, in all Christian churches. (Stowe hist. Rom. ad an. 330.) therefore none but Arrian Hereticks euer did, or will impugne it.

15. The next Pope which the≈øe meÃÑ finde, to haue added any thinge to this holy ≈øacrifice, was holy Dama≈øus, an acknowledged good Bi≈øhop, and as they teache, hee onely added the Confiteor, Confe≈ø≈øion, v≈øed in the beginninge of Ma≈ø≈øe, in which there is nothinge, which prote≈øtants di≈øallowe, but confe≈ø≈øion and prayer to Saints there remembred. (Io. Whitguift. ansvv. to the admonit. pag. 78. and def. of ansvv. pag. 489. Bal. in vit. in Dama≈øo. Barnes in eodem. Grimston. in Dama≈øus.) which as I haue proued
before was v≈øed in the church of God, and in this Realme of Britanie in the Apo≈øtles dayes. And to pa≈ø≈øe ouer ≈øo many examples, and te≈øtimonies, of other Chri≈øtian people, and places, in the ≈øecond age our Apo≈øtles S. Damianus and Fugatius praied to S. Michaell the Archangell, and other Angels, & dedicated a church or chappell to them, the ruines yet ≈øtandinge neare Gla≈øtenburie. (antiquit. Gla≈øton M. S. Gapgrau. in Catal. & alij.) diuers churches be≈øides with their allowance were founded and dedicated to S. Peter, S. Martin, and other Saints. In the third age S. Amphibalus at his Martirdome publickly prayed to S. Alban Martyred a little before, ≈øo did other holy Britti≈øh Chri≈øtians to him and other Martyrs and Saints of Britanie at that time. (tabul. M. S. in Eccle≈ø. S. Petri in Cornhill. Stowe histor. in K. Lucius Caius antiq. Cantabrig. Harris l. 2. Holinsh. hist. of Engl. M. S. antiq. in Lucio M. S. antiq. in S. Amphibal. Capgrau. in eod. & S. Alban. legend. antiq. & alij.) in the beginninge of this fourth age, I haue ≈øhewed before, what generall buildinge, and dedicatinge of churches there was, to our Martyrs, that had ≈øuffered a little
before, and ≈øolemnizinge their fe≈øtiuities, and con≈øequently prayer and inuocation vnto them. And all this longe before S. Dama≈øus was Pope, being ≈øcarcely borne at that time. Therefore many our prote≈øtants of England confe≈ø≈øe, that prayer and inuocation of Saints and Angels, was publicklie v≈øed in the primatiue church, euen in the ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe. And ≈øome of them make it an article of our creede: for to ≈øpeak in their wordes. If wee deny it, wee ≈øhall peraduenture depriue our≈øelues of a great part of their Angels ministery, and di≈ø≈øolue that communion of Saints, which vvee profe≈ø≈øe to beleeue as an article of Gods truthe. Couel examin. pag. 295.178. Parkins problem. pag. 89.93. Ormerod. Pict. Pap. pag. 26.27. Middlet. papi≈øtom. pag. 129. Morton. Apolog. part. 1. pag. 227.228. Couel ag. Burges pag. 89.90.

16. Wherefore I may boldly conclude of this holy Pope, in this matter, in the≈øe words of a Prote≈øtant Archbi≈øhop: Dama≈øus vvas a good Bishop, and therefore no good thinge by him appointed, to bee di≈øallovved. (Io. Whitg. ansvv. to the admonit. pag. 78. ≈øect. 2.3. and def. of ansvv. pag. 489. of Pope Siricius they ≈øay, hee commaunded that
Ma≈ø≈øes ≈øhould bee ≈øaid in places con≈øecrated by the Bi≈øhops: Mi≈ø≈øas in loco ab Epi≈øcopo ≈øacrato celebrandas e≈ø≈øe. (Rob. Barnes l. de vit. Pont. Rom. in Ciricio.) but this was onely a ceremoniall decree, and to Gods more honor, as I haue ≈øhewed in our old Britans by their dedication of churches, and our prote≈øtants in England after their ceremonies ob≈øerue it to this day. What a prote≈øtant Bi≈øhop meaneth, when hee writeth of this Pope, Mi≈ø≈øae memorias adiunxit. Hee adioyned memories to the Ma≈ø≈øe. (Io. Bal. l. 1. de act. Pontif. Rom. in Siricio.) I know not, if hee meaneth memories of Saints, to pray vnto them, or memories of other faithfull departed, to pray for them (as one of them hee mu≈øt needs vnder≈øtand) I haue proued before, they were both v≈øed from the Apo≈øtles time, and ≈øo cannot bee ≈øaid to bee any additioÃÑ of Pope Siricius in this time. The≈øe prote≈øtants do not mention any other Pope in this age, to haue added, or altered any thinge, in this holy ≈øacrifice: Therefore by their good leaue I doe here end this fourth hundred of yeares.

div.head: THE FIFTHE AGE, OR HVNDRED YEARES OF CHRIST.
THE XIX. CHAPTER. Wherein is manife≈øtly proued, that all this fift age, the ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe, ma≈øsing prei≈øts and Bishops did continue in honor in this our Britanie.
div.p:
THe fir≈øt Pope which offereth him≈øelfe in this next and fifth hundred of yeares, to ≈øpeake as a late prote≈øtant writer doth, was Innocent of Albania, or Scotland. (Edw. Grimst. est. of the church of Rome Pope 41. pag. 44. an. D. 402.) and commonly it is written of him, both by prote≈øtants and others. (Rob. Barnes in vit. Innocentij & Io. Bal. in eodem.) that by contrie hee was Albanus, or of Albania, the old common and receaued knowne name of Scotland. And if hee was of this our Albania, it might be occa≈øion that the Scots and Britans of this kingdome did more frequent Rome at this, then other times. But whether hee was of Northren Albania, that is in the ea≈øt, or of
Alba in Italy, or whence≈øoeuer, ≈øure wee are, that many of this nation which proued holy prei≈øts, and Bi≈øhops al≈øo, had their education, and in≈øtruction in Religion, at Rome in the≈øe dayes, by the ma≈ø≈øing and ≈øacrificinge prei≈øts, and Popes in that place. Such were S. Teruanus made Archbi≈øhop of the Picts, by S. Paladius the Popes Legate in Scotland, about the yeare of Chri≈øt 432. as our Scotti≈øh writers te≈øtifie. And that he was in≈øtructed in the faith at Rome, I gather from the ≈øame Authors, affirming that S. Paladius baptized him, beeing an Infant. Teruanum Infantem lustrico lauerat fonte Paldius. (Hector Boeth. l. 7. histor. foli 133. Po≈ø≈øeuin. in appar. To. 2. pag. 452.) which mu≈øt needs bee at Rome from whence S. Palladius was ≈øent into this kingdome, in or about the yeare of Chri≈øt 431. & died ≈øoone after his cominge hither. And ≈øo hauinge for his Ma≈øter and Tutor in Religion, that ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øt, and Bi≈øhop, and the Pope al≈øo then being the like, this man could not bee in≈øtructed there in any other Religion, different from that. And in the ≈øame age, before this, S. Ninian who was al≈øo brought vp, and in≈øtructed by the ma≈ø≈øinge Popes,
and their di≈øciples at Rome, was ≈øent from thence, to teach the ≈øame and other holie doctrines of Chri≈øtian faith to the ≈øame people, and was theire Bi≈øhop, as all antiquaries Catholicke and Prote≈øtant te≈øtifie. (Bed. hist. Angl. l. 3. c. 4. Bal. l. de ≈øcriptor. cent. 1. in Ninian. Capgrau. in eod. Theat. of great Brit. l. 6.) who≈øe ≈øucce≈ø≈øor S. Teruanus was, and about the ≈øame time as our Scotti≈øh and other hi≈øtories tell vs, S. Seruanus was made Bi≈øhop of the Orchades beinge in≈øtructed and con≈øecrated by the ma≈ø≈øinge Bi≈øhop Paladius, which that famous ma≈ø≈øinge Pope S. Cele≈øtine ≈øent his Legate into this nation, of whome herafter. Hector Boeth. Scotor. histor. l. 7. fol. 133.

2. Be≈øides the≈øe extraordinary, the ordinary Archbi≈øhops, and Bi≈øhops with their whole cleargie per≈øeuered in the≈øe holy doctrines, none to contradict them herin but in other que≈øtions moued by Pelagian hereticks. And that S. Innocentius the fir≈øt Pope in this age vnder whome our remembred Bi≈øhops had theire education and in≈øtruction, was a ma≈ø≈øinge Pope, our prote≈øtants a≈ø≈øure vs, te≈øtifyinge that hee confirmed the ceremonie of giuinge the Pax in
Ma≈ø≈øe. Vt pax in Mi≈ø≈øa daretur ordinauit. The like they te≈øtifie of Pope Sozimus, and Bonifacius, which were betweene S. Innocentius, and S. Cele≈øtine, that ≈øent ≈øo many Bi≈øhops into this kingdome, affirming how they both maintayned ≈øacrificinge prei≈øthood, and holy Ma≈ø≈øe, with the ceremonies thereof, and the ≈øupreamacy of the ≈øee of Rome. (Io. Bal. l. 2. de act. Pont. Rom. in Innocent. in Sozimo & Bonifacio. Robert. Barne in vit. Pontif. in ei≈ødem.) And for the ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe, that it was, Mi≈øsa papi≈øtica, the papi≈øticall, or, papi≈øts Ma≈øse, ≈øuch as Catholicks of this time (whome they call papi≈øts, and their Ma≈ø≈øe prei≈øts and Religion papi≈øticall) doe v≈øe. (Bal. ≈øupr. lib. 2. in Caele≈øtino.) before the dayes of Saint and Pope Cele≈øtine, who as they ≈øay added ≈øome thinges to the papi≈øticall Ma≈ø≈øe, v≈øed before his papacie. Papisticae Mi≈øsae in≈øeruit. And yet this ≈øacrificinge ma≈ø≈øinge and papi≈øticall Pope was hee, by all antiquities, on whome Britanie in tho≈øe dayes did cheifly depend for direction, and in≈øtruction in matters of Religion.

3. Therefore to make all peace, and attonement, wee may by the proceedings and
in≈øtitutions of this holy Pope, and our Ma≈øter and Pedagogue in Chri≈øt, let vs learne of our prote≈øtants them≈øelues, what were the things he added to the ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe, whether any matter e≈ø≈øentiall, or that may be excepted again≈øt. They haue told vs, that before his additions, the Ma≈ø≈øe was papi≈øticall, and concerninge his additions, In initio ≈øacrificij, vt p≈øalmus, Iudica me Deus, & di≈øcerne cau≈øam me am &c. √† ≈øacrificaturo diceretur ordinauit: graduale in Mi≈ø≈øa ordinauit. He ordeyned that the p≈øalme, Iudge mee √¥ God & di≈øcerne my cau≈øe, ≈øhould be ≈øaid in the beginning of the ≈øacrifice, by the prei≈øt that offereth the ≈øacrifice: and he ordeyned the graduale ≈øhould be ≈øaid in Ma≈ø≈øe. (Rob. Barn. l. de vit. Pontif. Rom. in Caelest. Magdeb. cent. 5. in Caele≈øt.) ≈øo write others of the≈øe prote≈øtaÃÑts, amoÃÑg whom one a Bi≈øhop ≈øaith: Caelestinus introitum, graduale, re≈øpon≈øorium, tractum, & offertorium, vt propria inuenta, papi≈øticae Mi≈ø≈øae in≈øeruit. Pope Cele≈øtine did put into the papi≈øticall Ma≈ø≈øe, as inuentions of his own, the introite, graduale, re≈øpon≈øorie, tract and offertory. (Iohn Foxe Tom. 2. in Q. Mary. Cartwright admon. Whitg. answ. to the admonit. pag. 94. ≈øect. 1.2. Io. Bal. l. 2. act. Pontif.
Roman. in Caelestino.) which wordes of his, vt propria inuenta, as his owne inuentions, are the euident forgery and inuention of this prote≈øtant, for all the≈øe thinges are plaine wordes of holy ≈øcriptures in all places, and ≈øo the inuentions of God him≈øelfe, and not Pope Cele≈øtines; And if hee meaneth that the placing them in the Ma≈ø≈øe was his inuention, which hee doth not in≈øinuate, why was it not lawfull for him to v≈øe the ≈øcriptures in Ma≈ø≈øe? otherwi≈øe no prayer or part of Ma≈ø≈øe, or what≈øoeuer liturgie or publicke office of any church could bee lawfull, nothinge could be lawfull, for nothinge is more lawfull or warranted then the word of God and ≈øcripture. Yet it was not S. Cele≈øtines inuention, to place any one of the≈øe in the Ma≈ø≈øe, but they were all v≈øed therin, before his time, euen by the confe≈ø≈øion of the≈øe prote≈øtants them≈øelues. For fir≈øt concerning the introite, it is one of the p≈øalmes of Dauid the 42. by the Latine accompt, and by the Hebrue 43. and ≈øuch kind of introite to the holy Ma≈ø≈øe, was in v≈øe longe before this Popes time, as our prote≈øtants acknowledge, wherof one thus confe≈ø≈øeth.. (Io. Foxe To. 2. Act. and Monum.
Q. Mary pag. 1401.) Chri≈øo≈øtome in the eleuenth homely vpon the Gho≈øpell of S. Matthew, ≈øaith, that in his time, and before his time, the v≈øe was to ≈øinge whole p≈øalmes till they were entered and a≈ø≈øembled together: And ≈øo belike Caelestinus borrowed this custome of of the Greekes, and brought it into the Latine church. Therfore by the≈øe men S. Caele≈øtine was not the Author of this cu≈øtome: yet if he had bene, no prote≈øtaÃÑt or Chri≈øtian will ≈øay, that ≈øayinge or ≈øinginge holy p≈øalmes, ≈øo warranted in ≈øcripture, is an vnlawfull, but a lawfull and godly exerci≈øe.

4. The ≈øame prote≈øtant Author maketh the graduale, re≈øpon≈øe, and tract of as auncient ≈øtandinge, when hee thus ≈øpeaketh of the graduale and con≈øequently of the others belonging vnto it. (Foxe ≈øupr.) the graduale the people were went to ≈øinge when the Bishop was about to go vp to the pulpit, or ≈øome higher standinge, where the worde of God might be better & more ≈øen≈øibly heard at his mouth, readinge the epi≈øtle and the gho≈øpell. Which cu≈øtome hee maketh as auncient, or more auncient, then the time of Pope Alexander, in the Empire of Traian. Touchinge the la≈øte which is the offertorie, it is euident by
the≈øe prote≈øtants, and al te≈øtimonies before, that it was, and of nece≈ø≈øitie mu≈øt needs be v≈øed from the begininge, for where there is Ma≈ø≈øe ≈øacrifice, and oblation offered, there mu≈øt needes bee an offeringe or offertorie thereof, otherwi≈øe it could not bee offered. Foxe ≈øupr. Therefore this prote≈øtaÃÑt acknowledgeth it to haue bene v≈øed before the time of S. Irenaeus ≈øo neare the Apo≈øtles, and that hee thus doth remember it. Iren. l. 4. cap. 18. pro diuer≈øis ≈øacrificiorum ritibus ≈øimplex oblatio panis & vini fidelibus ≈øufficiat. In ≈øtedd of diuers rites of ≈øacrifices in the olde lawe, one oblation of breade and wine ≈øerueth. Therfore I will conclude with the≈øe words, of a prote≈øtaÃÑt Archbi≈øhop. Cele≈øtinus was a godly Bishop, and the church of Rome at that time had the ≈øubstance of the Sacraments, according to Gods word, neither was there any ≈øuperstition mixed with them. Iohn Whitg. def. of the answ. to the admonit. pag. 588.

5. And in this opinion are, and ought to bee, all our Engli≈øh Prote≈øtant antiquaries, and diuines, which generally hold, & teach, that the Britans of this kingedome, inuiolablie kept the true faith and Religion of Chri≈øt, in all things, vntill the cominge of
S. Augu≈øtine, and his companions from S. Gregory the great Pope of Rome, in the later end of the ≈øixt hundred yeares: for mo≈øt certaine and vndoubted it is, by all antiquities, that this nation at this time of S. Cele≈øtine, being infected with the Pelagian Hereticks, learned and ≈øubtile in di≈øputation, this holy Pope ≈øent many holy Bi≈øhops hither to confute that here≈øie, in≈øtruct the ignorant, repaire the decaied di≈øcipline of our church, and reforme many abu≈øes growne by rea≈øon of that here≈øie, and the Saxon Pagans, which then were entered into this Iland. Which Legates of this holy Pope, mu≈øt needs bee adiudged to bee of the ≈øame faith, and Religion with him, that ≈øent them, by his authoritie and direction to effect tho≈øe holy labours. He ≈øent the two holie Bi≈øhops S. Germanus, & Lupus into this part of Britanie, S. Palladius into Scotland, S. Patricke and Segetius into Ireland. I haue ≈øpoken of S. Palladius before, how by his power from the ≈øee of Rome, hee placed ≈øacrificing and ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øts and Bi≈øhops amonge the Scots, and Picts, in the north parts of this kingdome, of vnited great Britanie. Pro≈øper. in Chronic. ad An. 432. Rob.
Barnes l. de vit. Pontif. Rom. in Caelestino. Io. Bal. l. 2. Act. Pontif. Rom. in eod. Bal. l. de ≈øcriptor. Brit. cent. 1. in Leporio Agricola.

6. Al≈øo I haue ≈øhewed out of our auncient Britti≈øh Manu≈øcript & otherwi≈øe before, how both S. German and Lupus were ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øts, and Bi≈øhops, and ob≈øerued the auncient forme of Ma≈ø≈øe compo≈øed by S. Marke, therefore beeing ≈øent by authoritie from that ma≈ø≈øinge Pope, S. Cele≈øtine, they neither did, nor might vary and differ from the opinion, and practi≈øe of him, that ≈øent him, as S. Pro≈øper who liued at that time, and others write, to ≈øupply his owne place and par≈øon in ordering and reforminge the church of Britanie. Papa Celestinus Germanum Anti≈øiodoren≈øem Epi≈øcopum voce ≈øua mittit, vt deturbatis haereticis Britannos ad Catholicam fidem dirigat. Hee con≈øecrated many ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øts, and Bi≈øhops in this kingdome, among whom the cheife≈øt was, that ma≈ø≈øing Saint Dubritius Archbi≈øhop, the cheife Doctor, Primate & the Popes Legate. (Pro≈øper. in Chronic. An. D. 432. Io. Capgrau. in S. Dubritio. Matth. Westm. Galfrid. Monument. hist. Brit. l. 9. cap. 12. Rob. Caenal. l. 2. M. S. Gallic. antiq. M. S.
antiq. & Io. Capgrau. in vita S. Dubritij.) Epi≈øcopos in pluribus locis Britanniae con≈øecrarunt: & dextralis partis Britanniae beatum Dubritium ≈øummum Doctorem & Archiepi≈øcopum ≈øtatuerunt: a prote≈øtant Bi≈øhop writeth: Dubritius was made Archbi≈øhop by Germanus and Lupus, and they appointed his ≈øee to bee at Landaffe. (Godwin. Catalog. in S. Dauide.) this holy Archbi≈øhop by the heauenly direction, did con≈øecrate that notorious ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øt S. Samp≈øon Archbi≈øhop of Yorke, in who≈øe con≈øecration a miraculous vi≈øion appeared to confirme his callinge and Religion, and both S. Dubritius and others did ≈øee a piller of fier miraculou≈øly proceeding from his mouth as hee celebrated the holy Ma≈ø≈øe, and hee him≈øelfe all his life had Angels mini≈øtring vnto him in that ble≈ø≈øed ≈øacrifice. Angelus Domini beato Dubritio apparens, Samp≈øonem ordinari Epi≈øcopum praecepit. In cuius con≈øecratione qui aderant, columbam celitus emi≈ø≈øam immobiliter ≈øuper eum stare videbant. Eodem die Samp≈øone celebrante, Dubritius cum Monachis duobus, columnam ignis de ore eius procedentem rutilare per≈øpexit. Ille vero omni tempore vitae ≈øuae Angelos dum celebraret,
≈øibi a≈øsistere, & in ≈øacrificio ministrare meruit. (M. S. antiquit. & Capgrau. in S. Samp≈øone Epi≈øcopo.) what ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øtes and Archbi≈øhops the immediate ≈øucce≈ø≈øors of the≈øe two renowned Archbi≈øhops were, I ≈øhall lay downe herafter more at large.

7. And ≈øuch as the≈øe were, ≈øuch al≈øo was the Archbi≈øhop of London S. Vodinus, and all Bi≈øhops and prei≈øts vnder him, and ≈øo con≈øequently in all Britanie at that time: which a≈øwel appeareth, by their owne hi≈øtorian, S. Gildas, venerable S. Bede, as al≈øo Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter with others, who ≈øpeaking of the mi≈øerable and generall per≈øecutioÃÑ of the chri≈øtian Britans, in al places qua≈øque Prouincias, amonge other cruelties they tel vs, the≈øe infidels martyred the Britti≈øh prei≈øts, as they were ≈øtanding at the altars where they ≈øaid Ma≈ø≈øe. Sacerdotes iuxta altaria trucidabaÃÑt. (Gild. de excid. & conque≈øt. Brit. Matth. Westm. an. gratiae 462. Bed. l. 1. histor. Eccle≈ø. cap. 15.) therefore the prei≈øtes generally then, were altare, ≈øacrificinge and ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øts, otherwi≈øe they could not haue beene thus cruelly put to death, at the altars, and places of ≈øaying Ma≈ø≈øe, in all
all parts of this nation at that time. Neither could there po≈ø≈øibly, at that time bee any other prei≈øts, but ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øts, except they would turne hereticks (which we doe not reade) and leaue the doctrine and Religion of their both Archbi≈øhops, Bi≈øhops, and Ma≈øters in diuinitie, which in this time were by all te≈øtimonie both of Catholicks, and Prote≈øtants, either the onely or principall, S. Dubritius of whome I haue ≈øpoken before, S. Iltutus, and S. Gildas, all mo≈øte holy and miraculous men, and knowne ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øts. For concerninge S. Iltutus he was (as a Prote≈øtant Bi≈øhop with Vicentius, and Antoninus confe≈ø≈øeth) ≈øcholler to the renowned Popes Legate and ma≈ø≈øinge Bi≈øhop S. German, ≈øpoken of before, Io. Bal. l. de ≈øcript. Britan. cent. 1. in Ilchtuto alias Iltuto. And to proue him a ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øt, and all his ≈øchollers after him, that were prei≈øts, to haue bene ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øts, Nennius our mo≈øte auncient (exceptinge Gildas) writer which wee haue left, te≈øtifieth in his Manu≈øcript hi≈øtorie, that there was in a church which this ma≈ø≈øinge Saint Iltutus builded, a miraculous Altar, ≈øu≈øteyned only without any propp, or foundation by the
power of God, altare quod nutu Dei fulcitur. (Nennius hi≈øtor. M. S. in fine post nomina ciuitatum Britanniae.) and this miraculous altar ≈øo inui≈øibly ≈øu≈øteyned, did remayne in Nennius time, & manet v≈øque in hodiernam diem altare potestate Dei fulcitum.

8. To proue S. Gildas to haue beene of this opinion, and practi≈øe, his hi≈øtorie, de excidio Britanniae, often cited in this treati≈øe, is full of altars, ma≈ø≈øinge and ≈øacrificinge prei≈øts, and maketh their irreuent ≈øayinge of Ma≈ø≈øe, and often neglect of celebrating that holy ≈øacrifice, to haue beene one of the cheife cau≈øes of Gods indignation again≈øt them, and depriuinge them of this kingedome, and giuinge it to the Saxons theire profe≈ø≈øed enemies. And hee was one of the renowned ≈øchollers of his ma≈ø≈øing Ma≈øter, S. Iltutus, as S. Samp≈øon the great ma≈ø≈øing Archbi≈øhop of Yorke, of whome I haue ≈øpoken before, and S. Dauid, that mo≈øte holy ≈øacrificinge and miraculous Archbi≈øhop of Caerlegion, of whome hereafter, and S. Paulinus were: as both Catholicks and Prote≈øtants are witne≈ø≈øes. (M. S. antiq. de vit S. Iltuti. Ioh. Capgrau. in Iltuto. Ioh. Bal. centur. 1. de ≈øcriptor. Brit. in eod.) what
this Paulinus was, and whether hee that was ≈øent hither with S. Augu≈øtine I dare not affirme, yet con≈øidering the longe time S. Iltutus liued, as many then did, and hee beeing liuinge as diuers write. (Bal. ≈øupr.) in the yeare of Chri≈øt 520. hee might haue in his olde age a ≈øcholler, that might liue longer then S. Paulinus death, that came with S. Augu≈øtine, and was Archbi≈øhop of Yorke: for many our holy Bi≈øhops as S. Kentegern, and S. Dauid liued longer, and we finde no other renowned Paulinus here in tho≈øe times. And Nennius who ≈øaith expre≈ø≈øely, that hee omitteth of purpo≈øe to ≈øpeake of tho≈øe that came with S. Augu≈øtine, and were not of this nation, yet maketh a mo≈øt honorable memory of that Paulinus Archbi≈øhop of Yorke, ≈øaying that hee baptized 12000. at one time, and cea≈øed not bapti≈øinge fourtie dayes together. Nennius in histor. M. S. prope finem.

9. So that it is not vnprobable but this holy man S. Paulinus, was the ≈øcholer of S. Iltutus, and leauinge his contry (as manie did in that rage of the Saxons) weÃÑt to Rome and liued to come hither againe to accompli≈øh ≈øo holy labours, as hee did with tho≈øe
other ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øtes ≈øent hither at that time. Which hee might well performe, if wee allowe him, to bee 20. yeares old, at the death of his Ma≈øter S. Iltutus, as before in the yeare 520. and as an other Prote≈øtant Bi≈øhop writeth. (Godwin Catalog. Yorke 1. pag. 558.) to haue died in the yeare 644. which accompt maketh him but 124. yeares old, two yeares yonger then his fellow ≈øcholler S. Dauid by all antiquities makinge him 146. yeares of age at his death. Po≈øt 146. aetatis annum, vt omnes eius fatentur hi≈øtoriae, mortuus. In the yeare of his age, 147. anno aetatis ≈øuae cente≈øimo quadrage≈øimo ≈øeptimo. And twenty one yeares yonger then S. Kentegern by all hi≈øtories, dyinge when hee was one hundred eightie and fiue yeares old, cum e≈ø≈øet centum octaginta quinque annorum. Ioh. Bal. centur. 1. de ≈øcriptorib. Britan‚ñ™ in Dauid Menenien. Ioh. Capgrau¬∑ Catal. in S. Dauid. M. S. antiq. in eod. S. A≈øaph. in vita S. Kentegern. Capg. in eod. Io. Bal. centur. 1. de ≈øcript. Brit. in Kentegern. Elgnen. Godwin Catalog. in S. A≈øaph. and Probus the auncient writer of S. Patricks life, dedicateth it to Paulinus, about that time S. Paulinus was Archbi≈øhop here, which argueth
that Paulinus had ≈øome acquaintance with, or reference to S. Patricke, otherwi≈øe an Iri≈øh Author would not haue dedicated his worke to one in England.Tho≈øe ≈øcholes were here of high authority approued both by the Popes & Kings of Britanie, as Cambridg teacheth. Prebus in vita S. Patricij inter opera S. Bedae. Io. Caius l. antiquitat. Camtab. pag. 147.148.

10. Now let vs come to S. Patricke, who although he was cheifly ≈øent by S. Cele≈øtine to the inhabitants of Ireland and Scotland, yet hee was a Britane borne, and by many antiquities preached much, and by ≈øome many yeares together before his death liuinge in this nation, died here. Therefore wee may boldly apply him as a Ma≈øter and witnes in this bu≈øines. This man being ≈øent by the ma≈ø≈øinge Pope S. Cele≈øtine, was ≈øo farr al≈øo a ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øt, and Bi≈øhop, that as the auncient writer of his life, not S. Bede but Probus an Iri≈øh man more auncieÃÑt then S. Bedes time, witne≈ø≈øeth. (l. 2. de vita S. Patricij in fine.) the inchaunters and magiciens of that contry, e≈øpecially three which he called Locri, Egled, and Mel, did tell to the Kinge and nobles of that contry beinge
idolaters, diuers yeares before the cominge of S. Patricke thither, that a certaine Prophet ≈øhould come thither with a new Religion, that though it was hard and au≈øtere, yet it ≈øhould quite de≈øtroy theire auncient wor≈øhip, and there continue for euer. And to ≈øpeake in this auncient Authors wordes of S. Patricks ≈øayinge Ma≈ø≈øe in particular: praecinebant qua≈øi in modum cantici lirico modo compo≈øiti ante aduentum Sancti viri duobus aut tribus annis decantantes de eo. Haec ≈øunt autem verba cantici ≈øecundum linguae illius Idioma in latinum conuer≈øa, non tamen manifesta. Adueniet artis caput, cum ≈øuo ligno praecuruo capite: ex eo omnis domus erit capite perforata: incantabit nephas ex ≈øua men≈øa ex anteriore parte domus ≈øuae, re≈øpondebit ei ≈øua familia tota, fiat, fiat. Quod nostris verbis pote≈øt manifestius exprimi. Adueniet totius artis Magister cum ≈øigno crucis, & quod omne cor hominum compungitur, & de altari Sacramentorum conuertet animas ad Chri≈øtum, & omnis populus Chri≈øtianorum re≈øpoÃÑdebit Amen. QuaÃÑdo erunt haec omnia regnum no≈øtrum gentile non ≈øtabit. Quod ≈øic totum completum est. They did ≈øinge before the cominge of the holy man S. Patricke a ≈øonge made lyrickwi≈øe
of him two or three yeares. And the≈øe are the words of the ≈øong according to that language turned into latine, but not manife≈øt. The head of art will come, with his ≈øtaffe with a crooked head, with that al the hou≈øe ≈øhall bee bored in the heade: he ≈øhall ≈øinge wickednes from his table from the former part of his hou≈øe, all his hou≈øeholde ≈øhall answere, ≈øo bee it, ≈øo bee it. Which in our words may be more manife≈øtly expre≈ø≈øed. The Ma≈øter of all art ≈øhall come with the ≈øigne of the cro≈ø≈øe, and all the harts of men ≈øhall haue compunction, and from the altare of Sacraments hee ≈øhall conuert ≈øoules to Chri≈øt, and all Chri≈øtian people ≈øhall an≈øwere Amen. When all the≈øe things ≈øhall bee, then our heathen kingedome ≈øhall not ≈øtand. All which was ≈øo fulfilled. Io. Capgrau. in Catalog. in S. Patricio.

11. Iohn Capgraue and others in S. Patricks life thus ≈øet downe this prediction of S. Patricke, adueniet homo cum ≈øuo ligno cuius men≈øa erit in oriente domus ≈øuae, & populus eius retror≈øum, & ex ≈øua men≈øa cantabit, & familia re≈øpondebit ei Amen. Hic cum aduenerit, Deos no≈øtros destruet templa ≈øubuertet, & doctrina eius regnabit in ≈øeculuÃÑ ≈øeculi. A man
≈øhall come with his ≈øtaffe, who≈øe table ≈øhall be in the ea≈øt part of his hou≈øe, and the people behinde him, and hee ≈øhall ≈øinge from his table, and the companie ≈øhall an≈øwere vnto him Amen. He when he cometh ≈øhall de≈øtroy our Gods, ouerthrowe our temples, & his doctrine ≈øhall reigne for euer. Where wee ≈øee an euident prediction, and foretelling, how this great Apo≈øtle ≈øhould be a ≈øacrificinge ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øt, his altar ≈øhould bee in the ea≈øt part of the church, as altars v≈øually are, and the people ≈øhould an≈øwere Amen. How deuout a ≈øacrificinge ma≈ø≈øinge man hee was, the hi≈øtorie of his life is witnes, and of many miracles to proue the ≈øanctitie and holines, both of that ≈øacrifice, and the ≈øacrificer; Amonge which a ≈øorcerer ouerthrowinge his chalice when hee ≈øaid ma≈ø≈øe, the earth opened and ≈øwallowed him vp. Factum est alto die cum Patricius Mi≈øsam celebraret quidam magus effudit calicem ≈øuam, & ≈øtatim terra aperieÃÑs os ≈øuum deuorauit eum. (M. S. antiq. in vit. S. Patric. Capgrau. in eod.) and the altare on which hee v≈øuallie ≈øaid Ma≈ø≈øe, healed di≈øea≈øes and wrought other miracles. And this mo≈øte holy Saint by all te≈øtimonies both of Catholicks, and
Prote≈øtants. (Bal. l. de ≈øcriptor. Britan. in Patric. Prob. in vita eius. Capgrau. & al in eod.) was ≈øo great a promoter of the ble≈ø≈øed ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe, and ≈øacrificinge ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øts, and Bi≈øhops, that for the honor and propagation of them, to in≈øi≈øt in the words of Nennius. (Nenmus M. S. hi≈øt. in S. Patricie.) hee founded 345. churches to that v≈øe. Hee con≈øecrated ≈øo many or more Bishops, endued with the ≈øpirit, of God, and ordered 3000. ma≈øsinge preists. Eccle≈øias numero fundauit 345. ordinauit Epi≈øcopos trecentos quadraginta quinque aut amplius, in quibus ≈øpiritus Domini crat. Presbyteros autem v≈øque ad tria millia ordinauit.

12. Therefore this ma≈ø≈øing Archbi≈øhop liuinge and rulinge in Ireland and Britanie vntill the yeare of Chri≈øt 491. by a Prote≈øtant Bi≈øhop makinge his age 122. yeares, and longer by Capgraue, & others, ≈øaying hee was, annis centum triginta, an hundred and thirty yeares old, & by Probus an hundred thirtie two, and more, when hee died. (Bal centur. 1. de ≈øcriptor. Britan. in Patricio. Capgrau. Catal. in eod. M. S. in vita S. Patric. Prebus in vit. eiu≈ød.) this kingdome of Britanie could not bee without Ma≈ø≈øe,
and many ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øts, and Bi≈øhops in this age. And as the great recited number of ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øts and Bi≈øhops, e≈øpecially Bi≈øhops, aboue 340. could not bee wholly employed in the≈øe kingdomes, which neuer had ≈øo many in ≈øo ≈øhort a time, we may be bold to extend his mi≈ø≈øion of ≈øuch ma≈ø≈øinge men, to a larger circuite, and ≈øay hee ≈øent diuers of the≈øe his ma≈ø≈øinge di≈øciples, euen into Armerica it ≈øelfe: for wee finde in the aunciently written life of S. Brendan 1100. yeares ≈øince. (M. S. antiq. & Io. Capgrau. in vit. S. Brendani.) of whom one of the Ilands of America ≈øtill beareth name, that in his longe and tedious trauailes, hee founde in tho≈øe parts, diuers ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øtes, that did v≈øually ≈øay Ma≈ø≈øe, and had mo≈øt ≈øumptuous Altars of Chri≈øtal, who affirmed they were di≈øciples to S. Patricke, and by him directed thither. And were mo≈øt holie and miraculous men, and amonge other things then prophe≈øied to S. Brendan, how that contrie ≈øhould bee de≈øcryed, and vi≈øited againe by Chri≈øtians, to their great good & comforte after many ages, as happily wee finde it was: Po≈øt multa annorum curricula declarabitur ista terra vestris Succe≈ø≈øoribus,
quando Chri≈øtianorum ≈øuperuenerit per≈øecutio. Written in many Manu≈øcripts manie hundreds of yeares before the late di≈øcouerie of America, and by Capgraue & others publi≈øhed longe before that time.

div.head: THE XX. CHAPTER. Wherein is proued by prote≈øtants and others, that the church of Britanie and Rome, accorded in this age in the≈øe misteries: and how all the Popes beeing ma≈øsinge prei≈øts and Popes, yet no one of them made any materiall alteration in this ≈øacrifice.
div.p:
THus hauinge ≈øhewed both by Catholicke, and Prote≈øtant authorities, that the holy ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe, ma≈ø≈øing prei≈øts, and prei≈øthood generally, and inuiolablie continued in Britanie all this age and hundred of yeares, becau≈øe it is confe≈ø≈øed this nation was ≈øtill hitherto directed in Religion, by the ≈øee Apo≈øtolicke of Rome, and there want not prote≈øtaÃÑt aduer≈øaries, which ≈øay the Popes there in this time al≈øo added, and altered diuers things, to, and in the ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe, wee will now proue by
the≈øe prote≈øtants them ≈øelues, that not anie one Pope altered, or added any one materiall, or lea≈øte e≈ø≈øentiall thinge therein in this age. The fir≈øt Pope after S. Cele≈øtine which the≈øe men accu≈øe for addinge, or alteringe in this matter, is that mo≈øte learned and renowned Pope, S. Leo, again≈øt whom a Prote≈øtant Bi≈øhop thus exclaimeth. (Bal. l. 2. de Act. Pontif. Rom. in Leone 1. Robert. Barns in vit. Pont. in cod.) Leo primus Thu≈øcus, in canone Mi≈ø≈øae, hoc ≈øanctum ≈øacrificium, immaculatam ho≈øtiam, & hanc igitur oblationem, non ≈øine magna Dei bla≈øphemia addidit. Pope Leo the fir≈øt, a Tu≈øchan by birth, did add in the canon of the Ma≈ø≈øe, not without great bla≈øphemie of God, this holy ≈øacrifice immaculate offeringe, and therefore this oblation. To this I an≈øwere, and fir≈øt to the pretended addition of the prayer. Hanc igitur oblationem: That as our renowned contryman S. Albinus with others, proueth. (Albin. Alcuin. l. de diuin offic. cap. de celebrat. Mi≈ø≈øae.) this prayer, e≈øpecially the fir≈øt part which hee taxeth, is as auncient in the Ma≈ø≈øe, as the Apo≈øtles time, and was v≈øed both by S. Peter and others of that ≈øacred order: Mi≈ø≈øam Petrus Antiochiae dicitur celebra≈øse,
in qua tres tantum orationes in initio fidei proferebantur, incipientes ab eo loco, vbi dicitur; Hanc igitur oblationem. Therefore S. Leo added nothinge in this prayer, beeing for the fir≈øt part v≈øed by the Apo≈øtles, and others in their dayes, which is that, this Prote≈øtant Bi≈øhop excepteth again≈øt: and for the later end thereof, which hee taxeth not, was by this man him≈øelfe, and others, both Catholicks, and Prote≈øtants, added longe time after, and then, fir≈øt by S. Gregorie the great and fir≈øt Pope of that name. Baleas l. 2. de Act¬∑ Pontfic. Rom. in Gregorio 1. Rob. Barnes in vit. Pontif. Rom. in eodem. & alij communiter.

2. So that it is euident S. Leo neither did, nor could add any part of this prayer, to the ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe as his owne addition or inuention, all that hee did, or po≈ø≈øiblie could doe therin, was to take order that the decree or cu≈øtom of the Apo≈øtles ≈øhould be ob≈øerued, which cannot be either great or little bla≈øphemie of God, as this barbarous mouth affirmed, but honor vnto God in that behalfe. To make all ≈øure, I will cite the whole praier then v≈øed thus in Engli≈øh: Therefore √¥ Lord wee be≈øeech thee, that thou
wilt be plea≈øed to accept this oblation of our ≈øeruice, and all thy family through Christ our Lord. The re≈øt being added by S. Gregory, is thus: and di≈øpo≈øe our dayes in peace, and commaund wee may bee deliuered from euerlasting damnation, and numbred in the flocke of thy elected ≈øeruants. In which addition of S Gregory there is not any one word, of matter now in controuer≈øie, but al holy and allowable, by Prote≈øtant Religion. And in that part, which I ≈øay with S. Albin or Alcuine, was v≈øed by the Apo≈øtles, there is not one word, except, oblation, which is, or can by prote≈øtants bee called into controuer≈øie, by them or any Chri≈øtiaÃÑ; Therfore to an≈øwere that & hoc ≈øacrificium, immaculatam ho≈øtiam, together; If S. Leo added the≈øe wordes, to the canon of the Ma≈ø≈øe, then the canon of the Ma≈ø≈øe was before S. Leo his pretended additions: and in other places of this canon of which no prote≈øtant doth, or will produce any Author, beeing as is proued before apo≈øtolicall, this Liturgie of Ma≈ø≈øe is called.
