(in can. Mi≈ø≈øae antiq.) donum, munus, ≈øanctum ≈øacrificium illibatum, oblatio benedicta, ad≈øcripta, rata, rationabilis, ≈øacrificium, ho≈øtia pura, hostia ≈øancta, hostia immaculata. A pre≈øent,
a guift, holy ≈øacrifice vn≈øpotted, an oblation ble≈ø≈øed, ad≈øcribed, ratified, rea≈øonable, a ≈øacrifice, a pure ho≈øte, an holy ho≈øte, an immaculate ho≈øte.

3. And this Prote≈øtant Bi≈øhop him≈øelfe hath te≈øtified al≈øo, that the offertorie was v≈øed in S. Cele≈øtines time before: which is this in Engli≈øh: O holy Father omnipotent eternall God, receue this immaculate ≈øacrifice, or oblation, which I thy vnworthie ≈øeruant doe offer vnto thee, my liuinge and true God, for my innumerable ≈øinnes, and offences, and negligences, and for all here pre≈øent, as al≈øo for all faithfull Christians both liuinge and deade, that it may bee to mee and them for ≈øaluation to eternal life. Su≈øcipe ≈øancte Pater omnipotens aeterne Deus, haÃÑc immaculatam hostiam, quam ego indignus famulus tuus offero tibi Deo meo, viuo, & vero, pro innumerabilibus peccatis, & offen≈øionibus, & negligentijs meis, & pro omnibus circumstantibus, ≈øed & pro omnibus fidelibus Christianis, viuis atque defunctis: vt mihi & illis proficiat ad ≈øalutem, in vitam aeternam AmeÃÑ. So likewi≈øe it was for the chalice: offerimus tibi Domine calicem ≈øalutaris: √¥ Lord wee offer vnto thee the chalice of ≈øaluation: And I haue proued in all ages before,
from Chri≈øt, euen with the allowance of our prote≈øtants, that Ma≈ø≈øe was an holie ≈øacrifice, and all truely con≈øecrated prei≈øtes, did euer in all times and places ≈øtill offer that mo≈øte holy ≈øacrifice, both for the liuinge and faithfull departed, and that this was ≈øo an vndoubted and generally receued cu≈øtome, & truth in the whole church, that by our prote≈øtants graunt, it was iu≈øtly condemned to bee here≈øie, to deny it, and this longe time before S. Leo was borne: Therefore none of tho≈øe names could bee by any po≈ø≈øibility his inuentioÃÑ in this kind. Which this prote≈øtant accu≈øing Bi≈øhop him ≈øelfe to confound and contradict him≈øelfe, teacheth in the ≈øame place, when hee ≈øaith of S. Leo, Mi≈ø≈øae ≈øacrificium approbanit. Hee did approue the ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe: therfore Ma≈ø≈øe was termed and knowne to be ≈øo accepted a ≈øacrifice, before his time, and approbation. For a thinge approued, or to bee approued, vn≈øeparably carrieth with it a precedency to the approbation, that which is, not cannot po≈ø≈øibly bee approued, as a thinge pa≈øt or pre≈øent, and euery ≈øuch allowance or approbation nece≈ø≈øarily ≈øuppo≈øeth the thinge to bee ≈øo allowed or approued.
And this will ≈øuffice for S. Leo.

4. After whome in this age the onely Pope which is produced by the≈øe men to haue added, or altered in the Ma≈ø≈øe, is Gela≈øius: of this Pope a prote≈øtant thus writeth. (Robert. Barnes in vit. Pontif. in Gela≈øio.) praefationem Mi≈ø≈øae, ver√® dignuÃÑ & iustum est, instituit. But this is euidentlie vntrue, as I haue proued before, for S. Ciprian, and before him Tertullian informe vs, it was in v≈øe in the church before their times; and S. Ciprian alleadgeth it is an apo≈øtolicall, common, & known cu≈øtome of the church. (Ciprian. l. de orat. Dominic.) and Foxe the prote≈øtant proueth. (Io. Foxe Tom. 2. in Q. Mary.) that this could not bee any inuention of Gela≈øius, for that both the auncient Greeke church before that time, and both S. Ciprian, and S. Augu≈øtine ≈øo agree it was in v≈øe before. Ciprian. ≈øup. Aug. de vera Religione cap. 3) therefore followeth therein the opinion of Thomas Walden≈øis, that it could not bee the inuention of Pope Gela≈øius. And Pope Vigilius which liued not longe after Gela≈øius, who writinge to the Bi≈øhops of Germany and Fraunce, de≈øirous to know the order which the church of
Rome ob≈øerued in the prefaces of Ma≈ø≈øe, an≈øwereth in this maner. (Vigilius epistola ad Epi≈øcopos Germaniae & Galliae.) Inuenimus has nouem praefationes in ≈øacro catalogo tantumodo recipiendas, quas long a retro veritas in Romana Eccle≈øia hactenus ≈øeruauit. Wee finde that the≈øe 9. prefaces are to bee receued in the holy catalogue, which truth hath longe time from former ages hitherto ob≈øerued in the Roman church. And thus hee recoÃÑpteth them: one of Ea≈øter, another of the A≈øcen≈øion of our Lord, the third of Penteco≈øte, the fourth of the natiuitie of our Lord, the fift of the apparition of our Lord, the ≈øixt of the Apostles, the ≈øeuenth of the holy Trinitie, the eight of the Cro≈øse, the ninth in Lent. And thus concludeth: has praefationes tenet & cu≈øtodit ≈øancta Romana Eccle≈øia, has tenendas vobis mandamus. The≈øe prefaces the holy Roman church ob≈øerueth, the≈øe wee commaund to bee kept by you. And Houeden as our prote≈øtants haue publi≈øhed him, reciteth all the≈øe, out of the ≈øame authoritie to haue bene receued in England in a councel of our Bi≈øhops manie hundred yeares ≈øince, ≈øetting downe the begininge of euery one of them, and addeth the tenth of the ble≈ø≈øed Virgin, decimam de
beata Virgine. Roger. Houeden in annal. part. po≈øterior. in Henr. 2.

5. And our Engli≈øh Prote≈øtants them≈øelues by their highe≈øt parlamentary authoritie in ≈øuch things with them, v≈øe the ≈øame prefaces, except that of the Apo≈øtles and ble≈ø≈øed Virgine, in their publick church ≈øeruice, their communion booke. (Protest. communion booke titul. communion.) and yet in that of the ble≈ø≈øed Virgine which ≈øeemeth to haue beene added after the dayes of Pope Vigilius, there is no inuocation of her, nor any matter now que≈øtioned by prote≈øtants found in it. And concerninge that of the Apo≈øtles of matters que≈øtioned there is onely this clau≈øe, or petition vnto God, for pre≈øeruing his church: vt gregem tuum Pastor aeterne non de≈øeras: ≈øed per beatos Apostolos tuos continua protectione cu≈øtodias, vt ij≈ødem Rectortbus gubernetur, quos operis tui Vicarios eidem contuli≈øti prae≈ø≈øe Pastores. That God the eternall Pastor will not for≈øake his flocke, but keepe by his ble≈ø≈øed Apo≈øtles, with continuall protection, that it may bee gouerned by the ≈øame Rulers, whome Vicars of his worke, hee hath appointed Pastors to rule it. Which is not a prayer immediatlie to the Apo≈øtles,
but to God for the protection of his Apo≈øtles, and ≈øuch as our prote≈øtants them≈øelues in their publick ≈øeruice, on S. Michael his day, doe v≈øe for the protection of Angels, as is manife≈øt in their collect or prayer of that fea≈øt, being the old Catholick prayer word by word tran≈ølated into Engli≈øh. And yet if there were any immediate prayer vnto the Apo≈øtles, or any other Saints or Angels, in any oÃÑf the≈øe prefaces, I haue proued before, that it was the receaued doctrine of Chri≈øts church, from the beginninge.

6. And if wee ≈øhould allow vnto prote≈øtants, that Pope Gela≈øius did add in the prefaces, all that clau≈øe, ver√® dignum & iu≈øtum est: vnto, per Christum Dominum no≈øtrum. What is there in it, but holy, and allowable, and ≈øtill practi≈øed by them≈øelues in their church ≈øeruice. This it is: ver√® dignum & iu≈øtum est aequum & ≈øalutare nos tibi ≈øemper & vbique gratias agere Domine ≈øancte Pater omnipotens aterne Deus, per Christum Dominum nostrum, √¥ Lord holy Father omnipotent eternall God, verely it is a thinge worthie and iu≈øt, right and belonginge to ≈øaluation, that wee alwayes and in all places
giue thanks to thee by Chri≈øt our Lord. Are not all Chri≈øtians in all iudgements bound to bee of this minde, and this being a dutie ≈øo bindinge and belonginge vnto al that beleeue in Chri≈øt, is it not the better, the oftner, and more publickly it be acknowledged? o ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ if it be good by prote≈øtants, and in their publick practi≈øe, how can it be ill in Catholicks, or could bee ≈øo in Pope Gela≈øius? And if hee had added, Te igitur clementi≈øsime Pater per Ie≈øum ChristuÃÑ filium tuum Dominum no≈øtrum ≈øupplices rogamus ac petimus: Therefore √¥ mo≈øte mercifull Father, wee aske and be≈øeeche thee, by Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, thy ≈øonne our Lord. It is the ≈øame rea≈øon, as before, this beinge a very Chri≈øtian, and holy prayer, by Prote≈øtant Religion, to aske all things of God in the name of Chri≈øt as hee him≈øelfe ≈øaid: what≈øoeuer you shall aske in my name, that will I doe. (Io. c. 14. v. 13.) and what≈øoeuer yee shall aske of the Father in my name hee may giue it you. Io. c. 15. v. 26.

7. Whereby the≈øe men may ≈øee, that neither the primatiue church which v≈øed inuocation of Saints, nor the pre≈øent church of Rome in≈øi≈øtinge therein, did, or doe dimini≈øh
any honor, or dutie to Chri≈øt, by honoringe them, which honor him, and are honoured by him. Yet S. Remigius witne≈ø≈øeth, this prayer, Te igitur clementi≈øsime Pater, to haue beene v≈øed from the Apo≈øtles. (Remig. in epist. 1. ad Timoth. cap. 2.) Wheras ≈øome prote≈øtants write of Pope Gela≈øius. (Balaeus l. 2. de actis Pontif. Rom. in Gela≈øio.) Gela≈øius hymnos, prefationes, gradualia, collectas & orationes prae≈øcrip≈øit: Pope Gela≈øius did pre≈øcribe hymnes, prefaces, graduals, collects, and prayers: I haue proued by the≈øe prote≈øtants, that all the≈øe were v≈øed in the church, and laudably longe before: and by the word prae≈øcrip≈øit, hee did pre≈øcribe, what hymnes, prefaces, graduals, and collects, or prayers were to bee v≈øed, it is euident, the≈øe were before, and he being Pope, and cheife, pre≈øcribed the order how they ≈øhould bee v≈øed: which proueth, he rather tooke ≈øome away, then added any, for amonge them were before, prae≈øcrip≈øit, he pre≈øcribed, which, and no others ≈øhould bee v≈øed. And wheras there is a controuer≈øie, by ≈øome, whether this pre≈øcription and orderinge the≈øe things was by Pope Gela≈øius, or one called Schola≈øticus; Ma≈øter Foxe the Prote≈øtant hi≈øtorian
decideth this que≈øtion. (Io. Foxe in Q. Mary pag. 1403.) teaching out of, vetusto quodam libro de officio Mi≈øsa, an old booke of the office of Ma≈ø≈øe, that the≈øe were both one, and Gela≈øius, beinge Schola≈øticus before, was made Pope: Gela≈øius Papa ex Schola≈øtico effectus in ordine 48) And thus much of Gela≈øius.

8. After whome, for an intermedler in the≈øe affaires, our prote≈øtants propo≈øe Pope Symmachus. (Barnes in vit. Pontif. Rom. in Symmacho. Bal. l. 2. in eod.) who commaunded, gloria in excel≈øis Deo, to bee ≈øunge vppon ≈øondayes, and fea≈øts of Saints. In Dominico die & Sanctorum natalitijs, gloria in excel≈øis canendum e≈ø≈øe dixit; or by an other, praecepit. But if they meane the fir≈øt part, of this holy hymne, it was the ≈øonge of the Angels, at the birthe of Chri≈øt, and recommended vnto vs in ≈øcripture, and by one of the≈øe prote≈øtants, v≈øed at Ma≈ø≈øe by the commaundement of Saint, and Pope Tele≈øphorus, who liued in the Apo≈øtles time: gloria in excel≈øis Deo &c. in Mi≈øsa canendum praecepit. (Rob. Barnes in vit. Pontif. Rom. in Tele≈øphoro. & S. Petro) and if they meane the whole canticle, as it is now v≈øed, their brother
Iohn Foxe, with others, thus te≈øtifieth. (Iohn. Foxe ≈øupr. in Q. Mary.) The hymne, gloria in excel≈øis, which was ≈øunge of the Angels at the birth of our Sauiour, was augmented by Hilarius Pictauien≈øis, with tho≈øe words, that follow, ≈øinging it first in his owne church, which was an. 340. & afterward brought into other churches by Pope Symmachus. And our hi≈øtories te≈øtifie it was v≈øed here in Britanie by S. German in his time. And our Engli≈øh Prote≈øtants v≈øe it, in their publicke church ≈øeruice, at this day, by publicke authoritie. Engl. Prote≈øtant communion booke morninge prayer.

9. That which a Prote≈øtant Bi≈øhop writeth of this Pope, that he reduced the Ma≈ø≈øe to forme, Mi≈øsam in formam redegit. (Bal. l. 2. Act. Pontif. Rom. in Symmacho.) is his formall forgery, or foolery, confounded by many vndeniable in≈øtances graunted by prote≈øtants before, as the forme of Ma≈ø≈øe of S. Peter, S Iames, S. Matthew, S Marke, S. Clement, S. Ba≈øile, S. Chri≈øo≈øtome, and Popes of Rome longe before this time, as amonge other witne≈ø≈øes this Prote≈øtant Bi≈øhop him≈øelfe te≈øtifieth of S. Innocentius, Syricius, S. Cele≈øtine, S. Leo and Gela≈øius.
(Bal. in Act. Pontif. Rom. in Innocent. Syric. Cale≈øtino Leon. Gela≈ø.) therefore without euident contradiction, and wilfull errour, he cannot intend, or affirme, that Pope Symmachus did fir≈øt bringe the Ma≈ø≈øe into order. Therefore of nece≈ø≈øitie to keepe him≈øelfe from the≈øe ab≈øurdities, he mu≈øt vnder≈øtand, that Pope Symmachus confirmed, or allowed of the forme of Ma≈ø≈øe, formerlie v≈øed in the church, which all Popes & good Chri≈øtians euer did, and ought to doe.

10. And here endeth the fift hundred yeare, at which time, and longe after, as with others, our prote≈øtants a≈ø≈øure vs, that S. Dubritius that great ma≈ø≈øinge Prelate, and Archbi≈øhop primate here, & the Popes Legate, and great Ma≈øter of diuinitie, together with S. Iltutus priuiledged in the ≈øame facultie by papall authoritie, and S. Gildas by whome all Britanie and other contries receaued in≈øtruction were liuinge, and con≈øequently agreeing in all thinges with the church of Rome. (Bal. cent. 1. in Dubritie Iltuto Gylda Albanio. Godwin. Catal. in S. Dauids. Capgrau. Catal. in Dubrit. Iltut. Gild.) About which time al≈øo amonge diuers others tho≈øe three great lights of our Britti≈øh
church knowne ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øts, and Bi≈øhops S. Dauid that ≈øucceeded S. Dubritius in his archiepi≈øcopall dignitie, S. Thelians and S. Patern, began to flori≈øh, and went that great Pilgrimage to Hieru≈øalem. (M. S. antiq. Capgrau. Catal. in S. Dauid. S. Thelian. & S. Paterno & alij. M. S. S. Theliai apud Godwin. Catal. in Landaff. 2.) and both in going and returninge through Italy and tho≈øe places, and ordinarily ≈øayinge Ma≈ø≈øe, mu≈øt needs v≈øe that order and forme therof, they found to bee v≈øed at Rome, and all places receauinge direction from thence in ≈øuch affaires, and ≈øo here I end this age, and centenary of yeares.

div.head: THE SIXTH AGE, OR HVNDRED YEARES OF CHRIST.

THE XXI. CHAPTER. Wherein being confe≈ø≈øed by our prote≈øtant writers, that all the Popes of Rome vnto S. Gregory were ma≈øsinge prei≈øts, and Popes, yet not any one of theÃÑ by the≈øe prote≈øtaÃÑts coÃÑ fe≈øsion, made any the least materiall chaunge, or alteration in the≈øe mi≈øteries.
div.p:
NOw wee are come to the ≈øixt age, or hundred of yeares, of Chri≈øt, wherin
liued S. Gregory the great, Pope of Rome, that ≈øent S. Augu≈øtine and diuers other holie cleargie men hither, which conuerted a greater part of this nation, and kingdome, called England; Wherefore ≈øeeing by confe≈ø≈øion of our be≈øt learned prote≈øtants, the Chri≈øtian Britans of this Iland, had from their fir≈øt conuer≈øion vnto Chri≈øt, and did at the coming of S. Augu≈øtine from Rome, continue in the ≈øame holy faith, and Religion, which they had learned, and receued in the Apo≈øtles time, and hitherto we haue not found any materiall difference in any age between them, & the church of Rome in the≈øe cheif que≈øtions I haue in hand; now to make euideÃÑt demon≈øtration by the≈øe aduer≈øaries to the holy Romane Religion, that this church neuer altered any ≈øub≈øtantiall matter, by their owne iudgement, at, before, or after, the cominge of S. Augu≈øtine hither, I will fir≈øt ≈øet downe all the pretended chaunges additioÃÑs or alteratioÃÑs, which the≈øe prote≈øtants charge that holy church withall, in the≈øe affaires, prouinge them to bee of no moment, or e≈ø≈øentiall; And after ≈øhew how the Chri≈øtian Britans in this age al≈øo, as in all the former, ≈øtill agreed in the≈øe
que≈øtions with the church of Rome. And wheras there was then ≈øome difference betweene the di≈øciples of S. Gregorie and the BritaÃÑs here about the ob≈øeruation of Ea≈øter, and ≈øome other que≈øtions, rather ceremoniall, then ≈øub≈øtantiall in Religion, that the church euen by the te≈øtimonie of our prote≈øtants, did hold the truth in the≈øe matters, and ≈øuch Britans and Scots as held the contrary, were in confe≈ø≈øed, and vnexcu≈øable error.

2. The fir≈øt alleaged chaunger or additioner of any thinge in the holy ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe, which our prote≈øtants obiect among the Popes of Rome, in this age, is Hor≈ømida, who as the≈øe men write: commaunded that altars should not be erected, without the a≈ø≈øent of the Bishop. Ne altaria ≈øine Epi≈øcopi a≈øsen≈øu erigerentur iu≈øsit. (Rob. Barnes in vit. Pontif. Rom. in Hor≈ømida. Bal. in Act. Pont. in eod.) but this was according to holy ≈øcriptures, to haue Superiors and commaunders to bee obeyed: remember them which haue the rule ouer you. Obey them that haue the rule ouer you, and ≈øubmit your≈øelues. (Hebr. cap. 13. v. 7.17. and S. Ignatius liuinge in the fir≈øt hundred yeares, proueth noe ≈øuch
thinge ought to bee done without the Bi≈øhops a≈ø≈øent. (Ignat. epi≈øt. ad Smyrnen≈øes.) and the puritan presbytery, and among our Engli≈øh parlament Prote≈øtaÃÑts no ≈øuch matter in their Religion may bee done, without the allowance of theire Prote≈øtant Bi≈øhops. And the≈øe prote≈øtant obiectors them≈øelues before confe≈ø≈øe, that Pope Syricius tooke order, that Ma≈ø≈øe ≈øhould not bee ≈øaid but in places coÃÑ≈øecrated by the Bi≈øhop. Mi≈ø≈øas in loco ab Epi≈øcopo ≈øacrato celebrandas e≈ø≈øe. (Rob. Barnes in vit. Syricij Papae.) which was ≈øoone after the cea≈øinge of per≈øecution by the Emperors, that places might bee freely dedicated to God, and hallowinge of altars beloÃÑged properly euer to the epi≈øcopal dignitie. And our prote≈øtants ar witne≈ø≈øes, that this was then practi≈øed and ob≈øerued in Britanie by S. Dauid, S. Dubritius and others, too many to be recited. And in Kinge Lucius his time, when ≈øo many churches with their altars were dedicated by our holy Bi≈øhops to God, S. Peter, and other Saints. Godwin conuer≈ø. cap. 2. pag. 11. Holinsh. hist. of Engl. Theat. of great Britanie. Capgrau. in S. Patricio & alij.

3. From Hor≈ømida, they lepp ouer Ioannes
1. Faelix 4. Bonifacius 2. Ionnes 2. Agapetus 1. Syluerius 1. vntil they come to Pope Vigilius, who as the≈øe men ≈øay, decreed, that Ma≈ø≈øe should bee ≈øaid towardes the caste: Instituit vt Mi≈øsa celebretur ver≈øus orientem. (Io. Bal. l. 2. de Act. Pontif. Rom. in Vigilio.) or as an other prote≈øtant interpreteth it: Vigilius in≈øtituted that preists being to ≈øay Ma≈ø≈øe, should turne their face towardes the east. (Barnes in vit. Vigilij) Vigilius instituit, vt Mi≈øsam celebraturi, faciem ad orientem verterent. But this is onely a ceremony if he had fir≈øt inuented it: but S. Ba≈øile telleth vs it was an apo≈øtolicall tradition, ≈øo to pray towards the ea≈øt. (Ba≈øil. l. de Spiritu Sancto cap. 27.) for ≈øpeaking of ≈øuch traditions from the Apo≈øtles, not conteyned in ≈øcripture he ≈øaith: vt ad orientem ver≈øus precemur, quae decuit ≈øcriptura? to pray with our faces towardes the ea≈øt is a tradition, and not taught in ≈øcripture. And this tradition and cu≈øtome of the primatiue Chri≈øtians to pray, and ≈øay Ma≈ø≈øe turning their faces towards the ea≈øt, was ≈øo common, publick, and well known longe before this time (Proclus ≈øupra in vita S. Patricij. Holinsh. hi≈øtor. of Ireland in S. Patrick) that as I haue declared before,
both Catholick and Prote≈øtant antiquaries ≈øo a≈ø≈øuring vs, it was giuen for a di≈øtinctiue ≈øigne, by the deuils and magiciens of Ireland, to the then Pagan inhabitants therof, before the cominge of S. Patrick thither, to know him and his Chri≈øtian di≈øciples by, that they ≈øhould ≈øett their Altar, ≈øay Ma≈ø≈øe, and pray towards the ea≈øt, as wee generallie ≈øee chauncels & high altars of Chri≈øtian churches are framed. Therefore wee may be ≈øecure, that hitherto the church of Rome and Britanie agreed in the≈øe mi≈øteries, nothinge added yet by any Pope, which the Britans did not embrace. For better te≈øtimonie whereof we are told by the antiquaries of Cambridge, that Kinge Arthur in his charter of priuiledge, to that ≈øchole, or vniuer≈øitie, bearinge date at London, in the yeare of Chri≈øt 531. doth therin expre≈ø≈øe, that hee giueth that confirmation with the coun≈øaile and a≈ø≈øent of all and euery Bishops, and nobles of his kingdome, and licence of the ≈øee Apostilick of Rome. Con≈øilio & con≈øen≈øu omnium & ≈øingulorum Pontificum & Principum i≈øtius regni, & licentia ≈øedis Apo≈øtolicae. (Io. Caius l. 1. antiquit. pag. 69. Diploma Regis Arthuri 7. die Aprilis an. 531. Londini
apud Caium ≈øupr. pag. 68.69.70.) therfore if the then Kings of Britanie, and all the Bi≈øhops, and Noble men thereof, by which the re≈øt were gouerned, did then ≈øo firmly adhere to the Pope of Rome in matters of Religion, that they would not ioyne in ≈øuch an Act, without his licence, no man will thinke, there was or then could be any difference in Religion betweene them. And to coÃÑfirme vs the more in this great vnion, and amitie of Rome and Britanie, in ≈øuch affaires, at this time of Pope Vigilius, and Kinge Arthur, our prote≈øtants Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter telleth vs. (Matth. Westm. an. 533. that this Religious Kinge committed Walwan ≈øonne to Loth his ≈øi≈øters ≈øonne, Who should haue inherited the kingedome of Norwey to Pope Vigilius to bee brought vp, when hee was but 12. yeares of age, and that hee was knighted by him. Erat autem Walwanus filius praedicti Loth, duodecim annorum iuuenis, Vigilio Papae traditus ad nutriendum, √† quo etiam & militiae cingulum accepit. How farr this Pope intermeddled in ordering the prefaces in Ma≈ø≈øe, I haue ≈øaid before, & the≈øe prote≈øtants being ≈øilent therin, thereby re≈øt contented in that point.

4. The next additioner with the≈øe prote≈øtants, is the next Pope, Pelagius the fir≈øt: who as the≈øe men ≈øay, gaue allowance that in time of Lent prei≈øts might ≈øay Ma≈ø≈øe at the ninth hower of the day, which is three of the clocke in the afternoone by our accompt. In quadrage ≈øima presbytero licere ≈øacra facere hora nona pronuntiauit. (Rob. Barnes in Pelag. 1.) an other ≈øaith: vt quadrag e≈øimali tempore hora nona ≈øacrificulis mi≈ø≈øare liceret. (Bal. in Pelag. 1.) but this was but a ceremony, and argued, how reuerent and deuout prei≈øts were, in that time, to this holy ≈øacrifice, that they did, and would fa≈øt ≈øo longe to ≈øay Ma≈ø≈øe, ≈øo nere the time it was in≈øtituted by Chri≈øt, and Chri≈øt was offered vpon the Cro≈ø≈øe, this proueth, they were not prote≈øtants in that time, which neither reuerence Ma≈ø≈øe, nor fa≈øt ≈øo longe, or at all in Lent. But they add of this Pope: mortuorum memorias approbauit, ac lucri gratia mi≈ø≈øis adiecit. Hee approued the memories of the dead, and for gaine added them to Ma≈ø≈øes. (Bal. in Pelag. 1.) but this Prote≈øtant Bi≈øhop is either very forgetfull, or maketh no ≈øcruple to contradict him≈øelfe, for he telleth vs before in the life of Saint and Pope Siricius
loÃÑge before S. Cele≈øtine ≈øent S. German and the re≈øt into the≈øe parts, that this S. Syricius adioyned memories vnto Ma≈ø≈øes, and yet died a confe≈ø≈øor in the yeare of our Lord 399. Syricius Mi≈ø≈øae memorias adiunxit, & anno Domini 399. confe≈ø≈øor occubuit. (Balaeus. l. 2. de Act. Pontif. Rom. in Syricio.) and Tertullian in his time ≈øetteth it downe for an Apo≈øtolicall tradition, to ≈øay Ma≈ø≈øe for the deade, and keepe their anniuer≈øary daies, oblationes pro defunctis, pro natalitijs annua die faecimus. (Tertul. l. de coron. milit. cap. 3.) S. Ciprian S. Chri≈øo≈øtome and others haue the like. And our prote≈øtants haue confe≈ø≈øed before, that it was an Apo≈øtolicall tradition to ≈øay Ma≈ø≈øe for the dead, and that Aerius was iu≈øtly condemned of here≈øie, and for an hereticke for his denyall thereof. And wee had here in Britanie many foundations to ≈øay Ma≈ø≈øe, and pray for Chri≈øtian ≈øoules, and frends decea≈øed, as we find in the charter of Kinge Arthur before recited, wherin among other motiues of that his confirmatorie priuiledge to the vniuer≈øitie of Cambridge, hee ≈øaith expre≈ø≈øely, that hee doth it, with the con≈øent of all his Bi≈øhops, for the helpe of the ≈øoules of his antece≈ø≈øors
Kings of Britanie. Pro amore caelestis patriae, remedioque animarum Antece≈ø≈øorum meorum BritaÃÑniae Regum. Charta Regis Arthuri apud Caium ≈øupr. antiq. Cantabr. l. 1. pag. 69.

5. After this Pope, vntill they come to S. Gregory, the≈øe prote≈øtants complaine of no additions, but onely in Pope Pelagius the ≈øecond, which was the immediate predece≈ø≈øor to S. Gregory, and ≈øent him, yet a priuate prei≈øt, his legate to Con≈øtantinople: of this Pope they write: nouem praefationes ante canonem in Mi≈ø≈øa canendas de dit. Hee gaue nyne prefaces to bee ≈øunge before the canon in Ma≈ø≈øe. (Bal. in Pelag. 2. l. 2. in Act. Pontif. an other thus more particularly expre≈ø≈øeth it: Pelagtus nouem praefationes Eccle≈øiae de dit ante canonem, in Mi≈ø≈øa canendas: in Natali, in Epiphania, in Quadrage≈øima, de Cruce, de Re≈øurrectione, de A≈øcen≈øione, in PeÃÑ teco≈øte, de Trinitate, de Apo≈øtolis¬∑ (Barnes in Pelag. 2. in vit. Pont.) Pelagius gaue nyne prefaces to the church, to bee ≈øunge before the canon in Ma≈ø≈øe, one in the natiuitie of Chri≈øt, an other in the Epiphanie, in Lent, of the Cro≈ø≈øe, of the Re≈øurrection, of the A≈øcen≈øion, at Whit≈øontyde, of the Trinitie, of the Apo≈øtles. I haue an≈øwered this before,
in Pope Gela≈øius, to whome the≈øe prote≈øtants before contradictinge them ≈øelues a≈øcribe the preface, how vaine this quarrell is I haue there declared, and onely add here from theire prote≈øtant like publi≈øhed Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter: Anno gratiae 581. Papa Pelagius decreuit nouem praefationes taÃÑ tum ad Mi≈ø≈øas debere cantari, ca≈øsatis quotidianis quae dici ≈øolebant. In the yeare of grace 581. Pope Pelagius decreed that only nine prefaces ≈øhould bee ≈øunge at Ma≈ø≈øe omittinge the daily prefaces which were wont to bee ≈øaid. Where wee ≈øee that this Pope did not add any thinge in this bu≈øines, but rather deducted ≈øome prefaces, though they had beene v≈øed to bee ≈øaid before, for ≈øo the words, dici ≈øolebant, manife≈øtly proue, as I wrote of Pope Vigilius before. All which doe euidentlie te≈øtifie, that the auncient receued cu≈øtome of the church of Chri≈øt was longe before the≈øe dayes, to v≈øe the≈øe prefaces.

div.head: THE XXII. CHAPTER. Wherein euident demon≈øtration is made, euen by the≈øe prote≈øtants them≈øelues, that neither S. Gregory the great, which ≈øent S. Augustine, with many other holy learned men into England, did make any materiall addition, or alteration in the≈øe mi≈øteries. But the Religion which tho≈øe his di≈øciples preached here, was in all points by all testimonies both of God and man, Britans them ≈øelues, and Saxons, Catholicks and Protestants, auncient and late writers, the true Religion of Chri≈øt, and in all things wherin they differed from the Britans, more pure then that which they then profe≈øsed.
div.p:
NOw wee are come to the happy dayes of S. Gregory the great, that ≈øent ≈øo many holy men, to preach Chri≈øtian Religion to this Engli≈øh nation, and ≈øo called our Apo≈øtle, in which it will bee more manife≈øt, euen by the≈øe prote≈øtant accu≈øers them≈øelues, that what≈øoeuer differeÃÑce there was, betweene the holy di≈øciples which he ≈øent hither, and ≈øome Britans, the error in
euery point was in tho≈øe that oppo≈øed again≈øt the Roman mi≈ø≈øion. And for S. Gregory him≈øelfe, one of the four holy Doctors of the church of Chri≈øt, he was by all te≈øtimonies a great learned man, & holy Saint, and ≈øo honored both in the Greeke and Latine church, and the Ma≈ø≈øe hee v≈øed as our prote≈øtants haue told vs. (Edw. Sands relation of Relig. ≈øupr.) both was, and is receued and publickly v≈øed euen in the Greeke church, beeing tran≈ølated into Greeke: hee is ≈øtiled by all writers prote≈øtants and Catholicks, Gregory the great, and commonlie named the Apo≈øtle of the Engli≈øh nation, in all publicke prote≈øtant Kalenders placed amonge the holy Saints, and by a Prote≈øtant Bi≈øhop his greate≈øt accu≈øer, dignified, with the≈øe honorable termes. (Bal. l. 2. de Act. Pontific. Rom. in Gregorio Magno.) Gregorius Magnus omnium Pontificum ≈øeu vt dictum est Patriarcharum Romanorum, doctrina, & vita prae≈øtanti≈øsimus: inuitus ac demu ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ coactus Pelagio praedicto ≈øucce≈øsit, vir doctus & bonus. Gregory the great the mo≈øt excellent both for learninge and life, of all the Romane Popes or Patriarkes, did again≈øt his will, and at la≈øte therto compelled, ≈øucceed
Pelagius the ≈øecond, hee was a learned and good man. Therefore it cannot bee either probable, or po≈ø≈øible, that a man ≈øo learned, vertuous, and holy, that hee is thus dignified by ≈øo great enemies, both for learninge and pietie aboue all the Popes that euer were ≈øo learned, & knowne holy Saints, and ≈øo vnwillinge to take that greate≈øt honor, and charge vpon him, would or could contrary both to ≈øo great learning, and pietie, which could not con≈øi≈øt with any the lea≈øt error in Religion in e≈ø≈øentiall things, make any erroneous publick decree in ≈øuch affaires. For in ≈øo doinge hee ≈øhould haue beene ≈øo farr from that eminent learninge, and pietie, and beinge a glorious Saint in heauen, which both by prote≈øtants and Catholicks are generally held and written of him, that quite contrary hee ≈øhould haue beene an vnlearned, wicked, and damned man. Which no tonge or mouth that hath learned to coÃÑfe≈ø≈øe Chri≈øt, dareth to affirme or vtter.

2. But to giue all contentment, I will examine all what≈øoeuer in particular, they ≈øay this ≈øo holy learned Pope added, or altered in the≈øe mi≈øteries, as they pretend. This
Prote≈øtant Bi≈øhop ≈øaith of him (Bal. l. 2. ≈øupr. in Gregor. Mag.) introitum in Mi≈ø≈øa ex aliquo p≈øalmo cancre iu≈øsit. Hee commaunded the introite in the Ma≈ø≈øe to bee ≈øunge out of ≈øome p≈øalme. They haue told vs before of more auncient times wherein the introite was v≈øed, before S. German, Lupus, Palladius & Patricius were ≈øent into the≈øe parts. But if S. Gregory did any ≈øuch thing, ≈øeeing it was ex aliquo p≈øalmo, out of the holy ≈øcripture, neither the≈øe men, nor any which will not di≈øallow of holy ≈øcripture, may reprehend it. And where this prote≈øtant accu≈øer further ≈øaith: Nonies in Mi≈ø≈øa, Kyrie eley≈øon canere iu≈øsit. S. Gregory commaunded that Lord haue mercy vpon vs, should bee ≈øunge 9. times in Ma≈ø≈øe. Hee is deceued, for that is ≈øonge but 6. times, and Christ haue mercy vpon vs, thri≈øe: And his frend Ma≈øter Foxe. (Io. Foxe in Q. Mary pag. 1401.) will tell him, that this was the auncient cu≈øtome of the Greeke church longe before, froÃÑ which is was taken by S. Gregory, only that S. Gregory added, Christ haue mercy vpon vs. But how≈øoeuer is it not a mo≈øte holy and warranted cu≈øtome, ≈øo to pray? our prote≈øtants theÃÑ≈øelues ob≈øerue it in their publick church
≈øeruice. (Com. booke tit. Litan. & alibi.) and commonlie preferr them before all other prayers, both in their priuate, and publicke writings.

3. Of S. Gregories addinge, die≈øque no≈øtros in tua pace di≈øponas, and di≈øpo≈øe our dayes in peace, and graunt wee bee deliuered from eternall damnation, and numbred in the flock of thy elect. I haue ≈øpoken before, & here only I add, that S. Bede, whome this Prote≈øtant Bi≈øhop. (Io. Bal. l. de ≈øcriptor. Britan. centur. 1. in Beda Girwino.) doth equall or rather preferr before S. Gregory, S. Augu≈øtine, S. Hierome, and S. Chri≈øo≈øtome, tho≈øe great lights of Chri≈øts church, doth ≈øay, that the≈øe wordes which S. Gregory added in the holie Ma≈ø≈øe, are words ful of greate≈øt perfection: Beatus Papa Gregorius in ip≈øa Mi≈ø≈øarum celebratione, tria verba maximae perfectionis plena ≈øuperadiecit, die≈øque nostros in tua pace di≈øponas, atque ab aeterna damnatione nos cripi, & in electorum tuorum iubeas grege numerari. (Beda Eccle≈ø. histor. l. 2. cap. 1.) in which place hee al≈øo commendeth him, for cau≈øinge in the churches of S. Peter and S. Paul at Rome, Ma≈ø≈øes to be ≈øaid ouer their bodies. Fecit inter alia beatus Papa Gregorius, vt in
Eccle≈øijs beatorum Apostolorum Petri & Pauli ≈øuper corpora eoruÃÑ Mi≈ø≈øae celebrarentur. Which ≈øacred bodies of tho≈øe two glorious Apo≈øtles, this lewde prote≈øtant ≈øuperintendent, & therin as his phra≈øe teacheth, a V ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ gilantian hereticke, calleth the deade ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ arca≈ø≈øes of the Apo≈øtles, ≈øo as wee terme the deade bodies of bea≈øtes, and therefore di≈øliketh S. Gregory for that in≈øtitution: ≈øuper Apostolorum mortua cadauera Mi≈øsas celebrari mandauit. (Bal. l. 2. de Act. Pontif. Rom. in Gregor. Magno.) but though it doth not belonge to this place, and my promi≈øe, yet to free S. Gregory from all pretended error in any matter, I wil ≈øhew in the next chapter, when I come to ≈øpeake of the britti≈øh prei≈øts, and Bi≈øhops of this age, that they were as farr engaged in this doctrine of reuereÃÑce to holie relicks, as either S. Gregory, or his di≈øciples hee ≈øent hither were, or the Catholicks of the pre≈øent Roman church bee at this time. The ≈øame I wil demon≈øtrate concerning the doctrine of Indulgences, an other preteÃÑded blott, which they would gladly find out, to ≈øtaine, and blemi≈øh the glory of that great Doctor, Pope, and Saint.

4. And whereas this prote≈øtant Bi≈øhop
≈øaith of this holy Pope: Hee admitted Ma≈ø≈øes for the dead, Mi≈ø≈øas pro mortuis admi≈øit, I haue often ≈øhewed by the≈øe prote≈øtants, that this was v≈øed from the beginninge. And whereas hee obiecteth. (Bal. ≈øupr. in Greg. Magno.) that S. Gregory fir≈øt in≈øtituted Candelma≈ø≈øe day, and palme ≈øonday, with ≈øolemnitie of proce≈ø≈øion, though the≈øe bee but ceremoniall, yet he contradicteth him≈øelfe, knowinge and acknowledginge, that proce≈ø≈øions were longe before in v≈øe, and that Candelma≈ø≈øe day was kept with candels in the time of Pope Vigilius, and by his approbation: candelaruÃÑ fe≈øtum in≈øtituit. (Bal. in Vigilio l. 2. Act. Pontific. Rom.) whereas this man ≈øaith in S. Augu≈øtine, S Gregories di≈øciple, that hee brought hither altars, ve≈øtiments, holy ve≈ø≈øels, relicks, and bookes of ceremonies, introduxit altaria, ve≈øtimenta, va≈øa ≈øacra, reliquias, & ceremoniarum codices. (Bal. l. de ≈øcriptor. Britan. l. 1. in Augu≈øtino. Monocho.) I haue ≈øhewed already, that all the≈øe were in v≈øe with the Chri≈øtiaÃÑ Britans longe before, and this prote≈øtant obiector among others, ≈øo acknowledgeth in diuers, both Scots, and Britans, in this Iland, and in the life of S. Patrick he receueth as S. Patricks,
the epi≈øtle written in his name: Patricius ≈øcrip≈øit ad Aualonios Inculas epi≈øtolam. (Bal. centur. 1. Gild. l. de excid. Bed. l. v. histor. Eccle≈ø. Bal. centur. 1. in Brigida Lagin. Kentegern. Patric. Iona. Monacho & alijs.) in which hee proueth both S. Patricke, S. Pope Cele≈øtine, S. Pope Eleutherius, and his Legates S. Damianus, and Fugatianus in Kinge Lucius time, and all the Britans in tho≈øe times, to haue beene as great Patrons, and practi≈øers of the≈øe doctrines and cu≈øtomes, which hee di≈øliketh in S. Gregory & his di≈øciples, as any of them theÃÑ was, or any learned Catholicke at this pre≈øent is. Thus f ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ rr the≈øe prote≈øtants exceptions again≈øt the doctrine of S. Gregory, and his di≈øciples, all turning to theire glory, and confu≈øion of the prote≈øtant accu≈øers by their owne ≈øentence.

5. To which I will add one thing more from our holy contrimaÃÑ S. Aldelmus ≈øcholler to S. Gregory as his words import, who thus relateth an addition of S. Gregorie to the canon of the Ma≈ø≈øe, which our prote≈øtants doe not remember in their oblations. (S. Adelmus l. de laudib. Virginitat. cap. 22.) mihi operae pretium videtur, vt Sanctae Agathae rumores ca≈øti≈øsimae Virginis Luciae praeconia
≈øub≈øequantur: Quas Praeceptor & pedagogus noster Gregorius, in canone quotidiano, quando Mi≈ø≈øarum ≈øolemnia celebrantur copula≈øse cogno≈øcitur, hoc modo in Catalogo Martyrum ponens: Faelicitate, Anasta≈øia, Agatha, Lucia. It is a thinge worth labour, that after ≈øpeach of S. Agatha (he ≈øpeaketh of the prai≈øe of virginitie) the prai≈øes of the mo≈øte cha≈øte Virgin Lucia, should follow, which our Ma≈øter and In≈øtructor Gregory, is knowne to haue coupled in the daily canon, when the ≈øolemnities of Ma≈øse are celebrated, placing them thus in the Catalogue of Martyrs: Faelicitas, Anasta≈øia, Agatha, Luciae. But this rather maketh again≈øt prote≈øtant quarrels, in this kinde, for they contendinge again≈øt the doctrine of prayer to Saints, are taught here, that it was the auncient cu≈øtome of Gods church to pray vnto them, euen in their publick Ma≈ø≈øes. (can. Mi≈ø≈ø. ¬ß. nobis quoque peccatoribus.) for S. Gregory did here onely add S. Agatha, and S. Lucia, vnto the others, which were in the canon before, copula≈ø≈øe cogno≈øcitur, and bee very many in particular, as appeareth in that place, be≈øides all the Apo≈øtles and holy Martyrs in generall, cum tuis Sanctis Apo≈øtolis, & Martyribus: and the
words, in canone quotidiano, in the daily canon of Ma≈ø≈øe, are an euident conuiction, that the daily canon of Ma≈ø≈øe was v≈øed, and this honor of Saints al≈øo therin before this time: as wee ≈øee in all old Ma≈ø≈øes, Greeke, Latine, or Syriake. And I haue before proued, that this holy doctrine was euer from the beginning of Chri≈øtianity in this kingdome reuerently ob≈øerued. Of the truth and excellency of S. Gregories and S. Augu≈øtines Religion planted amonge the Saxons, I haue ≈øpoken ≈øufficiently in all things in my eccle≈øia≈øticall hi≈øtorie at large.

6. To proue it breifly in this place more ≈øound and perfect then the Religion of the Chri≈øtian Britans, ≈øo dignified by our prote≈øtant writers, I fir≈øt v≈øe them for witne≈ø≈øes thereof. And fir≈øt the pre≈øent Prote≈øtant Archbi≈øhop of Canterbury D. George Abbots, the director of Ma≈øter Frauncis Ma≈øon, and this his directed ≈øcribe thus write, producinge the Britti≈øh Bi≈øhops them≈øelues at that time ≈øo acknowledginge. (George Abbot and Franc. Ma≈øon l. 2. of con≈øecrat. of Bish. cap 4. pag. 59.) The brittish Bishops confe≈ø≈øed, that they vnderstood that to be the true way of righteou≈ønes, which Augu≈øtine had
preached. Yea the faith which S. Augustine brought, and that which the Britans had before, mu≈øt needs be one and the ≈øame in all materiall and ≈øubstantiall points. Wherefore wee cannot excu≈øe the Britans, for refu≈øing to ioyne with him in the conuer≈øion of the Saxons. The like haue, Stowe, Howes, Hollin≈øhed and other prote≈øtants. (Stowe and Howes hi≈øtor. in K. Ethelbert. Holinsh. hist. of Engl. l. 5. cap. 15. pag. 96. pag. 97. an. 581.) ≈øhewinge directly, that the Chri≈øtian Britans at the coming of S. Augu≈øtine, and his companions, were farr inferiour vnto them, both in holines of life, and puritie of doctrine. Which is te≈øtified with great lameÃÑtation by S. Gildas a Britane, S. Bede writer of the britti≈øh hi≈øtory. (Gildas l. de excid. & conquest. Brit. Bed. histor. Eccl. l. 1. Galfrid. Monument. hist. Reg. Brit. l. 10. & 11.

7. And if wee di≈øcend vnto the particular differences, which then were betweene S. Augu≈øtine, and the Britans, there is not any one to bee found in any antiquitie, that concerned the que≈øtions I haue in hand, but in them there was an vniforme con≈øent by all writers, onely I finde that they differed in ≈øome ceremonies about the con≈øecration
of Bi≈øhops, but in no materiall thinge. (S. A≈øaph. in vit. S. Kentegerni. M. S. in vit. eius & Capgrau. in Catal. in Kenteg.) and our prote≈øtants differ from them both therein. For the Britans did then con≈øecrate Bishops with anointing their heads with holy Chri≈øme, Inuocation of the holy Ghost, Benediction, and Impo≈øition of handes: Mos in Britannia inoleuerat in con≈øecratione Pontificum tantummodo capita eorum ≈øacri Chri≈ømatis infu≈øione perungere, cum inuocatione Sancti Spiritus, & Benedictione, & manus Impo≈øitione. And the Romans be≈øides the≈øe nece≈ø≈øarie things, in that con≈øecration, kept and ob≈øerued the decrees of the holy Canons, in this bu≈øines; Which the Britans did not omit for any di≈ølike they had of tho≈øe ≈øacred ceremonies, but by di≈øtance of place, and infe≈øted with Pagans inua≈øions, were ignorant of the canons, as our Authors ≈øay: In≈øulam enim qua≈øi extra orbem po≈øiti, emergentibus Paganorum infestationibus, canonum erant ignari¬∑ (M. S. de vita S. Kenteger¬∑ antiq. & Capgrau ≈øupr. in eod.) and yet our prote≈øtants both knowinge the canonicall in≈øtitutions, and what both the Romans and Britans, with all the Chri≈øtian worlde at that time, thought
to bee e≈ø≈øentiall, and nece≈ø≈øary in this holy Sacrament, neither follow the one, or other, and ≈øo by al iudgement, haue depriued them ≈øelues of lawfull and true Bi≈øhops, and con≈øequentlie of all true cleargie men, which cannot be without true and lawful Bi≈øhops, ≈øuch as they want, to con≈øecrate them.

8. The other differences betwene S. Augu≈øtine, and the Britans, may appeare out of the words of S. Augu≈øtine vnto them, related by S. Bede, and others, and thus ≈øett downe by our prote≈øtant hi≈øtorians. Augu≈øtines oration breifly was thus. (Bed. histor. Eccle≈ø. l. 2. cap. 2. Stowe and Howes histor. in Kentish. Saxons. K. Ethelbert.) although deare bretheren, in many other points yee doe contrary to our cu≈øtome, or rather contrary to the cu≈øtome of the vniuer≈øall church of Christ: yet notwithstandinge if yee will in the≈øe three things con≈øent vnto mee, that is, to celebrate the easter in due time, to accomplish the ministerie of Bapti≈øme accordinge to the Roman, and Apostolick church, and last of all to preach with vs to this English nation, the vvord of our Lord, all your other ceremonies, rites, and customes, though they bee contrary to ours, yet vvee vvill vvillinglie ≈øuffer, and bee content
to beare vvith them. But they ansvvered they vvoulde doe none of the≈øe thinges requested. Where wee ≈øee, that S. Augu≈øtine and the Britans did differ principally, in the≈øe three things, and by our prote≈øtants them≈øelues, S. Augu≈øtine held the truth in them, and the Britans were in error. And ≈øo likewi≈øe in all other ceremonies rites and cu≈øtomes then coÃÑtrouer≈øed: for S. Augu≈øtine iu≈øtifieth that the Britans in them all were, contrary to the cu≈øtome of the vniuer≈øall church of Christ. In multis quidem nostrae con≈øuetudini, immo vniuer≈øalis Eccle≈øiae contraria geritis. And their learned contriman Gyraldus Cambren≈øis diuers hundreds of yeares ≈øince, beeing as a prote≈øtant, Bi≈øhop ≈øtileth him, vetustae cognitionis ver√® helluo, an vn≈øatiable ≈øeeker forth of antiquities, with prote≈øtants allowance thus ≈øetteth downe the ceremonies of the Britans, wherein they differed from all other churches, in this order. Bal. l. de ≈øcriptor. Britan. in Gyrald. Cambren. cent. 2. Gyrald. Cambren. de≈øcript. Cambr. cap. 18. Dauid Powell ib.

9. De quolibet pane appo≈øito primum fractionis angulum pauperibus donant. Of euerie loafe of breade ≈øett before them, they giue the
fir≈øt corner they breake to the poore. They ≈øitt three and three together, at dinner in memorie of the Trinitie. They cast away theire armour, and bare headed aske the benediction of euery Monke or preist, or any wearinge the habit of Religion: The people doth greatly, and more then other nations, de≈øire confirmation by a Bishop, and Inunction of Chri≈øme, by which the grace of the holy Gho≈øt is giuen. They giue tythes of all things they po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe, cattell, sheepe ≈øometimes wheÃÑ either they marry wiues, or go on pilgrimage, or correct their life by the coun≈øaile of the church. Aboue all forreine labour, moste willingly going on pilgrimage to Rome, they more readily vvith deuout mindes adore the Tombes of the Apo≈øtles. Wee ≈øee they yeeld deuout reuerence to churches and eccle≈øiastical men, and relicks of Saints, and portable bells, vvouen books, and the cro≈øse, & giue farr more honor to all the≈øe then any other nation. The immunities of theire churches, farr exceedeth the Indulgence of the canons. You shall not ≈øee any vvhere the Eremites and Anachorites of greater abstinence, or more ≈øpirituall. And ≈øpeakinge of the Britans in the time of S. Germanus, and Lupus, when they were troubled with Pelagiani≈øme, and fir≈øt irruptions
of the Pagan SaxoÃÑs, the≈øe Authors ≈øay. The≈øe cu≈øtomes and ceremonies of the Britans continued from them, to the time of Gyraldus Cambren≈øis, that died in the yeare of Chri≈øt 1190. ab eorundem doctrina haec, vt fertur, v≈øqe in hodiernum documenta tenuerunt.

10. Thus wee haue learned all the differences, that were betweene S. Augu≈øtine, and the Britans: and finde, that S. Augu≈øtine was the innocent partie in them all. For amonge all the≈øe la≈øte recited, where any thinge is remembred as ≈øingular, and differing from other churches, it is the ca≈øe of the Britans, and the Romans agreed with the common and receued cu≈øtomes of the church of Chri≈øt: And concerninge tho≈øe doctrines and cu≈øtomes which our prote≈øtants doe mo≈øte di≈ølike in S. Gregory, and S. Augu≈øtine, with his a≈ø≈øociates, and the now pre≈øent Roman church, which are pilgrimages, and e≈øpecially to Rome, with the honor of that holy Apo≈øtolicke ≈øee, reuerence of holy relicks, Indulgences, honor to ≈øacrificinge ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øts, and Religious men, and more Sacraments then prote≈øtants admit, as namely the Sacrament of
confirmation, giuinge of the grace of the holy Gho≈øt, by anointinge with ≈øacred Chri≈øme, reuerencing of the cro≈ø≈øe, and holie images, wee ≈øee by the te≈øtimony both of the Britans, and prote≈øtants them≈øelues, that the≈øe were more zelou≈øly ob≈øerued of the Chri≈øtian Britans at that time, who≈øe faith and Religion is ≈øo much commended by our prote≈øtant writers, then they were by S. Gregory, or S. Augu≈øtine then, or be at this time by the pre≈øent church of Rome, and the members therof.

11. Therfore it being the common and generally receued opinion, both of our Engli≈øh Prote≈øtant Bi≈øhops, as Parker, Bale, Godwin, with others, and their Doctors and antiquaries as Powel, Foxe, Fulke, Middleton, Go≈øceline, Stowe, Howes, Holin≈øhed, and too many to be recited, that at the cominge of S. Augu≈øtine hither, the faith and Religion of the Chri≈øtian Britans here, was in all materiall points ≈øounde, and perfect, and the ≈øame which they receued in the time of the Apo≈øtles, much more and rather mu≈øt they needes yeeld, and allowe that honor, to the Religion and doctrine of S. Augu≈øtine, and the other di≈øciples of S.
Gregory, which they preached and planted here, being by ≈øo many and all humane te≈øtimonies before acknowledged in all matters controuer≈øed betweene them, to be the vndoubted true, and perfect Religion of Chri≈øt. Parker. antiquit¬∑ Britan. pag. 6.45.46. Balaus l. 2. de Act. Pontific. in Gregorio Magno & l. de ≈øcriptor. Brit. centur. 1. in Augu≈øtin. Dionotho. Godvvin. conuer≈ø. of Brit. Povvell annotat. in l. 2. Giraldi Cambr. de Itinerar. Cambr. cap. 1. Foxe Act. and Mon. pag. 463. edit. an. 1576. Fulke ansvv. to counterf. Cathol. pag. 40. Middlet. Papi≈øtom. pag 202.) Io. Go≈øcelin. hi≈øt. Eccl. de vit. Arch. Cantuar. Stovve and Howes hist. in K. Ethelbert. Holinsh, histor. of Engl. cap. 21. pag. 102.

12. And to make all ≈øure, and vnque≈øtionable, except with athe≈øts, and infidels, enemies to Chri≈øt him≈øelfe, wee haue both the pre≈øent and propheticall witne≈ø≈øe of God him≈øelfe, that by no po≈ø≈øibilitie can deceiue vn in this ca≈øe, and this confe≈ø≈øed, and receued euen by our prote≈øtant writers, who fir≈øt a≈ø≈øure vs, that in the controuer≈øie betweene the Britans and S. Augu≈øtine, God gaue ≈øo miraculous te≈øtimony, for S. Augu≈øtine & his Roman companions to teach
the truth in all thinges controuer≈øed then betweene them and the Britans, that the Britans were therby ≈øo extraordinarily conuicted, and confounded (to ≈øpeake in prote≈øtant wordes) that they confe≈øsed in deede, that to bee the true way of righteou≈ønes which Augu≈øtine had preached, and shewed them. (Stowe and Howes histor. in K. Ethelbert.) and God could not po≈ø≈øibly giue other te≈øtimony by the≈øe prote≈øtants, and all learninge, except hee would or could (bla≈øphemie to affirme) contradict him≈øelfe, for by all profe≈ø≈øors of Chri≈øtian Religion he had promi≈øed, that Catholicke church vniuer≈øall ≈øhould neuer err, and yet prote≈øtants with others thus confe≈ø≈øe: all other churches throughout the world agreed with Augustine in Chri≈øt. Of Gods propheticall te≈øtimonie hereof wee haue many witne≈ø≈øes, Catholicks and Prote≈øtants, S. A≈øaph in the life of S. Kentegern, many Manu≈øcripts, the Britti≈øh hi≈øtory, Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter, with others for Catholicks; and amonge prote≈øtants, their fir≈øt Prote≈øtant Archbi≈øhop of Canterbury, their prote≈øtant Bi≈øhop Bale, with others. (S. A≈øaph. in vit. S. Kentegern. M. S. antiq. in eod. Galfr. Monum. l.
7. cap. 3. Matth. We≈øtm. an. 465. Matth. Parker. antiquit. Britan. pag. 49. Io. Bal. l. de ≈øcript. Britan. cent. 1. in Kentegern.) this la≈øt ≈øpeakinge of the Pagan Saxons inuadinge this kingdome, and ouerthrowinge Chri≈øtian Religion, bringeth S. Kentegern thus to prophe≈øie loÃÑge before, how S. Augu≈øtine and his a≈ø≈øociats ≈øhould re≈øtore it againe, not onely vnto the auncient ≈øtate of Religion, but a better then it enioyed in the time of the Britans. Christianae legis Religio v≈øque ad praefinitum tempus di≈øsipabitur. Sed in pristinum ≈øtatim immo meliorem mi≈øerante Deo in fine reparabitur.

13. The auncient Manu≈øcript hi≈øtory of S. Kentegerns life, S. A≈øaph, Capgraue and others ≈øay, S. Kentegern prophe≈øied this, and publickly told it, to his di≈øciples at the time of the death of S. Dauid, which as our prote≈øtants write, was aboue 50. yeares before the cominge of S. Augu≈øtine hither. (M. S. antiq. de vita S. Kentegerni. Io. Copgrau. in S. Kentegerno Epi≈øcopo & Confe≈ø≈øore.) who beeing at that time as often, very earne≈øt at his prayers, and much lamentinge, after being demauÃÑded by his di≈øciples the cau≈øe of his great ≈øorrowe, after a short ≈øilence, thus answered:
Knovve you my dearest children that S. Dauid the ornament of Britanie, Father of his contry, is euen novv loo≈øed from the pri≈øon of his flesh, and gone to the heauenly kingdome. Vnderstand you that Britanie depriued of ≈øo great a light, shall lameÃÑt the ab≈øence of ≈øo great a patrone, who oppo≈øed him ≈øelfe again≈øt the sword of God, halfe drawne against it, for the wickednes of the inhabitants thereof, that it should not be fully drawne and bringe it to de≈øtruction. Our Lord will giue Britanie ouer to forreine nations, that know him not. And the I≈øle shall bee emptied of the inhabitants, by Pagans. The Religion of the lawe of Chri≈øt shall bee destroyed, vntill a certaine time in it. But by the mercy of God, it shall be againe repayred vnto the former, and vnto a better state then it was before. Seruo Dei quodam die prolixius orationi intento, facies eius qua≈øi ignea apparens stupore & exta≈øi circumstantes repleuit. Intucbantur enim faciem eius tanquam vultum Angeli ≈øtantis inter illos. Completa oratione, graui≈øsimis lamentis ≈øe dedit. Et cum di≈øcipuli cau≈øam tri≈øtitiae humiliter ab eo peterent, pauli≈øper in ≈øilentio re≈øidens, tandem ait. Noueritis filij chari≈øsimi, Sanctum Dauid decus Britanniae, patrem patriae, carnis carcerem modo
egre≈ø≈øum, regna caelestia penetra≈ø≈øe. Credite mihi, quod non ≈øolum Angelorum multitudo in gaudium Domini ≈øui illum introduxit, ≈øed & Dominus no≈øter Ie≈øus Christus ei obuiam procedens, ad portas paradi≈øi gloria & honore coronauit eum, me vidente. Scitote etiam quod Britannia tanto lumine orbata, tanti patroni lugebit ab≈øentiam: qui gladio Domini propter malitiam inhabitantium ≈øemi euaginato ≈øuper illam, ne penitus ad internitionem extractus percuteret ≈øemetip≈øun opponebat. Tradens tradet Dominus, Britanniam exteris nationibus Deum ignorantibus: ≈øed & √† Paganis ab indigenis euacuabitur in≈øula, Christianae legis Religio v≈øque ad praefinitum tempus di≈øsipabitur in ea: ≈øed in pri≈øtinum ≈øtati ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ , immo meliorem mi≈øerante Deo iterum reparabitur.

14. Our prote≈øtant hi≈øtorians doe likewi≈øe relate the actuall chaunge of Religion here then for the better, and for better preachers in the≈øe wordes, (Edvv. Hovves and Stovve hi≈øtor. in K. Ethelbert. Gild. l. de excid.) Amonge many the Britans doings which their ovvne historiographer Gildas doth lamentably ≈øett forth in vvritinge, hee ≈øaith of them thus, that they neuer tooke care to preach the gho≈øpell of Christ vnto the Angles, and
Saxons, vvhich inhabited the land amonge them. But yet the goodnes of God prouided for the ≈øaid nation of the ≈øaid Angles, much more vvorthie preachers by vvhome they might be brought to the faith. And then immediatly they ≈øet downe S. Augu≈øtine, Mellitus, Iu≈øtus, and Iohn, with others ≈øent hither by S. Gregory, to bee the≈øe much more vvorthie preachers, by vvhom this nation was brought to the faith. And this might ≈øuffice in this matter, but for the ful clearing of al doubts, I will further & fully proue, how al prei≈øts and Bi≈øhops in Britanie in this age, were ≈øacrificing ma≈ø≈øing prei≈øts: and the be≈øt learned and mo≈øt holy amonge them, did in all things ioyne with the Popes, and church of Rome; and they which oppo≈øed mo≈øte again≈øt S. Augu≈øtine, and his a≈ø≈øociates ≈øent from thence in ≈øome ceremoniall cu≈øtomes, did in the≈øe points & all others which prote≈øtants mo≈øt di≈ølike in Catholick Romane Religion, vtterly di≈øagree from the≈øe prote≈øtants, and hold the ≈øame doctrine & practi≈øe generally, as S. Augu≈øtine did, and the members of the pre≈øent Romane Apo≈øtolick church doe at this day.

div.head: THE XXIII. CHAPTER. Wherein demon≈øtration is made both by prote≈øtants, and other testimonies, that during all this age and hundred of yeares vntill and after the coming of S. Augustine, this kingdome had many holy ma≈øsinge preists and Bishops, agreeinge in the≈øe, and all other articles of ReligioÃÑ with the church of Rome.
div.p:
IN the later end of the fift hundred of yeares, of Chri≈øt, I made relation, how amonge many others, tho≈øe two renowned ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øts, S. Dubritius the great Archbi≈øhop of Caerlegion, and the Popes Legate, made Bi≈øhop by the ma≈ø≈øing Bi≈øhop and Legate of the ≈øee Apo≈øtolicke, and S. Iltutus di≈øciple of the ≈øame ma≈ø≈øing Bi≈øhop and Legate S. Germanus were Tutors, and Ma≈øters in Religion and diuinitie, not only to the cleargie of this Iland but many others, and neither did, nor could teach them any other doctrine in the≈øe points, then they had receued from others, and practi≈øed by them≈øelues, about holy prei≈øthood, and ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe; And as both prote≈øtants & other antiquaries tell vs, both the≈øe liued 20. yeares at the lea≈øte, in the beginninge
of this ≈øixt age, S. Iltutus beeing aliue and flori≈øhinge in the yeare 520. claruit anno √† Chri≈øti natiuitate 520. and S. Dubritius liuinge two yeares after, obijt anno gratiae 522. (Bal. l. de ≈øcriptor. Britan. cent. 1. in Ilchtuto. & in Dubritio. Godw. Catal. in S. Dauids. in Dubritius.) therefore wee may boldly ≈øay, that among ≈øo great numbers of their ma≈ø≈øing ≈øchollers, many of them liued a great part, if not all this age. The auncient Manu≈øcript of the Saints of Wales, the Apologi≈øt of the antiquitie of Cambridge, and others thus te≈øtifie of S. Dubritius. (M. S. antiq. de vit. Sanctorum Wall. in S. Dubritio. Io. Caius l. 1. de antiquit. Cantabr. Academ. pag. 145.146.) Creuit illius fama cum vtriu≈øque legis, nouae & veteris peritia per totaÃÑ Britanniam, ita quod ex omni parte totius Britanniae ≈øcholares veniebant, non tantum rudes, ≈øed etiam viri ≈øapientes & Doctores ad eum ≈øtudendi cau≈øa confluebant. Imprimis Sanctus Helianus, Samp≈øon di≈øcipulus ≈øuus, Vbelnius, Merchiguinus, Elguoredus, Gunuinus, Longual, Artbodu, Longur, Arguistil, Iunabin, Conbram, Goruan, Guernabin, Iouan, Elheharn, Iudnon, Curdocui, Aidan, Cinuarch, & cum his mille clericos per ≈øeptem annos continuo
in podo ≈øeu pago Hentlan ≈øuper ripam Guy, in ≈øtudio literarum diuinae ≈øapientiae & humanae retinuit. Where we ≈øee he had a thou≈øand ≈øchollers at one time, and place, ≈øeuen yeares together that were clergy men ≈øtudents in diuinitie, and in an other place, called in the Britti≈øh languadge Mocros, miraculou≈øly a≈ø≈øigned vnto him, hee had as the≈øe antiquities ≈øay, innumerable ≈øchollers many yeares together, cum ≈øuis innumerabilibus di≈øcipulis man≈øit per plures annos regendo studium. l. de vit. Sanct. Wall. Caius ≈øup. pag. 147.148. M. S. antiq. & Capgrau. in S. Iltuto & Tatheo.

2. The like they write of the ≈øcholes of S. Iltutus, and S. Tatheus, or as ≈øome call him Thatheus. The antiquaries of Cambridge alleage for the immunities and priuiledges of their vniuer≈øitie, the auncient Charter dated at London in the yeare of Chri≈øt 531 of Kinge Arthur, that knowne reuerencer of ≈øacrificing prei≈øts, and Ma≈ø≈øe. Charta priuileg. Arthuri an. 531. apud Caium antiq. Cantabrig. l. 1.) and both Catholicks and prote≈øtants te≈øtifie, that the auncient vniuer≈øitie of Standford continued in this time, and vntill S. Gregory interdicted it for
here≈øies that fell amonge the Saxons and Britans together mixt. (Harding hi≈øtor. in King Ethelbert. Stowe and Howes historie in Bladud.) therefore wee may a≈ø≈øure our ≈øelues, that notwith≈øtandinge ≈øo many troubles, & alterations, as chaunced here in tho≈øe daies, they continued the holy doctrine and cu≈øtome of Ma≈ø≈øe, and ≈øacrificinge prei≈øts; For S. Gregory ≈øo knowne and confe≈ø≈øed a Patron and practi≈øer of the≈øe thinges, neither would, nor could haue interdicted that vniuer≈øitie, for any thinge which hee him≈øelfe ≈øo embraced and honored. So that it is euident, that the whole kingdome of Britanie in this time followinge the doctrine which their ≈øcholes and vniuer≈øities taught them, mu≈øt needs then allowe the≈øe holy mi≈øteries of which I write. The ≈øame is euident, both by the Kings which then reigned here, as al≈øo by the Archbi≈øhops who ruled in Religious affaires. The Kings in the beginning of this age were Vther pendragon, who died about the yeare of Chri≈øt 515. beeinge for Religion of the ≈øame with the ma≈ø≈øinge Archbi≈øhops S. Dubritius and S. Samp≈øon, with the ≈øacrificinge Bi≈øhops, and prei≈øts, by who≈øe generall con≈øent he was crowned
Kinge. Vther conuocato regni clero, caepit diadema In≈øula: annueÃÑtibu≈øque cunctis ≈øublimatus est in Regem. (Galfr. Mon. l. 8. cap. 17. Math. Westm. ad an. 498) and when his death was knowne they as ≈øolemly a≈ø≈øembled to giue him Princely Chri≈øtian buriall. Cum obitus Regis diuulgatus fui≈ø≈øet aduenerunt Pontifices cum clero regni: tuleruntque corpus eius ad caenobium Ambrij, & iuxta Aurelium Ambro≈øium more regio humauerunt.

2. Next was Kinge Arthur, how he was engaged in this holy doctrines it is ≈øufficieÃÑt Argument, that being but 15. yeares of age, and his birth by many not without exception, hee was with the generall applau≈øe both of the ≈øacrificinge cleargie, and their gho≈øtly children, crowned Kinge by S. Dubritius the Popes Legate, and renowned ma≈ø≈øinge Archbi≈øhop, and primate of Britanie with the other ma≈ø≈øing Bi≈øhops therof. Defuncto Vtherpendragon conuenerunt ex diuer≈øis Prouincijs proceres Britonum, Dubritio Vrbis Legionum ≈øuggerentes, vt Arthurum filium Regis in Regem con≈øecraret. Dubritius a≈ø≈øociatis ≈øibi Epi≈øcopis Arthurum regni diademate in≈øignuit. (Galfrid. Mon l. 9. cap. 1. Matth. Westm. ad an. gratiae 516. Stowe
histor. Britans and Saxons in Arthur. Io. Bal. l. de ≈øcript. Brit. cent. 1. in Dubritio. Godwin Catalog. in S. Dauids.) to this his whole life in fighting again≈øt the enemies of that holy Religion, the ≈øacred churches, and altars which he reedified for that heauenly ≈øacrifice, and charters of immunities which he graunted to the mo≈øt knowne ma≈ø≈øing places of Britanie, as Gla≈øtenbury and others, and the great reuerence he v≈øed to all ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øts and Prelates, are ≈øufficient te≈øtimony of this, and to bee ≈øeene allmo≈øt in all hi≈øtories, Manu≈øcripts and others of that time, and hee liued vnto the yeare of Chri≈øt 542. Now if wee come to the Archbi≈øhops & Bi≈øhops vnder them, Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter and others tell vs, that for Yorke, that renowned ma≈ø≈øinge man S. Samp≈øon was Archbi≈øhop there, 7. yeares after the beginning of this age, anno gratiae 507. Floruerunt in BritaÃÑnia Sanctus Samp≈øon Eboracen≈øis Archiepi≈øcopus, & S. Dubritius Vrbis Regionum Archiepi≈øcopus. (Matth. We≈øtm. an. 542. & alij. Matth. We≈øtm. an. gratiae 507.) what a miraculous ma≈ø≈øing prei≈øt, and Prelate he was, I haue ≈øpoken in the former age.

3. That S. Dubritius ruled all in the Archiepi≈øcopal
≈øee of Caerlegion, where mo≈øt both Bi≈øhops & prei≈øts were in the≈øe daies, at the lea≈øt vntill the 16. yeare of this age I haue ≈øhewed before, wheÃÑ S. Dubritius with the re≈øt of the Bi≈øhops of Britanie crowned King Arthur in that yeare. Who was Archbi≈øhop of London at this time, it is not ≈øo certainly remembred in particular. But the Author of the Britti≈øh hi≈øtory tran≈ølated by Galfridus a≈ø≈øureth vs, that there was an Archbi≈øhop of London at this time, & that hee together with S. Dubritius Archbi≈øhop of Caerlegion, & the Archbi≈øhop of Yorke did crowne Kinge Arthur. Trium Metropolitanarum ≈øedium Archi Prae≈øules, Londonien≈øis videlicet, Eboracen≈øis, nec non ex vrbe Legionum Dubritius hic Britanniae primas, & Apostolicae ≈øedis Legatus. (Galfr. Mon. hi≈øtor. Reg. Brit. l. 9. cap. 12.13.) and by the circum≈øtances of the hi≈øtory, the≈øe three Archbi≈øhops performed that great ≈øolemne coronation at the ≈øoleÃÑnitie of Ma≈ø≈øe, at which both the Kinge, the≈øe three Archbi≈øhops with the other Bi≈øhops of theire diui≈øions, and the nobilitie of Britanie were pre≈øent. And this coronation is cheifely attributed to S. Dubritius, becau≈øe it was in his dioce≈ø≈øe.
Dubritius quoniam in ≈øua dioce≈øi caria tenebatur, paratus ad celebrandum ob≈øequium, huius rei curam ≈øu≈øcepit, and he was the Popes Legate. And all hi≈øtories agree, that when the Bi≈øhops, and cleargie, either of London, or Yorke diui≈øion, were per≈øecuted by the Pagans, they fledd for ≈øuccour, to the knowne ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øtes, and Prelates of Caerlegion dioce≈ø≈øe, communicatinge with them in Religion.

4. S. Dubritius waxinge old, and de≈øirous to liue a ≈øolitary and contemplatiue life, the holy Saint Dauid was miraculou≈ølie cho≈øen to ≈øucceed him. (Capgrau. in S. Dauid. Gyrald. Cambr. Itiner. Cambr. l. 2. cap. 1. Godwin in S. Dauids.) I haue ≈øhewed before, that he was the ≈øcholler of the ma≈ø≈øing prei≈øt, S. Iltutus, ≈øcholler of the ma≈ø≈øinge Prelate & Popes Legate S. Germanus. This holy Archbi≈øhop was ≈øo renowned a ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øt, and Prelate, that as wee reade both in auncient Manu≈øcripts, and other hi≈øtories, hee brought with from Hieru≈øalem, beeinge a pilgrime there, an holy and miracalous Altar, giuen him by the Patriake there, on which he con≈øecrated the body of our Lord. In quo Dominicum con≈øecrabat corpus.
(M. S. antiq. de vit. S. Dauidis. Capgrau. in Catalog. in eod.) and to make euident vnto all, that S. be≈øides the Bi≈øhops which oppo≈øed them≈øelues to S. Augu≈øtine, commonly recompted ≈øeuen in number, yet agreeing with him in the≈øe mi≈øteries, the renowned holy Bi≈øhop S. A≈øaph, di≈øciple, and ≈øucce≈ø≈øor to S. Kentegern, in that ≈øee, when hee for≈øooke it; This holy ma≈ø≈øinge Bi≈øhop ruler of the colledge of ≈øo many ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øts, as I haue before related, did in all things ioyne him≈øelfe with the di≈øciples of S. Gregory the Pope, in ≈øo much as a Prote≈øtaÃÑt Bi≈øhop writeth of him: A Gregorij Pontificis Romani di≈øcipulis Angliam aduentantibus, authoritatem accepit. (Io. Bal. l. de ≈øcript. Britan. cent. 1. in A≈øapho.) he receued authority from the di≈øciples of Gregorie Pope of Rome, which came into England. And this is hee, who as the ≈øame Prote≈øtaÃÑt Bi≈øhop writeth, wrote the life of S. Kentegern his Ma≈øter. Therfore this holy Prelate mu≈øt needs bee a ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øt, as all the other vnder him were at that time. If we go further to other parts of this nation, wee ≈øhall finde in the kingdome of the Mercians, or by ≈øome the ea≈øte Angles, the renowned & miraculous Archbi≈øhop S. Iue, a noble Per≈øian by birth, who beeing ≈øent thither by the Pope of Rome S.
Gregory or Pelagius the ≈øeconde his predece≈ø≈øor both ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øts and Popes, was al≈øo a ma≈ø≈øing prei≈øt and Prelate, and dying at the towne, now of his name called S. Iues, in Hontington ≈øhire, gaue that name vnto it. (Annal. Mona≈øter. Ram≈øeiae. M. S. antiq. de vita S. Iuonis. Io. Capgrau. in Catalog. in S. Iuone Epi≈øcop. Florent. Wigorn. in Chronic. ad an. 600.) And to te≈øtifie that hee exerci≈øed both his ma≈ø≈øing prei≈øtly, and epi≈øcopall function there in preachinge to the Saxons, his body was found, buryed in epi≈øcopall manner, ≈øepulchro aperto Epi≈øcopum Pontificalibus indutum coÃÑ≈øpiciunt. This Apo≈øtolicke doctor of this nation as Florentius Wigornien≈øis, Capgraue, and the old Manu≈øcripts of his life ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ ll him, Doctor Apo≈øtolicus & vere caeli nuntius Ino, dyed here as Wigornien≈øis writeth in the yeare 600. foure yeares after the cominge of S. Augu≈øtine hither: and hither al≈øo came with him, and preached here, ≈øent from Rome, be≈øides others not named, S. Sithius, and S. Inthius his a≈ø≈øociats, ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øts. Qui cum Romam perueni≈øseÃÑt con≈øilio Papae di≈øpo≈øitione Dei, Sanctus Iuo cum Sithio nepote, & Inthio cognato ≈øuo alij≈øque quibu≈ødam, in Britanniam intrauit.
And to ≈øhew that hee was a true Apo≈øtle of this nation, ≈øent by the ≈øee Apo≈øtolicke of Rome, coming through Fraunce hither, beeinge honorably entertayned by the Kinge and people of Fraunce, to ≈øtay there, would by no entreaty con≈øent, but came as hee was, √† Domino destinatus, ordeyned for vs by God, into England Cum Galliam cum ≈øuis intra≈ø≈øet, √† Rege & populo honorific√® ≈øu≈øceptus, nec vlla gratia terrena quamuis a≈øsiduis precibus rogatus, ab ip≈øis retineri poterat, ≈øed Britanniam ingrediens.

14. And to pa≈ø≈øe into the kingedome of Kent it ≈øelfe, where S. Augu≈øtine landed, & ≈øettled him≈øelfe, his ≈øucce≈ø≈øors, and ≈øee at Canterbury, there, we had at his cominge, and twenty yeares before, and before the time, that Theonus Archbi≈øhop of London, and Thadiocus Archbi≈øhop of Yorke with their ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øts, for≈øooke their ≈øees, in that kingedome and city it≈øelfe of Canterburie, a renowned ma≈ø≈øing Bi≈øhop, S. Luithardus, and his ma≈ø≈øing prei≈øts, v≈øuallie ≈øayinge Ma≈ø≈øe, the Queene S. Bertha being pre≈øent in their theÃÑ cathedral church, dedicated to S. Martine, as all antiquaries agree, and as I finde in an old Manu≈øcript
hi≈øtory, builded in the time of Kinge Lucius. (Bed. hist. gent. Angl. l. 1. cap. 27. Io. Capgrau. in Catalog. in S. Lethardo Epi≈øcopo & Confe≈ø≈øore. M. S. antiq. in eod.) And by the per≈øua≈øion of this holy ma≈ø≈øinge Bi≈øhop S. Luithard, the Kinge and Saint afterward Ethelbert, entertayned S. Augu≈øtine with all humanitie, and was by him after actuallie conuerted to the faith of Chri≈øt, in ≈øo much that this holy Bi≈øhop is called, Ianitor venturi Augu≈øtini, opener of the dore to S. Augu≈øtine. (Capgrau. ≈øupr. in S. Lethard. Gulielm. Malm. l. 1. de ge≈øt. Reg. Anglorum.) And was before S. Augu≈øtines cominge when he ≈øtill liued a Pagan, fauourable and gentle vnto Chri≈øtiaÃÑs: Benignus erga Christianos in natiua gentilitate fuit. By occa≈øion whereof, his kingdome extending to Humber, and his ≈øi≈øter beeing marryed to Slede Kinge of the ea≈øt Angles, and her ≈øonne Sebert, or as Henry of Huntington calleth him Sibrictus, or Siberctus, beeing a Chri≈øtian Kinge, ≈øo great parts of this nation were free from per≈øecution, and ≈øome of the Saxons, that were conuerted, became ma≈ø≈øing prei≈øts, longe before S. Augu≈øtine came hither. (Henric. Hunting. histor. l. 2.) For ≈øuch
is numbred Godelbertus as a Prote≈øtant Bi≈øhop writeth, ex quorundam coniecturis genere Anglo≈øaxo, aboue an huÃÑdred yeares before this time an. 498. (Pit≈øeus historic. Rel. Tom. 1. aetate 5. Bal. l. de ≈øcript. Britan. cent. 1. in Godelberto Presbytero.) And as Seba≈øtiaÃÑ Mun≈øter & the fir≈øt Prote≈øtant Archbi≈øhop of Canterbury witnes, S. Offo an Engli≈øh Kings ≈øonne in this our EnglaÃÑd, went hence and preached in Germany in the yeare 601. (Mun≈øter. in Co≈ømograph. in German. Matth. Parker antiq. Brit. pag. 8.) not without other a≈ø≈øociats of this nation, except we will make, his ca≈øe ≈øingular from all other Apo≈øtolick men, & conuerters of contries. And except wee will make a very bold expo≈øitioÃÑ of the Engli≈øh Author of the booke, de Virginitate, or laude Virginum, of the prai≈øe of Virgins, commonly a≈øcribed to our holy learned Bi≈øhop, S. Aldelmus, callinge, S. Gregory the Pope his Master, and Tutor, Praeceptor & Pedagogus no≈øter Gregorius. (l. de laude Virginum. Bal. cent. 1. in Adel. Pit≈øeus To. 1. in eod.) wee mu≈øt needs as the rule of correlatiues. Ma≈øter and ≈øcholler requireth, make him ≈øcholler to S. Gregorie the great, which liued but few yeares after S. Augu≈øtines
cominge hither, and being Pope then, likely he was Tutor & Ma≈øter to this auÃÑcieÃÑt Engli≈øh writer, before the time of his papacie, as he was to many others, and not after.

15. So I might in≈øtance of others, but the≈øe aboundantly ≈øuffice, to proue, that after the fir≈øt plantinge of the faith of Chri≈øt in this our Britanie, there neuer wanted in it, either in the time of the Britans, Saxons or whom els ≈øoeuer, Ma≈ø≈øe, ma≈ø≈øing prei≈øts, and Bi≈øhops. For euen tho≈øe Britti≈øh prei≈øts and Bi≈øhops, which mo≈øte oppo≈øed again≈øt S. Augu≈øtine in ≈øome other things, were as farr engaged in the≈øe articles, to bee ≈øound and Orthodoxe as S. Augu≈øtine was, and ≈øo both practi≈øed here in Britanie, as I haue related before, & their mo≈øt learned S. Kelian, Columban, and Gallus, with others going hence into other nations did wholly ≈øubmit them≈øelues to the Popes of Rome; and their cheife≈øt S. KeliaÃÑ was made Bi≈øhop of Mitzburgh by the Pope, receuinge power from him to preach. Romam profectus e≈øt, & officio praedicandi √† Papa receptus Epi≈øcopus, orditus. (Manu≈øcript antiq. de vita S. Keliani. Io. Capgrau. Catalog. in eodem. Sur. die 8. Iulij.) And that S. Columbanus the man who≈øe
authority was mo≈øt obiected again≈øt S. Augu≈øtine, about the diuers keeping of Ea≈øter, was a notorious ma≈ø≈øinge prei≈øt, as al≈øo S. Gallus in as high degree, as any Catholicke now is, it is te≈øtified in their liues, where we find, S. Columban did dedicat a church, and altar, with the relicks of S. Aurelia, & adorninge the altar ≈øaid Ma≈ø≈øe vpon it. Beatus Columbanus iu≈øsit aquam afferri, & benedicens illam, ad≈øper≈øit ea templum: & dum circuirent p≈øallentes, dedicauit Eccle≈øiam, deinde inuocato nomine Domini, vnxit altare, & beatae Aureliae reliquias in eo collocauit, ve≈øtitoque altari, mi≈ø≈øas legittim√® compleuerunt And in the ≈øame Authors wee reade, that S. Gallus did ordinarily v≈øe, Mi≈ø≈øam celebrare, to ≈øay Ma≈ø≈øe, and beeing vrged both by the Prince, Bi≈øhops, and Cleargie, to accept of the Bi≈øhoprick of Con≈øtance, hee refu≈øed it and preferred Iohn his deacon, whome S. Gallus had conuerted vnto the faith of Chri≈øt. Who in his con≈øecration was ledd by the Bi≈øhops to the Altar, and ≈øolemnely con≈øecrated, and ≈øaid Ma≈ø≈øe: in which after the gho≈øpell, as the maner was, S. Gallus preached. Epi≈øcopi duxerunt eum ad altare, & ≈øolemni benedictionts officio ordinauerunt Antistitem,
con≈øumatoque ≈øacrae promotionis ministerio, rogauerunt cum ≈øacrificij ≈øalutaris celebrare my≈øteria. Praemi≈øsis ergo ex more diuinae oblationis initijs, po≈øt lectionem Euangelij rogauerunt venerabilem Gallum, vt multitudini quae aderat, verbi officio ≈øacrae instructionis pabulum ministraret. Where wee ≈øee as much deuotion, and reuerence, v≈øed by the greate≈øts oppo≈øites to S. Augu≈øtine, to the holy ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe, ≈øacrificinge prei≈øthood, holy water, holy oyle, to con≈øecrate altares, dedication of churches, and ≈øuch like matters mo≈øte di≈øliked by prote≈øtants, as S. Augu≈øtine v≈øed, or any learned Catholicke now profe≈ø≈øeth or defendeth.

16. And to remember Ma≈ø≈øes of requiem for the deade, ≈øo ≈øoone as S. Gallus heard of the death of Saint Columban, this S. Gallus ≈øo renowned a man, called his bretheren together, and they prayed and ≈øaid Ma≈ø≈øes for his ≈øoule. Audiens mortem S. Columbani collegit fratres., cau≈øas meroris aperuit. Deinde tanti patris memoriam precibus ≈øacris, & ≈øacrificijs ≈øalutaribus frequentarunt. What forme of Ma≈ø≈øe both the≈øe, and they which then continued in Britanie, v≈øed, I haue proued before, from the Britti≈øh antiquities, as al≈øo
how al which here were contrary to S. Augu≈øtine in ≈øome ceremonials, I haue demoÃÑ ≈øtrated by all kinde of te≈øtimonies, that in the≈øe and al other e≈ø≈øentiall and fundamentall things, and not ceremoniall, or alterable in Religion, they wholly agreed, and without the lea≈øte difference, con≈øented with S. Augu≈øtine, & the church of Rome, and differed in all now controuer≈øed que≈øtions, from the pre≈øent prote≈øtants of this nation, and all others. And ≈øo Catholicke Romane, or (as prote≈øtants call it) the papi≈øts church, as it hath euer ≈øince to the≈øe dayes of innouation from then, beene the onely knowne and vi≈øible church, as the≈øe men freely confe≈ø≈øe, and acknowledge, all antiquities, writers, and monuments ≈øo te≈øtifying; ≈øo it was in the ≈øame maner the onlie true, vi≈øible church, in euery age, or hundred yeares from Chri≈øt, and his Apo≈øtles vnto that time, no other in any thing reseÃÑ bling the pre≈øent prote≈øtants congregation, beeinge knowne, or heard of, at home, or abrode, by their owne confe≈ø≈øions, and all Arguments, in any one of tho≈øe ages, of the primatiue church of Chri≈øt. And ≈øo I end this hi≈øtorie.

AN ECCLESIASTICAL PROTESTANT HISTORIE, OF THE HIGH PASTORAL AND FATHERLY CHARGE and care of the Popes f Rome, ouer the church of Britanie.
