div.head: THE GENERAL ARGVMENTS OF THE ENSVINGE HISTORIE: SERVINGE ALSO FOR A PREFACE, to the Reader, to declare the ≈øcope of the Author, and contents of the worke.
div.p:
THE Catholick Author well acquainted with the proceedings of Prote≈øtants, in the≈øe times, and the controuer≈øies of them, to accept and allowe of nothing, but what is liked and allowed by them ≈øelues; and yet to make the world beleeue, they are Reuerencers of antiquitie, and would willingly embrace, and followe that, which was our fir≈øt faith in any que≈øtion deliuered by the Apo≈øtles, & thence continued from them: the greate≈øt of all
beeing that who planted here fir≈øt the holy faith, and ≈øince had cheife≈øt commanding power in ≈øuch things: Hee ≈øetteth hi≈øtorically downe from the be≈øt Antiquaries, and learned prote≈øtant writers of this contry, & other antiquities approued by them, the meanes and maner of our fir≈øt conuer≈øion vnto Chri≈øt, and by what ≈øpirituall cheife ruling authority this nation hath euer beene gouerned in ≈øuch thinges, ≈øince then, vntill the conuer≈øions of the Saxons by S. Augu≈øtine, and his a≈ø≈øociats ≈øent hither by Saint, and pope Gregory, the fir≈øt, after which tyme now aboue 1000. yeares, our prote≈øtants put it out of Que≈øtion, and agree, that the power of the popes of Rome ab≈øolutely ruled here in ≈øuch matters.

Therfore this hi≈øtorie of the fir≈øt ≈øixe hundred yeares, is diuided into ≈øixe Centuries or ages, euery one conteyninge one hundred yeares. In the fir≈øt, hee ≈øheweth from tho≈øe prote≈øtant Authors, and Antiquaries, how S. Peter that greate Apo≈øtle of Chri≈øt, both immediately by him≈øelfe, and mediately by his holy di≈øciples, fir≈øt preached here, founded our church, con≈øecrated for vs Bi≈øhops, prei≈øts, and other cleargie men, and ordeyned
all thinges thereto belonging: and how from this fir≈øt in≈øtitution by him, we euer had a continued ≈øucce≈ø≈øion of ≈øuch con≈øecrated par≈øons, vnto the more generall conuer≈øion by pope Eleutherius in the daies of kinge Lucius after which time there can bee no que≈øtion of ≈øuch a ≈øucce≈ø≈øion of Bi≈øhops here. And how after the death of S. Peter vnto the end of the fir≈øt hundred yeares, ≈øpirituall matters were ordered here by authoritie and direction from the ≈øee of Rome, and ≈øucce≈ø≈øors of S. Peter there.

In the ≈øecond hundred of yeares, is proued by the ≈øame prote≈øtant authors, and their antiquities, how from the beginninge of that age, to the end thereof, all ≈øpirituall things were likewi≈øe managed here, by that ≈øee Apo≈øtolicke, more or le≈ø≈øe, as the times then permitted. And in the generall conuer≈øion of kinge Lucius, and his kingdome, all eccle≈øia≈øticall bu≈øine≈ø≈øes were done, and ≈øettled by iuri≈ødiction of the popes of Rome, and their legats, directed hither by their authoritie, exerci≈øing here as ample iuri≈ødiction ≈øpirituall, to the greate honor of this kingdome, as any pope of Rome may clayme.

Such was the e≈øtate of ≈øpirituall power, and proceedings here in the third, fourth, fift, and ≈øixte age, or hundred of yeares al≈øo: in the later end whereof, S. Augu≈øtine was ≈øent hither to conuert our aunce≈øtors the Saxons. In all which ages, and Centenaries of yeares, both the Kings, Archbi≈øhops, Bi≈øhops, and others, both Rulers, and Ruled in this kingdome, gaue as much priuiledge, and prerogatiue to the popes of Rome, as Catholicks now may doe, by their catholick Roman Religion.

In which tyme al≈øo, amonge all tho≈øe chri≈øtians which then liued here, tho≈øe Bi≈øhops of Scotland, and Walles, who, as our prote≈øtants tell vs, and commend them for it, did onely or mo≈øt oppo≈øe again≈øt the pope, his legates, and authoritie here, were tho≈øe al≈øoe, by the ≈øame prote≈øtants, which did much more intermeddle in princes affaires, then any popes, their legats, or ≈øuch as were mo≈øt obedient vnto, or Ruled by them. Which proceedings the Author doth in all places leaue to prote≈øtants relation, and medleth not with them otherwi≈øe at all. But ≈øoe much as with probabilitie in hi≈øtorie, hee may, mitigateth ≈øuch matters, as
≈øome prote≈øtants, euen with publick allowance of the prote≈øtant ≈øtate of EnglaÃÑd, haue boldly publi≈øhed to the world in that kinde: freely and before God prote≈øting, as hee neuer hitherto had any intermedlinge with the temporall affaires of Princes, but euer to his vttermo≈øt, did yeeld and render all dutie vnto them, praying for the ≈øafety, honor and pre≈øeruation of his Soueraigne, and this kingdome, ≈øoe hee will euer continue the ≈øame mo≈øte humble and dutifull affection.

Other particular Que≈øtions in Religion depend vppon this. Becau≈øe who≈øoeuer in anie Religion hath the cheife chardge and cure, the particulars depend vpon his proceedings, whether it bee Pope, Prince, Superintendents, Presbyteries, or what≈øoeuer, and ≈øoe beeing proued that from the beginninge of chri≈øtianitie in this kingdome, the Pope of Rome euer had cheife coÃÑmaund & direction in Religious things. It mu≈øt needs followe, that which prote≈øtants name papi≈øtrie, euer raigned here. But I vnder≈øtand there is a generall controuer≈øiall hi≈øtorie to bee ≈øhortly publi≈øhed, of all ≈øuch things in particular, from the fir≈øt preaching of
the Go≈øpell in this kingdome, which will giue, full a ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ ample ≈øatisfaction, in all ≈øuch Que≈øtions.

div.head: THE FIRST CENTVRIE OR HVNDRED OF YEARES.

THE I. CHAPTER. Wherein is briefly made demon≈øtration by the best learned prote≈øtant Antiquaries, and others of England, that Saint Peter the Apostle fir≈øt preached the faith, and founded the Church of Christ in this our Britanie.
div.p:
TO bringe vs vnto a more certayne, and vndoubted knowledge, of the fir≈øt preachers of chri≈øtian Religion, in this kingdome, the be≈øt learned prote≈øtant Antiquaries wee haue, pre≈øcribe certayne Rules, and ≈øquares, to bee directed by to come vnto them, in their iudgment. Matth. Parker. antiq. Britan. pag. 1. Godw. Conuer≈ø. of Brit. Holinsh.
hist. of Engl. Ma≈øon. l. 2¬∑ c. 2. pag. 51. Theater of great Brit. l. 6. cap. 9. fir≈øt they affirme, that the Britans receaued the faith, ≈øoone after the A≈øcen≈øion of our ble≈ø≈øed Sauiour, in the time of Tiberius, Caius Caligula, or Claudius Emperor: and they build this their a≈ø≈øertion cheifely vppon the words of S. Gildas. l. de Excid. & conq. Britan. c¬∑ 5.6. Who ≈øpeaking of things done here in Britanie, either in the time of Caius, or Claudius, addeth: Interea glaciali frigore rigent In≈øulae, indulget ≈øua praecepta Chri≈øtus. In the meane time while the≈øe things were doinge, Christ doth afford his precepts to this frozen Iland. In which place, hee rather meaneth the time of Claudius, then any other, as may ea≈øely appeare, to all iudiciall and equall readers of that auncient Author in the place alleadged, needles to bee in≈øi≈øted vppon, if wee will bee guided by our prote≈øtant directors, becau≈øe in their next Rules they ≈øhall make it euident.

It mu≈øt needes in their opinion bee ≈øoe vnder≈øtood. For they deliuer for a ≈øecond Maxime, that this nation embraced, and was taught the Religion of Chri≈øt, by ≈øome one of the Apo≈øtles. Soe ≈øay their
Archbi≈øhop Parker. in antiq. Britan. Bal. in act. Pontif. Rom. in Gregor. 1. Cambd. in Brit. Fulke Answ. to a Romish. cath. pag. 40. Powel. annot. in l. 2. Giral. Cambr. Itiner. Cambr. c. 1. Holinsh. histor. of Eng. c. 21. pag. 102. Stowe histor. in Agricola. Stow. ≈øupr. Godwyn ≈øupr. their Bi≈øhops Bale, Godwyn, their doctors and Antiquaries, Cambden, Fulke, Powel, Holinshed. Stowe, the Theater writers and others, inclining to this opinion, and ≈øome of them plainely teaching, with diuers of the auntient fathers, that the 12. Apo≈øtles deuided the world among≈øt them, to preach the gho≈øpell in, a≈ø≈øure vs, that to ≈øpeake in their wordes, The holy Apo≈øtles beeing di≈øper≈øed throughout the whole earth, did diuide the prouinces amongst them, to preach the gho≈øpell in; and it is deliuered plainely by ≈øundry auntient writers, that Britanie fell in diui≈øion, among≈øt the Apo≈øtles.

The third and la≈øte generall Rule which the≈øe men a≈ø≈øigne vnto vs, is, that mention is not made of any Apo≈øtle in any antiquitie to haue preached here, but onely of S. Peter S. Paul, and S. Symon Zelotes, none of all the≈øe alleadged prote≈øtants or any other, I reade doth ≈øpeake of any other, and amonge
the≈øe one a prote≈øtant Bi≈øhop and Antiquarie writeth in the≈øe termes. Godwyn Conuer≈ø. of Britanie. cap. 1. pag. 2. I finde mention of three onely of the Apostles to haue beene in our Britanie, to wit, Peter and Paul, and Simon Chananaeus, called al≈øo Zelotes. For although ≈øome haue written that S. Iames preached in Ireland, and S. Philip in this next adioyninge Gallia Fraunce (which I haue at lardge refuted in other places) yett noe one hi≈øtorian to my remembrance, and reading, doth teach, that either of tho≈øe twoe, or any of the re≈øt, except tho≈øe three before ≈øett downe, were at any time in this Iland.

The≈øe Rules of Prote≈øtants thus ≈øuppo≈øed, and allowed, it will with a ≈ømall labour, euidently appeare vnto vs, by the≈øe men, and all antiquities, that the mo≈øte glorious Apo≈øtle Saint Peter was our fir≈øt father, and teacher in Chri≈øt. For fir≈øt concerning S. Paul, hee him≈øelfe, and other ≈øcriptures, and the≈øe prote≈øtants al≈øoe confe≈ø≈øe, hee was none of the 12. Apo≈øtles, by whoÃÑ the world was ≈øoe diuided, and though miraculou≈øly called by god before, yett not properly an Apo≈øtle vntill in the 13. chapter of the Acts of the Apo≈øtles, v. 2. hee was ≈øoe ordeyned:
as our engli≈øh prote≈øtants by their conference of the fir≈øt chapter and ver≈øe of S. Paules Epi≈øtle to the Romans. Rom. cap. 1. v. 1. are Interpretors hereof, when the other Apo≈øtles had preached longe before, and otherwi≈øe al≈øoe executed their Apo≈øtolicke function.

Secondly it is euident by the ≈øame holy ≈øcriptures. Rom. 1. c. 1. act. cap. 27.28. many Antiquities, and the≈øe prote≈øtants them≈øelues, ≈øoe clearely coÃÑfe≈ø≈øinge (Theater of great Brit. lib. 6. Godw. Conuers. Parker. antiq. Britan.) that S. Paul came not to Rome, nor any part neare Britanie, or the≈øe we≈øterne nations, vntill many yeares after S. Peter was both come to Rome, and this kingdome of Britanie had receaued the faith of Chri≈øt, at the late≈øt in the time of Claudius according to the≈øe prote≈øtants by ≈øome Apo≈øtle as before, the fir≈øt coming of S. Paul to any of the≈øe we≈øterne Regions, beeing longe after in the time of Nero, to whome hee appealed from the Iewes, and Fe≈øtus, and ≈øoe was brought pri≈øoner to Rome and ≈øoe continued two yeares, not going from thence to any other place. Actor. c. 25. v. 10.11.12. cap. 27. & 28. v. 30.

That S. Symon Zelotes ≈øhould bee the fir≈øt Apo≈øtle that preached here, or was here at all, it is as vnprobable, or rather vnpo≈ø≈øible by the≈øe prote≈øtants: for fir≈øt diuers of them di≈øable him euer to haue beene here, Stowe and Howes histor. in Agricola Holinsh. hi≈øt. of Engl. l. 4. c. 5. rather thinkinge, the place BritaÃÑnia, where ≈øome haue thought hee preached to bee mi≈øtaken, and not to bee vnder≈øtood of this nation, or that Simon which is ≈øuppo≈øed to haue beene here, was not S. SimoÃÑ the Apo≈øtle, but ≈øome other of that name, as S. Simon Lepro≈øus, or Nathaniel, al≈øo by ≈øome named Simon, which preached in the≈øe we≈øterne parts, namely in Fraunce, and not vnprobably here.

Secondly the≈øe prote≈øtants which would haue vs thinke S. Simon the Apo≈øtle preached here (Menologie. Graec. in Nathan. Bar. in martyrol. Rom. 28. octob. Guliel. Ei≈øengr. centurie¬∑ 1. & alij.) refer his beeing here vntil the coming of S. Io≈øeph of Aramathia, coniecturinge that hee came with him, who came not hither vntil the yeare of Chri≈øt 63. when they graunt that Britanie had receaued the gho≈øpell by an Apo≈øtle ≈øoe longe before, as is alreadie declared from them. Parker
Antiquit. pag. 3. Godwyn. Conuers. of Britanie pag. 10. Thirdly (to make all ≈øure) Such as haue taught that one S. Symon did preach in a place called Britannia; Doroth. in Synop≈ø. Maenolog. Graec. 6. Id. Maij. doe al≈øoe affirme, that the ≈øame S. Symon ≈øuffered martyrdome, and was crucified in the ≈øame place, and they keepe the fea≈øt of his martyrdome vpon the tenth day of May. When concerning S. Symon ZeloÃÑtes the Apo≈øtle, not onely the whole latine church, and all catholicks in the world, but Prote≈øtants al≈øo, both of England, and all other nations, in their mo≈øt publicke ≈øeruice bookes, and kalenders of their churches, receaued and allowed by their parlaments, and highe≈øt Rules in their Religion, which all of them ar bownde to obey, and followe, doe celebrate the fe≈øtiuitie of S. Symon Zelotes the Apo≈øtle, vpon the 28. day of October, aboue fiue moneths after, and all iointly agree, in the hi≈øtorie of his life, and death, teaching hee neuer preached in any part of Europe, or neare our Britanye, and was martyred in Per≈øia, diuers thou≈øands of myles froÃÑ hence. Martyrolog. Rom. die 28. Octobr. Breuiar. & Mi≈ø≈ø. Rom. eod. die. Bed. in Martyr. eod. die.
V≈øuard. & Ado eod. die. Protestant com. Booke and all their kalenders with their Bibles 28. of Octob.

Now there is noe other left to bee our fir≈øt Apo≈øtle and Father in Chri≈øt but S. Peter, except ≈øome ignorant or willfull man, will alledge S. Io≈øeph of Aramathia, who though hee was noe Apo≈øtle, yett as ≈øome ≈øay, hee was ≈øent hither out of Fraunce, by S. Philip one of the Apo≈øtles, and ≈øoe mediately the ≈øame S. Philip. though neuer here in par≈øon, might bee our Apo≈øtle. I an≈øwere as before, that wee contend for the fir≈øt Apo≈øtle, that either immediately by him≈øelfe, or mediatly by his di≈øciples, preached here, and founded our church, and not to exclude all Apo≈øtles in after times, from this kingdome, for I wil at lea≈øte probably ≈øhew, that S. Paul was here, a little before his death in an other place; and there al≈øoe giue his due to S. Io≈øeph, and his holy company, in a far more honorable degree, then any prote≈øtant, or other one writer yet to my reading hath performed towards them; But S. Io≈øeph from whom≈øoeuer hee was ≈øent, cominge hither but in the 63. of Chri≈øt, almo≈øt twenty yeares (as before) after this kingdome had receaued
the faith of Chri≈øt, neyther S. Io≈øeph, nor any of that holy fraternitie could bee the fir≈øt preacher here.

And ≈øoe farr vnprobable or impo≈ø≈øible it is, that by the Iudgment of our Engli≈øh prote≈øtants, or others, S. Philip the Apo≈øtle ≈øhould bee then in Fraunce to ≈øend S. Io≈øeph hither, that hee was many yares before crucified, & ≈øoe dead by martyrdome in Phrygia at Hierapolis there, in A≈øia, as the common con≈øent of antiquities, the whole-church of God, and the prote≈øtants of England, in the Rituall of their Religion, generally v≈øed and allowed by them, and all other prote≈øtants doe wittne≈ø≈øe, and therfore keepe his fe≈øtiuitie accordingly vppon the fir≈øt day of May, in or about the 54. or 55. yeare of Chri≈øt, longe before S. Io≈øephs cominge into this part of the world. Bre. Rom. 1. Maij. Martyrolog. Rom. Bed. V≈øuara. Ado 1. Maij. Chry≈øost. hom. de 12. Apost. Abd. lib. 10. Metaphrastes 14. Nou. Eu≈øeb. l. 4. c. 24. Niceph. lib. 1. ca. 39. Pet. de Natal. l. 4. c. 107. AntoÃÑ. part. 1. tit. 6. ca. 11. Ei≈øengr. contra. 1. Prot. Com. Booke and kalend. 1. Maij. Therfore of nece≈ø≈øitie, both Catholiks and prote≈øtants mu≈øt needs acknowledge, that S. Peter the
mo≈øt worthie and ble≈ø≈øed Apo≈øtle, was our fir≈øt mo≈øt happy father & ma≈øter in Chri≈øt, which I haue made lardge demon≈øtration of in other places, and will for particulars bee more euident in the next chapter, and this whole hi≈øtory: an hi≈øtoricall truth ≈øoe te≈øtified by many authors, that Syr William Cambden, whome others therein followe, the be≈øt antiquary of this nation, writeth in many editions, Quid ni crederemus? why should wee not beleeue them. Cambden in Britania in diuer≈øe editionis Andree Che≈ønee l 3. hi≈øt. d' Angleterre. Budley pag. 171. Makinge S. Peters preachinge and foundinge the church of Chri≈øt here in Britanie a thinge ≈øoe certayne, that hee meruayleth any man of Iudgment can make doubt thereof. Therfore I may boldly v≈øe the≈øe wordes (and affirme them true) of a prote≈øtant Bi≈øhop in the name of the re≈øt: Wee should accompt it a greate glory to deriue the pedigree of our ≈øpirituall linage, from ≈øoe noble, and excellent a father as Saint Peter. Godwyn Conuer≈ø. of Britanie pag. 6.

div.head: THE II. CHAPTER. Where both the former is more manife≈øtly declared, and in particular farther proued by the≈øe protestants, & antiquities by them allowed, what highest ≈øpirituall offices the ≈øame glorious Apo≈øtle, and his di≈øciples performed here.
div.p:
TO proue more amply what hath beene ≈øaid of S. Peters beeing and preachinge here, and to ≈øhewe what hee did for the fir≈øt foundinge of our church: A prote≈øtant Archbi≈øhop from diuers authorities writeth: Whit gifts Answ. to the Admonition pag. 65. ≈øect. 1. and def. of the Answ. pag. 318. The Apo≈øtle Peter did in euery prouince appoint one Archbishop, whom all other Bishops of the ≈øame prouince should obey. An other with great priuiledge ≈øaith (Sutcliffe Subuer≈ø. pag. 3.) Peter preached in ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ e place, but hee there ordeyned Bishops and teachers and founded churches. And to ≈øhew that all the≈øe and ≈øuch benefits came to vs fir≈øt from S. Peter and his holy ≈øee of Rome, among other Marcus Antonius de Dominis, now by the greate mercy of
God a penitent in the catholicke church, when hee was in profe≈ø≈øion a prote≈øtant in England (Marcus Anton, de Domin. de Repub. chri≈øtian. l. 4. cap. 10. with publick priuiledg in England) and a cho≈øen champion for that Religion again≈øt the Pope by cheife≈øt prote≈øtant authoritie in England, then te≈øtifieth: Est caput Roma quatenus ab ea diffu≈øum e≈øt euangelium in reliquas totius occidentis eccle≈øias, & in multas orientis, atque in barbaras etiam extra Romanum Imperium nationes. Rome is the head of the church, in ≈øo much as from it the gho≈øpell was diffu≈øed into the other churches of all the We≈øt, and into many of the Ea≈øt, and into barbarous nations al≈øo without the Romane Empire. And our. Soueraigne kings ≈øpeach in parlam. 1. publickly prote≈øted of this church of Rome: It is our mother church: and con≈øequently that it fir≈øt brought vs forthe in ≈øpirituall chri≈øtian birth, as mothers doe their natural children to the world and that wee, except wee will turne ba≈øtardly vnnaturall and di≈øobedient children, doe owe and mu≈øt performe all dutie and obedience vnto it, our mo≈øt holy mother in Chri≈øt. And to further this our bounden dutie, the prote≈øtants
of England in their Theater. of the Emp. of greate Britante pag. 203 l. 6. c. 9. num. 5. will helpe vs foreward whoe write in this maner: That S. Peter the Apo≈øtle preached the word of life, in this Iland, as to other gentiles hee did, for whome God had cho≈øen him, that from his mouth they might heare the gho≈øpell, as him≈øelfe alleadgeth, and that hee here founded churches, and ordeined prei≈øts and deacons, which is reported by Simon Metaphra≈øtes out of the greek Antiquities, and Gulielmus Ei≈øingrenius in the fir≈øt of his Centuries. Therfore this beeing written by ≈øoe learned and holy a man as S. Simon Metaphra≈øtes was, and ≈øoe auntient aboue 700. yeares ≈øince, and out of ≈øuch monuments and Authorities of the Gretians, as in his time were honored with the Title of Antiquities, this alone might content vs in this matter, as it hath already the be≈øt learned prote≈øtant Antiquaries of this nation.

But becau≈øe allowance is giuen to the authoritie which cannot be denyed, becau≈øe it is the maner of Prote≈øtants to mynce authorities, I will cite that holy auntient Father and Saint. S. Sim. Metaphr. 29. die Iunij. in his owne wordes which bee the≈øe. RomaÃÑ redijt,
ex qua venit Mediolanum, & Photicen quae ≈øunt ciuitates in Continente. In quibus cum con≈øtitui≈ø≈øet Epi≈øcopos & Presbyteros, venit in Britanniam. Quo in loco cum longo tempore fui≈ø≈øet moratus, & multas gentes non nominatas attraxi≈ø≈øet ad fidem Christi, angelicam a≈øpexit vi≈øionem, quae dicebat: Petre, instat tempus tua re≈øolutionts, & oportet te ire Romam: in qua cum mortem per crucem ≈øustinueris, recipies mercedem Iustitiae. Cum ergo propterea Deum glorifica≈ø≈øet, & egi≈ø≈øet gratias, & apud Britannos man≈øi≈øset dies aliquot, & verbo gratiae multos illumina≈ø≈øet, & eccle≈øias constitui≈ø≈øet, epi≈øcopo≈øque & presbyteros & diaconos ordina≈ø≈øet, duodecimo anno Cae≈øaris Neronis rur≈øus Romam reuertitur. S. Peter by reuelation came to Hieru≈øalem, at the death of the mother of God, then returning into Egipt, by Africk came againe to Rome. From whence hee came to Milane and Photice, which bee cities in the contineÃÑt: in which when hee had con≈øtituted Bi≈øhops, and prei≈øts, hee came into Britanie, where when hee had ≈øtayed a longe time, and drawne many nations not named, to the faith of Chri≈øt, hee had an Angelicall vi≈øion, which ≈øaide: √¥ Peter, the time of thy Re≈øolution is at hande,
and thou mu≈øt goe to Rome, in which when thou ha≈øt ≈øuffered death by the cro≈ø≈øe, thou ≈øhalt receaue the reward of lu≈øtice. Therfore when hee had glorified God and giuen thankes for it, and remayned ≈øome dayes with the Britans and illuminated manie with the word of grace, and founded churches, & ordeyned both Bi≈øhops, prie≈øts, and deacons, hee returned againe to Rome in the twelueth years of the Emperor Nero.

Hitherto the very words of this learned Saint, ≈øoe preci≈øely and particularly de≈øcribeing the tyme and comming of that glorious Apo≈øtle into this Iland, & ≈øtaying here, with his returne to Rome againe, that as noe man except an infidell will or can deny it, no Author of antiquitie or credit auouching halfe ≈øo much for either S Paul or any other Apo≈øtle to haue beene here at all: ≈øoe except wee of EnglaÃÑd wil ≈øhew our ≈øelues the mo≈øt vngratefull, & di≈øobedient to that our fir≈øt, and mo≈øt glorious Pa≈øtor, and parent, of all nations in the world except Hieru≈øaleÃÑ, Antioch and Rome, wee ar mo≈øt engaged to honor and reuerence this mo≈øt glorious Apo≈øtle & his Succe≈ø≈øors in his holy Sec: for neither
Pontus, Galatia, Cappadocia, A≈øia, or Bythinia, which hee him≈øelfe particularly remembreth, 1. Pet. 1. v. 1. nor any other kingdome or nation mentioned in any Author of credit and Antiquitie, and to bee paralelled with him whom I haue cited, approued euen in this point with all Catholicks, and the mo≈øte iudicious indifferently mynded and be≈øt learned prote≈øtants, can con≈øtantly affirme and proue, that they had receaued ≈øuch benefites and ble≈ø≈øings from S. Peter, as this our Britanie, which to vi≈øitt hee went ≈øoe farr, ≈øtayed therein ≈øoe longe, and enritched as with ≈øoe many and vnan≈øweareable graces and fauors: continuinge them ≈øoe longe, vntill he was admoni≈øhed from heaueÃÑ to returne from hence to Rome, as before his cominge thither, hee al≈øo was as Metaphra≈øtes, die 29. Rhenan. in history of Germany. Pantaleon.) And much about the≈øe times, as B. Rhenanus in his hi≈øtory of Germany, Pantaleon, and others doe reporte, one Suetonius a noble mans ≈øonne in Britanie, conuerted to the faith by the fir≈øt planters of the gho≈øpell in this Iland, and after his Bapti≈øme called Beatus, was ≈øent by the bretheren from hence, vnto Rome to bee better in≈øtructed, and further directed by Saint Peter him≈øelfe. And returninge through Suitcerland, found ≈øuch willingnes and flockinge of the people to heare, and receaue the doctrine of Chri≈øt, that hee there ≈øtayed, and built an oratory not far from the bake Thun, & neare the Towne called Vnderfewen, where in preachinge and prayers, hee employed his time to the day of his death, which happened in the yeare of grace 110.

Hitherto the words of our engli≈øh Prote≈øtants, of this glorious and renowned man, far exceeding that which they giue him here:
for as their Author Henricus Pantaleon. (de viris Illu≈øtr. Germaniae part. 1 p. 114 a German Prote≈øtant writeth plainely of him, that hee was, the Apostle of Heluetians. S. Beatus Heluetiorum Apostolus. Which Title and name none but puritans of anie Religion will giue to any but Bi≈øhops, and none but ≈øuch which onely haue power to con≈øecrate prei≈øts, (without which a true church cannot bee) can either bee, or truely called their Apo≈øtle. And that this holy Bi≈øhop of Britanie though hee ≈øtaied mo≈øt in Heluetia, yet that hee was principally ≈øent to bee a Bi≈øhopp in Britanie by Saint Peter, it is euident by the≈øe Prote≈øtants before, te≈øtifyinge that hee was returning into Britanie, and ≈øoe cheifely directed by Saint Peter: (Pantal. ≈øupra Stamph. lib. 7. de Sanct.) Which Pantaleon with Stamphius and others doe more plainely witne≈ø≈øe, ≈øaying. S. Beatus ille nobilibus parentibus natus ex Britannia, in patriam rediens &c. S. Beatus borne of noble parents in Britanie, returninge into his contry: and adding of him, omnia bona pauperibus di≈øtribuit: hee di≈øtributed all his goods to the pore: mu≈øt needes bee in Britanie, where of the≈øe his goods he was to
make di≈øtributor of them. And the≈øe GermaÃÑ hi≈øtorians tel vs, that hee had an other companion ≈øent and directed with him, from Rome by S. Peter or his authoritie there, and beeinge al≈øoe a Britaine returned hither, beeing con≈øecrated Prei≈øt or Bi≈øhop by the ≈øame authoritie, and at the ≈øame time.

So that wee ≈øee by the≈øe Prote≈øtants them≈øelues, that ≈øoe longe as S. Peter liued, the Bi≈øhops and Prei≈øts of Britanie were con≈øecrated by him in this contry, and in his ab≈øence hence went vnto Rome for their con≈øecration, and to bee directed by him. This other companion of S. Beatus, borne in this kingdome, and con≈øecrated at Rome by S. Peter, and returninge hither, where for any thinge wee reade otherwi≈øe in hi≈øtories, hee continued in preaching all his life, and died here, ≈øome Germane writers haue named Achates. (Anonymus apud Beat. Rhenan. de Reb. German. l. 3. pag. 172. Rhen. ≈øupr.) Whether that was his true name or noe, it is not materiall to my purpo≈øe to que≈øtion here: the hi≈øtorie it ≈øelfe in germany beeing ≈øoe certainely and generally receaued, that it is, and aunciently was published, printed, and painted in their churches there. Hac
hi≈øtoria non ≈øolum picta e≈øt in templis ac ≈øcripta, ≈øed etiam typis expre≈ø≈øa: of this hi≈øtorie mention is made, e≈øpecially of S. Beatus in the Romane Martyrologe, S. Beda, V≈øuardus, Molanus, Gulielmus Ei≈øengrenius, the Antiquities of Heluetia, and expre≈ø≈øely in the auncient monuments of the church of Con≈øtance, and others. (Martyrolog. Rom. 9. die Maij. Beda V≈øuard. & Mol. ab. Guliel. Ei≈ø. centur. 2. part. 5. Annal. Helu Momment. Eccle-Con≈øtant. Baron annot. in Mart. Rom. 9. Maij.) neyther can wee thinke that the≈øe two holy Bi≈øhops or prei≈øts of this kingedome of our Britanie were ≈øingular in this, but that wee had more ≈øo con≈øecrated, and directed from Rome be≈øides them, and needed not Bi≈øhops and pa≈øtors here, otherwi≈øe S. Beatus would not haue ≈øtayed mo≈øte of his time in Heluetia, forth of his contry, nor S. Peter his con≈øercator and director, & our Apo≈øtle by the≈øe Prote≈øtants before, giuen allowaÃÑce vnto it.

Neyther had S. Beatus beene ≈øent (the words of our Prote≈øtants and Pantaleon al≈øoe) by the brethren from hence vnto Rome to bee better in≈øtructed and further directed by S. Peter him≈øelfe. (Theater, and Pantal. ≈øupr.)
But that the Brethren and Chri≈øtians here depended of Saint Peter, and accompted it both their dutie, and honor to this nation, to haue their ≈øpirituall Guides, Bi≈øhops, and Prei≈øts con≈øecrated and directed by him, and his Apo≈øtolicque ≈øupreame power and commaunde, in Religious thinges.

Now lett vs returne to S. Peters beeinge here in Britanie; whereof I haue ≈øpoken before, how to ≈øupply all ≈øpiritual wants of this kingedome, and founde our church, in Britannia longe tempore fuit moratus, he ≈øtayed in Britanie a longe time, as the greeke antiquities remembred vnto vs by our Prote≈øtaÃÑts haue told vs: and to expre≈ø≈øe his greate lo ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ e, & care, to this & other we≈øtern natioÃÑs, more particularly comended to his chardge, this longe time was ≈øoe longe, and his loue to vs ≈øo greate, that as both S. SimoÃÑ Metaphra≈øtes, and Eu≈øebius Pamphili in ≈øome booke not now, but in the time of Metaphra≈øtes extaÃÑt, and by him con≈øtantly cited, ≈øay: S. Peter ≈øtayed at Rome, and in Britanie, and the cities of the west, three and twentie yeares. Eu≈øebius Pamphili dicit Petrum viginti tres annos traÃÑ≈øeg ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ ≈ø≈øe Romae, & in Britannia, & in ciuitatibus quae ≈øunt in occidente. (Simon Metaphrastes
die 29. Iunij. Eu≈øebius Pamph. apud eund. ≈øupr. Surius 29. Iunij.) allotinge onely as it ≈øeemeth the re≈øt of the 25. yeares which is commonlie ≈øaid, the time of his beeing at Rome and the≈øe parts, to his Iorney in the ea≈øt, at the time of the migration of the B. Virgin our Lady forth of this world. Which is confirmed by ≈øome of our Prote≈øtant antiquaries of England in the≈øe words. This yeare 70. beinge the fourteenth yeare of Nero Ba≈ø≈øus and Tu≈øcus, beeing then Romane Con≈øuls, the holy Apostle S. Peter hauinge accompli≈øhed his preachinge, in the west parts, returned to Rome, where hee preached agayne, as hee did before. (Ioh. Stow and Ed. Howes hi≈øtor. titul. Romans in Iulius Agricola.)

And before his departure hence, as I haue allready remembred, be≈øides S. Man≈øuetus, S. Beatus and ≈øuch as hee con≈øecrated Bi≈øhops of our nation in forreyn places, or for them out of Britanie, hee ordeyned here, and for this kingedome Bi≈øhops, Prei≈øts & Deacons. Apud Britannos Epi≈øcopos, presbyteros & diaconos ordinauit. Who the≈øe Bi≈øhops in particular were, I reade noe man preci≈øely to ≈øett them downe, yett if wee will followe the antiquities of Gla≈øtenbury
≈øaying that S. Io≈øophe the ≈øonne of S. Io≈øeph of Aramathia was a Bi≈øhop, as both Catholicks and Prote≈øtants allowe them in other things: I craue pardon probably to write, that he was one of them which S. Peter con≈øecrated here.

Fir≈øt, becau≈øe as is graunted, before S. Ari≈øtobulus our Archbi≈øhop, vnto whom S. Io≈øeph, whether Bi≈øhop or noe, was ≈øubiect, was ordeyned by S. Peter. Secondly becau≈øe S. Io≈øeph is named a Bi≈øhop, and yet in probable iudgmeÃÑt none when hee came hither, with his Father S. Io≈øeph, for by the ≈øame and all other antiquities and hi≈øtories of that matter, S. Io≈øeph his Father noe Bi≈øhop, was the Abbot or Superior of all that company, yet neither Catholick nor Prote≈øtant will ea≈øily in≈øtance that Bi≈øhops, by order and Sacrament Superiors, were or might bee Inferiors or ≈øubiects to any of Inferior degree.

Secondlie there is noe po≈ø≈øibilitie by any authoritie, that I finde at all, to ≈øurmi≈øe that S. Io≈øeph was a Bi≈øhop before his cominge hither, but the wordes of the antiquitie which ≈øay of him: that Ie≈øus con≈øecrated him Bishop before in the citie Sarath: Quem Dominus Ie≈øus prius in ciuitate Sarath, in Epi≈øcopum
con≈øecrauit. (Antiquit. Glast. apud Capgrau. in S. Io≈øeph ab Aramathia.) Which noe Prote≈øtant will or may by their Religion ≈øay, was a true and reall con≈øecration, but rather propheticall, what ≈øhould bee done, by orderly con≈øecration after. For this vi≈øion was longe after Chri≈øts A≈øcen≈øion into heauen, where all Prote≈øtants of England euer ≈øince, impri≈øon him to keepe him from being pre≈øent in the B. Sacrament of the altar.

Thirdlie they and all others generally denie ≈øuch extraordinary proceedings, where an ordinary and vniuer≈øall order, as in this ca≈øe is appointed by Chri≈øt him≈øelfe. Wherfore S. Paul him≈øelfe that ve≈ø≈øell of Election, and extraordinary Apo≈øtle, though miraculou≈øly conuerted, cho≈øen, and called, yett bee neither was actually a chri≈øtian without externall bapti≈øme, nor a Bi≈øhop but by Impo≈øition of hands, and ordinary con≈øecration. And wee reade of S. Samp≈øon, our holy Archbi≈øhop of yorke, that before hee was a Bi≈øhop, S. Peter, S. Iames, and S. Iohn appeared vnto him ≈øaying: (Io. Capgrau. in S. Samp≈øone Epi≈øc. & Confe≈ø≈øore.) Our Lord Ie≈øus Chri≈øt hath cho≈øen thee for a Bishop, and ≈øent vs to con≈øecrate thee: whom when they had
con≈øecrated with benediction, they di≈øappeared out of his ≈øight. Nocte quadam vidit ≈øe den≈øi≈øsimis candidatorum turmis circundari: & tres Epi≈øcopos ve≈øtibus aureis ornatos, cum illo eccle≈øiam ingredientes orare, cuius vnus illorum ab ip≈øo inqui≈øitus, qui e≈ø≈øet, ait. Ego ≈øum Petrus Christi Apostolus, & hic frater Domini Iacobus, & Euangelista Ioannes. Dominus Ie≈øus Chri≈øtus te ≈øibi in prae≈øulem elegit, & te con≈øecrare nos mi≈øit. QueÃÑ c√πm benedictione con≈øecra≈ø≈øent, ab eius oculis elap≈øi≈øunt. And yett neither S. Samp≈øon nor any other tooke this for a reall con≈øecration, but onely figuratiue of that which was after to bee done by the holie externall rite of the church of Chri≈øt; vntill as wee reade in the ≈øame hi≈øtory, our holy Archbi≈øhop S. Dubricius vpon the apparition and me≈ø≈øage of an Angell did truely and really, externally con≈øecrate him a Bi≈øhop: nec multo post Angelus Domini beato Dubricio apparens, Samp≈øonem ordinari Epi≈øcopum praecepit. (Capgr. ≈øupr.) Soe I might exemplifie in many ≈øuch ca≈øes, only propheticall and figuratiue, what ≈øhould afterward bee done, and not what was then effected.

Therfore if S. Io≈øeph was a Bi≈øhop as that antiquitie per≈øuadeth, by that figuratiue vi≈øion,
& not coÃÑ≈øecrated before hee came into Britanie, as is ≈øhewed before, & wee reade of no other which at that time made, & con≈øecrated Bi≈øhops but S Peter, I may probably at the lea≈øte affirme, that S. Io≈øephe was one of them which S. Peter at his departure heÃÑce, (S. Io≈øephe beeing certainely here at that time) was con≈øecrated Bi≈øhop by Saint Peter here in Britanie. And when I finde both Catholicks and Prote≈øtants affirme, (Martyrol. Angl. 7. die Februarij. Drekin Almin. an. 1620. 7. Feb. with others.) that S. Angulus was our Bi≈øhop of London & martyr, and yet noe hi≈øtoriaÃÑ, Catholick or Prote≈øtaÃÑt, putteth him in the nuÃÑber of them which were Bi≈øhops there after the time of K. Lucius, but quite leaue him out of that catalogue, as appeareth by our Prote≈øtants Harri≈øon, Godwyne, Stowe & others which with al diligeÃÑce they could, haue collected the auncient Bi≈øhops of London, I mu≈øt needs drawe him to an higher time then that of kinge Lucius was, before which noe con≈øecration of Bi≈øhops in Britany was, or is ≈øo memorable as this by S. Peter the Apo≈øtle (Harri≈ø. de ≈øcript. of Brit Godw. Catalog. of Bi≈øhop in London 1. Stowe and Howe. l. hi≈øt. Lucius Iocelin of Furnes l. de Epi≈øc. Brit.

And to end here the Relation of S. Peters proceedings in Britanie, wee haue clearly, deduced, with the allowance of our be≈øt Engli≈øh Prote≈øtant Antiquaries, and other Authors by them approued; That S. Peter Prince of the Apo≈øtles, was our fir≈øt Father in Chri≈øt, and renowned Apo≈øtle, both immediately by him≈øelfe, and his holy di≈øciples; That hee performed here all cheife and eminent pa≈øtorall duties and offices, when our Emperors with our Lieutenants here, as al≈øo all our Kings were pagan Infidels; That hee ordeyned and con≈øecrated for vs Bi≈øhops, prei≈øts, and other clergie men, and founded churches to the honor & Religion of Chri≈øt, and the honor of his ble≈ø≈øed Mother S. Mary the Virgin, (few other chri≈øtian Saints then decea≈øed) as that of Gla≈øtenbury not ≈øoe dedicated without his approbation, beeing cheife in ≈øuch affaires. Hee con≈øecrated other Britans out of this nation, exemptinge them from the pagan ≈øeruice of tho≈øe ≈øuch remembred princes, hee ≈øent them by authoritie to preach the gho≈øpell, in other contries, hee or his di≈øciples conuerted Pomponia Graecina the Lord Lieutenants wife of Britanie, as the≈øe Prote≈øtants haue proued, and
many in the like ca≈øe, their husbands continuing in their infidelitie, and contradiction, and many husbands and children, the wiues and parents not allowinge, as ≈øeruants in re≈øpect of their Lords and ma≈øters, and Subiects in regard of ≈øoueraignes.

I, a Catholick Prei≈øt, now demaund of the be≈øt learned Prote≈øtaÃÑts Bi≈øhops of England, whether the≈øe proceedings and prerogatiues in that mo≈øte glorious Apo≈øtle, and his worthie di≈øciples, our fir≈øt Ma≈øters in Chri≈øt, were not as greate and ample, as the renowned Prei≈øts and Catholicks of this kingedome now attribute, and giue to the Popes of Rome his Apo≈øtolicke Succe≈ø≈øors? Wee whoe haue reade mo≈øte, and ≈øuffered much for this cau≈øe, cannot ≈øee the difference, or finde in≈øtance of di≈øparitie, except in number of par≈øons, le≈ø≈øe or greater quantities of groundes, and ≈øome improportions in ≈øuch thinges, which make noe e≈ø≈øentiall diuer≈øitie, for otherwi≈øe wee haue beene told by the be≈øt learned Prote≈øtants with others, that S. Peter and his di≈øciples did manife≈øtlie and directly transfer and chaunge tho≈øe par≈øons, places, and propertie of thinges of this our Britanie from a temporall, to al ≈øpirituall
v≈øe, from the commande (except in temporall dutie) of the pre≈øent Emperors, Lieutenants, Kings and Soueraignes alienated from Chri≈øtiaÃÑ Religion, to the coÃÑmande of Chri≈øt, his Religion, our mo≈øte holy Apo≈øtle and his di≈øciples, by his authoritie ≈øoe directinge.

div.head: THE III. CHAPTER. How in the re≈øt of this first Hundred yeares of Chri≈øt after Saint Peter, The Apostolicke See of Rome, still continued and exerci≈øed this ≈øupreame ≈øpirituall power in Britanie.
div.p:
IT is a que≈øtion, not onely amonge Catholicks (but ≈øome Prote≈øtants al≈øo) whether S. Linus & Cletus were Popes after S. Peter, or onely Suffragan Bi≈øhops, as ≈øoe ordeyned by him at the fir≈øt. And Pope Leo the ≈øecond an holy Saint, with there nowned of our Hi≈øtorians to omitt others, S. Marianus & Florentius Wigornien≈øis, ≈øay plainely: Si Petrus Apostolorum princeps adiutoris ≈øibi a≈øciuit Linum & Cletum, non tamen pontificij potestatem cis tradidit, ≈øed Clementi ≈øucce≈ø≈øori ≈øuo. If Peter
Prince of the Apo≈øtles, did take Linus and Cletus to bee his Adiutors, yett hee gaue not them the Papall power, but to Clement his ≈øucce≈ø≈øor. And Linus and Cletus did nothinge by their owne Lawes and power as popes, but only ≈øoe much as was commaunded them by S. Peter. (S. Leo 2. in epist. decretal. Marian. Scot. lib. 2. aetat. 6. Florent. Wigor. in Siluan. & Otho Con≈øul. Robert. Barns in vit. Port. Rom. in Linum.) Therfore to omitt doubtfull and vncertaine thinges, and to come next to S. Clement whoe mo≈øte certainely by all Cathololicks and Prote≈øtants was Pope of Rome nominated by S. Peter: (though Baronius and others whom he alleageth are of opinion that S. Clement yeelded his right, and did not exerci≈øe the office of ≈øupreame pa≈øtour til after Linus and Cletus, yet who in S. Peters life him were his Coadiutors & after his death his ≈øucce≈ø≈øors before S. ClemeÃÑt, (to 1. Annal. p. 742.743.744.745.) before any other: by this Pope, Doctors were ≈øent into the west (as our Prote≈øtants tell vs (Margin. annot. vppon Matth. We≈øtin. an. 94. Matth. We≈øtm ≈øupr.) in greate numbers, as S. Denis, Nica≈øius, Taurinus, Trophimus, Paulus Narbonen≈øis, Saturninus, Martialis, Gratianus,
Iulianus, Lucianus, Firminus, Photinus all Bi≈øhops, & they add S. Regulus. Whome although they ≈øetle theÃÑ with their Bi≈øhopricks in Fraunce, yett it proueth the power & ≈øpirituall commaund of that holy pope, to haue extended it ≈øelfe a≈øwell to this kingdome, one and the ≈øame rea≈øon beeing for, and again≈øt them both.

But wee finde diuers Authorities both late and auncient to induce vs, to con≈øent that ≈øome of the≈øe named holy Bi≈øhops, ≈øent at this time, by S. Clement, were ≈øent by him into this kingdome of Britanie, namely S. Taurinus and S. Nica≈øius: and that S. Taurinus was Archbi≈øhop or Bi≈øhop of yorke. Amonge others, William Harri≈øon a Prote≈øtant hi≈øtorian. (In de≈øcript. of Britanie. pag. 23. Chronolog. ibid. an. 141.) produceth an Antiquitie that ≈øoe affirmeth: whereuppon hee writeth in this maner: Whether Taurinus Bishop ouer the congregation at yorke, were one of the nyne ≈øchollers of Grantha Cambridge ≈øpoken of in the chronicles of Burton, I doe not certainely finde. But certayne it is, that Walterus Rollewink in his hi≈øtory fa≈øciculus temporum. (an. 94.) ≈øaith. S. Taurinus was Epi≈øcopus Eboracen≈øis, Bishop of yorke, which is here
in Britanie: and ≈øoe not Ebroicen≈øis in Fraunce, where the ≈øame or an other of that name was Bi≈øhop about the ≈øame time And an other late writer. (Harris Theatrum. l. 1.) in his manu≈øcript hi≈øtory, alleadging both S. Antoninus and diuers others, ≈øaith: diuers haue written that both S. Nica≈øius and Taurinus were here in Britanie, and for S. Taurinus, S. Antoninus ≈øaith, that S. Taurinus: filiam Lucij Regis Britanniae √† morte ≈øu≈øcitauit. S. Taurinus did rai≈øe from death the daughter of Lucius, Kinge of Britanie. (S. Antonin. hist. part. 1. titul. 6. cap.) Which directly proueth, that S. Taurinus was here in out Britanie, & this Kinge Lucius for certaine, was eyther hee that liued to receaue the faith of Chri≈øt publickly in the time of Pope Eleutherius, beginning his reigne in the yeare of Chri≈øt 124 (Matt. Westm. an. 124.) or Lucius Antenous the Romane praefect in Britanie called there vppon. Rex Britanniae, Kinge of Britanie, as well hee might, pre≈øcribinge lawes vnto vs in Britanie as Hector Boethius. (Scetor. hi≈øt. l. 5. fol. 76.77.78.) with others wittne≈ø≈øe: and was re≈øident at yorke in the time of the Emperor Adrian, when and where S. Taurinus is ≈øuppo≈øed to haue beene Bi≈øhop
and wrought this miracle. For S. Anaca≈øius beeing ≈øent hither by S. Clement, they which teach ≈øoe. (Harris ≈øupr.) produce the french hi≈øtories that hee preached to the Britans, which in that time were onely tho≈øe of this kingdome, the little Britanie in Fraunce then and longe after named Armorica, and not Britannia.

And yett to omitt others, Arnoldus Mermannus in his Theater of the conuer≈øion of nations, (¬ß. Britones.) ≈øaith, that amonge other people, S. Anaca≈øius beeing delegated thither an Apo≈øtle by S. Clement, did instruct and informe in the faith the Britans, and all the waste of the Ocean Sea. Britones, Normandos, Rhotomagen≈øes, Picardos, omnemque Maris Oceani tractum instruxit, formauitque fide S. Nica≈øius √† S. Clemente illuc Apostolus delegatus. And to putt vs out of doubt, that S. Clement did take vppon him the ≈øpirituall chardge of this our Britanie, as well as of Fraunce and other places, the ≈øame Author from others te≈øtifieth, that our Archbi≈øhop S Ari≈øtobulus whoe as Ei≈øingrenius ≈øaith, had beene a Bi≈øhop from anno Chri≈øti the 39 the 39 yeare of Chri≈øt, was yett our Apo≈øtle in Britanie aliue in the yeare of
Chri≈øt 99. S. Clement then Pope. Et quod excurrit 99. Clemente Pontifice Maximo, Domitiano Imperatore. (Guliel. Ei≈ø ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ ng. centen. 1. part. 1. di≈øt. 7. fol. 67. Arnold. Mermman. Theater conuer≈ø. gent. in Albione) And wee haue vett in England an old manu≈øcript, a ≈øhort hi≈øtoricall relation. (M. S. antiq. pr. Stores in Exordium) Of the publicke Ma≈ø≈øe, and church ≈øeruice, of the Britans, and French men, from the Apo≈øtles time, written before the vnion of the Britans with S. Augu≈øtines mi≈ø≈øion, by S. Gregorie, and written by a Britti≈øh Author, te≈øtifying that the publicke church ≈øeruice and Ma≈ø≈øe, both of the french and Brittans was carried vp to Rome to S. Clement, to bee examined and approued by him then Pope, which hee accordingly performed by his papall power, & this Ma≈ø≈øe was euer after v≈øed both in FrauÃÑ ce, and this our kingedome of Britanie.

Soe that mo≈øte euident it is, by tho≈øe few Antiquities left vnto vs, that in the time of S. Clement whoe was Pope in the later end of the fir≈øt, & beginninge of the ≈øecond hundred yeare of Chri≈øt, this our church of Britanie was wholly in ≈øpiritual thinges, dependant and ≈øubordinate to the church and
Popes of Rome: and thus much of the fir≈øt age and hundred yeare, from the birth of Chri≈øt. When here and of this nation there were yett liuinge many Bi≈øhops con≈øecrated by S. Peter, and the Romane Papall authoritie: S. Aristobulus, Man≈øuetus, Beatus, and probably S. Io≈øephe, Taurinus, Nica≈øius, Angulus, and others: for to add to the former, S. Anacletus ≈øaith in his Epi≈øtle, approued by our Prote≈øtants of England, our contryman S. Marianus and others. (Rob. Barns in vita pont. Rom. in Anacl. Mar. Scot. l. 2. de aetat. 6. col. 250. Florent. Wigorn. in Domit.) that the prouinces where Archbi≈øhops were, were diuided by the Apostles and S. Clement his predece≈ø≈øor, ab Apo≈øtolis & Beato Clemente praece≈ø≈øore no≈øtro, ip≈øa Prouincia diui≈øio renouata est. (Some do make Clitus and Anaclitus alone, and make him praedece≈ø≈øour to S. Clement ≈øee. Baro. to. 1.) Therefore mo≈øt euident it is that S. Clement tooke vppon him and exerci≈øed, this ≈øupreame Papall and ≈øpirituall power in this kingedome.

div.head: THE SECOND CENTVRIE OR HVNDRED YEARE.
THE IV. CHAPTER. Shewing by the≈øe Prote≈øtants, how the popes of Rome in this ≈øecond Century of yeares claymed, had, and exerci≈øed ≈øupreame ≈øpirituall Iuri≈ødiction and power in Britanie.
div.p:
TO begin with the ≈øecond age, and hundred yeare, Saint and Pope Anacletus offereth him ≈øelfe fir≈øt, beeing the next and immediate Succe≈ø≈øor to S. Clement, and as hee him≈øelfe wittne≈ø≈øeth. (Epi≈øt. decretal. Marian. Scot. l. 2. aetat. 6. col. 250. Florentius Wigorn. in Domitiano. Matth. Westin. an. 102.) Both in≈øtructed, and taught and made preist by S. Peter cheife of the Apo≈øtles: vt √† beato Petro principe ≈øumus instructi, √† quo & presbyter ≈øum ordinatus. This holy Pope S. Peters di≈øciple beginning his papacy in the 102. yeare of Chri≈øt as our Prote≈øtants of England enforme vs. (Rob. Barns. in vit. pontif. Rom. in Anacleto. Ormerod. pict. of Pap. pag. 78.) Thought that the primacy ouer all churches
was grauÃÑted to the church of Rome by our Lord him≈øelfe, and ouer all Christian people. Ab ip≈øo Domino primatum Romanae Eccle≈øiae ≈øuper omnes Eccle≈øias, vniuer≈øumque Christiani nomine populum conce≈ø≈øum e≈ø≈øe a≈ø≈øeruit. And they tell vs further, how according to this ≈øupreamacie graunted by Chri≈øt to the Sea of Rome, ouer all churches and Chri≈øtian people, hee executed the ≈øame in makinge his general decrees, bindinge all Bi≈øhops, Prie≈øts and others, both concerninge the mo≈øt ble≈ø≈øed ≈øacrifice of the Ma≈ø≈øe, and Iuri≈ødiction.

Amonge other thinges, to ≈øpeake in Prote≈øtant words. (Rob. Barns ≈øupra.) Epi≈øcopos officio pares, ordine duplici distinxit: eos primates, ≈øiue patriarchas appellari voluit, qui in illis ciuitatibus praee≈øsent, in quibus olim primarij Flamines ≈øederunt: in alijs metropolitanis vrbibus, Epi≈øcopos Metropolitanos vel Archiepi≈øcopos nominandos e≈ø≈øe cen≈øuit. Hee di≈øtingui≈øhed Bi≈øhops equall in order, into two degrees: cau≈øinge them to bee named Primates, or Patriarkes, which ruled in tho≈øe cities, in which of olde the Archflamens did ≈øitt: in other Metropolitane cities, hee would haue them named Metropolitans
or Archbi≈øhops, and hee calleth this not his owne decree, but the decree of S. Clement his predece≈ø≈øor, and Saint Peter al≈øoe. (Anacl. ≈øupr. & apud Mar. Scot. & Flor. Wigorn. ≈øupr.) And ≈øetteth downe in a certayne Tome, what cytes were to haue primates, both accordinge to his owne, S. Clements, and the Apo≈øtles order.

And this decree of Sainct Anacletus, in this highe≈øt que≈øtion of Iuri≈ødiction, was ≈øoe vniuer≈øall and generall in it ≈øelfe, ≈øoe embraced of all, and includinge, that as not onely Giraldus Cambren≈øis, and auncient authorities of this nation, (Lib. 2. de Iure Metropol. eccle≈ø. Meneuen. ad Innocent. 3.) but the cheife Prote≈øtant Antiquaries them≈øelues, as Mathew Parker the fir≈øt Prote≈øtant Archbi≈øhop of Canterburie, (Lib. antiquit. Britannic. pag. 24.) and Syr Iohn Pri≈øe, (Io. Pri≈ø. defen≈ø. histor. Britan. pag. 73.) doe plainelie acknowledge, that by that Tome of Saint Anacletus Pope, it was conteyned and decreed, how manie and which were the places throughout all this Iland euen as it conteyned England, Scotland, and Wales. And thereupon this Prote≈øtant Archbi≈øhopp, doth in expre≈ø≈øe
termes call the diui≈øion of Britanie in that re≈øpect: Ex Anacleto huius In≈øulae diui≈øionem. The diui≈øion of this Iland according to the decree of Pope Anacletus: And though this diui≈øion was not actually made at that time for ≈øetting Archbi≈øhops in tho≈øe prouinces at that time, but was deferred vntill in after when the faith was recreaued here in more publicke maner, when per≈øecution cea≈øed, or was mitigated; yett by the≈øe authorities there is noe doubt, but this holy Pope both claymed, and exerci≈øed the ≈øame highe≈øt ≈øpirituall Iuri≈ødiction, as well in this, as all other nations, that decree beeing generall, and without limitation for all nations, as it is allowed by the≈øe Prote≈øtants, and making all prouinces in the knowne world, ≈øub≈øtitute and ≈øubordinate to the church of Rome in ≈øuch affaires, and none exempted.

And as this decree alone will witnes, hee ≈øent as opportunitie and the cau≈øe required, Bi≈øhops and prei≈øts into other contries, ≈øoe he did the like to this, to encrea≈øe and continue that happy buildinge, which his predece≈ø≈øors had founded here before. Soe wee mu≈øt ≈øay of his immediate Succe≈ø≈øor Saint Euari≈øtus, except wee will reiect the authoritie
of one, of our mo≈øte auntient and approued hi≈øtorians, Nennius, who in his manu≈øcript auntient hi≈øtory, written if wee may beleeue the Prote≈øtant Bi≈øhop Bale. (l. de ≈øcriptor. cent. 1. in Nennio.) A thow≈øand yeares ≈øince, confidently affirmeth that, Britannicus Rex, A kinge of Britanie receaued an amba≈ø≈øadge from Euari≈øtus Pope of Rome, to receaue the faith of Christ, mi≈ø≈øa legatione √† Papae Romano Euari≈øto; (Mennius hist. M. S.) who yett ≈øayth with others, that the generall coÃÑ uer≈øion of this land, was not vntill the yeare of Chri≈øt 167. others making it later.

This holy Pope began his papacie in the yeare 111. and liued therein vntil 120. before which time our kinge Coillus, brought vp at Rome, was ≈øoe well di≈øpo≈øed to Chri≈øtian Religion, that as our Prote≈øtants and the antiquities of Gla≈øtenbury tell vs, hee confirmed the twelue hides of land to the religious Eremitage of Gla≈øtenbury. (Antiquitat. glast. apud Capgrau. in S. Io≈øeph and others.) And therefore cominge from Rome into Britanie to bee kinge (his Father kinge Marius beeinge deade) wee cannot thinke but as many of our contrimen his ≈øubiects then at Rome, were Chri≈øtians, and in ≈øoe
greate number, that in one Britti≈øh hou≈øe there, the hou≈øe of S. Claudia our Briti≈øh Lady, and children after her, there were at, or ≈øoone after this time, in the time of Pope Pius the fir≈øt, 96. chri≈øtians: (Act. 5 Pudentianae Breuiar. Rom. in vit. eius 19. Maij.) So many of them, and of other nations al≈øo, and cleargie men, were ≈øent hither by the Pope of Rome at that time, which many of our Prote≈øtant hi≈øtorians will confirme, a≈ø≈øuringe, that both now and at all times vntill the conuer≈øion of kinge Lucius, there were many chri≈øtians which came from Rome, liuinge in this kingdome. (Godwyn Conuer≈ø. of Britanie pag. Caius l. 1. antiq. Cantabrig. Will. Harri≈øon. de≈øcript. of Brit. Holinsh. hi≈øt. of Engl.) Soe doe diuers auntient antiquities of the Annals of Burton, and others of forreine nations.

And touchinge the time of Pope Alexander the fir≈øt, next ≈øucce≈ø≈øor to S. Euari≈øtus, hee beinge made Pope in the yeare 120. and continuinge Bi≈øhop of Rome by common opinion 8. yeares, and fiue moneths, in the fourth yeare of the papacie of this ble≈ø≈øed Saint, as both Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter. (Annal. Burton. an. 141. Catal. Epi≈øcop. Tungr.)
and the autient Table hanging in the church of S. Peter in Cornehil, in London, then builded in the time of kinge Lucius, wittne≈ø≈øe, beeinge the 124. yeare of Chri≈øt. The yeare of our Lord God 124. Lucius was crowned kinge: ≈øoe the one, & the other ≈øaith: anno gratiae 124. Coillo Britonum Rege defuncto, Lucius filius eius regni diademate in≈øignitus e≈øt. In the yeare of grace 124. Coillus kinge of the Britans beeing deade, Lucius his ≈øonne was crowned king. Math¬∑ Westin. an. 124.

This kinge Lucius, although neither hee nor the kingdome were yett ≈øoe generally conuerted, yet well knowinge that many preachers had beene ≈øent hither from Rome, and diuers Brittans here were de≈øirous to embrace the faith of Chri≈øt, did not onely giue way vnto it, in this beginning of his Reigne, but except Albertus Krantzius a man well acquainted with our Britti≈øh antiquities (as a Prote≈øtant antiquary witne≈ø≈øeth) doth deceaue vs. (Io. Caius antiq. Cantabrig. l. 1. Albert. Krantzius Metropol. l. 1. cap. 6.) Did write vnto S. Alexander the fir≈øt, Pope of Rome to haue chri≈øtian Religion preached in this kingedome. Religionem Chri≈øti Lucius quondam Britanniae Rex, ab Alexandro primo
eius nominis ≈øummo pontifice, impetrauit in In≈øula predicari. Lucius Kinge of Britanie did obteyne of Pope Alexander the fir≈øt, to here Chri≈øtian Religion preached in that Iland. Which is confirmed by many Authorities, prouening vnto vs, that this Iland at, and immediately after that time, had diuers preachers of the faith of Chri≈øt, and among them ≈øome Bi≈øhops, be≈øides tho≈øe I named before, to proue that wee had a continuall ≈øucce≈ø≈øion of holy Bi≈øhops from Rome, as the≈øe al≈øoe were, from our fir≈øt chri≈øtianity.

And that wee had many preachers, and many by them conuerted, may appeare by that is acknowledged before from the≈øe Prote≈øtants: to which many of them add, & from antiquities, that many Schollers & Doctors of our Vniuer≈øities then were conuerted in the yeare 141. nyne in one place of Cambridge. In peruetustis Annalibus Burtonen≈øibus ≈øic lego. Anno Domini 141. hic baptizati ≈øunt nouem ex Doctoribus & Scholaribus Cantabrigiae. I doe reade (≈øayth one) in very old Annals of BurtoÃÑ thus. In the yeare of our Lord 141. here were baptized nyne of the Doctors & Schollers of Cambridge. (Caius lib. 1. de antiq. Cantab. pag. 95. Theater
of greate Brit. lib. 6. Harri≈ø. de≈øcript. of Brit.) Like to this haue many other Prote≈øtants: who a≈ø≈øure vs, this ≈øucce≈ø≈øion could not come from S. Io≈øeph of Aramathia and his company, for a Prote≈øtaÃÑt Bi≈øhop, according to the truth of hi≈øtories writeth: (Godwyn. conuer≈ø. of Brit. pag. 16. c. 3.) It ≈øeemeth that Io≈øeph and his fellowes preuayled little by their preaching, and therefore gaue them≈øelues at last vnto a monasticall and ≈øolitary life in the Iland of Aualon.) And euen their memorie was ≈øoe much forgotten when kinge Lucius was conuerted, that as our be≈øt antiquities wee haue of that matter, tel vs, tho≈øe which S. Eleutherius ≈øent from Rome, found the be≈øt information of them at Rome, & their auncient how≈øe or church was foe de≈øolat, that it was become, LatibuluÃÑ Ferarum, a den for wyld bea≈øts at their cominge hither. (Antiquit. Glaston. apud Capgrau. in S. Io≈øeph Aramath. in S Patr.)

I finde in hi≈øtories no others, from whom wee haue the lea≈øte probabilitie to clayme a continuaunce in Religion, therefore it mu≈øt needs bee from Rome, from whence al≈øoe wee had amonge the≈øe holy men, ≈øome Bi≈øhops to continue a ≈øucce≈ø≈øion from thence.
For although S. Beatus was but lately deade liuing vnto this yeare 110. it is not vnlikely but his companion was ≈øtill liuinge, and except there were twoe of that name, and in tho≈øe times and the ≈øame contrie, which no hi≈øtory doth remember, S. Man≈øuetus was yet a liue, and longe after vntil wee had manie other Bi≈øhops ≈øent from Rome, or con≈øecrated here by the Romane authoritie, in the time of this Kinge Lucius. For wee reade in the Annals and Catalogue of the Archbi≈øhops of Treuers, neare vnto Tullum, that in the yeare 160. S. Man≈øuetus was Bi≈øhop there: Man≈øuetus qui huic nomini & vocationi ≈øuae vita proba, anno Domini 160. optime re≈øpondit. The ≈øeuenth Archbi≈øhop of Treuers was Man≈øuetus, whoe by his godly life did excellently answeare this his name to bee meeke, and his vocation in the yeare of Christ 160. (Annales Arch. Treuer. Petrus Mer≈ø≈øaeus Catal. Arch. Treuer.) Which by noe hi≈øtorye I can finde, was or could bee any other, but Saint Man≈øuetus our contryman ≈øpoken of before, both the name, time, and place ≈øoe neare vnto Tullum, where hee was fir≈øt Bi≈øhopp alloweinge it, and nothinge impugninge it.

And amonge tho≈øe Bi≈øhops here in Britanie, and of our owne nation, I finde two named beinge both con≈øecrated and ≈øent hither by the Authoritie of the See of Rome: one of them S. Tymotheus ≈øonne to our holy contryman, Saint Marcellus, or by ≈øome Marcellinus a Britanne borne, and a Bi≈øhop here, and after Bi≈øhop of the Tungers, and la≈øtely, Archbi≈øhop of Treuers, both which preached here in the time of Kinge Lucius longe before his conuer≈øion, and at or before this time, and were in≈øtruments of his happy conuer≈øion, actually and par≈øonallye concurringe therto by mi≈ø≈øion and Authoritie from the Popes of Rome: of which I haue made more lardge and ample relation in other places: for this purpo≈øe ≈øoe many Authors here cited will ≈øuffice, both Catholicks and Prote≈øtants con≈øentinge that S. Tymothie and S. Marcellus or Marcellinus, preached here in the time of kinge Lucius and before his conuer≈øion. (Petrus de Natalib. lib. 1. cap. 24. Harris Tom. 2. Magdeb. centur 2. Annal. Eccle≈ø. Cur. Io Stumph. in Rhetia. Petrus Mer≈ø≈øaeus in catalog. Archiep¬∑ Treuer. in Archiep. 20. Anton. Democh. l. 2. de Mi≈ø≈ø. cont. Caluin. Gulielus. Ei≈øengren. centen. 2. part. 4.
distinct. 7. Petr. Mer≈ø≈ø. in Archiep. Treuer.)

And that this S. Tymothie could not bee Saint Tymothie Bi≈øhop of Ephe≈øus S. Pauls Scholler, to whome hee wrote the Epi≈øtles, whoe was martyred many yeares before Kinge Lucius was borne, and S. One≈øimus was his Succe≈ø≈øor in S. Ignatius time as hee him≈øelfe is witne≈ø≈øe: (Epi≈øt. ad Ephe≈ø.) But onely S. Tymothie our ble≈ø≈øed contryman by his mother S. Claudia, (Martyrol. Rom. die 20. Iunij) and a child baptized by the Apo≈øtles, and thereupon called their di≈øciple, whoe was owner of the hou≈øe in Rome, where S. Peter by the Roman tradition fir≈øt entertayned there, and of S. Tymothie the Lord thereof in his time named Thermae Timothinae, the Bathes of Tymotheus, (Act. 5. Iu≈øtini Philo≈øoph. Baron. annot. in 20. Iunij in S. Nouato.) which hee for≈øooke for the loue of God, and this his nation, ≈øoe ≈øoone, that by Pope Pius the fir≈øt, martyred in the yeare 154. his ≈øaid hou≈øe was coÃÑ≈øecrated a church, hee him≈øelfe beeing then in all probabilitie preaching in this Iland, as ≈øo many Authorities cited doe warrant.

The hi≈øtorie of S. Marcellus or Marcellinus, both to haue beene a Britane, a Bi≈øhop,
and to haue preached here longe before S. Linus was conuerted, that hee per≈øuaded him to bee a Chri≈øtian, and after went into Germany, and returned from thence into Britanie againe, ≈øent with others from Pope Eleutherius to conuert kinge Lucius & this kingdome as they did, is an vndoubted veritie, acknowledged by all that write of that matter. And therefore our Prote≈øtaÃÑts of England freely graunt vs in the≈øe wordes. Euen from the dayes of tho≈øe godlie men, whoe fir≈øt taught the Britans the gho≈øpell, there remayned amonge the ≈øame Britans, ≈øome Chri≈øtians which cea≈øed not to teach and preach the word of God, mo≈øt ≈øincerely vnto them: But yett noe kinge among≈øt theÃÑ openly profe≈ø≈øed that Religion, till at length this Lucius perceauinge not onely ≈øome of the Roman Lieutenants in Britanie, as Trebellius and Pertinax with others, to haue ≈øubmitted them≈øelues to that profe≈ø≈øion, but al≈øoe the Emperor him≈øelfe to begin to bee fauorable to them that profe≈ø≈øed it. And then hee ≈øetteth downe how kinge Lucius ≈øent to Pope Eleutherius to bee in≈øtructed in, and receaue the faith of Chri≈øt: and in like maner is the RelatioÃÑ of other Prote≈øtaÃÑts.
(Holinsh. histor. of England lib. 4. cap. 19. Math. Park, Antiquit Britan. pag. 4.5. Ioh. Go≈øcelius in hi≈øtor. Manu≈øcript. Bal. l. 2. de actibus Pontif. in Gregor. 1. & l. de Scriptor. cent. 1. in Augu≈øt Dirnoth. Godwyn Conuer≈ø. Powel annot. in l. 2. Girald. Cambr. c. 1. Foxe to 2. Act. pag. 463. Fulke An≈ø. to count Cath. pag. 40. Middlet. papi≈øt am pag. 202. Stowe. Holinsh. &c.

Then if by the≈øe men there ≈øtil continued a ≈øucce≈ø≈øion of true preachers in Britanie from the Apo≈øtles time. (Protestant Articl. of Religion. Bil≈ø. Whitgift, Barlow, Bridges, Downam, Hookeer, Couel & others against puritans.) Which the puclick Prote≈øtant Religion denieth to bee without true Bi≈øhops to con≈øecrate ≈øuch prei≈øts and preachers: and the Romane Luietenants them≈øelues and chri≈øtians, and ≈øoe con≈øequently as the greatnes of their ≈øtate and nece≈ø≈øitie of the church here required had Bi≈øhops, and rather from Rome, beeing them≈øelues Romans; And I haue exemplified in ≈øoe many Bi≈øhops con≈øecrated and ≈øent hither by S. Peter and his holy ≈øucce≈ø≈øors Popes of Rome, and not any one In≈øtance can bee giuen of any one Bi≈øhop or prei≈øt in all this time, ≈øent or con≈øecrated by any others, wee mu≈øt needes leaue
that prerogatiue to Rome, and honor to Britanie, to haue had the holy Bi≈øhops and pa≈øtors of this church from thence: And that Apo≈øtolicke See to haue ruled here in ≈øpirituall things, as the≈øe Prote≈øtants haue freely acknowledged in the holy Popes S. Anacletus, Euari≈øtus and S. Alexander allready. (Rob. Barns in vit. Pontific. in nominibus citat. Downam lib. 1. of Antichri≈øt. cap. 3. pag. 35.

And ≈øoe they teach, that al the following Popes vnto S. Eleutherius, to witt S. Sixtus the fir≈øt, Tele≈øphorus, Higinius, Pius and Anicetus the immediate predece≈ø≈øor to Eleutherius, tooke vppon them generally the ≈øupreamacy and highe≈øt commanding power in all ≈øpirituall things, and all places without exception or limitation. S. Sixtus gaue authoritie to appeale to the Popes of Rome from all Bi≈øhops. Ab Epi≈øcopo ad Romanum Pontificem appellandi Ius dedit eccle≈øiasticis ministris. (Barnes ≈øupra in Sixto.) Saint. Tele≈øphorus pre≈øcribed generally the fa≈øt of Lent. (in Tele≈øphoro.) Publi≈øhed the maner or order of Ma≈ø≈øe, and made a decree as ≈øupreame Iudge, howe all ≈øuites and controuer≈øies ≈øhould be tryed, and decided. Saint Higinius made a lawe byndinge
all Bi≈øhops & Metrapolitans, and the whole cleargie, (in Higinio) S. Pius dedicated the howle of our renowned contry womaÃÑ S. Pudentiana in Rome, to bee a church, (in Pio) made general decrees for the holy ≈øacrifice of the Ma≈ø≈øe, binding all Prie≈øts & Bi≈øhops. Declared it to bee ≈øacriledge in all people whom≈øoeuer, which coÃÑuerted laÃÑds or goods dedicated to Religion, to prophane v≈øes Appointed the age of virgins to bee con≈øecrated. Hee decreed that matters apperteyning to Religion ≈øhould, bee heard in prouinciall councells of Bi≈øhops, re≈øeruinge the authoritie of the Pope of Rome and appeales to him. Quae ad Religionem ≈øpectant √† ≈øuae Synodis audienda e≈ø≈øe statuit, ≈øalua tamen pontificiae authoritate. (Idem in vit. Pont. in Aniceto.) S. Anicetus the next before S. Eleutherius, made or renewed the decree, how both Bi≈øhops and Metropolitans were to bee ordeyned. That an Archbi≈øhop was to bee accu≈øed before the Pope of Rome. That noe Archbi≈øhops ≈øhould bee called primates, except that prerogatiue of name were graunted him from the Pope of Rome. Archiepi≈øcopos non primates appellandos, ni≈øi i≈øta praerogatiua nomenclaturae ei √† Ro
‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ ano Pontifice co ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ e deretur.

Wherfore the≈øe Popes beeing by all Prote≈øtants holy Saints, and Martyrs, and the church of Rome then by his maie≈øtie and al other learned men of the Prote≈øtant profe≈ø≈øion, our mother church, the true churche, commandinge church, most high Apo≈øtolicque church, and the≈øe their decrees vniuer≈øal and generall comprehending all, and excluding none, either in Britanie, or any other nation, except wee will bee willfully head≈øtronge in di≈øobedience, wee mu≈øt needs acknowledge, that this kingdome from S. Peters fir≈øt preachinge here, vnto the generall conuer≈øion thereof in the time of Pope Eleutherius (of which ≈øufficiently in the next chapter) euer was, and did acknowledge it ≈øelfe ≈øubiect in ≈øpirituall thinges to the holy Apo≈øtolicke See of Rome. And this in particular al≈øoe proued by ≈øoe many auncient, and approued Authors, hi≈øtorians and others that entreate of this ≈øubiect, ≈øhewinge how often the Popes of Rome in the≈øe remembred dayes ≈øent preachers hither, and the Britans likewi≈øe acknowledginge euer, that See for the cheife≈øt and ≈øupreame, ≈øent thither though ≈øoe far di≈øtant hence, to haue preachers and In≈øtructors to bee
≈øent hither by the highe≈øt papall power there.

I will in≈øi≈øt in Prote≈øtants relation for this bu≈øines: They tell vs that S. Bede, the old chronicle of LaÃÑdaffe, Goceline in the life of S. Augu≈øtine cap. 31. historiae maioris, the old chronicle called Brutus, Ioannes Nauclerus, an old manu≈øcript hi≈øtory which the Prote≈øtaÃÑt Bi≈øhop Godwyn ≈øaith hee had in latine, ≈øay that many preachers were ≈øent hither froÃÑ the Pope of Rome in the yeare of Chri≈øt 156. when S. Pius was Pope: and I haue read a very old manu≈øcript, te≈øtifyinge that king Lucius did in that yeare, ≈øend legats to the Pope of Rome to that purpo≈øe. An epi≈øtle written from the Pope of Rome to the kinge of Britanie, dated in the yeare 159. found amonge the old con≈øtitutions of this lande, and in the old chronicle called Brutus, which the Prote≈øtant Bi≈øhop Bridges, ≈øaith hee had ≈øeene, ≈øaith there was the like ≈øendinge, in, or about that time. Mennius, as the≈øe men tell vs, affirmeth as much of the yeare 164. ≈øoe doth an other auncient chronicle, which Godwin citeth. William of Malmesbury hath the ≈øame, of the next yeare 165. S. Edwards lawes ≈øay
≈øoe, of the yeare 167. Henry of Hardford hath the life of the yeare 169. Marianus Scotus publi≈øhed by our Prote≈øtaÃÑts, ≈øo writeth of the yeare 177. The Prote≈øtant Bi≈øhopp Bale hath ≈øo of the yeare 179. Polydor Vergil the hi≈øtory of Roche≈øter, Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter, and Martinus Polonus by Prote≈øtaÃÑts, ≈øoe ≈øay of the yeare 188. Therefore to ≈øaue the creditt of the≈øe, and many others ≈øoe auncient, and allowed by Prote≈øtants, wee mu≈øt needes by their leaue and allowance ≈øay al≈øoe, that this our kingedome in tho≈øe daies depended vppon the See of Rome in Religious affaires. And thus much of this matter before our generall conuer≈øion in the time of Kinge Lucius. (Io. Caius antiq. Cantabrig. lib. 1. pag. 109.110.111. Godwin. conuer≈ø. of Britannie. p. 21.22. Holinsh. hi≈øt. of King. Lucius Theater of Brit. lib. 6. M. S. pr. glorio≈øi, ac Deo dilecti. in S. Dubritio. Matth. Westm. an. 154. Godwyn. Conuer≈ø. pa. 29.30. Stow hi≈øt. in Lucius. Caius ≈øupr. pag. 100. Godw. Conuer≈ø. pag. 29.20.22. Ma≈øon booke of con≈øecrat. in Lucius. Will. Lambard. lib. de leg. Reg. fol. 130. pag. 2. Godwyn. Conuer≈ø. pag. 22.

div.head: THE V. CHAPTER. How in the generall Conuer≈øion of this kingedome in the time of Kinge Lucius, all ≈øpirituall thinges were ordered, ≈øettled, and confirmed here, by the Popes Authoritie.
div.p: AT the time when our Kinge Lucius, & this kingedome was generally conuerted, there were, as the≈øe Prote≈øtants haue proued, or graunted before, diuers Bi≈øhops and Prei≈øts in England, wee had many vniuer≈øities, as Cambrige, Stamford, Greekelade, Belli≈øium, Oxford, and others, as our Prote≈øtants contend, and diuers learned men in them, our next and neighbouringe contries, Fraunce, the hither parts of Germany, Lorraine, Heluetia, and all Italie, euen vnto Rome it ≈øelfe, ≈øcituated in the further part thereof were full of Bi≈øhops, prei≈øts, and learned cleargie. (Ioh. Lidgate in Cant. Caius antiq. cont. Brian. Twin. antiquit. Oxon. Harri≈øon de≈øcript. of Brit. Cambd. in Britan. Harding. histor. l. 1. c. 15. Ioh. Bal. in praefat. ad l. de ≈øcriptor. &c.)

And yett Kinge Lucius and his nobles,
now re≈øolued to receaue the faith of Chri≈øt, could finde noe center, to re≈øt their holy de≈øires of ≈øoe happy a chaunge, vntill they arriued at the Apo≈øtolicke See, from whence this nation from the fir≈øt originall, of chri≈øtianitie here, euer receaued in≈øtructors, and in≈øtruction. And to obteyne this his ≈øoe heauenly purpo≈øe, this Renowned kinge with applau≈øe of his nobilitie, did not ≈øend one onely Me≈ø≈øadge, Amba≈ø≈øadge or epi≈øtle, and at one time to that end, but as our be≈øt antiquities ≈øay: Epistolas ≈øuas Eleutherio Papae direxit: (Epi≈øt. Eleuther. ad Luc. & leg. S. Eduardi apud Lumb. Calfrid. Monum. l. 5. cap. 19. Pont. Virun. l. 4. Matth. We≈øtm. an. 185.186.) hee directed his epi≈øtles to Pope Eleutherius: diuers Epi≈øtles, and con≈øequently diuers Amba≈ø≈øadges, ≈øoe reade the old Britti≈øh hi≈øtorie, Ponticus Virunnius, Matthew We≈øtmin≈øter, as they ar publi≈øhed and allowed by our Prote≈øtants, and others.

And the≈øe ≈øoe diuers epi≈øtles, were onely to become a Chri≈øtian, & to haue his kingdome in≈øtructed in the faith of Chri≈øt, and all things thereto belonginge ordered by his highe≈øt papall authoritie, petens ab eo, vt christianus efficeretur. And none of the≈øe
epi≈øtles was that which our Prote≈øtants tell vs hee wrote vnto that holy Pope, for lawes to gouerne his kingdome by, which were di≈øtinct from this, of which I ≈øhall ≈øpeake hereafter: Wherby it is euident that this ble≈ø≈øed kinge & his wi≈øe≈øt councell at that time, by ≈øoe often writinge both to this holy Pope Eleutherius, and ≈øome others of his predece≈ø≈øors before, as appeareth by that I haue written alreadie, did fully and con≈øtantly informe them≈øelues, that the highe≈øt directing power in things religious, was onely re≈øiding in the Popes of Rome, otherwi≈øe they were all ≈øtraungers vnto him, far di≈øtant, and aboue all Bi≈øhops of the world more per≈øecuted, all of them before this time and longe after, ≈øufferinge cruell deathes and Martyrdome for Chri≈øt. Therefore it was for the due honor, and right belonginge to that holie See, and not temporall glory or countenance, as a Prote≈øtant Bi≈øhop would glo≈ø≈øe the matter. (Godwyn Conuer≈ø. of Britanie c. 3. pag. 36.) but the ≈øupreamacy of the Roman Bi≈øhops, which the≈øe Prote≈øtants haue giuen to all the Popes before.

And becau≈øe, to ≈øpeake in the words of the fir≈øt Prote≈øtant Archbi≈øhop in England: The
renowne of the popes of Rome at that time, was most famous in all the world, for their often martyrdome, and con≈øtancy & ≈øincere di≈øcipline of faith: quorum tunc fama crebro martyrio & constantia, ac ≈øincera fidei di≈øciplina, per totum Christianum orbem celeberrima fuit. (Matth. Parker, antiquit. Brit. pag 5.) This was that, which moued kinge Lucius, to giue this due honor to the See of Rome, and appeale vnto it for in≈øtruction: for he ≈øaw that by that holy See the faith of Chri≈øt, was dilated into all the≈øe nations, as the recited Prote≈øtant Archbi≈øhop thus witne≈ø≈øeth. (Parker. ≈øupr. pag. 4.) Cognouit complures nobiles Romanos candem fidem √† pontifice Romano accepi≈ø≈øe, eorumque exemplo Chri≈øtianum nomen in ≈øingulas prouincias ≈øpar≈øum & di≈ø≈øeminatum fui≈ø≈øe, ≈øtatuit in eadem fide ≈øub Eleutherio tunc Romano pontifice inaugurari. When Kinge Lucius knew, that very many noble Romans, had receaued the faith of Chri≈øt from the Pope of Rome, and by their example, the Chri≈øtian name was di≈øper≈øed and ≈øowen abrode into all prouinces, hee did re≈øolue to receaue the ≈øame faith, from Eleutherius the Pope of Rome Where it is euidently confe≈ø≈øed, that if kinge Lucius had not acknowledged this
highe≈øt ≈øpirituall dignitie in the See of Rome, and haue ≈øued to haue the Chri≈øtian Religion ≈øettled here by that authoritie, hee ≈øhould haue beene ≈øingular in that kinde, as our Prote≈øtants now are, all other prouinces giuing then that honor to Rome, and hauinge their faith in Chri≈øt e≈øtabli≈øhed from thence.

And this is euideÃÑtly declared, by the maner of the ≈øending, & writting of this kinge, to that Pope S. Eleutherius, S. Bede ≈øaith: hi≈øt. eccl. l. 1. c. 4. that K. Lucius did humbly be≈øeech Pope Eleutherius by his letters, that by his coÃÑ maundement hee might bee made a Christian. Ob≈øecrans vt per eius mandatum Christianus efficeretur. The Roman Tradition ≈øaith: In the beginninge of the papacy of Eleutherius, there came humble letters vnto him froÃÑ Lucius Kinge of the Britans, to receaue him and his ≈øubiects into the number of Christians. Huic initio pontificatus ≈øupplices literae venerunt √† Lucio Britannorum Rege, vt ≈øe ac ≈øuos in Christianorum numerum reciperet. (Breu. Rom. in S. Eleuther. 26. Maij. Baron. hist. Eccl. tom. 2.) A Prote≈øtant Bi≈øhop readeth: praying that by his direction, and appointment, hee might bee made a Chri≈øtian. (Godwyn. conuer≈ø. p. 20.) An
other Prote≈øtant antiquary ≈øaith: De≈øiring Eleutherius Bishop of Rome, to ≈øend ≈øome deuout and learned men, by who≈øe instruction hee and his people might bee taught the faith, and Religion of Christ. The old chronicle of LaÃÑdaffe is: implorans vt iuxta eius ammonitionem chri≈øtianus fiat. Humbly entreatinge, that by his appointment hee might bee made a chri≈øtian. (Annal. Landaf. apud com. antiq. Cantab. l. 1. pag. 98. thus our Prote≈øtants alleadge that Antiquitie. Others of them ≈øay. Lucius ≈øent an Amba≈øsadge to Eleutherius, Bishop of Rome by Eluanus, and Meduinus Britans, intreating Eleutherius by them, that hee would open a pa≈ø≈øadge by him≈øelfe and his ministers, for the fo≈øteringe and cheri≈øhinge of christian Religion in Britanie. Frauncis Ma≈øon. l. 2. p. 52. ca. 3.

Like is the te≈øtimony of other hi≈øtorians, both Catholicks and Prote≈øtants, that kinge Lucius proceeded in this humble, and ≈øubmi≈ø≈øiue maner in his writings, and Amba≈ø≈øadges to the Pope of Rome at that time, & in the≈øe affayres. The which highe≈øt authoritie ≈øpirituall in the Pope of Rome, the≈øe our Prote≈øtants further confirme, in that they teach generally, that the≈øe two Amba≈ø≈øadors
of Kinge Lucius, Eluanus and Meduinus, receaued all the authoritie they had, to preach here in Britanie, from Pope Eleutherius, whoe con≈øecrated the one Eluanus a Bi≈øhop, and made the other a Doctor to preach the gho≈øpell. (Theater of great. Brit. l. 6. Stow. hist. in Lucius, Godwyn conuer≈ø. of Brit. Ma≈øon l. 2. c. 3. Bal. cent. 1. in Eluan.) And the pre≈øent Prote≈øtant Archbi≈øhop of Canterbury, Doctor George Abbot, director of Ma≈øter Ma≈øon as hee prote≈øteth, and his directed Scribe ar of this opinion, that all the Bi≈øhops of Britanie after this, deriued con≈øecration and ≈øucce≈ø≈øion epi≈øcopal, from this one onelie Bishop Eluanus, con≈øecrated and authorized by Pope Eleutherius. (Frauncis Ma≈øon con≈øecrat. of Bi≈øh. l. 2. c. 3. p. 55.56.) Which, and more, is approued by an other a Prote≈øtant Bishop, by whome Pope Eleutherius euen in this great bu≈øines is termed. Paterfamilias, the Master of this ≈øpirituall how≈øe and familie of Britanie. (Bal. l. de Act. Pont. Rom. l. 1. in Eleuther.) and this kingedome was con≈øequently of his family, and vnder his rule and commaund, and thereupon as a good Master and Gouernour of this familie, did confirme and ≈øolidate the Brittans, and the
whole kingedome in the faith receaued by the Apostles. Eleutherius, vt bonus paterfamilias de the≈øauro ≈øuo noua cum veteribus proferens, effecit, vt confirmatis & con≈øolidatis Britannis, in ≈øu≈øcepta prius ab Apo≈øtolis doctrina, totum illud regnum in eius fidei verba iuraret.

And to make mo≈øte euident demon≈øtration further, euen by the≈øe Prote≈øtants, a≈øwel as by al other Antiquities, that the ≈øupreame power ≈øpirituall in all proceedinges in this kingedome at that time was wholly, and vndeniably in Pope Eleutherius, and tho≈øe his twoe Legats, which hee ≈øent hither, Damianus and Fugatianus, as they are commonly called. The Prote≈øtant Archbi≈øhop and his Ma≈øon tell vs, in the≈øe words. (Ma≈øon l. 2. e. 3. p. 55 56.) From Rome there came two, Fugatius and Damianus, but wee cannot learne that eyther of them was a Bi≈øhop. This is the con≈øtant writinge of the≈øe Prote≈øtants: yett to deale plainely, the≈øe men knew not all thinges, or el≈øe they might ea≈øelye haue knowne, that both the Brittish hi≈øtorie, Ponticus Virunnius, and Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter, as they are published by Prote≈øtants, call them Anti≈øtites, Bishops:
and a Prote≈øtant Bi≈øhop produceth an old Manu≈øcript Author, te≈øtifying that the fir≈øt church of Wince≈øter was hallowed and dedicated to the honor of our Sauiour, October 29. 189. by Fuganus and Damianus Bi≈øhops. (Galfrid. monum. l. 4. hist. c. 20. Pontic. Virun. lib. 4. in fine, Godwyn. Catal. in Winchest. Matth. Westm. an. 186.)

And if they were noe Bi≈øhops, it ≈øoe much more aduaunceth the Popes power, in this kingedome, for the≈øe Prote≈øtants with others ≈øhall te≈øtifie, that by their legatine power from Pope Eleutherius, they exerci≈øed more and greater Iuri≈ødiction ≈øpirituall here, then any Bi≈øhop, or Archbi≈øhop of that time. And if they were Bi≈øhops, as tho≈øe Authors affirme, yett I finde none to write that either of them was an Archbi≈øhop: yett as before, and ≈øhall immediately bee proued, they by their delegate power from Pope Eleutherius, executed here greater Iuri≈ødiction ≈øpirituall and more ample, then any Bi≈øhop, Archbi≈øhop, prince, kinge or who≈øoeuer, the Pope him≈øelfe excepted, could lawfully doe Which the≈øe Prote≈øtants and other vndeniable antiquities doe, thus demon≈øtrate vnto vs.

The fir≈øt Prote≈øtant Archbi≈øhop of Canterburye (Parker. antiquit. Britan. pag. 5.) writeth from diuers wittne≈ø≈øes, that the≈øe two Religious men were, a≈øsigned by Pope Eleutherius as cheife worke men, tanto operi praeficiundo, in gouerninge ≈øoe greate a worke, and establi≈øhinge the di≈øcipline of chri≈øtian Religion. In ≈øancienda christianae religionis di≈øciplina, and „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ cooperarij adhibiti in administranda eccle≈øia periti. Ioined by Pope Eleutherius with the Bi≈øhops in gouerninge the church, beeings killfull therein. Which mu≈øt needes bee, by their legatine power from Pope Eleutherius. Martianus Polonius. (In Eleutherio Papa col. 49.) publi≈øhed by Prote≈øtants, and dedicated by them to Queene Elizabeth, ≈øaith: Papa Eleutherius mi≈øit duos Religio≈øos viros Fuganum & Damianum qui Regem praedictum & populum baptizarent, erant tunc in Britannia viginti octo Pontifices Idolorum, quos Flamines vocabant: Inter quos tres Archiflamines erant, ≈øed praedicti Sancti, de mandato Apo≈øtolico, vbi erant Flamines, instituerunt Epi≈øcopos, vbi Archiflamines, Archiepi≈øcopos. Pope Eleutherius ≈øent two Religious men Fuganus and Damianus, who baptized the ≈øaid Kinge Lucius and his people.
There were then in Britanie 28. high prei≈øts of the Idols, whome they called Flamins, amonge which there were three Archflamins, but the ≈øaid holy men by the commaundement of the Pope, did in≈øtitute Bi≈øhops, where there were Flamins, and Archbi≈øhops where there were Archflamins.

This is confirmed, not onely by all Antiquities of the≈øe things, but the cheife Prote≈øtant writers, amonge which the Prote≈øtant Archbi≈øhop Whitgift, and his frend Foxe write in this maner.
