(Whitg. defence of the Answ. pag. 323. Foxe tom. 1. fol. 146.) Eleutherius the good Bi≈øhop, hearinge the reque≈øt of the kinge, and glad to ≈øee the godly towardnes, of his well di≈øpo≈øed minde, ≈øendeth him certaine teachers and preachers, called Fugatius, or by ≈øome Fuganus, and Damianus, or Dimianus, which conuerted fir≈øt the kinge and people of Britanie, and bapti≈øed them. The temples of Idolatrie and other monuments of gentility they ≈øubuerted, conuertinge the people from their diuers and many gods, to ≈øerue one liuinge God. Thus true Religion with ≈øincere faith increa≈øing, ≈øuper≈øtition decayed with all rites of Idolatrie.
There were then in Britanie 28. Head prei≈øts, which they called Flamins, and three Archprei≈øts amonge them, which were called Achiflamins, hauinge the ouer≈øight of their maners, as Iudges ouer the re≈øt. The≈øe 28. Flamines they turned to 28. Bi≈øhops, and the three Archiflamines to three Archbi≈øhops, hauinge their ≈øeates in the three principall cities of the Realme: That is, in London, in Yorke, and in Glamorgantia, videlicet in vrbe Legionum, by Wales.

Thus far the≈øe Prote≈øtants, and one of them named the Archbi≈øhop telleth vs, that the con≈øtitutinge of Archbi≈øhops, in the places of the gentiles Archflamines, by the≈øe Legats of Pope Eleutherius, was to followe the example, and order of S. Peter him≈øelfe, whoe did ≈øoe, as S. Paul likewi≈øe, and ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ eth this rea≈øon. (Whitgift def of the An ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ w. pag. 320.321. Which might bee done in re≈øpect of the citie and place, and not in re≈øpect of the Idolatrous prei≈øts; for Archiflamines were in greate cyties, which being conuerted vnto Christ, might haue in the place of their Archiflamines, godly and learned Archbishops, to ouer≈øee and direst
the re≈øt of the Bi≈øhops and preachers, that vnitie and order might bee ob≈øerued. Thus Paul did at Ephe≈øus and Creta. And why might not Peter doe it in other places likewi≈øe? Ma≈øter Iohn Selden, a greate Prote≈øtant antiquary, and lawier, writinge of the≈øe two holy Legats, ≈øpeaketh thus. (Io. Selden Analect. c. 6.) Beat ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ doctores cum per totam fer√® Ieru≈øalem paganitatem deleui≈ø≈øent, Templa quae in honore plurimorum deorum fundata fuerant, vni Deo eiu≈øque Sanctis dea ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ cauerunt, diuer≈øisque ordinatorum coetibus repleuerunt. When the ble≈ø≈øed Doctors had blotted out pagani≈øme allmo≈øt throughout the Iland, the temples which were founded in honor of manye gods, they dedicated to one God, and his Saints, and repleni≈øhed them with diuers companies of cleargie men. The very ≈øame bee the words of Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter, as hee is publi≈øhed by E ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ ≈øh Prote≈øtants. Matth. We≈øtm. an. Dom. 18 ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶

And this pre≈øent Prote≈øtant, Antiquarie refutinge the ridiculous and ignorant, or verie willfull ≈øingularitie of Godwyn the Prote≈øtant Bi≈øhop, ≈øingularlie and onely as hee him≈øelfe writeth. (Godw. conuer≈ø. of Britanie p. 26.) excepting Sutcliffe, denying Archflamines
in this Iland, citing for authors Pomponius Laetus, and Fene≈øtella, thus addeth. (Pompn laet. de Sacerdot. Rom. ca. 7. Fenestell. de Sacerd. Rom. c. 5.) Quemadmodum autem Epi≈øcopis apud nos Archiepi≈øcopi, ≈øic Flaminibus Archiflamines praeponebatur. Horum pote≈øtati caeteri Iudices in In≈øula ≈øubijciebantur. Hos autom ex praecepto Apostoli Idolatriae eripuerunt, & vbi erant Flamines Epi≈øcopos, vbi erant Archiflamines Archiepi≈øcopos po≈øuerunt. Sedes autem Archiflaminum in tribus nobilioribus ciuitatibus ≈øuerunt, Londonijs videlicet, Eboraco, & in vrbe legionum. His tribus euacuata ≈øuper≈øtitione, octo & viginti Epi≈øcopi ≈øubduntur, diui≈øi≈øque parochijs, ≈øubiacuit Metropolitano Eboracen≈øi Deira & Albania, quas magnum flumen Humbri √† Loegria ≈øecernit. Eboracen≈øis autem Archicpi≈øcopis in omnes Scotiae prae≈øules, ac Anti≈øtites iure primatis olim fungebatur. Quod & re≈øaucitum erat ≈øub Henrico ≈øecundo & Hugone Legato Pontificio celebrato concilio. As Archbi≈øhops with vs Chri≈øtians, are in power ouer Bi≈øhops, ≈øoe were Archflamines ouer Flamines. In this Iland the other Iudges were ≈øubiect to their power, the≈øe by the the coÃÑmandement of the Apo≈øtle (and Pope) they deliuered from Idolatry, and where
there were Flamines they placed Bishops, and Archbishops where there were Archflamines. And the Seats of the Archflamines, were in the three more noble cyties, in London to witt, in Yorke, and the cytie of the Legions. To the≈øe three, ≈øuper≈øtition beeing taken away, eight and twentie Bishops are ≈øubiected, and the parishes or dioce≈ø≈øes beeinge diuided, Yorkeshire & Scotland (which the great riuer of Humber doth diuide from Loegria England) was made ≈øubiect to the Metropolitane of yorke. And the Archbishop of Yorke, did of old time enioy the Right of Primate ouer all the prelates, and Bishops of Scotland. Which was againe decreed in a cowncell held vnder kinge Henry the ≈øecond, and Hughe the Popes Legate.

The like to this haue all our Antiquaries, Catholicks or Prote≈øtants writinge of this matter. The Author of the old Brittish hi≈øtorie, the booke of Landaffe, the Antiquities of Gla≈øtenbury, S. Bede, Ponticus Virunnius, Radulphus de Diceto, A≈ø≈øerus, Capgraue, Will: of Malmesbury with other auncients, and our pre≈øent Prote≈øtant Antiquaries con≈øentinge, as Cambden, HoÃÑ linshed,
Harri≈øon, Stowe, Howes, the Theater writers and others two many to bee recited, and needles, their workes commonly extant and to bee ≈øeene of all, onely I will alleadge Bicetes, becau≈øe his manu≈øcript is rare, and hee much commended, both for Antiquitie and Authoritie by the Prote≈øtaÃÑt Authors of the greate Theater, Thus hee writeth: Eleuther Papa ad quem Lucius Rex Britanniae mi≈ø≈øa epi≈øtola ≈øe fieri Chri≈øtianum impetrat. Eleuther ergo mi≈øit Faganum & Dinuanum, qui Regem Lucium baptizauerunt. Templa etiam quae in honore plurimorum deorum fundata erant, vni Deo dedicauerunt. Erant tunc in Britannia 28. Flamines, & tres Archiflammines, & vbi erant Flamines, Epi≈øcopos, vbi autem Archi≈øtamines, Archiepi≈øcopos po≈øuerunt. Londonen≈øi ≈øubiacuit Loegria & Cornubia. Eboracen≈øi Diera & Albania, vrbi autem legionum Kambria. Eleuther Pope of whome Lucius kinge of Britanie obteyned by an epi≈øtle hee ≈øent vnto him, to bee made a Chri≈øtian, ≈øent Faganus and Dimianus, which baptized Kinge Lucius. The Temples which were founded in honor of manie gods, they dedicated to one God.
There were then in Britanie 28. Flamines, and three Archiflamines, and where there were Flamines they placed Bi≈øhops, and where there were Archflamines they placed Archbi≈øhops. To the Archbi≈øhop of London, England and Cornwall were ≈øubiect. To the Archbishopp of Yorke, were ≈øubiect Diera, the North of England and Scotland, and Wales to the Archbishop of Caerlegion. (Galfrid. Monum. l. 4. c. 19.20. Chronic. eccl. Lond. apud Cam. l. 1. antiq. cantabrig. Antiq. Gla≈øt. apud Capgra. in S. Patric. Bed. l. 1. hi≈øt. c 4. Pontic. Virun. l. 4. Radulph. de Dicet. hist. in Lucio. Guliel. Malme≈ø. de antiq. caenob. Glast. Camb. in Brig. Holinsh. hi≈øt. of Engl. in Lucius. Harri≈ø. de≈øcript. of Brit. Stow & Howes in Lucius. Theat. of greate Brit. lib. 6. Hector Boeth. l. 5. fol 86.85. with others.

Thus wee ≈øee by all hi≈øtorians, olde and late, Catholicks, and Prote≈øtants, that in this general plantinge of the faith in this nation, all Religious matters were wholly ordered by the≈øe Legats of the Pope, & his ≈øupreame direction, all Iuri≈ødiction ≈øpirituall of Archbi≈øhops and Bi≈øhops, with their peculiar dioce≈ø≈øes and gouernements, a≈ø≈øigned and di≈øtingui≈øhed by this highe≈øt papall authoritie
of the Pope of Rome by his legats here. And to a≈ø≈øure vs, that nothing was then thought by the kinge him≈øelfe, or any chri≈øtians here, to bee firme and validate in this kinde, without the confirmation of the Pope him≈øelfe, when the≈øe Archbi≈øhops, and Bi≈øhops with their Iuri≈ødictions were ≈øettled, many churches dedicated to God, and his holy Saints, vniuer≈øities or colledges for chri≈øtian learninge and education a≈ø≈øigned, all orders of cleargie men in≈øtituted, with all other nece≈ø≈øary things in ≈øuch a cau≈øe remembred in our hi≈øtories, which I haue at lardge related in an other place, the≈øe holy Legates returned to Rome againe, to obtaine the Popes confirmation of all the≈øe their holy ordinances, & con≈øtitutions, which was orderly performed, as both Catholick antiquities, and Prote≈øtant hi≈øtorians doe thus vndoubtedly a≈ø≈øure vs herein.

Fir≈øt Ponticus Virunnius in his Britti≈øh hi≈øtorie, l. 4. as it is warranred by Prote≈øtants, ≈øaith of the≈øe Legates, ≈øent by Pope Eleutherius: Romam redierunt, & cuncta quae fecerant, a Pontifice confirmari impetrarunt: confirmatione facta, cum pluribus alijs redierunt in Britanniam. They returned to Rome, and
obteyned to haue all things they had done, to bee confirmed by the Pope, and the confirmation beeing made, they returned into Britanie with other. The Author of the old Birtti≈øh hi≈øtory, publi≈øhed with the ≈øelfe ≈øame Prote≈øtant approbation. (Galfrid. Monument. l. 4. histor. Britan. cap. 20.) ≈øaith. Denique restauratis omnibus, redierunt Antistites Romam: & que fecerunt √† beati≈øsimo Papa confirmari impetrauerunt, confirmatione vero facta, reuer≈øi ≈øunt in Britanniam compluribus alijs comitati. At la≈øte when the Bi≈øhops (≈øoe Virunnius al≈øo termeth tho≈øe Legats) had re≈øtored all things they returned to Rome, and obteyned to haue tho≈øe things they had done to bee confirmed by the mo≈øt ble≈ø≈øed Pope, and the confirmation beeing made, they returned againe into Britanie, accompanied with many others. Like bee the words of Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter, warranted by the≈øe Prote≈øtants in this maner. (Matth. Westm. an. 186.) Anno gratiae 186. beati Antistites Faganus & Deruuianus Romam reuer≈øi, quae feceraÃÑt impetrauerunt √† Papa beati≈øsimo confirmari. In the yeare of grace 186. The ble≈ø≈øed Bi≈øhops Fuganus and Deruuianus returned to Rome, and obteyned tho≈øe things, which
they had done to bee confirmed by the mo≈øte ble≈ø≈øed Pope. Which beeing fini≈øhed, the ≈øaid doctors with many others, returned into Britanie.

And our Engli≈øh Prote≈øtants in their Annotation vpon this place thus, approue it. (Protest. annot. Merginal. in Matth. West. ≈øupr. ad an. 186. (Fides Christi in Britannia confirmatur. The faith of Chri≈øt is confirmed in Britanie. All things of this nature were here confirmed by the Popes Authoritie. De mandato Apostolico, by the Popes commaundement, as Martinus Polonus turned Protete≈øtant, by the≈øe men in their publishinge of him. De mandato Apo≈øtolico, ex praecepto Apostoli, by the commaundement of the Apo≈øtle or Pope, as readeth the Prote≈øtant Antiquarie Ma≈øter Selden. (Martin. Pol. in Eleutherio col. 49. Selden ≈øupr. in Anaclet. c. 6.) And ≈øoe all Prote≈øtants doe, or ought to confe≈ø≈øe, approuinge tho≈øe Authors I haue cited before, and fetchinge the greate≈øt euidence they haue of the≈øe things and tymes, from them, ≈øoe particularly as before, regi≈øtringe both the nece≈ø≈øitie of the Popes approbation and confirmation to bee ≈øuch, that the Legates them≈øelues were enforced to go froÃÑ hence to
Rome to procure it, and returned not hither for a finall ≈øettlinge of all things, vntill the Pope had confirmed and approued them at Rome.

And ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ his illimitated and ≈øupereminent Power, both claimed and exerci≈øed by this holy Pope, was not confined in and with his proceedinges with this kingedome, ≈øoe happily conuerted to the faith by him, but to ≈øhew him≈øelfe by the≈øe Prote≈øtants, as his his holy predece≈ø≈øors before haue beene proued by the ≈øame allowance, to bee the ≈øupreame and highe≈øt commaunder, and gouernor of the church of Chri≈øt in all places on earthe, hee generally proceeded accordingly, makinge and ordeyninge decrees, for all par≈øons and places, and times, as the≈øe Prote≈øtants thus a≈ø≈øure vs. (Robert Barnes in vit. Pontif. Rom. in Eleutherio.) Hoc tempore Lucius Britanniae Rex, Chri≈øtiano caetui cum ≈øuis ≈øubditis adiungi, √† Po ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ fice petijt per literas. In this time of Pope Eleutherius, Lucius Kinge of Britanie de≈øired of the Pope by his letters, that hee and his ≈øubiects, might bee ioyned to the Chri≈øtian companie: as though S. Eleutherius then Pope, by power of that nam & place had ≈øuch power ouer the whole
company of Chri≈øtians, that none that is a kinge or greate prince, on who≈øe publick conuer≈øion together with his people, ≈øo manie matters requiring the con≈øent and confirmation of the highe≈øt Pa≈øtor, & ≈øupreame Iuri≈ødiction depended, might bee admitted to bee a Chri≈øtian, without the Popes Approbation.

And to confirme this highe≈øt power ≈øpirituall in him, as in his predece≈ø≈øors before, they further tell vs. (Rob. Barns. ≈øupr.) That generally in the ca≈øes of Bi≈øhops, which is the greate≈øt, hee decreed that nothing ≈øhould bee defined in their ca≈øes, but by the Pope him≈øelfe. Accu≈øationem contra Epi≈øcopos intentatam, Epi≈øcopos audire permi≈øit: ≈øed vt nihil, ni≈øi apud Pontificem definiretur, cauet. And againe that any prei≈øt might appeale from his Bi≈øhop to the Pope of Rome, if the ≈øinceritie of the other iudge his Bi≈øhops was ≈øu≈øpected. Vt nemo Clericum accu≈øatores, pertraheret ad alterius dioece≈øis Epi≈øcopum, ≈øed accu≈øaret euÃÑ apud ≈øuum Epi≈øcopum: Sivero Iudex Glerico ≈øu≈øpectus e≈ø≈øet, appellandi facultatem dedit Reo. Where hee euidently by the≈øe Prote≈øtants maketh him≈øelfe & his Succe≈ø≈øors in the See Apo≈øtolick of Rome, ≈øupreame Iudge in ≈øpiritual thinges,
and re≈øerueth appeales to them in ≈øuch affaires from all other Iudges.

div.head: THE VI. CHAPTER. How this mo≈øte renowned Pope Eleutherius, did by the≈øe Prote≈øtants, and antiquities allovved by them, clayme, exerci≈øe, and ≈øettle here, for him, and his Succe≈øsors, as ample prerogatiue, and Iuri≈ødiction, as Catholicke Scholes doe, and Catholicques may giue to Popes.
div.p:
ANd becau≈øe there is greate difference betweene Catholicks and Prote≈øtants, concerninge ≈øome priuiledges which the former commonly yeeld, and the ≈øecond as v≈øually in England denye vnto him, and eyther of them would bee thought to reuerence and embrace the opinion, and practi≈øe of that ble≈ø≈øed Pope Eleutherius, and tho≈øe vn≈øpotted times, e≈øpecially as they are interpreted by them≈øelues, lett vs now take coun≈øaile and adui≈øe of the≈øe Prote≈øtaÃÑts their per≈øecutors in this kinde, whether this mo≈øte ble≈ø≈øed Pope Eleutherius,
whoe ≈øoe conuerted this nation, and was ≈øoe ble≈ø≈øed, and worthie a Saint with the≈øe men, was not by their Iudgements, and te≈øtimonies, as far ingaged in this matter, as Pope Gregorie, the fifteenth of that name, now is; or Kinge Lucius that holy kinge and Saint, the holy Bi≈øhops, and cleargie, and all the Chri≈øtians of this land, at that tyme did not giue to the Popes of Rome then, as much in this kinde, as anie Engli≈øh prei≈øt, or Catholicke now doth, and by the pre≈øent Roman Religion may giue, and allowe to this pre≈øent Pope, or any other.

This is euidently proued, and inuincibly made manife≈øt vnto vs before, not onely by ≈øoe many our be≈øt Antiquities, but generallie by the be≈øt learned Engli≈øh Prote≈øtant hi≈øtorians, iointly and with an vniforme con≈øent, agreeing in this, that at the ≈øettlinge of manie Archbi≈øhops, and Bi≈øhops in this Iland, by the highe≈øt Papall power of Saint Eleutherius, by the ≈øame al≈øoe the whole kingedome of Scotland, with the Northern Ilands, were made ≈øubiect to the Archbi≈øhopp of Yorke, in ≈øpirituall thinges, as I haue proued before
by the be≈øt hi≈øtorians, Catholicks & Prote≈øtants which haue written of this matter. Which al≈øoe agree, that the≈øe kingedomes were at that time, longe before, and vntill the vnion of them by our pre≈øent Soueraigne kinge Iames, not onely di≈øtinct, and diuers kingedomes, vnder diuers kinges, lawes, and gouernments, but ordinarily, as then they were, at open warres, and ho≈øtilitie in ciuill and temporall re≈øpects; Therfore it was neyther Kinge Lucius, whoe to v≈øe the words of Hector Boethius. (Scator. hi≈øtor. l. 5 fol. 83. Godwyn conuer≈ø. of Britanie pag. 22.23) aggreing with our Engli≈øh Prote≈øtants, and others in this, was but a kinge by curte≈øie of the Romane Emperors and their Authoritie. Lucius Britonibus Cae≈øaris beneuolentia & authoritate imperitabat. Therefore hee neyther had, nor po≈ø≈øibly could haue his power, and principalitie extended further, then that of the Romans was, which went noe further then the wall of Adrian, which diuided the kingedomes, makinge Scotland a di≈øtinct kingedome, and neuer ≈øubiect to the Roman Emperors. Which could not allowe to kinge Lucius more, then they were Lords and Ma≈øters of them≈øelues, for accordinge
to that lawe maxime, v≈øed by manie Prote≈øtants, and a grownde in the lawe, and light of nature it ≈øelfe; Nemo pote≈øt plus Iuris in alium transferre, qu√†m ip≈øe habet: Noe man can giue more power to another, then hee him≈øelfe hath. For ≈øoe hee ≈øhould giue that which hee hath noe right or power to giue, beeinge a thinge vnpo≈ø≈øible.

Therefore kinge Lucius, nor the Roman Emperors, hauinge any power, or right at all ≈øpirituall, or temporall, ouer the Scots or Britans, or any people then dwellinge beyond that Wall, in the kingedome now called Scotland, they could not by any po≈ø≈øibilitie giue ≈øuch ≈øpirituall power, to the Archbi≈øhop of Yorke to commaund in that contrie, nor commaund the inhabitants of Scotland, in noe re≈øpect ≈øubiect vnto them, to bee ≈øubiect to the Bi≈øhop of Yorke, their ≈øubiect in temporall re≈øpects. Neither did, would or could the kings of Scotland, then pagans ≈øubiect, and ≈øubmitt their people and contry to the Archbi≈øhop of yorke of an other kingdome, now enemy to them, both in ≈øpirituall and temporall re≈øpects. And it is directly again≈øt all Prote≈øtants profe≈ø≈øions, confe≈ø≈øions, or churches, that any Prote≈øtant Prince
or other who≈øoeuer clayminge or pretending ≈øupreame ≈øpirituall Iuri≈ødiction among them, ≈øhould challendge or pre≈øume to extend it further, then their temporall ditions and Gouernments, as is euident in all places where the new Religion is admitted, as England, the Lowe contries, the cantons of Swit≈øerland and the re≈øt, where the ≈øpirituall Iuri≈ødiction which they claime, is limited and confined within the circuites of their temporall Dominions, without any further progre≈ø≈øe. Parlam. 1. Elizab. 1. Iacob. Scotic. Confe≈øsiones Heluet. Gallic. Saxonia. Belgic.

Therefore this highe≈øt ≈øupreame directing ≈øpirituall power (which e≈øtabli≈øhed at that time, and longe after, the ≈øubordination and ≈øubiection of Scotland and the Ilands to the Archbi≈øhop of Yorke) mu≈øt needs by the≈øe Prote≈øtants, and all Antiquities, bee onely peculiar to the Pope of Rome, whoe and that alone effected the≈øe things: as ≈øoe manie Prote≈øtants and others haue proued before, and others from our be≈øt antiquities affirme, that all eccle≈øia≈øticall thinges were ordered here, according to the commaundment of Pope Eleutherius that ble≈ø≈øed man. Secundum iu≈ø≈øum beati Eleutherij Papae. (Annal. Landaf.
apud Io. Caium l. 1. de antiquit. Cantabrig. p. 90.) Which is an euident demon≈øtration, that this holy Pope had this ≈øupreame ≈øpirituall power ouer all this Iland at that time; for without ≈øuch a power, the≈øe things could not haue beene performed. And demon≈øtrateth al≈øoe, that noe other power on earth, could haue duely performed it, e≈øpecially any temporall Kinge, Prince, Emperour or Lieutenant what≈øoeuer, for ≈øoe, contrarie to the names, offices, and powers of ≈øuch Rulers, they ≈øhould bee Emperors, Kinges, Rulers, Regents and the like where they haue noe Empire, Kingedome, Rule, Regiment, ≈øoueraigntie or any ≈øubiects, a thinge in the light of nature of it ≈øelfe, imployinge contradiction, and impo≈ø≈øible.

And lett noe man ≈øay, that accordinge vnto ≈øome, as namely Giraldus Cambren≈øis, this Iland was diuided into fiue prouinces, Britannia prima, Britannia ≈øecunda, Flauia, Maxima, and Valentia, which now is Scotland, and that there was an Archbi≈øhop there. (Girald. Cambr. l. de Iure Metropol. eccl. Meneu. apud Park. antiq. Britan. pag. 24. & Io. Pri≈ø. def. hist. Brit.)
For I an≈øweare, this diui≈øion was made longe after this, as the twoe la≈øte prouinces Maximia & Valentia proue in their owne names. For the ≈øame Author ≈øaith, that Maximia was ≈øoe named, of Maximus the Emperour, Maximia. Ab Imperatore Maximo vocata, and Valentia now Scotland, was ≈øoe called of Valens the Emperour. Valentia √† Valente Imperacore ≈øic dicta e≈øt. (Girald. Cambr. Parker. & Pri≈ø. ≈øup.) Both which Emperors Maximus and Valens, were longe after this time, and Scotland not vnder the Romans, to bee made a prouince by them, and be≈øides ≈øoe many Prote≈øtant Authors and Antiquities before, that there were but onely three Archbi≈øhops here at this time, nor after diuers hundreds of yeares, the Scotti≈øh hi≈øtories, and all Prote≈øtants agree, that Scotland had neyther Archbi≈øhops nor Bi≈øhops, perhaps longe after this time.

The te≈øtimonies of the≈øe things ar to manie to bee produced, therefore I will onely in≈øtance in the pre≈øent Prote≈øtant Archbi≈øhop of Canterbury and his deputy, in writinge the booke, Intituled of the Con≈øecration of the Bishops of the church of England, who ≈øpeake in this maner: (FraÃÑc. Ma≈øon epi≈øt.
dedicat. and l. 2. c. 3. pag. 54.) The Romans before this time of Kinge Lucius his receauinge the faith, had diuided Britanie into three Prouinces, one of them was called Maxima Cae≈øarien≈øis, the Metropolis whereof was Yorke. An other, Britannia prima, the Metropolis whereof was London: the third Britannia ≈øecunda, the Metropolis whereof was Caerlegion. And prouinge, be≈øides ≈øoe many other Authorities before cited; both by A≈ø≈øeruius Meneuen≈øis ≈øchole-master to Kinge Alfred, Ptolomeus Lucen≈øis in the life of Eleutherius, William Reade, (De vit. Pont. in Eleuther. pag. 3.) and Iohn Leland, (M. S. Leland. in a≈ø≈øert. Arthur. fol. 36.) that the Archbi≈øhops of this Iland, were onlie ≈øeated in tho≈øe three Metropolitane cyties, of London, Yorke, called al≈øo Maximia or that prouince, wherof it was Metropolis, and Caerlegion. To an≈øweare fully this obiection thus they add: Georg. Abb. & Fraunc. Ma≈øon ≈øupr. pag. 54.

Although Britanie was after the Nicen. councell diuided into fiue Prouinces, Valentia and Flauia Cae≈øarien≈øis beeinge added to the former: yett there were noe new Archbi≈øhopricks erected. The rea≈øon whereof was, becau≈øe tho≈øe two new Prouinces.
(Notitia Prouinc. Occid. pag. 117.) were taken out of the former; and con≈øequentlie could not haue Bi≈øhopricks, without the dimini≈øhinge of the authoritie of the former, in who≈øe Iuri≈ødiction originally they were, which was not ≈øufferable, becau≈øe it was again≈øt the canon of the Nicen councell (Can. 6.) decreeinge, that in Antioche and in other Prouinces, the dignities, prerogatiues, and authorities of churches ≈øhould bee maintayned. And for S. Andrewes in Scotland to haue beene alwayes ≈øubiect to Yorke, or when Yorke had noe Archbi≈øhop, as at the cominge of the pagan Saxons hither, and driuinge the Archbi≈øhop from thence, to the Pope him≈øelfe, immediately the≈øe Prote≈øtants proue vnto vs, by the auncient Antiquitie called Notitia Prouinciarum, which they cited before: for in that thus wee reade: S. Andrea Epi≈øcopatus e≈øt Domini papae. The Bi≈øhoprick of S. Andrewes beloÃÑgeth to the pope of Rome, where the Annotation is: olim in Scotia nullas erat Archiepi≈øcopatus, adeoque Epi≈øcopatus Scotiae Domino Papae in ≈øpiritualibus immediat√® ≈øuberant, vt in manu≈øcriptis exemplaribus no≈øtris notatur. In auncient tyme there was
noe Archbi≈øhopps See in Scotland, but the Bi≈øhops of Scotland in ≈øpirituall thinges, were immediatelie ≈øubiect to our Ma≈øter the Pope, as is noted in our manu≈øcript copies. Notat. Epi≈øcopat. in Scotia edit. per Aubert. Miraeum. Aubert. Miraus in annot. in illum locum.

Which fir≈øt immediate ≈øubiection to the Pope, and not the Archbi≈øhop of Yorke, did begin but in the time of Kinge William of Scotland, as Roger Houeden and others proue, ≈øetting downe the Popes decretall letters thereof at lardge, but had continued vnder the Iuri≈ødiction of Yorke, by the fir≈øt in≈øtitution of Pope Eleutherius a thou≈øand yeares, and be≈øides the te≈øtimonies of many Authors both late and auntient, Catholicks and Prote≈øtants, ≈øettinge downe the whole proceedinges at lardge, how Pope ClemeÃÑt did onely exempt it from the See of Yorke, and ≈øubiected it immediately to the See of Rome, becau≈øe of the continuall, all mo≈øte, wars betweene the≈øe twoe nations. This matter is publicklie confe≈ø≈øed and acknowledged by Kinge William of Scotland, and Dauid his Brother, Richard Bi≈øhop of S. Andrewes,
with others in their publick Charter, in publick councell in the church of S. Peter at Yorke, as Houeden and others ≈øett downe at lardge. Epi≈øtol. Clementis Papae ad Guliel Scotorum Regem apud Roger. Houed. part. histor. in Henric. 2. & epist Papae Caelestini apud eundin Richard. 1. & Thom. Wal≈øing. in Eduard. 1. Polydor. Vergil. Angl. histor. l. 13. l. 9. l. 24. Guliel. Malmesb. l. 3. de Regib. Godwyn Catalog. in Yorke in George Neuill. Roger Houede ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ Annal. part. postr. in Henric. 2.

And when Scotland after a thou≈øand yeares ≈øubiectioÃÑ vnto the Archbi≈øhop of Yorke by the Popes ordinance, neither was nor could, notwith≈øtandinge ≈øoe many di≈ø≈øentions betweene the≈øe kings, and nations, bee exempted from that obedience, but by the Pope him≈øelfe, and yet with this re≈øeruation, to bee immediately ≈øubiect to the Pope of Rome, as the words of the Popes decree thus te≈øtifie. (Epistol. Clement. Papae apud Rog. Houed. ≈øupr.) Clemens Epi≈øcopus ≈øeruus ≈øeruoruÃÑ Dei, Chari≈øsimo in Chri≈øto filio Willielmo illu≈øtri Scotorum Regi prae≈øentis ≈øcriptis pagina duximus sta≈øtuendum, vt Scotticana eccle≈øia Apostolicae ≈øedi, nullo mediante debeat ≈øubiacere. Clement to his mo≈øt beloued ≈øonne in Chri≈øt
William the Renowned kinge of Scots. Wee haue thought good to decree by this our pre≈øent writinge, that the church of Scotland, ≈øhall bee immediatly ≈øubiect to the See Apo≈øtolicke. Soe that it is mo≈øt euident by all te≈øtimonies, that this kingedome of Britanie, was from the fir≈øt conuer≈øion thereof to Chri≈øt, euer ≈øubiect to the See of Rome in ≈øpirituall things, as farr as the Pope of Rome now requireth, or Catholicks attribute vnto him.

Which the≈øe our Prote≈øtants of England, and from Authenticall Antiquities, as they ≈øay, will more Amply proue vnto vs, and in the highe≈øt degree of papall priuiledges. For they tell vs, that kinge Lucius did not onely receaue the Chri≈øtian faith, Iuridicall direction, and ≈øettling of all ≈øpirituall and meerlie Religious affaires, by the authoritie of the Pope of Rome, but the ≈øame holy Pope, not onely with the good likinge and con≈øent of Kinge Lucius, but by his ≈øuite and petition interpo≈øed him≈øelfe, in the ordeyninge alteringe, or correctinge and ≈øettlinge, the very temporal lawes theÃÑ≈øelues in this kingedome, to gouerne Rule and direct it, euen in ciuill and meerely humane thinges, as is manife≈øt
in a certaine Epi≈øtle which the≈øe Prote≈øtants, with generall con≈øent a≈ø≈øcribe to S. Eleutherius him≈øelfe, written to kinge Lucius, as re≈øpon≈øory, and ≈øatisfactory to ≈øome letters, which this kinge had written vnto him to ≈øuch purpo≈øe, to haue temporall lawes from him to gouerne this kingdome by: Peti≈øtis √† nobis leges Romanos, & Cae≈øaris vobis tran≈ømitti. You require of vs (writeth this holy Pope to king Lucius) the Romane Lawes, and the Emperors, to bee ≈øent ouer vnto you, vvhich you vvould practi≈øe, and put in vre, vvithin your Realme: the Romane Lawes and the Emperors, vvee may euer reproue, but the Lawe of God vvee may not; you haue receaued of late through gods mercy, in the kingedome of Britanie, the Lawe and faith of Christ. You haue vvith you vvithin the Realme, both parts of the ≈øcriptures, out of them by gods grace vvith the councell of your Realme, take you a Lawe, and by that Lavve by gods ≈øufferance, rule your kingedome of Britanie, for you bee gods vicar in your kingedome. Epist. Eleutherij Papae ad Lucium Reg. Britan. apud Foxe to. 1. Iuel contra Hard. Franc. Ma≈øon l. 2. Godwyn. Conuer≈ø. of Brit. pag. 38. Lambert. in leg. S. V≈øuardi. Stow in Lucio.

Thus the≈øe Prote≈øtants tran≈ølate that part of that Popes Epi≈øtle. Whereby fir≈øt it is manife≈øt, That Kinge Lucius now a Chri≈øtian did not, and in con≈øcience coulde not, write for, or ab≈øolutely de≈øire the Imperiall Lawes, the Emperors then beeing pagans, and their Lawes accordingely mayntaining the Idolatries of the gentiles, but as they ≈øhould bee moderated and corrected by the Lawes of Chri≈øt, which noe man could with more authoritie and better performe, then the holy Pope, hauing then the ≈øupreame place in the church of God. For otherwi≈øe he ≈øhould haue beene an enemy to Chri≈øt, & his lawe which hee now profe≈ø≈øed: and beeing in ≈øoe high grace, and fauour with the Emperor, and Roman Senate, as the≈øe Prote≈øtants and other antiquities tell vs, hee might & ≈øhould with farr more honor, loue and likeinge, haue receaued the≈øe Lawes from the Emperor him≈øelfe, the Senate of Rome, or manie Romans here in Britanie, whoe then liued accordinge to tho≈øe Roman and Imperiall Lawes, then from Pope Eleutherius, whoe liued not as tho≈øe Lawes commaunded, but ≈øoe farr otherwi≈øe, that hee and all the Popes of Rome before, and many after him,
were both per≈øecuted, and putt to death for chri≈øtian Religion by tho≈øe lawes.

Therefore kinge Lucius reque≈øtinge ≈øuch Lawes from Pope Eleutherius, mu≈øt needs hereby acknowledge, that as by ≈øendinge ≈øoe farr vnto him, to be in≈øtructed in the fa ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ th of Chri≈øt, and all ≈øuch matters ≈øpirituall to bee ≈øettled and ordered here by his highe≈øt power: ≈øoe in his temporall proceedings which to bee iu≈øt, & holy mu≈øt needs haue a ≈øubordination vnto ≈øpirituall, and the iudgement ouer Lawes. Whether they ar holy iu≈øt and ≈øuch as Chri≈øtians in con≈øcience and Religion ought to v≈øe, and bee directed by, is to bee made by them cheifly, whoe haue the greate≈øt knowledged, and commaunde in ≈øuch ca≈øes, and iudgements, which bee the gouernors and Bi≈øhops of the church of God, hee thought noe Lawes to bee vncontrolably warrantable, but ≈øuch as the cheife pa≈øtor of the church of Chri≈øt, the Pope of Rome ≈øhould giue validitie vnto, by his confirmation and allowance. For amonge ≈øoe many Lawes, as ≈øoe ample, and greate a kingedome was to bee ruled and gouerned by, there mu≈øt needs bee many, which of nece≈ø≈øitie were thus to bee examined
by the Lawe of God, and cheife≈øt interpreters thereof. Which Saint Eleutherius warned Kinge Lucius of, when hee pre≈øcribed vnto him, to haue his Lawes warranted by the ≈øcriptures, and taken forth of them by the councell of the Realme, and by that Lawe to Rule the kingedome: where it is euident, that hee appointeth the Lawe of Britanie to be conformable to the Lawe of God, and to bee ≈øecure it ≈øhould bee ≈øuch, it to bee enacted and concluded by the be≈øt councell of his Realme in ≈øuch things, which were the Bi≈øhops, cleargie and learned diuines, cheifely which S. Eleutherius had ≈øettled here, for they were the onely or principall Interpreters of holy ≈øcriptures here at that time: and others in a maner, concerninge ≈øuch things, Catechumenes, to bee in≈øtructed them≈øelues, and not to drawe Lawes out of ≈øcriptures, to in≈øtruct, and direct others. And ≈øo a Prote≈øtant Bi≈øhop with ≈øuch publick warrant expoundeth it in the≈øe wordes: By the adui≈øe of the cleargie of their dominion. Bridges def. l. 16. pag. 1355.

And S. Eleutherius takinge vppon him≈øelfe, as Pope of Rome, the ≈øupreamacy ouer the whole church, as the≈øe Prote≈øtants haue
told vs, cannot by any but carele≈ø≈øe or ignoraÃÑt of truth bee interpreted, to giue any ≈øuch preeminence to a newly become Chri≈øtian temporal prince, but calleth him onely the Vicar, or Vicegerent of God, as all princes Chri≈øtians and others ar, or ≈øhould bee to ≈øee iu≈øtice performed to all within their dominions, which is ≈øufficiently expre≈ø≈øed in this very epi≈øtle it ≈øelfe, where that holy Pope telleth Kinge Lucius, what is the dutie and office of a king, the wordes by Prote≈øtant traÃÑ≈ølation ar: The people and nations of the kingedome of Britanie is yours, ≈øuch as ar diuided, you ≈øhould gather them together to the Lavve of Christ, his holy church to peace and concord: & cheri≈øh, maintayne protect, gouerne and defend them from the iniurious malicious, and their enemies. A kinge hath his name of gouerninge, and not of his kingedome, ≈øoe longe you shall bee a kinge, as you rule well, otherwi≈øe you shall not bee ≈øoe named, and loo≈øe that name vvhich God forbid. God graunt that you may ≈øoe rule your Realme of Britanie, that you may Reigne vvith him euerlastingely, who≈øe Vicar you ar in the ≈øaid kingedome. Epi≈øtol. Eleuther. apud Godwyn. Conuer≈ø. pag. 23. Foxe tom. 1. Stowe and Hovves histor. in Lucius. Bridg. def. p. 1355.
Ieuel. ag. Hard. Lambard. de legib. Theater of Brit. and others.

Where wee ≈øee, in what ≈øence this holie Pope called Kinge Lucius the Vicar, or Vicegerent in his kingdome, to ≈øee iu≈øtice mini≈øtred, the church of Chri≈øt to bee defended from wronge, and the priuiledges thereof to bee kept inuiolable. Which this holy king mo≈øte chri≈øtianly performed, for when all eccle≈øia≈øticall matters were ≈øettled here by the Popes authoritie, and the≈øe Lawes here appointed for this kingedome, fir≈øt here coÃÑ cluded, and then with the re≈øt confirmed by the Pope: cuncta quae fecerant √† Pontifice confirmari impetrauerunt: Then this kinge accordinge to the direction and in≈øtructions of the holy Pope to ≈øpeake in Prote≈øtants owne, words: endowed the churches of Britanie with liberties, Lucius Rex, eccle≈øias Britanniae libertatibus muniuit. Which ar to many to bee related, and ar ≈øett downe in the Britti≈øh hi≈øtorie, Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter and others. (Pontic. Virun. lib. 4. in fine. Galf. Mon. lib. 4. histor. Reg. Britan. cap. 20. Matth. We≈øtm. an. 186. Prote≈øt. Annot. vppon Matth. West. an. 187. Galfrid. Monum. ≈øup. l. 4. Matth. West. an. 187.) And in this ≈øence our be≈øt Britti≈øh and
chri≈øtian Saxon kings, who were mo≈øt obedient euer to the church of Rome, were from that time, and by vertue of that donation, of Pope Eleutherius, giuinge Lucius the Title of the vicar or vicegerent of God in his kingdome, ≈øoe called and enioyed that Title as a Prote≈øtant Lawier, and Antiquarie thus deduceth. (Selden Analect. l. 1. pag 4 ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ ) Ex quo non ≈øolum Britannorum, ≈øed etiam Anglorum ≈øub≈øequentes Reges, hoc nomine vicarij Dei ≈øunt potiti. From which time, or the graunt of Pope Eleutherius, the kings that followed, not onely of the Britans, but Engli≈øh al≈øoe obteyned this name of the vicars of God: and citeth the auntient Lawyer Henry Bracton, for the ≈øame. But wee neede not demurre vppon the authorities of priuate Lawyers, or Antiquaries for this matter. For wee haue Lawes them≈øelues of good kinge Edward, which William the Bastard afterward confirmed (a Prote≈øtant Lawyers or rather the words of the Lawe, to confirme & warraÃÑt this: Where the very words of the Lawe thus auntient and confirmed, are the≈øe. Leges S. Eduardi apud Gul. Lamb. fol. 126. pag. 2. leg. 1. cap. 17. & leg. 77.

Rex autem quia Vicarius ≈øummi Regis est,
ad hoc est con≈øtitutus, vt regnum terrenum & populum Domini, & ≈øuper omnia ≈øanctum veneretur Eccle≈øiam eius, & regat & ab iniurio≈øis defendat, & maleficos ab ea euellat, & destruat & penitus di≈øperdat. Quod ni≈øi fecerit, nec nomen Regis in eo constabit, verum testante Papa Iohanne nomen Regis perdit. The kinge becau≈øe hee is the Vicar of the highe≈øt king, is con≈øtituted for this to rule the terrene kingedome and people of God, and aboue all things hee ought to reuerence his holy church, and defend it from iniurious people, and to pull from it, and de≈øtroy and wholly ouerthrowe euill doers. Which except hee performeth, the name of a Kinge ≈øhall not bee appearinge in him, but as Pope Iohn doth wittnes, he lo≈øeth the name of a kinge, or Ruler. Where wee ≈øee by the publicke Lawes them≈øelues, that the Kinge is not called the Vicar or Vicegerent of God in re≈øpect of ≈øpirituall but temporall affaires, to reuerence and defend it, and ≈øuffer noe wronge to bee done vnto it, or priuiledges taken from it; which is more plainely expre≈ø≈øed in the ≈øame Lawe in this maner: (leg. S. V≈øuardi ≈øupr.) Debet Sanctam Eccle≈øiaÃÑ regni ≈øui cum omni integritate, & libertate iuxta
constitutiones patrum & praedece≈ø≈øorem ≈øeruare, fouere, manutenere, a kinge ought to keepe, fo≈øter, & maintayne the holy church of his kingedome, with all integritie, and libertie, accordinge to the con≈øtitutions of the Fathers, and predece≈ø≈øors. Which a kinge ought to ≈øweare in proper par≈øon vppon the gho≈øpels and relicks of Saints before the laietie, prei≈øts, and clergie, before hee is crowned by the Archbi≈øhops & Bi≈øhops of the kingdom: hither to this holy law of our auntieÃÑt kings.

I haue in≈øi≈øted vpon this Epi≈øtle of Pope Eleutherius the longer, becau≈øe with Prote≈øtants it is in ≈øoe high e≈øteeme, ≈øoe auntient and certaine, that a Prote≈øtant Bi≈øhop writeth: Wee haue ≈øeene the Bi≈øhop of Romes owne letter to kinge Lucius, that is reputed to bee the first christian kinge of Britanie. (Iohn Bridges def. of the gouernm. in the church of Engl. l. 16. pag. 1355.) The Theater writers ≈øay, it is in the cu≈øtody of Syr Robert Cotton Baronet of Conington in Huntington ≈øhire, (Theater of greate, Brit. l. 6. c. 19.) Others ≈øay it is likewi≈øe founde, in the old hi≈øtorie called Brutus. (Caius antiquit. Cantab. l. 1.) Stowe writeth: I finde the ≈øame entered in a booke intituled, Constitutions, pertayninge to the
Guilde hall of London. (Stovve hi≈øtor. in Kinge Lucius.) And it is founde al≈øoe amonge the old Lawes of Saint Edward our kinge and others before him, and placed & receaued as a part of our Lawe, both by our Saxon kinges, and Norman al≈øoe, as namely kinge William the fir≈øt, as the Prote≈øtant publi≈øher of them him≈øelfe, a lawyer and antiquarie is witne≈ø≈øe, vvith all moste all writers, plaeri
que ≈øcriptores omnes, as hee te≈øtifieth: (Williel. Lambard. lib. de Pri≈øcis Anglorum legib. fol. 1. ante praef. fol. 126.131.) Therefore I may boldely terme Pope Eleutherius the fir≈øt Chri≈øtian Lawe maker, and fir≈øt director, and confirmer of Lawes in this kingedome. Which how it can ≈øtand to bee iu≈øtly done, as all the≈øe our kinges, their nobles, clergies, lawyers and the≈øe Prote≈øtants auouche, without as greate a preeminent power as the Popes of the≈øe times doe clayme, or commonly Catholicks a≈øcribe vnto them, I leaue to the quicke≈øt ≈øighted Prote≈øtants to di≈øtingui≈øh.

And yet this ≈øchole of Prote≈øtant antiquaries, doe reade a le≈ø≈øon vnto vs, to clymbe a ≈øtepp higher in ≈øuch affayres. For they a≈ø≈øure, from the ≈øame publick lawes of our
auncient Saxon and other kinges, and from the ≈øame Pope Eleutherius his owne donation, that hee declared to be annexed to the crowne of this kingedome, all the Ilands betweene vs and Norway, and that our kings ≈øhould haue care thereupon, to enioye them. The words of that auncient Lawe by Prote≈øtant publi≈øhing, and allowance publick ar the≈øe: (Leges Ed ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ wardi Regis c. 17. apud Lumbard. ≈øupr. fol. 130 pag. 2.) Debet de iure Rex omnes terras & honores, omnes dignitates & iura & libertates coronae regni huius in integrum cum omni integritate, & ≈øine diminutione ob≈øeruare, & defendere, di≈øper≈øa & dilapidata, & ami≈ø≈øa regni iura in pri≈øtinum ≈øtatum, & debitum viribus omnibus reuocare. Vniuer≈øa vero terra & tota, & In≈øulae omnes v≈øque Norwegiam & v≈øque Dariam pertinent ad coronam regni eius, & ≈øunt de appendicijs, & dignitatibus Regis, & vna est Monarchia, & vnum e≈øt regnum, & vocabatur quondam Regnum Britanniae, modo autem vocatur Regnum Anglorum, tales enim metas & fines, & praedictae ≈øunt, constituit & impo≈øuit coronae Regni Dominus Eleutherius Papa ≈øententia ≈øua, qui primo de≈øtinauit coronam benedictam Britanniae, & christianitatem Deo in≈øpirante Lucio
Regi Britonum. The kinge of right ought with all integritie and without diminution ob≈øerue, and defende all lands, and honors, all dignities, and Rights, and liberties of the crowne of this kingedome, wholly, and call backe againe al the Rights of the kingdome that bee di≈øper≈øed, dilapidated, & lo≈øte, with all his power vnto their auncient and due ≈øtate. And the whole and all the Land, and the Ilands euen to Norway, and Denmarke doe belonge to the crowne of his kingdome, and at of the Appendicies, and dignities of the kinge, and it is one monarchie and one kingedome, and it was anciently called the kingedome of Britanie, & now is called the kingedome of the Engli≈øh men, for our Lord the Pope Eleutherius did by his ≈øentence coÃÑ ≈øtitute, and appointe ≈øuch limites, and boundes to the crowne of the kingedome, fir≈øt ≈øending by the in≈øpiration of God, a hallowed crowne and Chri≈øtianitie to Britanie to Kinge Lucius. Hitherto this ≈øoe auncient & publicke authoritie and antiquitie, now, ≈øeeing all writers, Catholicks and Prote≈øtaÃÑts agree, that both S. Eleutherius, which made this declaration and confirmation of ≈øoe manie Ilands and Rights, and Kinge Lucius
which accepted it, was in the like degree, and all our kings ≈øoe many hundred yeares after, many of them holy Saints, which by this declaration e≈øteemed the≈øe territories to bee their owne, to keepe them all, or any of them, declarer or receauers from horrible and damnable v≈øurpation, as of nece≈ø≈øitie by the≈øe Prote≈øtants wee mu≈øt doe, what way is there to end this difficultie, except wee allowe, of the Popes Authoritie in ≈øuch a declaration.

But to yeeld a greater, and more auncient honor, and priuiledge, to this kingedome, and the kings thereof, then many Prote≈øtants, enemies to our Britti≈øh Antiquities, will allowe vnto it, not onely to comprehend al the≈øe Northren Ilands vnto Norway, vnder the name of, In≈øulae Britannicae, the Britti≈øh or Britons Iland. But that the kingedome of Denmarke was ≈øubiect and tributary to Britanie, diuers hundreds of yeares before Chri≈øt, and ≈øoe con≈øequently the adiacent Ilands, which by Ius gentium, belonged to the Continent, next adioyninge, wee ≈øhall by this exempt this kingdome from receauing any thinge by a free donation from Pope Eleutherius in this kinde, claiminge
by this, that hee only adiudged the old Right and Title of Britanie to bee true and lawfull in this ca≈øe, not giuing any new prerogatiue by that confirmation. Yett this will not exempt either kinge Lucius from embracinge, or Pope Eleutherius from a≈ø≈øigning and confirminge that diui≈øion, and preferringe the Title of kinge Lucius before the Scots and others, which by their hi≈øtories had then enioyed longe time diuers of tho≈øe Ilands, and ≈øoe wee mu≈øt ≈øtill acknowledge that both Eleutherius the Pope, and kinge Lucius, then thought, the deci≈øion of ≈øuch things, did in ≈øome re≈øpect in con≈øcience belonge to that See Apo≈øtolick, otherwi≈øe neither would the one haue made it, or the other ≈øought for, or accepted it, in that maner, both of them beeing worthie and renowned Saints in the church of Chri≈øt. M. S. pr. Regnum Britanniae in Gurguntio. Ioh. Rom. apud Stowe in cod. Stowe and Howes histor. in Gurg. an. ante Chri≈øt. 375. Ioh. Lydgate in Cantab. Ioh. Harding Chron. c. 34. fol. 29.30. Caius antiq. Cantab. l. 1. Matth. Westm. aetat. 5. c. 5. Hect. Boeth. hist. Scot. Giral. CaÃÑb. ap. Stow. ≈øupr. And into the ≈øame laborinth we fal, by the≈øe men denying power in the Pope of Rome, to giue pardoÃÑs,
or Indulgences to mitigate, or relea≈øe the puni≈øhments of ≈øinnes, if wee ≈øhould harken vnto them; for they greately commend vnto vs the Epi≈øtle a≈øcribed to S. Patrick the Iri≈øh Apo≈øtle in the antiquities of Ga≈øtenbury, to bee of greate authoritie, and yett in this wee reade. Quod ≈øanctus Phaganus & Deruuianus ab Eleutherio Papa qui cos mi≈øerat, deceÃÑ annos Indulgentiae impetrarunt. That S. Phaganus and Deruuianus, obteyned of Pope Eleutherius that ≈øent them, ten yeares of Indulgence for the pilgryms vi≈øiting that holie place, a greater power in the Pope then the other, by the≈øe Prote≈øtants. And thus much of this hundred yeares. Theater of great Britanie lib. 6. Godwyn. Conuer≈ø. of Britanie cap. 2. pag. 10. Ioh. Leland. in A≈ø≈øert. Arthur. Antiquitat. Gla≈øton in tabula lignea. Capgrau. in Catal. in S. Patricio. & M.S. Antiq. in eodem.

div.head: THE THIRD CENTVRIE OR HVNDRED YEARE.

THE VII. CHAPTER. How the Popes of Rome in this third Centurie, or hundred of years al≈øoe, by our Prote≈øtants and others, ruled and gouerned here in Britante in ≈øpirituall things, by their ≈øupreame power therein.
div.p:
NOw hauing ended this ≈øecond hundred yeare, when there was ≈øoe generall an acceptance of this highe≈øt papall Authoritie in Britanie by the kinge, his Nobles, three Archbi≈øhops, ≈øoe many other Bi≈øhops, and the noble cleargie and others here, wee may bee more breife in ages followinge: for it is a common con≈øent of the Prote≈øtant writers of England, that the ≈øame faith and Religion in all materiall points (≈øuch as this is) continued firme and inuiolable here at the lea≈øt vntill the cominge of S. Augu≈øtine hither in the later end of the ≈øixt hundred yeare. And it is a veritie granted by all, followinge S. Bede, ≈øu≈øceptam fidem Britanni v≈øque in tempora
Diocletiani Principis inuiolatum integrumque quieta in pace ≈øeruabant. The Britans kept the faith which they receaued in the time, of kinge Lucius, inuiolable and whole in quiet peace vntill the times of Diocletian. (Bed. hi≈øt. eccle≈ø. l. 1. c. 4.) Whoe did not begin his Empire, vntill the yeare 285. & his per≈øecution longe time after about the yeare 296. And no man can thinke, but amoÃÑge ≈øoe many Archbi≈øhops, Bi≈øhops, and cleargie men, which together, with the whole chri≈øtian Religion, embraced the papall power, liued, and gouerned the church of Britanie here many yeares in this age, in the ≈øame maner and order, as it was commended vnto them by the Romane ≈øupreame ≈øpirituall Authoritie, of S. Eleutherius and his Apo≈øtolicke Legates.

Therefore to bee breife, the next Pope which was in the beginning of this hundred yeare, Scotland (as hereafter) a greate portion of this Iland, and then a di≈øtinct greate and inuincible kingedome, vnto the mo≈øt powerable Romane Emperors, was conuerted to the faith of Chri≈øt. The very name of this holy Pope and Martyr carieth ≈øpirituall ≈øupreamacy with it, in all the Chri≈øtian
world, A≈øia, Africk, and Europe, by the mouthes and pennes of all Prote≈øtants and others. A Prote≈øtant Bi≈øhop for all ≈øhall an≈øwere in the≈øe words. Pope Victor excommunicated all churches both greeke and latine, which differed from his church, in the ob≈øeruation of Ea≈øter. (Morton. appeale l. 1. cap. 9.) Which noe man can que≈øtion, but it was the highe≈øt act, to haue and exerci≈øe ≈øuch power ouer all churches, and yett mo≈øte iu≈øtly and lawfully, and hee a ble≈ø≈øed man, which both a Prote≈øtant Archbi≈øhopp and his maie≈øtie kinge Iames ≈øhal te≈øtifie for all. The church of Rome was then a Rule to all, ≈øaith our Kinge. (Kinge Iames in parlam.) The other ≈øaith: Victor was a godly Bi≈øhop, and a martyr, and the church at that time was in greate puritie, not beeinge longe after the Apostles times. (Whitgift Answ. to the admonition p. 80. ≈øect. 4.) Wherfore Kinge Donalde of Scotland now moued by the example of Kinge Lucius, his neighbouring Sociate in terrene principalitie, and his whole kingedome, and beeing a≈ø≈øured by this ≈øupreame power ≈øpirituall exerci≈øed by S. Victor ouer all churches, that it was his right, and the ≈øure≈øt waye in time of controuer≈øies (as that was in the ob≈øeruation
of Ea≈øter) to adhere vnto the cheife and commandinge church of Rome, hee ≈øent to this holy Pope, to bee in≈øtructed in the faith of Chri≈øt, a longe, paineful & trouble≈øome iorney & labour on both ≈øides, ≈øoe many Bi≈øhops now beeing in Britanie, Fraunce, and in all places betweene Scotland and Rome, if kinges & kingedomes could haue beene conuerted to the faith of Chri≈øt, and matters of the church with them ordered, without his direction or confirmation. For as truely write the Scotti≈øh hi≈øtorians. Pope Victor ≈øent prei≈øts, in extremam Albionem, to the vttermoste part of Albion, or the vttermoste Albion, to preach the doctrine of Chri≈øt. (Hector Boeth. l. 5. Scot. histor. fol. 89. p. 2. Boeth. ≈øupr. p. 1. Buchan. Rer. Scotic l. 4. Reg. 27. Holinsh. histor. of Scotl. in Donald. Ed. Grym≈øt. p. 20. in Scotl. ¬ß. 17.) the narration whereof is this.

Talem dederat Donaldo Regi animum, pacis Princeps & author Chri≈øtus Dominus quod verae pietati, a≈øpernato malorum demonum cultu, ≈øe≈øe paul√≤ ante addixerat. Nam Seuero Imperante Romanis, apud Victorem Pontificem maximum qui quintusdecimus post Petrum Eccle≈øiae praefuit, per legatos obtinuit, vt viri, doctrina & Religione in≈øignes, in Scotiam ab eo
mi≈øsi, ≈øe cum liberis & coniuge Chri≈øti nomen profitentes, bapti≈ømate in≈øignirent. Regis exempla Scotica nobilitas ≈øequuta, auer≈øata impietatem, Christique Religionem complexa, ≈øacro fonte est abluta. Fuit annus ille quo Scoti ad lumen verae pietatis, Dei Optimi Maximi benignitate vocati ≈øunt, & recepti; ab eo qui primus fuit humanae ≈øalutis tertius ≈øupra duceÃÑte ≈øimum: √† Scotorum Regni institutione quingente≈øimus trice≈øimus tertius. Chri≈øt our Lord prince, and Author of peace, gaue ≈øuch minde to kinge Donald, that ca≈øtinge a≈øide the wor≈øhip of wicked deuils, hee had a litle before addicted him≈øelfe to true pietie. For when Seuerus was the Romane Emperor, hee obteyned of Pope Victor the fifteenth after S. Peter, that ruled the church, that men renowned for learninge and Religion, ≈øent from him into Scotland, might bapti≈øe him, with his wife and children, profe≈ø≈øinge Chri≈øt. The Scotti≈øh nobilitie followeinge the example of the kinge, for≈øakinge impiety, and embracing the ReligioÃÑ of Chri≈øt, was baptized. This was in the yeare of the Incarnation of Chri≈øt, two hundred and three, and from the beginninge of the kingdome of the Scots, fiue hundred thirtie and three.

And a little after ≈øpeakinge of the renowned leardned Chri≈øtians, of that time, hee addeth. Incipere & nostri tum primum, ≈øacras colere literas, Sacerdotibus praeceptoribus, quos Victor Pontifex Maximus ad Christi dogma propalandum, in extremam mi≈øerat Albionem. At that time our Scotti≈øh men fir≈øt began to ≈øtudy diuinitie, hauinge for their Tutors, tho≈øe prei≈øts which Pope Victor ≈øent to teach the Religion of Chri≈øt in Albion, the vttermo≈øt country in this part of the world. And againe: nostri qua fide & pietate instituti ≈øemel fuerunt, hactenus erroribus a≈øpernatis, per≈øeuerant. Our contrimen (of ScotlaÃÑd) per≈øeuer at this day (it was written in the yeare 1526.) in the faith and pietie wherein they were then in≈øtructed. (Hector Boeth. in fine praefat. Bal. centur 5. in Hector Boeth.) And a Prote≈øtant of England in the yeare 1615. writteh: Scotland receyued the faith in the time of Pope Victor the first, in the yeare 203. Celestin the first ≈øent Palladius thither, to roote out the Pelagian here≈øie, which began to increa≈øe there, vnder Eugenius the ≈øecond, whoe died in the yeare 460. ≈øince this time the Realme continued longe in the profe≈øsion of the Romish church, vntill the≈øe
later dayes. (Edward. Grim≈øton. Booke of E≈øtates pag. 20. cap. 17.) Hee meaneth the dayes of this our Soueraigne kinge Iames the fir≈øt of England, and ≈øixt of that kingedome. Therfore it is a thinge without que≈øtion, that this holy Pope, ≈øoe earne≈øt for the ≈øpirituall ≈øupreamacie of his Apo≈øtolicke See, ≈øettled it with other doctrines in this Iland, where with the re≈øt it ≈øtill continued vntill the≈øe times, as the≈øe Prote≈øtants haue declared. Which is euident by all hi≈øtories, not any one affirminge, but rather denyinge, that hee altered anie thinge of that con≈øtitution of Pope Eleutherius, ≈øubmittinge the whole nation of Scotlande, to the Archbi≈øhopp of Yorke in ≈øpirituall affaires. And if kinge Donald and the nobilitie of Scotland then had not beene a≈ø≈øured, that this ≈øupreame ≈øpirituall power, in di≈øpo≈øinge and orderinge church matters, in ≈øuch ca≈øes, had belonged onely to the Popes of Rome, of all people and places in the world, they would not haue appealed to Rome, for tho≈øe thinges at that time in the Empire of Seuerus, when aboue all others, there was the greate≈øt enmytie and warrs betweene
the Romans and Scots, that euer were te≈øtified by all their hi≈øtories. Bed l. 1. histor. c. 5. Hect. Boeth. lib. 5. Scot. hi≈øt. Bucan. Rer. Scotic. l 4. Holinsh. hist. of Scotl. in Seuerus.

In an other point al≈øoe wee are a≈ø≈øured, that S. Victor whoe had by his highe≈øt authoritie excoÃÑmunicated ≈øoe many churches, both greeke and latine, as the≈øe Prote≈øtants haue told vs before, for their wronge keepinge of Ea≈øter, ≈øettled the right ob≈øeruatioÃÑ thereof in Scotland at this time. For to ≈øpeake in Prote≈øtants wordes of this Pope: Hee confirmed the ordinance of Pius, touching the celebration of Easter vppon the Sonday. Soe did Pope Eleutherius before him, and ≈øoe con≈øequently al≈øoe amonge other Chri≈øtian doctrines, by his legates taught and deliuered it here in Britanie. And wee are taught by the≈øe learned Prote≈øtants, that in the fir≈øt generall councell of Nice: De ob≈øeruatione Pa≈øchae antiquus canon ≈øancitus e≈øt, ne porro in hac re Eccle≈øiae variarent: The old canon of the ob≈øeruation of Ea≈øter was decreed, lea≈øt the churches ≈øhould afterward differ, about it. (Ed. Grymstonp¬∑ 436. in Victor. Rob. Barnes in vit. Pont. Rom. in Victor. Bal. lib. 1. de act. prat. in eod. Magdeburg. centur.
3. & in Eleuther. Dama≈ø. in Eleuther. Barns iu Siluestro. Magdeburg. cent. 4.) And that wee had Britti≈øh Bi≈øhops there, which con≈øented to this decree, and receaued it for Britany, they te≈øtifie in the≈øe termes. (Theater of greate Britanie l 6. cap. 9 pag. 206 n. 19.) The Britannes continued con≈øtant in chri≈øtianitie, and the cen≈øures of their Bishops, for the greate estimation of their constancie, pietie and learninge, were required, and approued in greate points of doctrine, amonge the a≈ø≈øemblies, of ≈øome generall councells, as that of Sardis (where appeales to the Pope were decreed) and Nyce, in the tyme of greate Con≈øtantine, vvee had our Bishops pre≈øent. And all men of readinge are a≈ø≈øured of this, both Con≈øtantine the Emperor in his epi≈øtle to the churches, and S. Athana≈øius in his Apologie write plainely, that this our Britanie receaued the councell of Nice. Epi≈øt. ConstaÃÑt. apud Theodoret. Athana≈ø Apolog.

Therefore it is a very idle and ignorant coniecture, or rather malitious error of ≈øome Prote≈øtants, to ≈øeeme to write as though Britany had receaued the faith froÃÑ ≈øome of the A≈øiatical churches, becau≈øe ≈øome of the later Scots and Britans die erre in that ob≈øeruation,
but this error of the Britans as diuers haue proued allready was quite differeÃÑt from that of ≈øome part of A≈øia & greeke. And the fir≈øt gretian that came hither, except ≈øome ≈øent by Roman Authoritie, that I finde was S. Regulus Albutus borne in Achaia, whoe came into Scotland, when Augu≈øtinus was kinge, allmo≈øt two hundred yeares after this, and longe after the controuer≈øie of keepinge Ea≈øter was ended, and brought thither holy relicks of S. Andrew the Apostle, vvhoe coming into Pictland, and the fame of this knowne, very many came to reuerence the holy relicques of the Apo≈øtle, and made offerings there, and the kinge of the picts Hirgustus receaued by him with proce≈øsion and lyinge vppon the grounde, vvith much reuerence, ki≈ø≈øed the holy relicques, and after ma≈ø≈øe ended hee bequeathed his palace to Saint Andrew, and to Regulus and the Preists to ≈øerue God in. Huius rei fama per Pictorum regiones delata permultorum animos ad vi≈øendas veneranda≈øque ≈øacras Apostoli reliquias attendit. Confluxerunt ergo illuc vndique donaria Christi Apo≈øtolo pretio≈øa afferentes. Affuit & Heirgastus Rex eorum, quae fama ad eum detulerat, vi≈øendi cupidas. Venientem ad ≈øe Regulus
cum ≈øociijs pio apparatu cum Sacerdotum ac Monachorum religio≈øa deductione in hymnis & canticis excepit. Rex humi procumbens, ≈øacras reliquias multa veneratione o≈øculatus, vbi ≈øacra Chri≈øtiano more, cuius ip≈øe Heirgustus erat ob≈øeruanti≈øsimus, erant peracta, regium palatium amplis ≈øtructuris ornatum diuo Andreae, Regulo, ac Sacerdotibus ibidem deinceps Optimo Maximo Deo famulaturis, liber√® erogauit, struxit & haud procul √† palatio, ≈øacram aedem diuo Apostolo dicatam: and builded an other church not far from the palace, dedicated to the holy Apostle. And thus much of S. Victor.

Next to him ≈øucceeded Pope and S. Zepherinus, whoe to proue hee ≈øtill maintayned this Romane ≈øupreamacie, as his predece≈ø≈øors before, ouer all Bi≈øhopes, Primates, Patriarckes, and whom≈øoeuer, or where≈øoeuer of the cleargie, or others, did generally decree as the≈øe Prote≈øtants tel vs. (Rob. Barns in vit. Pontif. Rom. in Zepherin. hee calleth him Seuerus.) Sine Romani Pontificis authoritate accu≈øatum Epi≈øcopum, nec √† Primate, nec √† Patriarcha, nec √† Metropolitano, in Iudicio condemnandum e≈ø≈øe. That a Bi≈øhop
accu≈øed, should not bee condemned, neyther by the Primate, nor Patriarcke, nor Metropolitane, without the authoritie of the Pope of Rome. By which is euident, that euen the Archbi≈øhops them≈øelues of Britanie, to whome all others were ≈øubordinate in thinges ≈øpirituall, were ≈øubiect to the Pope of Rome at this time.

Pope Calixtus ≈øucceeded next, and to ≈øpeake in a Prote≈øtant Doctors wordes: (Powel l. 1. of Antichri≈øt. pag. 130.131.) Calixtus Pope defined, that all Bishops though gathered in a generall councell, shall fulfill the vvill of the church of Rome. They which doe not this are pronounced to keepe a conciliable, & not a councell. And to bee ≈øhort in this matter, the Prote≈øtants of England proue vnto vs, that this bu≈øines of the ≈øpirituall power of that See ouer all other churches, is the cheife ≈øcope of many of their Epi≈øtles decretall. (Rob. Barns in vit. Vrbani, Antheri. & Dovvnam. lib. 1. Antichristi. cap. 3. pag. 35.) And to giue ≈øome particular in≈øtances hereof more in Britanie, in this age: wee finde in hi≈øtories. (Matth. We≈øt. an. 257.258.) that Pope StepheÃÑ about the yeare of Chri≈øt 257.258. or 259. When S. Mellon, then noe Chri≈øtian, was ≈øent from hence by publick
authoritie to Rome, about the temporall affaires of this kingedome, conuerted him to the faith of Chri≈øt, made him prei≈øt, and ≈øoone after Bi≈øhop, exempting him from his ciuill imployments of this his country, and by his Apo≈øtolicke power ≈øent him Archbi≈øhop to Rhoan in Normandie. (Petr. de Nat. de vit. 51. Vincent. in. Specul. l. 11. c. 74. Martyrol. Rom. 22. Octob. Ioh. Capgr. in 5. Mel. M. S. antiq. in eod. & Catal. Epi≈øcop. Rothmag. Matt. West.) And amonge others our glorious men and martyrs here in this age, it is the common opinion, that S. Amphibalus whoe conuerted S. Alban. (Matth. Paris p. 178.179. Lidg. in vit. cius. Engl. Martyrol. 25. Iun.) both was a Britan borne, and con≈øecrated at Rome, ≈øome ≈øay by Pope & Saint Zepherinus, what and how glorious his hi≈øtorie is, for his preaching and martyrdome with vs, all hi≈øtories of that time are full: and how renowned hee and others of his holy company, ≈øent by that Apo≈øtolicke See were at the ≈øame time in Scotland, namely Modocus, Pri≈øcus, Calanus, Ferranus, Ambianus, and Carnonus, both Scotti≈øh and Engli≈øh hi≈øtories wil witne≈ø≈øe. Where S. Amphibalus was the fir≈øt Bishop they had, and in Mona the
Iland: Amphibalus Brito vir in≈øigni pietate primus Anti≈øtes ibi creatus. Hector Boethius Scotor. hi≈øtor. lib. 6. fol. 102. Bal. centur. 1. in Amphib. Holinsh. hist. of Scotland in Chrakint. Veremund. apud Boeth. ≈øupr.

And ≈øoe honored was he of that mo≈øt worthie Kinge of Scotland Chrathlintus, that to ≈øhew the honor hee yeelded to this holie Legate, and his companions, and ≈øomewhat to behold the ReligioÃÑ of that time, the Scotti≈øh hi≈øtorie thus ≈øpeaketh vnto vs. (Hector Boeth. ≈øupr Holinsh. hi≈øt. of ScotlaÃÑd in Chrah.) Chrathlintus Rex ≈øacram Anti≈øtitis aedem muneribus ornauit ampli≈øsimis, calicihus, patenis candelabris, alij≈øque ≈øimilibus ad ≈øacrorum v≈øum commodis, ex argento, auroque fabrefactis, altarique cupro & are clau≈øo: prouentus ad ea ex agris in ≈øacrae aedis vicini constituit. Fuit id templum omnium primum, Christiano ritu, vbi Pontifex ≈øacerque magistratus ≈øedem haberet primariam, inter Scotos, cuius nostri meminere ≈øcriptores dedicatum. Kinge Chrathlint did adorne the Holy How≈øe, of the Bi≈øhop Amphibalus, with mo≈øt honorable guifts, chalices, patens, candle≈øticks, and others ≈øeruinge for the v≈øe of Ma≈ø≈øe made of ≈øyluer, and gold, and an Altare,
inclo≈øed with copper and bra≈ø≈øe, and appointed reuenewes for them out of the country adioyninge. That was the fir≈øt Chri≈øtian church where a Bi≈øhop and holy magi≈øtrate had his cheife See, amonge the Scots, that is remembred by our writers. Thus were the Bi≈øhops and prei≈øts con≈øecrated at, and ≈øent from Rome, honored in this nation at that time. When wee reade further the See of Rome to haue beene here in ≈øuch high honor, that the Britti≈øh writer, and witne≈ø≈øe of S. Albans life, liuinge then, writeth. (Compilator vitae S. Albani apud Capgrau. & M.S. antiq. in vit. eiu≈ød.) Romam profici≈øcor, vt illic veniam merear delictorum, libellum quoque i≈øtum offeram Examini Romanorum: vt ≈øi quid in eo ≈øecus qu√†m debuit fort√® prolatum fuerit, hoc per eos dignetur in melius commutare. I goe to Rome, that there I may de≈øerue forgiuenes of my ≈øinnes: and I will offer this booke to the Examination of the Romans, that if any thinge be vttered therein otherwi≈øe then it ≈øhould, it may bee amended.

And that all ≈øpirituall power and iuri≈ødiction then in Britanie, was ≈øubordinate
vnto, & dependinge of the Popes of Rome, in that time, the Antiquities and Antiquaries, Prote≈øtants and others, both of Cambridge and other places doe plainely te≈øtifie, whoe amonge other euidences for this matter, produce vnto vs the auntient Bull of Pope Honorius, dated at Rome the 20. day of Februarij in the yeare 624. (Bulla Honorij 1. Papae an. 624.20. Februar. apud Caium l. 1. de antiquit. Cantabrig. Accad. p. 75.76.77.) Wherein hee affirmeth that hee followeth the example of Pope Eleutherius, of whome I haue ≈øpoken before: Pope Fabian who liued in this age, and others who beeinge likewi≈øe holy Popes, had done the like which hee did towardes the vniuer≈øitie or ≈øchoole of Cambridge, and concerninge his power ≈øpirituall ouer all par≈øons in this nation, thus it is.

p.hi:
Honorius Epi≈øcopus ≈øeruus ≈øeruorum Dei, dilectis filijs doctoribus & ≈øcholaribus in vniuer≈øitate Cantabrigiae ≈øtudentibus Apostolicam benedictionem. Dilecti≈øsimi in Christo filij, noÃÑ ab≈øque labore, & plurima perturbatione didicimus, quomodo nonnulli propriae ≈øalutis immemores luporum faucibus, & vulpina facie, libertates & priuilegia, quae vobis & praedece≈ø≈øoribus
in eadem vniuer≈øitate ≈øtudentibus gratios√® indul≈øit ≈øedes Apostolica, moliuntur ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ neruare: Ita qu√≤d plures eccle≈øiarum praepo≈øiti ab≈øque rationis. Iure min√πs in≈øt√® in vos iuri≈ødictionem indebitam, & in≈øolitam v≈øurpantes, quamque non con≈øueuerunt hactenus, ad vntuer≈øitatem ve≈øtram accedunt, materiam perturbationis, & di≈øcordiae ≈øeminantes, correctionis, emendationis aut reformationis ibidem officia exercentes, contra inhibitionem ≈øedis Apo≈øtolicae. Volentes igitur, vt tenemur iustitia ≈øuadente, paci & tranquillitati vniuer≈øitatis ve≈øtrae paterna ≈øollicitudine ≈øalubriter prouidere. Praedece≈ø≈øorum nostrorum Romanae Eccle≈øiae Pontificum, Eleutherij, Fabiani, Leonis, Simplicij, Felicis & Bonifacij ve≈øtigijs debit√® inhaerentes, authoritate omnipotentis Dei districtius inhibemus, ≈øub poena excommunicationis, quam veniens in contrarium ip≈øo facto incurrat, ne quis Archiepi≈øcopus, aut eorum officiales, ≈øeu vi≈øitatores generales aut ≈øpeciales √† Sede Apostolica deputati, audent in aliquem ve≈øtrum ≈øu≈øpen≈øionis vel excommunicationis, ≈øcu interdicti ≈øententias inferre, aut vos familiares vestros molestare prae≈øumat.

div.p:
Honorius Bi≈øhop, ≈øeruant of the ≈øeruants of God, to his beloued ≈øonnes the doctors &
≈øchollers of the vniuer≈øitie of Cambridge ≈øendeth Apo≈øtolicall benediction. Wee haue learned not without labour and much ≈øorrowe, mo≈øte beloued ≈øonnes in Chri≈øt, how ≈øome vnmindfull of their owne ≈øaluation, like greedy wolues, and craftly foxes goe about to weaken or euacuate the liberties & priuiledges which the See Apo≈øtolicke hath graunted graciou≈øly to you, and your predece≈ø≈øors ≈øtudents in the ≈øame vniuer≈øitie. Soe that many Rulers of churches without right of rea≈øon, v≈øurping, vniu≈øtly ouer you vndue iuri≈ødiction, and vnaccu≈øtomed, and which hitherto they haue not v≈øed, come to your vniuer≈øitie, ≈øowing matter of trouble, and di≈øcord, exerci≈øing there the offices of correction, emendation, or reformation, again≈øt the inhibition of the See Apo≈øtolick. Wee therfore willing, as wee are bound by iu≈øtice per≈øuadinge it, with a fatherly care ≈øafely to prouide for the peace, and quietne≈ø≈øe of your vniuer≈øitie, duely followinge the ≈øteps of our predece≈ø≈øors, Popes of Rome, Eleutherius, Fabianus, Leo, Simplicius, Felix and Bonifacius, by the authoritie of almightie God, doe ≈øtrictlie forbid vnder payne of excommunicatioÃÑ ip≈øo facto to bee
incurred by the coÃÑtrary doer, that noe Archbi≈øhop, or their Officials, nor the vi≈øitors generall or ≈øpeciall deputed from the See Apo≈øtolicke, ≈øhall dare to inflict the ≈øentences of ≈øu≈øpen≈øion or excommunication, or interdiction, again≈øt any of you, or pre≈øume to mole≈øt you, or your ≈øeruants.

By which it is euident, that in this age the Popes of Rome, exerci≈øed the highe≈øt ≈øpiritual iuri≈ødictioÃÑ in this kingdome, limited (as they thought good) the power of Bishops, and Archbi≈øhops, ≈øubiecting them to their ceÃÑ≈øures, and made exemptions from them, & all others, except the See of Rome it ≈øelfe, & had their vi≈øitors here to ≈øuch purpo≈øes, except the≈øe Prote≈øtants doe deceaue vs. Which further te≈øtifie, that this Pope Fabian, in that time miraculou≈ølie cho≈øen Pope, and liuing & dying an holy Saint, made diuers decrees, generally bindinge all Chri≈øtians as: That euery ChristiaÃÑ ≈øhould coÃÑmunicate thri≈øe a yeare, that is to ≈øay, at the fea≈øts of Ea≈øter, whit≈øonday, and the birth of our Sauiour, that prei≈øts should not bee puni≈øhed in prophane courts. And the like. Ed. Grym≈øton. in Fabian. Pope. Rob. Barns l. de vit. Pontif. Rom. in Fabiano.

div.head: THE FOVRTH CENTVRIE OR HVNDRED YEARE.
THE VIII. CHAPTER. Wherein is proued likewi≈øe by the Protestant diuines, and Antiquaries of England, that the Popes of Rome, euer claymed and exerci≈øed, this their highest power here in this Age.
div.p:
NOw wee are come to the fourth hundred yeare, in the beginninge whereof, Diocletian the per≈øecutinge Emperor dyinge, although hee had put euen in this Iland, diuers thou≈øands of Chri≈øtiaÃÑs to death, and one thou≈øand in one time and place, Lichfeild, (Theater of greate Brit. l. 6. Stowe histor. in the Rom. in Coill.) (taking therevpon the name of a Feild of Blood.) yet hee was ≈øoe farr from extingui≈øhinge the name of Chri≈øt, that wee had a continuall ≈øucce≈ø≈øion at that very time of Bi≈øhops, prei≈øts, religious, and other cleargie men, without intermi≈ø≈øion deudced from this Roman in≈øtitution in this kingedome. And this te≈øtified
by the be≈øt Antiquities wee haue, S. Gildas, S. Bede, and allmo≈øte all after them both Catholicks, and Prote≈øtants. (Gildas l. de excid. & conquest. Brit. cap. 8.) The words of Saint Gildas ar the≈øe, as Prote≈øtants publi≈øh him.

Bilustro ≈øupradicti turbinis necdum ad integrum expleto, emerce≈øcentibu≈øque nece ≈øuorum Authorum nefarijs decretis, laetis luminibus omnes Chri≈øti Tyrones qua≈øi po≈øt hyemalem ac prolixam noctem, temperiem lucemque ≈øerenam aurae cele≈øtis excipiunt, renouant eccle≈øias ad ≈øolum v≈øque de≈øtructas, Ba≈øilicas Sanctorum Martyrum fundant, construunt, perficiunt, ac velut victricia ≈øigna pa≈øsim propalant, dies fe≈øtos celebrant, ≈øacra mundo corde, oreque conficiunt, omnes exultant filij gremio ac ≈øi matris eccle≈øiae confoti. When ten yeares of the ≈øaid per≈øecution were not wholly expired, and the wicked decrees were now voide by the death of their Authors, al the ≈øouldiars of Chri≈øt with ioyfull countenance, as it were after a winter longe night, receaue the temper and cleare light of the heauenly ayre, they renew their churches de≈øtroied euen to the ground, they build churches of the holy martyrs, frame, and perfect them, & as it were publicklie
≈øett forth euery where their victorious En≈øignes, they celebrate holy dayes, they perfect their ≈øacrifices, or ≈øacred things with a cleane hart, and mouth, they all doe reioyce, as it were children fo≈øtered in the lap of their mother the church.

The very ≈øame hath S. Bede whoe addeth (Bed. histor. Eccl. l. 1. cap. 8.) Progre≈øsi in publicum fideles Christi, qui ≈øe tempore di≈øcriminis, ≈øiluis ac de≈øertis, abditi≈øque ≈øpeluncis occultauerant. The faithfull ≈øeruants of Chri≈øt shew them≈øelues now in publick, whoe in the time of the daunger had hidd them≈øelues in woods, and wilderne≈ø≈øes, and hidden dens. And then hee writeth as S. Gildas before. By which publick and hierarchicall Acts and offices of Bishops, and prei≈øts, as founding and dedicatinge churches, to the honor of holy Martyrs, that had late ≈øuffered in that per≈øecution, in in≈øtitutinge and celebratinge their fe≈øtiuities, renewing and con≈øecrating other defaced churches, which none but Bi≈øhops might doe, and ≈øayinge Ma≈ø≈øe, which hee expre≈ø≈øely by perfecting their ≈øacrifices or ≈øacred rites, with a cleane hart, and mouth, the prei≈øtly office and function, it is mo≈øte euident, that diuers both
prei≈øts and Bi≈øhops, with other cleargie men e≈øcaped in this per≈øecution, and ≈øoe ≈øtill continued the hierarchicall ≈øucce≈ø≈øion of Archbi≈øhops and Bi≈øhops, ≈øoe vniuer≈øally e≈øtabli≈øhed here before by the Popes of Rome, and with the ≈øame dependance which they had before. For noe hi≈øtorie maketh mention, of any chaunge, neyther of our Bishops then putt to death, except S. Amphibalus, vnle≈ø≈øe wee wil coniecture without warrant, that S. Angulus ≈øuffered martyrdome in this time. And notwith≈øtanding ≈øoe many lo≈ø≈øes, and de≈øolations of our Antiquities, wee haue te≈øtimonie of ≈øome Bishops in particular then liuing, the per≈øecution being ended.

For whoe can thinke but ≈øome of tho≈øe which fledd into Scotland, whether the per≈øecution extended not, with S. Amphibalus, remayned there ≈øtill in the Epi≈øcopall See of Mona, which kinge Chrathlinte, had ≈øoe honorably endowed to that purpo≈øe, and longe after was an Epi≈øcopall See? I haue named diuers of the≈øe renowned men before, of whome ≈øome one in all probabilitie after the returne of Saint Amphibalus into the≈øe parts, ≈øupplied that place and dignitie there. And here in England it is euident by
tho≈øe antiquities wee haue left, that wee had pre≈øerued from the fury of that per≈øecution, many both Bi≈øhops, and Archbi≈øhops. To exemplifie in London, wee haue the names of Sixteene Archbi≈øhops there, before the cominge of S. Augu≈øtine hither, as both Iocelin of Furnes, the Prote≈øtants, Stowe, Godwyn and others collect them. (Iocelin Catalog. of Briti≈øh Bi≈øh. Stowe histor. in Lucius. Godwyn. Catalog. in London, 1. concil. Arelat. in Sub≈øcript. tom. 1. concil. Stowe & Godwyn ≈øupr.) And it is manife≈øt that either Re≈øtitutus which was Archbi≈øhop of London, and was pre≈øent at the councel of Arles in Fraunce, in the yeare 326. ≈øoone after this, or Thedred, or Hillary ≈øuppo≈øed to bee his immediate predece≈ø≈øors, was then Archbi≈øhop. And ≈øoe becau≈øe euery Archbi≈øhop inferreth inferiour Bi≈øhops vnder him, that wee had Bi≈øhops al≈øoe. I will in≈øtance onely in Winche≈øter, where wee ar informed both by an old Manu≈øcript Author, and a new Prote≈øtant Bi≈øhop. (Godwyn Catalog. of Bi≈øh. in Winchest. 1. old M. S. apud eundem ≈øupr.) That one Con≈øtans was Bi≈øhop there in this time, and in the yeare 309. or 310. did vpon the 15. day of march, hallowe and dedicate
vnto the honor & memory of S. Amphibalus, that had ≈øuffered death for Chri≈øt in the late per≈øecution, a church there reedified with ≈øuch wonderfull forwardnes and zeale, as within one yeare and thirtie dayes, both it and all the edifices belonginge vnto it, were quite fini≈øhed in very ≈øeemely and conuenient maÃÑner. And that Deodatus was Abbot of this new erected Mona≈øtery. Thus this Prote≈øtant Bi≈øhop from an old Manu≈øcript.

By which, and that which is ≈øpoken before in this chapter, it is euident, that England this part of Britanie then had both Bi≈øhops, and Archbi≈øhops continuinge in the ≈øame order and maner as they were fir≈øt in≈øtituted here by the See of Rome: neither did they now begin to depart or ≈øeperate them≈øelues from obedience to that See Apo≈øtolicke; for ≈øoone after this, the fir≈øt general councel of Nice beeinge called, the≈øe Prote≈øtaÃÑts haue told vs, wee had Bi≈øhops there, and mo≈øt euident it is, that it was receaued in this kingdome. And yet the canon of that councell is ≈øoe manife≈øt for the Popes of Rome ≈øupreamacy, at the lea≈øt ouer this we≈øtern world, wherein England is, both in the time of this holy councell, and before, that
a Prote≈øtant Bi≈øhop doth thus confe≈ø≈øe it. (Feild. l. 3. p. 60.61.) In the time of the Nicen councell, & before, as appeareth by the Acts of the councell limitinge their bounds, there were three principall Bi≈øhops, or Patriarkes of the chri≈øtian church: namely the Bi≈øhop of Rome, Alexandria, and Antioch. Soe writeth the Prote≈øtant Archbi≈øhop Whitgift, Foxe and others, whereof one ≈øaith. (Whitgift def. of the Answ. p. 331. Foxe tom. 1. pag. 12. Rob. Barns in vit. Pont. Rom. in Siluestro.) Sollicitudinem eccle≈øiarum, pro recepta con≈øuetudine veterum habendam e≈ø≈øe ≈øtatuerunt. The fathers of the nicen councell did decree, that accordinge to the cu≈øtome receaued from them of old, that the three cheife patriarkes of Rome, Antioch, and Alexandria, ≈øhould haue chardge of the churches.

Soe that if wee would ≈øeeke noe further then to the≈øe great enemies them≈øelues of the Romane See, yett they confe≈ø≈øe vnto vs, that it was not onely decreed in this nicen councell, where, as our Prote≈øtants haue told vs, wee had Bi≈øhops con≈øentinge, and our kinge and contriman Con≈øtantine the great Emperor al≈øoe ≈øubmittinge him≈øelfe vnto it, but that it was the old cu≈øtome and tradition of
the church, that the Bi≈øhop of Rome was the principall Bi≈øhop, and commaundinge Patriarke of all we≈øterne churches, amonge which this of our Britanie was euer, now is, and of nece≈ø≈øitie mu≈øt bee one, and if wee will bee members of the church of Chri≈øt, except wee can remoue Britanie from the vttermo≈øt part of Europe, to lepp to Alexandria in Africke, or Antioch in A≈øia, wee mu≈øt needs by this councel as it is glo≈ø≈øed by our Prote≈øtants, bee ≈øubiect to Rome, as wee euer were by the old cu≈øtome before that councell. The words of the≈øe Prote≈øtants Whitgift and Foxe are the≈øe. (Whitgift Def. pag. 331. Foxe tom. 1. pag. 12.) The councell of Nice which was the yeare of our Lord 340. and in the ≈øixt canon of the ≈øaid councell wee finde it ≈øoe decreed, that in euery prouince, or precinct ≈øome one church or Bi≈øhop of the ≈øame, was appointed and ≈øett vp, to haue the In≈øpection and Regiment of other churches about him, ≈øecundum morem antiquum, that is after the auncient cu≈øtome, as the words of the councell doe purport. Soe that the Bi≈øhop of Alexandria ≈øhould haue power of Libia, and Pontapolis, in Egipt, for as much as the Bi≈øhop of Rome
hath the like or ≈øame maner.

Therefore ≈øeeing there is none named either by the councell, or cu≈øtome related by that councell, but the Bi≈øhops of Rome, Antioch, and Alexandria to haue this high Regiment and power ouer the churches, wee mu≈øt needs adhere and appeale to Rome by the≈øe men, as wee euer did by the old cu≈øtome from the beginninge of our fir≈øt life in Chri≈øt: otherwi≈øe wee ≈øhall fall into errors and conclude inualidate things euen in the highe≈øt matters, the≈øe men a≈ø≈øuringe vs, that at this time there were but three „Äà‚óä„Äâ Metropolitane churches before recited, and that to v≈øe their words. (Whitgift def. pag. 359.) The church of Rome is called all that is ≈øubiect to the Bishop of Rome: And (Whitgift Answeare to the Admonit: cap. 2.17. diui≈øion.) that notable and famous councell of Nice mu≈øt be, and is of all wi≈øe and learned men next vnto the ≈øcriptures them≈øelues reuerenced, e≈øteemed and embraced, in the ≈øixt canon of that councell it is thus written: This councell doth determine him to bee noe Bishop, which is made without the con≈øent Metropolitani Epi≈øcopi, of the Metropolitane. Which cheife Metrotropolitane
to vs then as the≈øe men haue told vs, was the Bi≈øhop of Rome; ≈øoe that it is euident by them, that we could not here haue any Archbi≈øhop, or Bi≈øhopp made without his allowance.

And yett the≈øe our Prote≈øtant Bi≈øhops & Doctors mu≈øt needs eleuate this power ≈øpiritual higher, then to make it onely cheife ouer Britanie, tho≈øe We≈øt nations and Europe, and giue, it the highe≈øt place in the whole church of Chri≈øt, for ≈øoe all that can bee pretended by the≈øe Prote≈øtants, to haue had intere≈øt in ≈øuch things at that time, whether the Pope him≈øelfe S. Silue≈øter and others, our kinge and Emperor Con≈øtantine, or the Bi≈øhops of Britanie, and other nations; for all the≈øe in tho≈øe daies acknowledged the Supreamacy in the Romane See ouer all churches. S. Silue≈øter Pope with the con≈øent, and Sub≈øcription of the Emperor Con≈øtaÃÑtine his Mother S. Helena, and 284. we≈øtern Bi≈øhops, and 45. prei≈øts, decreed. (Concil. Roman. ≈øub Syluestro can. 20. to. 1. Concil.) Nemo Iudicabit primam ≈øedem: quoniam omnes ≈øedes √† prima ≈øede de≈øiderant temperari, neque ab Augusto, neque ab omni clero, neque √† Regibus, neque √† populo Iudex iudicabitur. Noe man shall iudge
the cheife See (of Rome): becau≈øe all Sees de≈øire to bee gouerned by the cheife See. The iudge (Pope of Rome) shall not bee iudged, neither by the Emperour, nor by all the cleargie, nor by kings, nor by the people. Where wee ≈øee the Pope of Rome to bee by all con≈øent the highe≈øt iudge, and ≈øubiect to noe others iudgment, who≈øoeuer. The honor and reuerence which Con≈øtantine yeelded to Saint Silue≈øter then Pope, is ≈øufficiently knowne by Eu≈øebius in his life and others. (Eu≈øeb. de vita Constantini.) I will onely exemplify by the warrant of an engli≈øh Prote≈øtant Bi≈øhop, how this greate dutie and Reuerence of him to that holy Pope, and endowinge that Apo≈øtolicke See with honor and ritches, was ≈øuch, that it was longe before foretold by an Angell from heauen, to S. Bla≈øius. ≈øaying (l. 1. de Act. Rom. Pontif. in Sylue≈øtro.)
