That in the time of Con≈øtantine, Idolatry ≈øhould cea≈øe by his meanes, and this Constantine for his honor to the See of Rome, should tran≈ølate the ≈øeate of his Empire from thence, into Thracia, and there ≈øettle it at the mouth of the Riuer Bo≈øphorus, and leaue Italy and Rome to the Pope, Chri≈øts vicar there. Adueniet Princeps, ≈øub quo pacabitur orbis: &
finem accipiet veteram cultura deorum. Constantinus apud Thraces, qua Bo≈øphorus aequor Thracius Euxinis Aegaeum ingurgitat vndis, con≈øtituet ≈øedem Imperij: latiumque relinquet Chri≈øto & Romuleam ≈øeptem in collibus vrbem.

Now for the Bi≈øhops of Britanie there can bee noe que≈øtion, but they gaue this primacie to S. Silue≈øter: for fir≈øt it is mo≈øt probable ≈øome of them were pre≈øent at this Roman councell, ≈øoe great, con≈øi≈øtinge of the we≈øterne Bi≈øhops. Secondly in all Iudgments they mu≈øt needs acknowledge this ≈øupreamacy either in the Pope, or Emperor; But not the Emperor which yeelded it to S. Silue≈øter. Thirdly becau≈øe the next Pope Saint Marke, who was Pope but three yeares, claimed for the Romane See to be, mater omnium eccle≈øiarum, the mother of all churches, and priuiledged from here≈øie. (Marcus epist. ad Athana≈ø. & caeter. Egipti Epi≈øcopos.) And as the≈øe Prote≈øtants tell vs, his ≈øucce≈øsor S. Iulius appointed appeales to the See of Rome, and taught noe councel could bee kept lawfully without his con≈øent. (Rob. Barns in vita Pontif. Roman. in Iulio.) And two other Prote≈øtant Bi≈øhops ≈øpeaking of this time affirme: The canoÃÑ of the primatiue church made euery thinge
voyde that was done without the Bi≈øhop of Rome. (Bil≈øon true differ. pag. 66.67.) And againe: The canon of the primatiue church forbad any councell to bee called, without his con≈øent. (Morton Appeale pag. 286.) And to make all ≈øure in this matter, that the whole cleargie of Britanie and Chri≈øtians vnder them, at this time attributed this ≈øpirituall ≈øupreamacie to the Pope of Rome, our Prote≈øtants haue told vs before, which auncieÃÑt Authorities al≈øoe affirme (Theater of greate Britanie l. 6. Sulpit. Seuer. ≈øacr. hi≈øtor. lib. 2. Athan. apol. l. 1. cont. Ar. Concil. Sardic. can. 4.7.) that wee had of this nation diuers Bi≈øhops in the generall councell of Sardis, a cytie of Lydia in A≈øia with 300. Bi≈øhops; and therfore this kingedome with the re≈øt, acknowledged the ≈øupreamacie of the Pope of Rome in all places, and that Appeales were to bee made to him as highe≈øt iudge.

And whereas the councell of Arles in Fraunce in the time of S. Silue≈øter, in the ≈øub≈øcription of the Bi≈øhops there, many Prote≈øtants and other Antiquaries a≈ø≈øure vs, (Concil. Arelat. in ≈øub≈øcript. Theater of Brit. lib. 6. Stow histor. in Lucius. Godwyn. catalog. in London. 1.) that Re≈øtitutus our Archbi≈øhop
of London was pre≈øent there, and ≈øub≈øcribed for this nation, that place beeinge ≈øoe remote from London, wee mu≈øt needs ≈øay, that hee was called thither by the Pope of Rome, or doe that, which neuer any yett would allowe, to graunt a ≈øuperioritie vnto the Bishops of Fraunce ouer them of this kingedome. And ≈øoe for tho≈øe our Bishops which were at the councell of Ariminum in this time, for noe others medled in the≈øe affaires in tho≈øe dayes. Which wee are further taught by the Example of our holy Bishop S. Ninian, (Capgrau. in Catal. in Ninian. Bed. hi≈øt. Anglic. Theater of greate Britanie. lib. 6. Bal. centur. 1. de ≈øcript. in Ninian ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ Bernini.) whoe towards the later end of this centurie of yeares, was made Bishopp at Rome by the Pope there, and by him ≈øent Apo≈øtle to the We≈øtern parts of Britanie, to people there which had not yett receaued the faith of Chri≈øt. Where hee conuerted the nation of the Picts, preached the gho≈øpell through the contryes of the Britans, Scots, and Picts, ordeyned there prei≈øts, con≈øecrated them Bishops, and diuided the contry into parishes, as both Catholicks and Prote≈øtants are witne≈ø≈øes. Audiens Pontifex Romanus
quo≈ødam in occiduis Britanniae partibus necdum fidem Christi ≈øu≈øcepi≈ø≈øe, ad Epi≈øcopatus gradum Ninianum con≈øecrauit.
Concreditum √† Deo talentum per Britannorum, Scotorum, australium Pictorum terras, ad ≈øenium v≈øque lati≈øsim√® profudit. Ordinauit presbyteros, Epi≈øcopos con≈øecrauit, & totam terram per certas parochias diui≈øit. And liuinge in this preachinge vntill hee was very ould, as a Prote≈øtant Bishop writeth, (Bal. centur. 1. in Ninian. Palladio Patricio.) he died in the yeare of Chri≈øt 432. before which time S. Palladius, S. Patricius, SS. Germanus and Lupus were ≈øent hither by S. Cele≈øtine Pope of Rome. And yett that hee came hither in the fourth century, it is euident: for in his cominge hither from Rome, hee came by S. Martin Bishopp of Tours, in Fraunce as Capgraue and others writte, (Ioh. Capgr. in S. Ninian.) and yett by Sigebert and others, S. Martine died within the fir≈øt 400. yeares. (Sigebert. in Chronic. ad an. 399.) In which time al≈øoe wee had Coelius Sedulius of this nation, ≈øcholler (as a Prote≈øtant Bishop writeth) to Hildiberthus a learned Bishop of Scotland, (Ioh. Bal. centur. 1. in Coel. Sedul.) after who≈øe death hee trauailed
many nations for learninge ≈øake, as Spayne, France, Italy and A≈øia, and beeinge excellently learned returned to Rome, where hee longe time continued, and was ≈øoe learned holy and gratefull a man to the Popes of Rome, that Pope Gela≈øius (to v≈øe the Prote≈øtants words) in the decrees di≈øtinct 15. calleth him, venerable Sedulius, and much pray≈øeth his writings.

Neyther can wee thinke otherwi≈øe of his Ma≈øter, Bishop Hildibertus, of whome hee was in≈øtructed, and directed in the≈øe cour≈øes. And this Sedulius him≈øelfe al≈øoe was a Bi≈øhop, as both Sigebertus, and Bostius our contryman, and the Prote≈øtant Bi≈øhop Bale from them, are wittne≈ø≈øes. (Sigebertus & Bostius apud Bal. centur. 1. de Script. in Coel. Sedul.) In which time al≈øoe liued S. Kebius our Corni≈øh Bi≈øhop, ≈øucce≈ø≈øor, though perhaps not immediate, to S. Amphibalus in the Bi≈øhoprick of Mona. (Ioh. Capgrau. in S. Kebio. Harpesf. hi≈øtor. pag. 26. Pit≈ø. in Kebio.) Whoe liued longe time with S. Hilary Bi≈øhopp of Poicters in Fraunce, that worthie piller of the true Catholick faith, and honor of the church of Rome, and Succe≈ø≈øor of Saint Peter there, that hee calleth him.
(Hilar. ad P≈øalm. 131. & in Matth. can. 16.) Eccle≈øiae fundamentum, caelestis Regni Ianitor, cuius arbitrio aeterni aditus traduntur, cuius terrestre iudicium praeiudicata authoritas ≈øit in caelo: Foundation of the church, porter of the kingedome of heauen. The happy foundation of the church, the ble≈ø≈øed porter of heauen, to wo≈øe will die eternall pa≈ø≈øadges are committed, who≈øe iudgement on earth is preiudicate authoritie in heauen.

Such a tutor, pedagoge, and con≈øecrator al≈øoe had this our happie contryman Saint Kebius, in tho≈øe turbulent hereticall times of the Arrians, and their oppo≈øition again≈øt the Romane church, a greate meanes by this our holy Bi≈øhop, S. Re≈øtitutus, Fa≈øtidius, Pri≈øcus, our Archbi≈øhops then, and other godly Bi≈øhops of this nation, to pre≈øerue this kingedome in the true faith, and obedience to the Pope of Rome, in ≈øoe much that S. Hilarie him≈øelfe, (lib. de Synodis aduer≈øus Arr.) commendeth the Bi≈øhops of Britanie for the ≈øinceritie in tho≈øe times, to their eternall honor. Hee dyed, as our Prote≈øtants write, in the yeare of Chri≈øt, 370. And in this age al≈øoe was that renowned S. Vr≈øula, with her glorious company of Bi≈øhops, other
cleargie men, Virgins and others, as tho≈øe Prote≈øtants ar witne≈ø≈øes, whoe as both Ptolomaeus Lucen≈øis, Capgraue, the Antiquities of Collene, and the German hi≈øtories te≈øtifie (Baleus centur. 1. in Vr≈øula. Cyno≈øura an. 390. Stowe histor. an. 394. in Theodo≈øius. Martyrolog. Roman. die 21. & 22. Octob. & Beda hac die & Vandelbert. Baron. in annot. Ptolom. Lucen≈ø. in S. Vr≈øula. Capgrau. in S. Vr≈øula. & Annal. Colonien≈ø. &c.) made that their mo≈øte holy pilgrimadge to Rome, and at their returne receaued the crowne of Martyrdome at, or neare Cullen in Germanie, where, as al≈øoe in the whole Chri≈øtian world, and both to their honor and the glory of our country, they are celebrated in the mo≈øt auncient Martyrologes, in which ≈øacred company, as Capgrauius and diuers others te≈øtifie, there were manye Bi≈øhops of this kingedome, as namelie Willielmus or Michael, Columbanus Ywanus, Eleutherius and Lotharius. Which I rather name, that wee may know, how this kingedome at that tyme, both was ≈øoe repleni≈øhed with Bishops, that it might ≈øpare ≈øoe manie to bee ≈øent from hence, with tho≈øe holy Virgins, and to giue euidence how
deuoted and re≈øpectiue, the Bishops and cleargie, with the re≈øt the Chri≈øtians of this kingedome, were towards the See of Rome, in the≈øe dayes.

div.head: THE FIFTE CENTVRIE OR HVNDRED YEARE.

THE IX. CHAPTER. Shewinge by the≈øe Protestants of England, how both the Popes highe≈øt ≈øpiritual power, was still here continued, and a perpetuall ≈øucce≈øsion of our Bishops and Cleargie al≈øoe in Britanie from the See of Rome, as in the other Ages before.
div.p:
NOw wee are come to the fift Century, in the beginning whereof the fir≈øt Fathers of Here≈øie, and Oppo≈øers again≈øt the holy Apo≈øtolick See of Rome, which I finde to haue beene of our Britti≈øh nation, were the mon≈øtrous rebellious Hereticks Pelagius and Timotheus, not that I finde them more formally & directly oppo≈øite to the See Apo≈øtolick then other Hereticks were, but as the
nature and nece≈ø≈øitie of here≈øie is, to bee euer contrarie and di≈øobedient to their cheife iudge, and commaunder in ≈øuch ca≈øes, the Pope of Rome, with councels a≈ø≈øembled: for as our Prote≈øtants tell vs, diuers Popes of Rome both by them≈øelues, and in councels had condemned Pelagius for an hereticke, and yett hee ob≈øtinately per≈øi≈øted in his condemned errors. Innocentius the fir≈øt condemned, Pelagius the monke, and Coelestius of here≈øie, for preferringe free vvill before the grace of God, and ≈øayd the vvil of man by it ≈øelfe, was ≈øufficient & able to fulfill the coÃÑmaundements of God, and tooke avvay the nece≈øsitie of Bapti≈øme and faith in Chri≈øt. (Rob. Barns in vit. Pont. Rom. in Innocent. Bal. centur. 1. de Scriptorib. in Pelagio here≈øiarcha.) Innocentius primus Pelagium monachum, & Coele≈øtium haere≈øeos damnauit: quod liberuÃÑ arbitrium gratiae Dei praeferrent, dicerent
que voluntateÃÑ per ≈øe ≈øufficere, ad implenda Dei maÃÑdata, prae≈øul ordinatus Pelagius ≈øui nominis haere≈øim fabricabat, a≈ø≈øerens hominem ≈øine peccato na≈øci, ac ≈øolo voluntatis imperio ≈øine gratia ≈øaluari po≈ø≈øe, vt ita nefarius bapti≈ømum ac fidem tolleret. Pelagius after hee was made a Bi≈øhopp, framed an here≈øie of his name, affirminge that man was borne
without ≈øinne, and by the onely commaunde of his wil, without grace by Chri≈øt, might bee ≈øaued, that the wicked man might ≈øoe take away both bapti≈øme and faith.

Pope Sozimus al≈øoe, as the≈øe men tell vs, condemned this hereticke, and to v≈øe their wordes. (Rob. Barnes ≈øup. in Sozimo Papa.) That Sozimus might declare, that nothinge was in any place ratified, that was done in holy things, except it were done by the Popes authoritie, hee ≈øent Faustinus a Bi≈øhop, & two prei≈øts, to the councell of Carthadge. The decrees of the councell were brought to Pope Sozimus, which beeinge by him approued, the Pelagian here≈øie was condemned euery where. Vt Sozimus declararet, nihil v≈øquam ratum fore, quod in rebu ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ ≈øacris ageretur, ni≈øi id Romani Pontificis authoritate fieret, Fau≈øtinum Epi≈øcopum, & duos presbyteros, ad Cathaginen≈øem Synodum mi≈øit. Synodalia decreta ad Sozimum perlata ≈øunt: quibus approbatis, Pelagiana haere≈øis pa≈øsim damnata e≈øt. And Primate of Britanie, there can bee noe doubt of the Popes power here in this time, if wee had noe other in≈øtances and Arguments to In≈øi≈øt vpon in this matter for tho≈øe daies.

But the≈øe Prote≈øtant Antiquaries. Galfrid. monum. histor. Reg. Britan l. 6. c. 13. Io. Capgrau. Catal. in S. Dubritij Manu≈øcript. of Saints old in Dubrit.) and others tell vs, that the≈øe
Legats thus ≈øent from the Pope, did not come hither onely to extirpate tho≈øe here≈øies, but to preach the true Religion in all other things, for the christianitie of the Britans was then corrupted, not onely by the Pelagian here≈øie, but by the Pagans which the kinge had brought hither, and by the preachinge of the≈øe ble≈ø≈øed men (the Popes Legats) the Religion of true faith was restored amonge them. In tempore illo venit S. Germanus Anti≈øsiodoren≈øis Epi≈øcopus, & Lupus Trecen≈øis Epi≈øcopus vt verbum Dei Britonibus praedicarent, corrupta namque fuerat christianitas eorum, tum propter Paganos quos Rex in ≈øocietatem corum po≈øuerat, tum propter Pelagianam haere≈øim. Beatorum igitur virorum praedicatione, restituta e≈øt inter eos verae fidei Religio. And in particular be≈øides the common Pelagian here≈øies again≈øt the nece≈ø≈øitie of Bapti≈øme, and grace of Chri≈øt, it ≈øeemeth the Pelagian prei≈øts and Bi≈øhops, contrary to chri≈øtian Religion, in all churches, had women, whom they called their wiues, for wee reade that Leporius Agricola, the greate promoter of that here≈øie here, was the ≈øonne of Seuerianus a Pelagian Bishop, ≈øaith
one Prote≈øtant. (Stowe hi≈øtor. in Theodo≈øius the yonger.) Seueri cuiu≈ødam Pelagianorum Sacerdotis in Britannia filius, the ≈øonne of one Seuerus a Pelagian prei≈øt in Britanie, ≈øaith an other. Io: Bal. centur. 1. de Scriptor. in Leporio Agric.) And the kinge Vortiger ≈øoe countenanced the Pagan Saxons, that wee heare, that many chri≈øtians intermarried with them, as the kinge him≈øelfe had done, although hee had then aliue his chri≈øtian wife, by whome hee had three ≈øonnes, to wit Vortimer, Catigern, and Pa≈øcentius, yett hee married the Pagan daughter of Hongi≈øtus the Pagan, named Rowenna, and ≈øoe aduanced the Infidels, that the whole kingedome was endaungered, and to aggrauate the≈øe ≈øinnes, this kinge kept in vvicked maner his owne daughter vvhich hee had by his Chri≈øtian vvife, and begott a child a daughter of her. (Mattheus Westmin≈øter. anno 450.) Generat etiam ex eadem coniuge filiam, quam in ≈øocietatem thori ≈øu≈øcipiens, filiam ex ea proceauit. Whereupon (to ≈øpeake in Prote≈øtant wordes.) (Stovve and Hovves hi≈øtor. in Vortigern.) Vodine Archbi≈øhopp of London,
a man of ≈øingular deuotion, and good life, by the adui≈øe of Vortimer (the kinges elde≈øt ≈øonne and next kinge) went to Vortiger, and ≈øaid to him that hee had not done as a Chri≈øtian prince, in departinge from his lawfull wife, and takinge an other woman, who≈øe father was an enemy to the Chri≈øtian faith, and al≈øoe went about to conquer the crowne of Britanie. Hengi≈øt hearing Vortiger make lamentation, forth with ≈ølew the good Archbi≈øhop Vodine, and many other prei≈øts, and Religious par≈øons, all the churches in lent were polluted with blood, the Nunnes with other religious par≈øons, were by force putt from their how≈øes, and goods, & con≈øtreined to pollutioÃÑ of their bodies. The BrittaÃÑs con≈øideringe the daily repaire of the Saxons into this Realme, ≈øhewed to their kinge the Ieoperdie that might therof en≈øue, and aduerti≈øed him of the daunger, but all was in vaine: for Vortiger by rea≈øons of his wife, bare ≈øuch fauour to the Saxons, that hee would in noe wi≈øe heare the coun≈øaile of his ≈øubiects. Thus farre the≈øe Prote≈øtants.

But Nennius in his manu≈øcript hi≈øtory writing as a Prote≈øtaÃÑt Bi≈øhop ≈øaith. Io: Bal. centur. 1. in Nennio Bamachoren≈øi. Nennius in M. S.
histor. in Guorthigirno Rege.) a thou≈øand yeares ≈øince, writeth plainely, that amonge other wickedne≈ø≈øes of this kinge, hee tooke his owne daughter for his wife, and had a daughter by her. Which when it was proued to S. Germanus (the Popes Legate) hee came with all the cleargie of Britanie to correct the kinge: And when a Synode of the cleargie and nobilitie was a≈ø≈øembled. The kinge aro≈øe and was very angry, and ≈øought to fly from the face of S. German, and hee was accur≈øed, and condemned by ble≈øsed German, and all the councell of the Britans. Super haec omnia mala adijciens Guorthigirnus, accepit filiam ≈øuam propriam in vxorem ≈øibi, quae poperit ei filiam. Hoc autem cum compertum e≈ø≈øet √† Sancto Germano, venit corripere Regem, cum omni clero Britannum: & dum conuenta e≈øset magna Synodus Clericorum in vno concilio, ip≈øe Rex ≈øurrexit, iratu≈ø
que est vehementer, & vt √† facie Sancti Germani fugeret, quaerebat, & maledictus est, & damnatus √† beato Germano, & omni concilio Britannum. Our engli≈øh Prote≈øtants in their Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter, as hee is publi≈øhed by them, (Matth. We≈øtm. an. 450.) Thus tell vs: A S. Germano & ab omni Epi≈øcoporum conuenta e≈øt excommunicatus. Vortiger was excommunicated
by S. German, and the whole a≈ø≈øembly of Bi≈øhops, yet this notwith≈øtandinge, hee al≈øo went about to ouerthrow both chri≈øtian Religion, and the kingdome, ioyninge with the Pagan Infidels, and hauing three wiues of which one an Infidell enemy to the land, the other his own daughter; which & ≈øuch things noe chri≈øtian could or would doe, yet it doth not appeare by NeÃÑ nius. (Nennius ≈øupr.) That hee was depo≈øed, but ≈øtraungly puni≈øhed by God, neither doth the Britti≈øh hi≈øtory or Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter ≈øay, hee was depo≈øed, but de≈øeruerunt eum. The Britans for≈øooke Vortigern, ioyninge with their enemies the SaxoÃÑs Infidels, wherby hee rather relinqui≈øhed to bee their kinge, then they depo≈øed him, although afterward they ≈øay, Vortimerum filium eius in Regem erexerunt, they made Vortimer his ≈øonne kinge to defend the kingedome, beeing driuen to tho≈øe extremities. (Galfrid. monum. l. 6. c. 13. Matth. We≈øtm. But our Engli≈øh Prote≈øtants, (noe vnlearned ≈øchollers in depo≈øing kings) write confidently: The BritaÃÑs vvith one mind depriued him of his roiall dignity, vvheÃÑ hee had reigned ≈øixe yeares, & ordeined to bee their king, Vortimer his eldest sonne. (Stow & Hov hist.
in Vort. Hol. hi≈øt of Eng. Matth. Park. ant. Brit. p. 78 prot. aÃÑnot. in Matth. Westm. in Mer. aÃÑ. 454.

And the≈øe men are ≈øoe far from findinge fault herein, that generally they applaud, and much commend the fact. I will In≈øtance onely in one their fir≈øt Prote≈øtant Archbi≈øhop, which relatinge the continuall pre≈øeruinge of true Religion inuiolate by the Britans, doth exemplify in this as an heroicall Act in that kinde, his words bee the≈øe. (Matth. Parker. antiquit. Britan. pag. 7.8.) Magnum e≈øt Britannorum perfectae in Chri≈øtum fidei argumentum, illa expostulatio & Querela, qua in Vortigernum ≈øuum Regem vehementer egerunt: quod Hengisti Infidelis filiam matrimonio ≈øibi iunxi≈øset. Quare Incen≈øi proceres, Vortigerno regia potestate abdicato, Vortimerum eius filium Regem creabant. It is a great Argument of the perfect faith in Chri≈øt of the Britans, that their expo≈øtulation and quarrell by which they delt vehemently again≈øt Vortigern their kinge, becau≈øe he had martyred the daughter of Hengi≈øt an infidell; wherfore his noble men beeing offended, depriue him of his kingly power, makinge Vortimer his ≈øonne their kinge. This is our Prote≈øtants Relation, and con≈øtruction of this matter.
Whoe propo≈øe vnto vs an other like example, of the ≈øame S. Germane in the ca≈øe of Bulie, kinge of Pow≈øey, in walles. (Holinsh. histor. of Engl. l. 5. pag. 84.) Whoe contemninge the preachinge of S. German, was miraculou≈øly puni≈øhed with death, and a meane man a chri≈øtian called Ketell, by Nennius, placed in that dignitie, and they cite Ranulphus Higeden, whoe as they write citeth Gildas for the ≈øame hi≈øtory. But NeÃÑnius hath it at lardg, and ≈øaith of this Ketell, ≈øoe erected. (Nennius M. S. in S. German.) Et omnes filij eius facti ≈øunt Reges, & √† ≈øemine eorum omnis Regio Proui≈øorum regitur v≈øque hodiernam diem. And all his ≈øonnes after him were kings, and from their ≈øeede the whole Region of Pouis is ruled to this day. From the time of S. German to the writinge of Nennius.

And it is euident by Nennius, the Relator of this hi≈øtorie, that S. German was not a depo≈øer of this wicked kinge. For fir≈øt it is manife≈øt by the hi≈øtory, that hee was a pagan, which was in noe wi≈øe ≈øubiect to Chri≈øtian di≈øcipline, or coercion, ≈øecondly hee & his kindred were miraculou≈øly de≈øtroyed and con≈øumed by God, and noe heyre left of that linadge to inherite. Then if S. German
with the con≈øent of the nobles, and people; now de≈øtitute of a Ruler, gaue way to the election of an other, a worthie and holy man, what wronge or iniurie in any opinion was here committed by him? none at al, but an action which all Religions doth allowe, and commend vnto vs.

But to leaue the≈øe things to Prote≈øtants, as their propertie quarto modo in all places, & times, when they haue preuailed, and which I would not haue mentioned, but beeinge thus called vppon, by them, wee are further taught by them, that in this time our dependance here in Britanie, was ≈øoe greate on the Popes of Rome, that not ≈øoe much as as a publick ≈øchole was here kept without his allowance, and the audience of other matters was referred to him. The≈øe things appeare to bee ≈øoe, in the ca≈øe of the ≈øchole of Cambridge, priuiledged by the holy Popes S. Leo, and Simplicius in this age, and S. Iltutus, that renowned Ma≈øter of many mo≈øte Learned Schollers. (Honor. Papa. ≈øupr. Caius Antiquitat. Cantabrig. l. 1. p. 147. lib. vit. Sanctoaum Wall. in Iltuto.) To vvhome, magi≈øtralis cura conce≈ø≈øa est √† Pontifice: The magi≈øtrall chardge was committed by the
Pope. How renowned this man was in this kinde, as al≈øo S. Dubritius in the like ca≈øe, hauinge a thou≈øand ≈øchollers, as our Prote≈øtant te≈øtifie. (Caius ≈øupr. p. 145.146. Bal. l. de ≈øcript. centur. 1. in Dubrit. & Iltuto. Godvvin Catalog. S. Dauid. 1. Bal. cent. 1. in Macceo.) And Macceus a di≈øciple of S. Patricke beeinge accu≈øed at Rome, was con≈øtrayned to purge him≈øelfe there, edito libello Romanae vrbis pontifici ≈øatisfecit, and ≈øatisfied the Pope of Rome in his booke publi≈øhed to that purpo≈øe.

Neither without great cau≈øe, were the≈øe duties performed to the Pope from hence, or hee did require them ≈øingularly of the Britans in this time: for the≈øe our Prote≈øtants a≈ø≈øure vs, that the Pope in tho≈øe daies, claimed and exerci≈øed that their highe≈øt ≈øpirituall power, ouer all churches, and par≈øons how eminent ≈øoeuer, temporall or ≈øpirituall, For to in≈øi≈øt in the≈øe mens very words. (Io: Bal. l. 2. de Act. Rom. Pont. in Hilario. Rob. Barns in vit. Pontif. Rom. in Hilar.) Hilarius decreta ≈øynodalia fecit, & per vniuer≈øum mundum ≈øeruanda, publicauit. Pope Hilary (about the yeare 142.) did make ≈øynodall decrees, and publi≈øhed them to bee kept
throughout the whole world. Faelix AchatiuÃÑ CoÃÑstantinopolitanum epi≈øcopum vna cum Petro Eutichiano excommunicat, quod Eutichianum exilium propter baere≈øim pui≈øum, reuocauerat. Pope Faelix the third, did excommunicate Achatius patriarke of Con≈øtantinople with Peter an Eutichian heretick, becau≈øe he had recalled an Eutichian, that for here≈øie was exiled. Gela≈øius Anasta≈øium Imperatorem √† coetu Christianorum exclu≈øit, qu√≤d Achatio & alijs haereticis faueret. (Idem in Gela≈øio) Gela≈øius the Pope, did exclude Ana≈øta≈øius the Emperor from the companie of Chri≈øtians, becau≈øe hee fauoured Achatius and other hereticks. And they further tell vs, (Balaeus & Barns in Ana≈øta≈øio 2.) how Pope Ana≈øta≈øius the ≈øecond, did al≈øoe excommunicate the ≈øame Emperor for the like. Soe it is euident by this our Engli≈øh Prote≈øtants, that the Popes of Rome in al this age both claymed, and exerci≈øed this their ≈øupreame ≈øpirituall power and commaunde in this kingedome of Britanie. And becau≈øe the kingedome of Ireland is now belonging to the crowne of greate Britanie, and S. Patricke (generally called the Apo≈øtle of that nation) was borne in this our Britanie, and ≈øent to Ireland by
the ≈øame Pope Cele≈øtine, whoe ≈øent S. Palladius Germanus and Lupus hither, I mu≈øt ≈øay ≈øome-what of him, and his proceedings in this matter.

The very name of the Apo≈øtle of Ireland which is giuen vnto him in all Antiquities, and that hee was thus ≈øent from the Pope of Rome, Saint Cele≈øtine, with that highe ≈øpirituall power requi≈øite in ≈øuch a ca≈øe of the conuer≈øion of ≈øoe greate a contrye, will ≈øufficiently warrant the dependance of the ≈øame in ≈øpirituall things of the Apo≈øtolicke See of Rome. For to ≈øpeake nothinge of his miraculous & powerable proceedings with greate oppo≈øites vnto him, remembred by the writers of his life and others, Nennius him≈øelfe is thus farr a witne≈ø≈øe for this renowned Saint and Iri≈øh Apo≈øtle. (Nennius in manu-≈øcripto codice antiq. in Patricio.) Sanctus Patricius Euangelium Christi externis nationibus per annos 40. Praedicabat, virtutes Apo≈øtolicos faciebat, caecos illuminabat, lepro≈øos mundabat, ≈øurdos audire faciebat, daemones ob≈øe≈øsis corporibus fugabat, mortuos numero v≈øque nouem ≈øu≈øcitauit, captiuos multos vtriu≈øque ≈øexus proprijs donis redemit, ≈øcrip≈øit Abegetoria 300. ≈øexaginta quinque, aut amplius, eccle≈øias
quoque eodem numero fundauit, trecentas ≈øexaginta quinque, ordinauit Epi≈øc ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ pos 365. aut amplius, in quibus ≈øpiritus Dei erat, presbyteros autem v≈øque ad tria millia ordinauit, & duodecim milia hominum in vna Regione Conachta ad fidem Christi conuertit, & baptizauit, quadraginta diebus totidemque nocti ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ us in cacumine montis Eile ieiunauit. S. Patrick did preache the gho≈øpell of Chri≈øt 40. yeares to externe nations, hee wrought Apo≈øtolicall miracles, hee made the blinde to ≈øee, clean≈øed lepers, cau≈øed the deaffe to heare, draue away deuills from po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed bodies, hee rai≈øed to life nyne deade par≈øons, hee redeemed many captiues of either ≈øexe, with his owne goods, hee wrote Abegetories 365. or more, hee founded churches in the ≈øame number, three hundred ≈øixtie fiue, hee ordeyned three hundred three ≈øcore & fiue Bi≈øhops or more, in whom there was the ≈øpirit of God, hee ordeyned prei≈øts to the number of three thou≈øande, and hee conuerted to the faith of Chri≈øt and baptized, twelue thou≈øand men in one Region called Conacht, hee fa≈øted fourtie dayes & ≈øoe many nights in the topp of the montaine Eile.

Thus this auntient Britti≈øh Author comparing
this holy Bi≈øhop S. Patrick, to Moy≈øes in fower thinges: fir≈øt for his ≈øpeakinge with an Angell, in rubo, in a bushe: ≈øecondlie for his fa≈øt of fourtie dayes and nights: thirdlie for the yeares of his age 120. fourthlie for the place of his buriall vnknowne. By which narration of Nennius ≈øoe auntient, and recommended an Author, that S. Patricke did con≈øecrate ≈øoe manye prei≈øts and Bi≈øhops, e≈øpeciallie aaboue three hundred and three≈øcore holy Bi≈øhops, when the fourth part of them could not bee employed for the≈øe Ilands of Britanie and Ireland, it is an euident argument, that his legatine power from the See Apo≈øtolick of Rome, did not confine it ≈øelfe in the≈øe Ilands, but extended it ≈øelfe to other parts farr off, which wee now call America, becau≈øe neyther Fraunce nor any nation in the old continent, was then ≈øubordinate to Britanie, or Ireland, to receaue Bi≈øhops and preachers from them. And this Nennius ≈øeemeth to in≈øinuate, when hee ≈øayth Saint Patricke preached the gho≈øpell, externis nationibus, to externe and ≈øtraunge nations, the Popes power ≈øpiritual rechinge vnto all Regions, & this is coÃÑ firmed
by the writers of the life of S. Brendan, whoe as both an old manu≈øcript which I haue ≈øeene (an old manu≈øcript in the life of S. Brendan.) written diuers hundreds yeares ≈øince; and Iohn Capgraue, (in Catal. in S. Brendan.) whoe wrote longe before, (and was publi≈øhed in print an. 1516.) the late di≈øcouerie of America, are witne≈ø≈øes, founde in diuers places, manie dayes ≈øaylinge from Ireland, in America and Ilands belonging vnto it, diuers religious Chri≈øtians that came thither in the time of S. Patricke, and ≈øent or brought thither by him. And the Iland called ≈øtill S. Brendan, in tho≈øe parts, may ≈øeeme to haue taken, and ≈øtill to keepe the name from that holy Saint, beeinge there in tho≈øe his holie trauailes. In≈øul. Sancti Brendani in de≈øcript. Amaric. apud Abrah. Ortel. & alios.

And yet to conclude the labours of Saint Patrick, and his te≈øtifyinge the ≈øpirituall prerogatiue of the Roman See here in Britanie, where hee was borne, the≈øe Prote≈øtants haue before recommended his epi≈øtle vnto vs, wherein hee declareth, that as Saint Phaganus, and Deruuianus (Damianus by others) obteyned ten yeares Indulgence of S.
Eleutherius for the holy place of Gla≈øtenburie. (Antiquit. Glasten. apud M. S. antiq. Ioh. Capgrau. & al. in S. Patricio.) ≈øoe hee obteyned of S. Cele≈øtine Pope, whoe ≈øent him into the≈øe parts, twelue yeares of IndulgeÃÑce for the ≈øame place. Et ego frater Patricius, √† piae memoriae Caelestino Papa duodecimo annos Indulgentiae acqui≈øiui. And to make all cleare, that neither S. Palladius, S. Germanus, and Lupus, or S. Patricius did any thinge in the≈øe parts, nor any vnder them, but by the Popes actuall or virtuall approbation, or allowance, thus it is te≈øtified by our Prote≈øtant hi≈øtorians in the≈øe words. (Raphael Holinsh. Iohn Hooker histor. of Ireland pag 53.) Palladius Landed in the North of Ireland, whence hee e≈øcaped right hardly with his life, into the Iles adioyninge, where hee preached the gho≈øpell, and conuerted noe ≈ømall number of Scots to the chri≈øtian faith, and purged that part which was chri≈øtened from the infection of the Pelagians. Hee was required by the Scots that inhabited here in Britanie, to leaue the Iles, and come ouer vnto them, there to In≈øtruct the people in the way of true ≈øaluation, to the which with the Popes Licence, hee ≈øeemed willinge enough, and
the Bi≈øhop of Rome the more redily condi≈øcended thereunto, for that in the in≈øtant time, when Palladius was to depart, and Patrick attended at Rome, ≈øuinge for licence to bee ≈øent into Ireland, the Pope therefore graunted that Palladius might pa≈ø≈øe ouer to the Scots in Britanie, and appointed Patricke to goe with authoritie from him into Ireland. Thus wee ≈øee all eccle≈øia≈øticall things, ordered and di≈øpo≈øed here by the Popes authoritie in this age.

div.head: THE SIXTE CENTVRIE OR HVNDRED YEARE.
THE X. CHAPTER. Wherein the ≈øame highest ≈øpirituall power of the Popes of Rome, is still by the≈øe English Protestant Diuines and Antiquaries continued, in this kingedome.
div.p:
IT is euident by that which is entreated before, that in the beginninge of this ≈øixt hundred yeares, and longe after, the ≈øupreame
papal power continued inuiolably in this kingedome; for S. Dubritius the Popes Legate liued vntill the yeare 522. And many or mo≈øte of the renowned men in this age in Britanie were his Schollers, taught, and in≈øtructed by him: thus the Antiquarie of Cambridge writeth. (Ioh. Caius antiquit¬∑ Cantabrig. l. 1. pag. 148. Catal. Sanct. Wall. in S. Dubrit. In vetu≈øto codice, cui titulus est de vitis Sanctorum Wallen≈øium, in vita S. Dubritij i≈øta lego: creuit illius (Dubritij) fama cum vtriu≈øque legis notae & veteris peritia, P ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ rtotam Britanniam, ita qu√≤d ex omni parte totius Britanniae Scholares veni ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ bant, non tantum rudes, ≈øed etiam viri ≈øapientes, & doctores ad eum ≈øtudendi gratia confluebant. The≈øe I reade in an old booke intituled of the liues of the Saints of Walles, in the life of Saint Dubritius: The fame of him (Dubritius) with his knowledge both of the new and old lawe, ≈øoe increa≈øed throughout all Britanie, that out of euerie part of all Britanie ≈øchollers came vnto him, not onely the ignorant, but wi≈øe men and doctors, flocked vnto him to ≈øtudy: cheifely S. Helian, Samp≈øon his di≈øciple, Vbelinus, Merchiguinus, Elguoredus, Guninus, Longual, Artbodu,
Longur, Argui≈øtus, Iunabin, Conbram, Goruan, Guernabin, Iouan, Elhebarn, Iudnon, Curdocui, Aidan, Cinnarh, and with the≈øe he had a thou≈øand clergie men ≈øeuen yeares together, in the villadge Hentlan, vppon the riuer fide of Guy, in the ≈øtudie of diuine and humane learninge, giuinge them example in him≈øelfe, of a religious life and perfect charitie. Therefore the≈øe ≈øoe manie renowned men out of all parts of Britanie, and ≈øchollers to a Ma≈øter the Popes Legate, and primate of Britanie, and many of them by the ≈øame authoritie, after made Rulers in the church of Britanie, and one of them S. Samp≈øon Archbi≈øhop of Yorke, they could not in any equall iudgement, bee otherwi≈øe affected to the See of Rome, then that their ≈øoe glorious and renowned Ma≈øter, and in≈øtructor was; for otherwi≈øe they could not haue bee named his ≈øchollers, and beeing ≈øoe many a thou≈øand & more in number, it is not credible but all, mo≈øte, or many of them, followed him in this, as in other doctrines.

Like was the ca≈øe of S. Iltutus of whome I haue breiflye ≈øpoken before, hee al≈øoe liued longe after this time, as a Prote≈øtant

And as our Prote≈øtants with others te≈øtifie this Apo≈øtolick man, thus warranted and priuiledged, ≈øent of his di≈øciples ≈øome to the Orchades, to Norway, and I≈øland, that they might receaue the light of faith by their instructions. For hee had in his colledge at Elguel in Walles, three hundred, ≈øixtie, and fiue learned men, allwayes ≈øoe prepared to preach. (Bal. l. de Scriptor. centur. 1. in Kentegerno Elguen≈øi. Cap. ≈øupr. eod. Hector Boeth. Scot. hist. l. 9.) Ex di≈øcipulis ≈øuis quo≈ødam ad Orchadas, ad Norwegiam & I≈ølandiam mi≈øit, vt eorum
in≈øtructionibus fidei lumen reciperent, nam in Elguen≈øi collegio, trecentos & ≈øexaginta quinque literatos viros ad id ≈øemper paratos hahebat. And to add further to the honor of the See Apo≈øtolick of Rome, by the example of this mo≈øte ble≈ø≈øed man S. Kentegern, hee neuer beeing but an ordinary Bi≈øhop ≈øomtimes in Walles, ≈øometimes in Scotland, yett by the priuiledge hee had from the Popes of Rome in that kinde, be≈øides his labors here in Britanie, Norway, and the remembred other places, to write in a Prote≈øtant Bi≈øhops words. (Ioh. Bal. centur. 1. in Kentegerno in Elguen.) Formam primitiuae ≈øeruauit Eccle≈øiae, Apostolico more pedes ad praedicandum porrexit, plaero≈øque ad fidem conuertit, Apo≈øtatas reuocauit, Pelagianos ciecit, nondum renatos baptizauit, ≈øimulachra ≈øubuertit, Eccle≈øias construxit, agrotis ministrauit, languores curauit, atque in magna vixit abstinentia, praedicabat ad flumen v≈øque Forden≈øe, & ad mare Scotium, Caledonos, Athalos, Horestos ac vicinarum Albainae regionum Incolas, docendo, mouendo, hortando, ad verae pietatis ob≈øeruationem in≈øtigauit. Hee kept the forme of the primatiue church, after the maner of the Apo≈øtles goinge on foote to preach, hee conuerted
very many to the faith, recalled Apo≈øtats, ca≈øt forth Pelagians, baptized tho≈øe that wanted bapti≈øme, ouerthrew the Idols, builded churches, mini≈øtred to the ≈øick, cured di≈øea≈øes, and liued in great ab≈øtinence: hee preached euen to the riuer of Fordune, & the Scotti≈øh See, hee incited by teaching, admoni≈øhinge, and exhortinge to the ob≈øeruation of true piety, the CaldoniaÃÑs, Athals, Hore≈øts, and the inhabitants of the Regions neare to Albania. This holy Bi≈øhop beeing fir≈øt Bi≈øhop of Gla≈øcow in Scotland, came into Walles about the yeare of Chri≈øt 560 and there ≈øettled an epi≈øcopall See, hee beeing the fir≈øt Bi≈øhop thereof by the riuer Elwy, and notwith≈øtandinge hee was at the fir≈øt re≈øi≈øted therein by Malgo, or Malgocunus a Britti≈øh kinge in that contry, yett his authoritie and power ≈øoe preuailed, that to ≈øpeake in a Prote≈øtant Bi≈øhops phra≈øe. (Hector Boeth. hi≈øt. Scot. in Kentigern. Godwin. Catalog. in A≈ø≈øaph. 1.

The kinge at la≈øt was content to allow the ≈øame church to bee an epi≈øcopall ≈øee, and moreouer to be≈øtowe vppon it, diuers Lord≈øhips, manners, immunities, and priuiledges. Kentegern hauinge ≈øtayed here ≈øome number
of yeares gaue ouer his Bi≈øhoprick vnto a di≈øciple of his named A≈ø≈øoph, a man of greate vertue and learninge, whoe writ the life of his Ma≈øter Kentegern; and be≈øides that hee was di≈øciple to ≈øoe greate a patron of the Apo≈øtolick Roman See, to giue Euidence that hee him≈øelfe was ≈øoe al≈øoe affected, notwith≈øtandinge there were then many Bi≈øhops, and Archbi≈øhops al≈øoe in Britanie, yett a Prote≈øtant Bi≈øhop writeth. (Bal. centur. 1. in Asapho.) √† Pontificis Romani di≈øcipulis Angliam aduentantibus, authoritate & vnctionem accepit. Hee receaued both authoritie and con≈øecration from the di≈øciples of the Pope of Rome, that came into England, and liued vntill the yeare of Chri≈øt 590. claruit anno √† communis ≈øalutis origine 590. Within foure yeares of S. Augu≈øtines coming hither. Before which time al≈øoe and in this age S. Iuo a Per≈øian by birth, and an holy Archbi≈øhop, was ≈øent by the Pope of Rome into this our Britanie or England, together with Sithius his Nephew, Inthius his Kin≈øman, and others of whome the Towne yet called S. Iues in Huntington ≈øhire, where about hee mo≈øte liued tooke the name, dyinge after many yeares in the yeare of Chri≈øt 600. or
there about, beeinge here longe time by the Pope of Rome his mi≈ø≈øion before S. Gregory his ≈øendinge S. Augu≈øtine hither. Iohn Capgrau. in S. Iuone. Flor. Wigorn. an. 600. An ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ r. Leucand. & Got ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ elin. in vita eius.

Neyther were our owne Archbi≈øhops that liued in this age after S. Dubritius, Vodinus and Samp≈øon otherwi≈øe affected in this matter. Fir≈øt S. Samp≈øon beeing driuen by the pagans from Yorke, Pyramus, or Pyrannus, chapleyne to that greate freind of the Romane See, kinge Arthur was Archbi≈øhop there, conuocato Clero & populo, with common con≈øent, and con≈øecrated by S. Dubricius the Popes Legate, and primate here then, noe other beeing to con≈øecrate him. (Galfrid. Monum. histor. Reg. Brit. lib. 9. cap. 8. Matth. Westm. an 522.) The immediate ≈øucce≈ø≈øor to S. Dubricius, bothe in his legatine power from the See of Rome, and primate Metropolitane here, in tho≈øe times by common con≈øent of writers, Prote≈øtants and others was, (Godwyn. Catalog. in S. Dauids. 1.2. and Landaffe 1. Bal. centur. 1. in Dubrit and Dauid. Capgrau. Catalog.) that glorie of this nation, S. Dauid, to vvhome S. Dubritius re≈øigned in his life, liuing as an Exemite. Delicto
Epi≈øcopatu eremiticam vitam elegit ac tenuit. S. Dauid by his legatine power tran≈ølated the Archbi≈øhops See from Caerlegion, where it was in≈øtituted by Pope Eleutherius, to Meneuia, S. Dauids, of this name, where it after remayned. (in S. Dubrit. & S. Dauid. Giral. Cambr. itinerar. Cambr. Capgrau. in S. Dauid.) Wee reade of this our holy and learned Metropolitane, that hauinge expelled the Pelagian here≈øie, and re≈øtoringe the true faith, Saint Dauid was constituted Archbi≈øhop of all Britanie, and his citie dedicated the Metropolitane See of all the contry, ≈øee that who≈øoeuer ≈øhould gouerne it, ≈øhould bee Archbi≈øhop: Therefore all here≈øie beeing expelled, all the churches of Britanie, receaued the maner and Rule by the Romane Authoritie, monasteries or builded in all places, and S. Dauid vvas made the highest protector, cheife≈øt preacher, from vvhome all receaued the Rule, and forme of well liuinge. Hee vvas an order, correction, and imitation to all: learninge to the Readers, life to the needy, nori≈øhment to Orphans, a ≈øu≈øteyner of the naked, the head of the contry, a Rule to monkes, life to ≈øeculars. Expul≈øa haere≈øi, fides ≈øanis pectoribus reboratur, & ≈øanctus Dauid totius Britanniae Archiepi≈øcopus con≈øtituitur,
necnon ciuitas eius totius patriae Metropolis dedicatur, ita vt quicumque eam regeret, Archiepi≈øcopus foret. Expul≈øa itaque haere≈øi, omnes Britanniae Eccle≈øiae modum & regulam Romana authoritate acceperunt. Monasteria per loca con≈øtruuntur, & ≈øanctus Dauid ≈øummus protector, ≈øummus praedicator, √† quo omnes normam atque formam rect√® viuendi acceperunt, effectus est. Ip≈øe cunctis or do, correctio, innitatio, legentibus doctrina, egentibus vita, orphanis nutrimentum, nudis fulcimen, patriae caput, monachis regula, ≈øecularibus vita fuit.

The Archbishop of London in this time, as our Prote≈øtants tel vs. (Matth. Parker. antiquitat. Brit. pag. 7. Godwyn. Catal. in London in Theonus. Stowe hi≈øtor. in Lucius. Holinsh. hi≈øtor. of Engl. Matth. Westm. an. 586. Galfrid. Monument. hi≈øt. i. 11. c. 10.) was Theonus, or Theanus, vvhoe takinge the chardge of London vpon him the yeare 553. the yeare 586. hee vvith Thadiorus Bishop of Yorke, takinge their clergie, and reliques of Saints, with them, gett them into Walles and Cornwall to the re≈øt of their contrymen, whom the Saxons had drovven thither. Soe that except the≈øe Prote≈øtants deceaue them≈øelues and others, this Archbi≈øhop of London and Thadiorus
of Yorke al≈øoe mu≈øt needs bee of the ≈øame minde with the others before for the Roman ≈øpirituall power in this nation; for the≈øe Prote≈øtants, (Godwyn Catal. in S. Dauids 1.2.) telling vs, that S. Dubritius liued vntill the yeare of Chri≈øt 522. and S. Dauid which ≈øucceeded him, ≈øate longe, to vvit 65. yeares, they both mu≈øt needs bee made Bi≈øhops vnder him, and their flyinge into Walles and ioyneninge with the Britans there, dooth planely conuince, that they were of that opinion: for if S. Dauid was now deade, which cannot appeare, yet mo≈øte manife≈øt it is, that both S. Kentegern and S. A≈øaph, tho≈øe mo≈øte worthie Bi≈øhops cheife≈øt then in tho≈øe parts, and all Britanie al≈øoe, if S. Dauid was deade, were longe time liuing & ruling after this, and yett ≈øuch patrons of the Romane ≈øpirituall power, with their whole cleargie, as before is euidently proued by the≈øe Prote≈øtants, that noe Catholick may yeeld more to the See of Rome in the≈øe, then they did in tho≈øe dayes. And if S. Dauid was deade; yett the next ≈øucce≈ø≈øors of him in that Archiepi≈øcopall See, which were Cenauc and S. Teliaus or Eliud, mu≈øt needs al≈øoe ≈øucceed him in that opinion of
him towards the Roman See: for though little is written of Bi≈øhop Cenauc, but onely that hee was Bi≈øhop of Patern and after ≈øucce≈ø≈øor to S. Dauid in the See Archiepi≈øcopall of S. Dauids, this ≈øufficiently conuinceth it, for the Bi≈øhoprick of Paterne beeing then vnder the iuri≈ødiction of S. Dauid, „Äà‚óä„Äâ cannot thinke that the Bi≈øhop thereof was otherwi≈øe affected in this matter, then his ≈øoe holye and learned Metropolitane, to whome hee owed obedience.

And his very beeing Archbi≈øhop of Meneuia immediatly after S. Dauid doth proue the ≈øame by the≈øe Prote≈øtants before, (Godwyn. Catal. in S. Dauids. Girald. Cambr. itiner. Cambr. antiquit. eccle≈ø. Meneuen. apud Godwyn. ≈øupr.) whoe haue tould vs, that by the power of the Romane See, Meneuia was made the Metropolis, and this Bi≈øhop did not, nor could accept it in any other ≈øence, or by other Title, of S. Teliaus the matter is more manife≈øt, more beeinge written of him by Prote≈øtants and others, that hee was Scholler to S. Dubritius the Popes Legate, the vndiuided companion of S. Dauid, in their holy pilgrimadge, not onely ≈øoe farr as Rome, but to Hieru≈øalem it ≈øelfe where hee
was con≈øecrated Bi≈øhop, and after his returne home, and the death of Cenauc, beeing Archbi≈øhop of Meneuia, then had principalitie ouer all the churches of the west Britanie vnto the end of his life. Principatum ≈øuper omnes eccle≈øias occidentalis Britannia v≈øque ad ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ em vitae ≈øua tenuit. (Godwyn in Landaffe. Girald. Cambr. Caius antiquit. Cantabrig. l. 1. pag. 146. Catal. Epi≈ø. Landaf. Ioh. Capgr. in Catal in S. Thellao. Engl. Martyrol. die 25. Nouember.) And was Archbi≈øhop there at, and after al≈øoe by ≈øome, the death of S. Augu≈øtine. For it is euident by the Britti≈øh hi≈øtorie, as it is allowed by our Prote≈øtants, and by their owne chronologie of the kings of Britanie, that S. Dauid him≈øelfe liued within 16. yeares of S. Augu≈øtines coming hither. (Galfrid. monum. hi≈øtor. Reg. Brit. l. 11. cap. 3.) Tunc obijt ≈øancti≈øsimus vrbis Legionum Archiepi≈øcopus Dauid Meneuia ciuitate, intra Abbatiam ≈øuam, & iubente Malgone Venedotorum Rege in eadem Eccle≈øia ≈øepultus, pro eo ponitur in Metropolitana ≈øede Kincos Lampaternen≈øis. Eccle≈øia Antistes, & ad altiorem dignitatem promouetur. Then Dauid the mo≈øte holy Archbi≈øhop of the citie of Legions, died in the citie of Meneuia within
his owne Abbey, and by commande of Malgo kinge of North walles, was buried in the ≈øame church Kincus (hee which by others before is called Cenauc) Bi≈øhopp of the church of Patern, is placed in the Metropolitane See, and promoted to an higher dignitie. For as the≈øe Prote≈øtants, Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter, and others are witne≈ø≈øes. (Prote≈øt. Catalog. Rer. Britan. in Malgo. Matth. West. an. 586 581.) this kinge began his Reigne in the yeare of Chri≈øt 581. or 580. ≈øo that by this calculation, there cannot bee from the death of S. Dauid dyinge in this kings time, and the coming of S. Augu≈øtine hither by all accompts in the yeare 596. aboue 15. or 16. yeares at the mo≈øte. Soe that wee either mu≈øt ≈øay, the≈øe two. Succe≈ø≈øor of S. Dauid liued a very ≈øhort time, after they were called to that dignitie (the contrarie whereof is ≈øett downe before) or that S. Telaus this patrone of the See of Rome, and a canonized Saint of that church, was liuing in the time of S. Augu≈øtines preaching in this kingedome.

Which is the more confirmed by all tho≈øe hi≈øtories, which relate the oppo≈øition of ≈øome Britti≈øh Bi≈øhops and religions men
again≈øt S. Augu≈øtine (Bed. lib. 2. histor. cap. 2. Galfrid. mon. lib. 11. hist. Matth. Westm. an. 603. Capgran. in S. Augu≈øtino.) and ≈øpeaking of an Archbi≈øhop of the citie of Legions, and yett not anie one of them maketh the lea≈øt mention, that any Archbi≈øhop did either re≈øi≈øt S. Augu≈øtine, or pretend the lea≈øt di≈ølike of the ≈øpirituall ≈øupreamacie in the See of Rome, or gaine≈øay any order or decree of the ble≈ø≈øed Pope S. Gregorie which ≈øent him hither, nor any Prote≈øtants though diuers of them name the Bi≈øhops as they coniecture which re≈øi≈øted S. Augu≈øtine, (Matth. Parker ant. Britan. in August. Godwyn. Conuer≈ø. of Brit. Stowe histor. in Ethelb. Bal. l. de Act. Pont. Rom. in Gregor. 1.) doe once name S. Telaus, or any Archiepi≈øcopal See, at S. Dauids, or anye other place in Walles at that time, to haue con≈øented to that oppo≈øition.

Hardinge in his Cronicle maketh this matter playne, that the Britans which gain≈øaid S. Augu≈øtine did not deny the ≈øupreame ≈øpirituall power of the Pope of Rome in Britanie at that time, but rather defended and maintayned it, and thereby al≈øoe, as they thought, did iu≈øtely refu≈øe S. Augu≈øtine, for
when hee demaunded obedience of them thus they an≈øweared by this Author: Ioh. Hardinge Chronicle cap. 88. in Ethelbert kinge of Saxons fol. 83.84.

q.l: To which BritoÃÑs answeared that they not knew
That hee had ≈øuch estate in all Britanie,
For they had three Archbishops, to obeyu,
Of Caerlion, London and Yorke citie
By Bishops of Rome graunted to vs & ordinate
Full longe afore yee had ≈øuch dignitie
Wherefore wee will obey noe nevv primate
For Englishmen and Saxons haue vs noyed,
And haue our Land and all our kyn destroyed.

div.p: Where wee ≈øee the Britans were ≈øoe far from di≈øallowinge the Popes Authoritie in ≈øuch things, that by the ≈øame they both claymed, and maintayned the power, and prerogatiues, of three Archbi≈øhops, amonge them, now foure hundred yeares ≈øince

But the≈øe Prote≈øtants them≈øelues with others acknowledge, that the mo≈øte renowned Bi≈øhops that were in this kingedome at that time, both receaued the Authoritie of the Pope of Rome, and ≈øubmitted them≈øelues to S. Augu≈øtine his holy Legate. Of the holines and learninge of S. A≈ø≈øaph, I haue
≈øpoken before, yett a Prote≈øtant Bishop ≈øaith of him, (Bal. centur. 1. in A≈ø≈øaph.) A Gregorij Pontificis Romani di≈øcipulis Angliam aduentantibus, authoritatem accepit, hee receaued authoritie from the di≈øciples of Gregorie the Pope of Rome that came into England. S. A≈øaph in the life of his Ma≈øter S. KeÃÑtegern. Capgraue and others after, affirme as much of S. Kentegern. (S. A≈ø≈øaph & Ioh. Capgrau. in vit. S Kentegerni.) that hee did acknowledg this high power in S. Gregory the Pope, and receaued power, and confirmation from him. All our hi≈øtories with generall con≈øent affirme the ≈øame of S. Lethardus, the french Bishop that liued with Queene Bertha in Kent. I haue proued the ≈øame of S. Iuo the Per≈øian Archbishop, that then preached in Huntington-shire. Of S. Telaus al≈øoe the Archbi≈øhop of Walles, ≈øufficient is ≈øaid allready. And yet the≈øe were onely the cheife holy, and learned Bishops here in that time, not anie one comparable to the meane≈øt of the≈øe mentioned in any writer I can finde, to haue re≈øi≈øted either the Popes ordinance, or his Legats authoritie.

And to ≈øatisfie a vaine obiection of ≈øome Prote≈øtant writers; That S. Columbanus the
holy Iri≈øh, or Scotti≈øh Abbot, who≈øe authoritie ≈øome Britans in the tyme of S. Augu≈øtine pretended for defence of their error in ob≈øeruing the fea≈øt of Ea≈øter, & not pre≈øently ≈øubmitting theÃÑ≈øelues to the coÃÑmaund of the church of Rome, it is euident by auntieÃÑt hi≈øtories, that both this S. Columban, and the cheife≈øt of them, ≈øubmitted theÃÑ≈øelues wholly vnto it, & receaued both in≈øtruction and iuri≈ødictioÃÑ froÃÑ thence. For it is te≈øtified in a very old Manu≈øcript cited by Surius, that both S. Kelian, which was the mo≈øt renowned of them, and that S Columbanus and S. Gallus, ≈øubmitted them≈øelues with their a≈ø≈øociats to the Pope of Rome in all thinges at that time. Thus it te≈øtifieth of S. KeliaÃÑ, made Bi≈øhop of Herbypolis Wirtzburg in Franconia by the Pope. (Sur. in vit. S. Kel. M. S. peruetu≈øt. apud eund. ≈øupr.) Praedicationi ab≈øtinuit, donec Romano ≈øe Pontifici prae≈øentaret, quatenus apud RomanaÃÑ ≈øedem & integruÃÑ christianae Religionis dogma, & licentiaÃÑ praedicaÃÑdi acciperet. Hibernia ≈øiquidem olim Pelagiana faedata fuerat haere≈øi, Apo≈øtolica
que cen≈øura damnata. Hee ab≈øtayned from preaching, vntil hee pre≈øented him≈øelfe vnto the Pope of Rome, that hee might receaue froÃÑ the See of Rome, both the ≈øownd
doctrine of Chri≈øtian Religion, and licence to preach. For Irland (his contry) was auntiently defiled with the pelagian here≈øie, and condemned by apo≈øtolick cen≈øure: and there ≈øheweth how hee had companions both of his iorney and ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion, amonge others Saint Columbanus, and S. Gallus, leauing the fir≈øt in Italy, and the other in Almayne. The like hath Iohn Capgraue, and a verie old manu≈øcript which hee followeth, if not the ≈øame with that of Surius. (Ioh. Capgrau. in S. Kilian. M. S. antiq. pr. glorio≈øi≈øsimus Rex Eduardus in S. Kiliano.) In oppido orientalis Fraunciae quod Wirttzburch eorum lingua dicitur, cum aliquo tempore ≈øub ≈øilentio steti≈ø≈øet, Romam profectus est, & officio praedicandi √† Papa recepto, Epi≈øcopus ordinatus: ≈øocijs eius Columbano ≈øcilicet in Italia, & Gallo in Almania remanentibus. Saint Kilian ≈øtayed in a Towne of ea≈øt France, called in their languadge Wirtzburch, and when hee had beene there ≈øome time in ≈øilence, hee went to Rome, and receauing from the Pope power to preach, and beeing ordeyned a Bi≈øhop, returned, leauing his Companions, Columbanus in Italy, and Gallus in Almayne. Where it is euident not onely the≈øe
Scotti≈øh Saints did not onely ≈øubmitt them≈øelues to the Pope in all matters both of doctrine and iuri≈ødiction, but the Pope at that time extended and exerci≈øed that his ≈øupreame ≈øpirituall power, both in Italie, Fraunce, Almayne, Britaine, and Ireland, both to cen≈øure a whole nation, and to di≈øable any to preach or exerci≈øe ≈øpirituall function without his licence.

And although the kings of Britanie after Kinge Arthur euen to the de≈øolation of the Britans, were by all hi≈øtories euen of their owne as Gildas, Nennius, the Britti≈øh hi≈øtorie, and others, mo≈øte wicked men, and ≈øuch that by all te≈øtimonie of Prote≈øtants, and others, their kingedome was ouerthrowne by God for the ≈øinnes of them, and their people, yett not anie one of them by any hi≈øtorie did denie this power of the See Apo≈øtolick, but euen their la≈øt kinge Cadwalladar, as their owne hi≈øtorian writteth. (Gildas de excid. Britan. Galfrid. mon. l. 11. histor. cap. 3.4.5.6.7.8. monum. hi≈øtor.) beeing admoni≈øhed from heauen: Nolebat Deus Britones in In≈øula Britanniae diutius regnare: that God would not haue the Britans reigne any any longer in the Iland of Britanie, went as
hee was admoni≈øhed on pilgrimage to Rome, ≈øubmitted him≈øelfe to Pope Sergius, and died an holy Saint, in ≈øoe much that our Prote≈øtants thus note of him. (Galfrid. mon. l. 12. cap. 17.18. Bed. l. 4. histor. & in Epitom. an. 688. Matth. Westm. an 688.689. Prote≈øt. annot. in Matth. We≈øtm. an. 688.) Regnum relinquens propter Deum, Romam venit: leauinge his kingdome for gods ≈øake, hee went to Rome. An other ≈øaith. (Stowe histor in Cadwallader.) Cadwallader for≈øakinge his kingely authoritie, went to Rome, whoe after became a monke, and was buried in S. Peters church at Rome, hee was the la≈øte kinge of Britanie, ≈øaith Geffrey (Galfrid. Mon. l. 11. cap. 12.) And for the Archbi≈øhop of Walles to whome ≈øome Briti≈øh Bi≈øhops in the time of S. Augu≈øtine ≈øaid, they ought obedience, cum ≈øuum Archiprae≈øulem haberent, there is not the lea≈øt colour, or pretence of any title by the≈øe Prote≈øtants them≈øelues, how hee or his See could bee exempted from the Popes Authoritie: for as the≈øe men haue told vs before, it was fir≈øt in≈øtituted by Pope Eleutherius, in the time of kinge Lucius, and by the ≈øucceedinge Popes and their Legats here as is before declared, confirmed and
ratified, they receaued their Palle, the ≈øigne of an Archbi≈øhop from Rome, and after their vnion with the Saxons and di≈øciples of Pope Gregory, in the time of S. Theodore Archbi≈øhop of Canterbury v≈øed it, and Archiepi≈øcopall Authoritie in all degrees, and by the Popes permi≈ø≈øion and allowance, fiue and twentie Archbi≈øhops ≈øucce≈ø≈øiuely from S. Dauid to Archbi≈øhop Samp≈øon, and had ≈øeuen Bishops ≈øubiect vnto them vntill this Samp≈øon, flyinge the contry in a time of ≈øicknes carried away the Pall into little Britanie. Amonge manie others a Prote≈øtant Bishop thus relateth this matter. Girald. Cambren. in Itinerar. Cambr. Antiquit. eccl. S. Dauid apud Godwin S. Dauid. Matth. Park. antiquit. Brit. Rog. Houeden. Godwin Catalog. in S. Dauids in Samp≈øone.

In the time of Samp≈øon the See of S. Dauid had ≈øeuen Bishops Suffragans ≈øubiect vnto it, as the Antiquitie of the church of S. Dauid declareth, to witt, Exeter, Bathe, Hereford, Landaff, Bangor, S. A≈ø≈øaph, & Furnes in Ireland.
Roger Houeden, vvhich I accompt more likely, reckoneth the≈øe, Landaffe, Lanpatern in Cardigan shire, Bangor Saint A≈ø≈øaph,
Chiche≈øter, Hereford, and Worce≈øter. While hee was Bi≈øhop it hapned the people of all that contry were wonderfully vexed, with Ianudi≈øe, ≈øoe as great numbers of them died daily of that di≈øea≈øe. By the importunitie of his clergie and di≈øciples, hee was induced to flie the contry, and ≈øailed into Britanie, where the Bi≈øhoprick of Dola beeing voide, hee was ≈øtraight way elected vnto the ≈øame. Hee had brought thither with him the Archiepi≈øcopall Pall of S. Dauid, and v≈øed it duringe his life, as did al≈øoe his ≈øucce≈ø≈øors there, for many yeares, vntill they were compelled by the Pope, at the ≈øuite of the Archbi≈øhop of Turon, to leaue it, and make profe≈ø≈øion of obedience vnto him, as in former times. By this occa ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ on it fell out that the Succe≈ø≈øors of Samp≈øon in Saint Dauids, what for want of their Pall, or for pouertie, or negligence, or ≈øome other occa≈øion, lo≈øte their Title of bi≈øhop, and to this day neuer recouered the ≈øame. Howbeit they v≈øed all authoritie belonginge to an Archbi≈øhop by con≈øecratinge of other Bi≈øhops; and neither did they euer make profe≈ø≈øion of ≈øubiection vnto Canterburie vntill the time of Henry 1. Kinge of England. (Godwin ≈øupr. in Bernard. 46.)
When Bernard Chaplaine vnto King Henry the fir≈øt, and chauncellour to his Queene, was con≈øecrate by the Archbi≈øhop of Canterbury, Iulij 12. 1115. not cho≈øen by the clergie of Walles as hitherto had beene accu≈øtomed, but forced vpon them by the Kinge of England. And there with others declareth, how this Bernard tooke vppon him the title of Archbi≈øhop, but Theobaldus Archbishop of Canterbury, prouinge before the Pope in the councell of Rhemes, by witne≈ø≈øes, cum ≈øuam fidem & ob≈øeruantiam cantuarien≈øi astrinxi≈ø≈øe: that Bernard had promi≈øed obedience vnto the Archbishop of Canterbury, the cau≈øe was by the Pope adiudged again≈øt Bernard, and the See of S. Dauid. Match. West. an. 1115. Matth. Par. an. 1115. Godwin. ≈øupr. Girald. Lambr. in Itiner. Camb. & Topogr Harp≈ø. ≈øecul. 12. cap. 46.

Soe it is euident, that from the beginning thereof to the endinge of the ≈øame, the Archiepi≈øcopall See of Walles depended of the Pope of Rome, and it was not hee, but the Acts of their owne Bishops, which ouerthrew the dignitie & priuiledges of it, which the Popes had graunted and confirmed. Of the Popes power here after the cominge of S.
Augu≈øtine there is noe denial amonge Prote≈øtants, all generally con≈øentinge that from that time now aboue a thou≈øand yeares, the Popes ≈øupreamacy euer ruled here in ≈øpirituall thinges, hee chaunged the Metropolitone See of London to Canterbury, con≈øtituted that of Yorke, interdicted our vniuer≈øities, con≈øtituted Bishops in places as ≈øeemed be≈øt to him, Kinge Ethelbert chaunged his lawes, and receaued the cu≈øtomes of the Romans: ca≈ø≈øatis paternis legibus, nouas Sapientum con≈øilio iuxta Romanorum con≈øuetudines Anglorum ≈øermone con≈øtituit. (Bal. centur. 1. in Ethelberto.) The greate flaterer of King Henry the eight, whoe fir≈øt denied the Popes ≈øupreamacy, and tooke it to him≈øelfe, Polidor Vergil, ≈øpeaketh of that parlament. (Polidor Verg. l. 27. pag. 689) Habetur concilium Londini, in quo eccle≈øia Anglicana formam pote≈øtatis nallis ante temporibus vi≈øam induit: Henricus enim Rex caput ip≈øius eccle≈øiae con≈øtituitur. A parlament is held at London, in which the church of England did put on a forme of power, neuer ≈øeene in any time before: for Kinge Henry was made head of the church. The fir≈øt Prote≈øtant Archbishop of Canterbury ≈øpeaking of the lawes of that
parlament plainely confe≈ø≈øeth. (Matth. Parker. antiquit. Britan. in Tho. Cramner pag. 329.) His legibus potentia papalis quae nongentis amplius annis in Anglia durauit facile concidit. By the≈øe lawes the power of the Pope, which had continued here in England aboue neyne hundred yeares, was ea≈øely ouerthrowne. The pre≈øent Prote≈øtant Archbi≈øhop of Canterbury, director to Francis Ma≈øon, and hee with others in their booke of pretended con≈øecration of Bi≈øhops, ≈øpeaking of the ≈øame Matthew Parker. (Fran: Ma≈øon Booke of con≈øecrat. 3. cap. 4. pag. 131. vit. Matth. Parkeri.) ≈øay: Concerninge Archbishop Parker beeing the 70. Archbishop after Austin, yett of all that number, hee was the onely man, and the fir≈øt of all, which receaued con≈øecration without the Popes Bulls. To this, this man him≈øelf, together with their Prote≈øtant Bi≈øhop, Godwin, Goceline and others, in the liues of the Archbi≈øhops of England doe plainely te≈øtifie; to this all antiquities and antiquaries agree, none di≈ø≈øenteth. Matth. Parker in antiq. Britan. Godwin Catalog. in Canterbury and Yorke, Goceline in epi≈øt.

div.head: THE XI. CHAPTER. How by the≈øe Protestants the Britans and Scots which oppo≈øed against S. Gregories di≈øciples, did take vpon then greater or as ample power in Princes matters, as euer the Popes of Rome or their Legates did in this kingedome.
div.p:
BEcau≈øe our Prote≈øtant Antiquaries and writers of England doe with a common con≈øent agree in this, that the Britans at the coming of S. Augu≈øtine hither, from S. Gregory, did truely and inuiolably keepe in all points that holy Religion which was planted here in the Apo≈øtles time, e≈øpecially they which at the fir≈øt oppo≈øed again≈øt the proceedings of that our holy Apo≈øtles. (Matth. Park. antiq. Britan. pag. 1. Godwin Conuer≈ø. pag. 43.44. Bal. l. 2. de Act. Pont. Rom. in Gregor. 1. Theater of greate Brit. l. 6. cap. 9. Dauid Povvel. in annot. in l. 2. Girald. Cambr. Itiner. Cambr. c. 1. Holinsh. histor. of Engl. cap. 21. pag. 102. Fulk. Ansvv. to a count. cath. pag. 40.) therefore to walke ≈øtill by their directions, lett vs now learne of them, what was the opinion and practice of tho≈øe Scots,
and Britrans in this que≈øtion of Iuri≈ødiction in ≈øpiritual Rulers, claimed and deriued from whome≈øoeuer they will, or any of them shall plea≈øe, though it is euidently proued in all ages before, that neuer any ≈øuch was practized here, but that which was deriued and approued from, and by the Apo≈øtolick Roman See. And wee ≈øhall plainely ≈øee, that the≈øe their ≈øoe much by them commended gayne-≈øaiers to S Augu≈øtine, and the Pope al≈øoe, as many of the≈øe men contend, did further intermeddle with Princes and temporall affaires, then the Popes of Rome, or any their Legats in this kingedome: our Prote≈øtant Antiquaries with others, write of Kinge Frequahard or Frechard the fir≈øt of Scotland ≈øonne to Eugenius, in this maner. Hect. Boeth. lib 9. fol. 179. pag. 1. Georg. Buchan. Rer. Scotic. lib. 5. Reg. 52. pag. 160. Holinsh. histor. of Scotand in Frequahard pag. 112.

Frequahard be≈øides other his vvicked behauiours, vvas al≈øoe infected vvith the erroneous opinion of the Pelagian here≈øie. Which ≈øu≈øpition vvas the more increa≈øed, for that hee v≈øed to haue ≈øondry Brittish preists in his company: the vvhich nation had beene euer noted vvith the
≈øpot of that damnable infection. The nobilitie of the Realme moued herevvith ≈øommoned him to come to a councell, vvhich they had appointed to hold of all the states, that they might there vnder≈øtand, if it vvere true or not, vvhich vvas commonly reported of him. But hee refu≈øinge to come, they a≈ø≈øembled together, and be≈øeiged him in a castle, vvherein hee had inclo≈øed him≈øelfe, and vvinning the place, got him into their hands, and immediately thereuppon committed him to ≈øafe keepinge. This done they con≈øult together for the administration of the Realme, vvhether they should quite depo≈øe Frequahard, or re≈øtore him to his place. Then it followerh how they depo≈øed him, and ≈øent to S. Fiacre his Brother then an Eremite in Fraunce, to gouerne the kingedome, but hee refu≈øed it. Then the≈øe Prote≈øtants add. (Holinsh. & Buch. ≈øupr. & Hect. Boeth. ≈øupr.) The Lords of the land a≈ø≈øembled them≈øelues together in Argile, about the choo≈øinge of a nevv kinge, vvhere by common con≈øent, Domoald the third ≈øonne of Eugenius beeing called thither vvith Bishop Conan, out of the Ile of Man, vvas inue≈øted kinge vvith greate ioy, and triumph.

Where wee ≈øee that S. Fiacre though next
heire liuinge in Fraunce, where the Popes Authoritie was generally embraced, would not con≈øent to the depo≈øition of kinge Frequahard, to gaine a kingedome, when his Brother Domoald and all tho≈øe Scots which by the≈øe Prote≈øtants then oppo≈øed again≈øt the Popes Authoritie, performed this with great Ioy and triumphe. Of kinge Frequahard the ≈øecond they write in this order. (Holinsh. histor. of Scotl. pag. 114. Buchan. Rer. Scoticar. l. 5. Reg. 54.) Hee was couetous, wicked towards God, a Tormentor of the iu≈øt and righteous people, in≈øatiable in all vnlawfull affections, ≈øuch of the prelates, as hee vnderstood to bee wealthie, hee rested not till hee had picked one matter, or other vnto them, vvhereby they vvere ≈øuer to forfeite all their Trea≈øure vnto his coffers. Buchanan addeth, which I am a≈øhamed to tran≈ølate. (Buchan. ≈øupr.) Eandem in ≈øuos furorem vertit, Iugulata vxore, & stupratis filiabus, ob haec ≈øcelera communione christianoruÃÑ fuit exclu≈øus. For the≈øe wicked offences hee was excluded from the communion of Chri≈øtians. (Holinsh. ≈øupr.) The Bishops of the Realme, namely tho≈øe tvvo reuerend Fathers, Colman, & Finnan perceyuinge ≈øuch wickednes in the prince, blamed him sharply ≈øondry
times for the ≈øame: and at length becau≈øe they ≈øavv hee regarded not their admonishments, hee vvas by them excommunicated. Thus continuinge certaine yeares in his vvickednes, at length the nobles began to con≈øpire against him, ≈øoe that they vvould haue deui≈øed a meane hovv to haue ridd him out of the vvay, if Bi≈øhop Colman, had not forbidd them that practi≈øe. Then followeth how beeing mi≈øerably puni≈øhed for his ≈øinnes, and beeinge at the la≈øt penitent, hee was ab≈øolued of his excommunication by the ≈øame Bi≈øhop Colman: whoe was that great oppo≈øer again≈øt the di≈øciples of Saint Gregory, and Saint Augu≈øtine, and di≈øputant for the Scots again≈øt S. Wilfride.

And the Bi≈øhops of Walles which were in the ≈øame oppo≈øition to the di≈øciples of S. Gregory the Pope, were in the ≈øame ca≈øe by the≈øe Prote≈øtants: One a Bi≈øhop and antiquary amonge them writeth, from the antient antiquities of that nation. (Godvvin Catalog. in Landaff. Annal. eccle≈ø. Landaffen: in Oudoceus. 3.) Kinge Morcant hauinge killed one Frioc his Vncle, beeinge therefore excommunicate by the Bi≈øhop, vppon his ab≈øolution, be≈øides a graunt of diuers priuiledges
vnto the church of Landaff, gaue Cyncirill and certaine land called Cynfall, as al≈øoe the churches of Ythat-Haffern. (In Guruan. 10.) Bi≈øhop Guruan excommunicated Tendur king of Brechinianc, for killing Engi≈øtill a kinge of that contry trecherou≈øly, & for ab≈øolutioÃÑ had from him the guift of Lannihangel tref. ceriaÃÑc. Guoderec ≈ølew his owne Brother Merchion. (In Greciclus.) for which deed, hee was by Bi≈øhop Grecielus excoÃÑmunicate, and enioyned by way of penance before hee might bee ab≈øolued, to ≈øpend a yeare in pilgrimadge to the church of Dola in little Brittanie. Garcan the ≈øonne of GuinaÃÑ (In Berthygion 14.) kept his owne ≈øtepmother, and beeing excommunicate for that Ince≈øt, gaue to the Bi≈øhop Marchywis. (In Bish. Cerenhir 18.) Houel Kinge of Glewi≈ø≈øig by periury circuÃÑuented GalluÃÑ the ≈øonne of Cidrich, for which hee was held vnder excommunication, by the ≈øpace of a yeare, at the time of his ab≈øolution hee gaue Merthir-buceil, Merthirminor, & Tircollan. Like was the ca≈øe of Ili the ≈øonne of Conblus whoe vpon the like occa≈øion gaue Gulipe. Aquod ≈øonne of Ioua falling out with the Bi≈øhop, draue him and his men into the church of Landaff, & threw
≈øtones at them into the very church, for ≈øoe doinge hee was excommunicate, and to bee ab≈øolued, was glad to giue Pennoun, with the church of Lautilul, and certaine other Lands. (In Bish. Io≈øeph. 28.) Monric Kinge of Glamorgan beeinge excommunicate for puttinge out the eyes of Ergum, the ≈øonne of Guriat of Guein≈øcot in the time of a truce, to haue his ab≈øolution gaue Painipri≈øc.

Whoe de≈øireth more of ≈øuch proceedings by the Britans, ≈øoe recommended by Prote≈øtants, may enquire theÃÑ in the auntient Annals of Landaffe, and this Prote≈øtant Bi≈øhop Francis Godwin, Prote≈øtant Bi≈øhop there, who in his treati≈øe of that See, is very plentifull in ≈øuch Examples. And this ≈øhall ≈øuffice for this ≈øhort hi≈øtorie of the Popes preeminence and proceedings here, from the beginning of our fir≈øt faith in Chri≈øt, by them and their happie in≈øtruments therein. By whome, & who≈øe preeminence ≈øpirituall, this kingdome from that time, hath receaued many greate and irrecomprehen≈øible graces and benefites, both ≈øpiritual & temporal, to bynde vs euerla≈øtingly to honor and reuerence, with al dutie, that Apo≈øtolick See, and cheife≈øt pa≈øtors
thereof, ≈øucce≈ø≈øors to our mo≈øt glorious fir≈øt Fathers and founders in the faith of Chri≈øt, and our cheife Sheephards on earth, except wee will de≈øperately runne away and ca≈øt our ≈øelues out of the ble≈ø≈øed flock and folde of the militant church of God, out of which there is noe ≈øaluation.

div.head: Faults e≈øcaped.
div.p: Pag. 42. line 1. distributor, reade, distribution pag. 52. line 19. there nowned, reade, the renowned. pag. 153. line 19. this, reade, the≈øe.

div.head: AN ADVETISEMENT. Whereas in the first hundred yeare it is as ≈øuppo≈øe written in the story of S. Man≈øuetus, that Ireland was neuer plainely called Scotia, I wi≈øh it thus to bee qualified. pag. 34.
div.p: For if we graunt as ≈øome few write, that Ireland hath beene called Scotia, or Scotia Maior, Scotland, or the greater Scotland, yett that is very ≈øeldome found in hi≈øtories, but it is commonly called in them auntient and late, Hibernia, Iuernia, Inuernia, and Ierne, Iris, and Ogigia little Brittanie, and by the Iri≈øh them≈øelues, Erin, when the part of great Britanie, after the name of Albania cea≈øed, is commonly in all hi≈øtorians named Scotia, Scotland. Ari≈øtotil. l. de mundo Pompon. Mela l. 3. Solinus Poly. histor. c. 25. Strab. l. 4. Iuuenal. Satyr. 2. Claudian. l. 7. Stangh. Hunfrid. Lhuid. Stow Holinsh ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ hist. Hect. Boeth. Buchan. Capgr. in Catalog. ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ Gryimst. in Ireland.
